list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

sense.s: The eleventh letter of the alphabet; commonly called zaAIN, and sometimes zaMCN, [and zFA, and zaA, (see zaAIN in art. zwI,)] and zaIRN, and zaIo. (MF.) It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed OasilayRap, because proceeding from the tip of the tongue. (TA.) Az says that it is not conjoined with S in any Arabic word. (TA.) It is substituted for s and for S; as in yazodilu for yasodilu, and yazoduqu for yaSoduqu: and in the Tes-heel it is said that it is sometimes interchanged [with s] after j, as in jusotu xilaAla AldRiyaAri for juzotu; and after r, as in rasaba and razaba: which interchange, accord. to MF, is said to be of the dial. of Kelb; or, as Et-Toosee says, of the dial. of 'Odhrah and Kaab and Benul-' Ambar. (TA.)
[As a numeral, z denotes Seven.]
zaA and zFA and zaMCN: see the letter z, and zaAIN in art. zwI.
zaOobara: &c.: see art. zbr.

Q. 1. zaOobaqa He did over dirhems, or pieces of money, with ziYobiq [i. e. quicksilver]. (Mgh.) [It is said that] the verb [from zYbq, or rather its inf. n.,] is AltRazobiyqu: (TA:) [but see mazaOobaqN, below.]

ziYobiqN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) thus pronounced by some, (S,) and this is the form preferred by ElMeydánee, and that which is in the Fs and its Expositions, (TA,) rendered quasi-coordinate to ziYobirN and DiYobilN, (S, in which it is mentioned in art. zbq,) also pronounced ziYobaqN, (S, K, [in both of which it is implied that this is the more common form, and such is the case now,]) and it is allowable to pronounce it ziybiqN, (Msb,) an arabicized word, (S, K,) of well-known meaning, [i. e. Quicksilver,] (Msb, K,) originally Pers. [\xQ698Yiywaho and ziybaqo or ziybiqo]; (S;) i. q. zaAwuwqN: (Mgh, TA:) some of it is drawn in a fluid state from its mine, and some is extracted from stones of the mine by means of fire: its smoke, or vapour, puts to flight serpents and scorpions from the house, or kills such of them as remain [therein]. (K.)
Hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) ziYobiqN and ziYobaqN signify also (tropical:) A man who is light, inconstant, unsteady, irresolute, or fickle. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.)
[ziYobaqiIRN Of, or relating to, quicksilver.
And A seller of quicksilver.]

dirohamN muzaOobaqN, (Lth, S, Mgh, TA,) said by Th to be correctly mazaOobiqN, with kesr to the b, (TA in art. zbq, [but this is app. a mistake,]) or muzayobaqN, with fet-h to the b, (Msb,) A dirhem, or piece of money, done over with zYbq [i. e. quicksilver]: (Lth, Mgh, Msb, TA:) the vulgar say muzabRaqN. (S, Mgh.)

1. zaOara, aor.
zaAi^a
(S, A, K) and
zaAa^a
; (A, K;) and zaYira, aor.
zaAa^a
; (S, K;) inf. n. zaYiyrN and zaOorN; (S, A, K;) said of a lion, He roared, or growled; i. e., made his cry, or voice, to be heard (S, A, K) in his chest, (S, A,) or from his chest; (K;) as also tzORr↓ (S, K) and AzOr↓: (K:) he cried out, and was angry. (TA.)

And [hence], said of a stallion-camel, as also AzOr↓, (K, by implication,) or zaOara [only], (TA,) or zaOara fiI hadiyrahi, (A,) (tropical:) He reiterated his voice, or cry, in his chest, and then prolonged it, (A, K, TA,) in his braying: (A:) or zaOara, aor.
zaAi^a
, he threatened in his braying. (TA.)
[Hence also,] samiEa zaYiyra AlHarobi faTaAra UilayohaA (tropical:) [He heard the roaring of the war, or battle, and flew to it]. (A, TA.)
4: see 1, in two places.
5: see 1.
zaYir: see zaAYirN.
Also (assumed tropical:) An angry man, who severs himself from his companion. (IAar, TA.)

zaOorapN A thicket, wood, or forest; or a bed of canes or reeds; syn. OajamapN; (S, A, K, TA;) as also zaArapN; (IJ, TA in art. zwr [q. v.];) originally with C; (TA;) [such as is the haunt of the lion; for] you say, AlOasada fiI zaOoratihi [The lion is in his thicket, &c.]; (A;) and Oabuw AlHaArivi marozubaAnu AlzRaOorapi (S, TA) i. e. Abu-l-Hárith [the lion] is the lord of the Oajamap [or forest, &c.]. (TA.)
[Hence,] (tropical:) A garden. (A, TA.)
And (tropical:) A collection of camels, or of sheep or goats, dense like the Oajamap [or thicket, &c.]. (A, TA. [See also zaArapN, in art. zwr.])

zaAYirN, applied to a lion, Roaring, or growling; i. e. making his cry, or voice, to be heard (S, A, K) in his chest, (S, A,) or from his chest; (K;) as also zaYirN↓, (S, K, TA,) like katifN, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, zaYiyrN,] and muzoYirN↓. (K.)
Also (assumed tropical:) An enemy: (TA:) the pl. zaAYiruwna is thus used by 'Antarah. (S, TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) Angry: (IAar, TA:) and so zayirN; but original with hemzeh: so says AM. (TA. [See also zaYirN.])
muzoYirN: see the next preceding paragraph.
ziYoniIRN, applied to a dog, Short: (S, K:) one should not say SiyniIRN. (S.)

zuWaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and zuwaAnN (M, Msb) and ziYaAnN (M, K) and ziwaAnN (M, Msb) and zaMnN (K) and zawaAnN, (K in art. zwn, q. v.,) but the like of saHaAbN is said by ISd to be a form not seen by him on the authority of anyone, (TA,) [A noxious weed, that grows among wheat; app. darnel-grass; the lolium temulentum of Linn.; so in the present day;] a certain grain, (Msb,) the bitter grain, (M,) that mingles with wheat, (S, M, Msb, K,) and gives a bad quality to it: (Msb:) [the grain thus called is often, accidentally, or carelessly, mixed with wheat, and causes giddiness: the plant resembles that now called Xayolam, a decoction of which is used as an anæsthetic: it is said in the K in art. Xlm that the zWAn is the same as the Xayolam: but it is said in the TA in that art., on the authority of AHn, that the grain of the Xayolam does not intoxicate, (as that of darnel-grass is well known to do in a certain manner,) and that it is very bitter: and in the K in art. dnq it is said that the danoqap is the zuwaAn, and the danaqap is the Xayolam: the TA states more fully in that art. that the danoqap is said by AHn to be the zuwaAn that is in wheat, which is cleared therefrom; and that the danaqap is said by AA to be the Xayolam: Forskål mentions the ziwaAn and the Xayolam, as different species, among undetermined plants, and describes the former thus: zizania Aleppensibus notissima: inter triticum viget: si semina restant farinæ [sic] mixta, hominem reddunt ex panis esu temulentum: messores plantam non separant; sed post triturationem vanni aut cribri ope semina rejiciunt: (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. 199:)] the n. un. is with p. (Msb.)
OazoOaniIRN: see what next follows.

yazoOaniIRN and OazoOaniIRN↓, applied as epithets to a spear, are dial. vars. of yazaniIRN (K, TA) and OazaniIRN: (TA:) spears being thus called in relation to cuw yazanK, one of the Kings of Himyer: (S in art. yzn:) as also MzaniIRN and OayozaniIRN, both formed by transposition. (TA.)

1. zabRa, (K,) aor. yazibRu accord. to the K, but correctly yazabRu, the verb being like fariHa, [so that the sec. pers. is zabibota,] and the inf. n. being zababN, (MF, TA,) [He, or it, was, or became, downy: and he (a man) had abundant and long hair; was hairy: or had abundance of hair in the ears and eyebrows: or had abundance of hair on the fore arms and the eyebrows and eyes: and he (a camel) had abundance of hair on the face and under the lower jaw: or in the ears and on the eyes:] the verb of zababN expl. below. (K, TA.)

Hence, (TA,) zabRati AlXRamosu, (K,) inf. n. zabRN [perhaps a mistranscription for zababN], (TA,) (tropical:) The sun was near to setting; (K, TA;) because it becomes concealed as the colour of a limb does by the hair upon it; (TA;) as also AzbRt↓, (S, K,) and zbRbt↓. (K.)
zabRa, aor. yazubRu, (K,) inf. n. zabRN, (TA,) He filled a water-skin (K, TA) to its head. (TA.)
Also, and AzdbR↓, like zaOaba [and AzdOb], He carried, or took up and carried, a load, or burden. (TA.)
2. zbRb, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazobiybN, (S,) He converted grapes into zabiyb [or raisins]; (S, Mgh, Msb;) he dried grapes, (K,) and likewise figs; (AHn, K;) as also AzbR↓. (K.)

Also, (K,) and zbRb XidoqaAhu, (S, K,) Spittle collected in the two sides of his mouth: (K:) or froth, or foam, came forth upon the two sides of his mouth: (S:) and zbRb famuhu (K, TA) [signifies the same; or] dry spittle appeared at the angles of his lips, next the tongue: (TA:) and tzbRb↓ (K) and XidoqaAhu tzbRb↓ (TA) froth, or foam, appeared in the two sides of his mouth. (K.) You say, takalRama fulaAnN HatRaI zbRb XidoqaAhu Such a one spoke, or talked, until froth, or foam, came forth upon the two sides of his mouth. (S.) [And in like manner you say, zabRada Xidoquhu and tazabRada Xidoquhu: and tazabRada alone.]
See also 1.
4: see 1:
and see also 2.
5. tzbRb AlEinabu The grapes became converted into zabiyb [or raisins]. (Mgh, Msb.)
[Hence,] tazabRaba qabola Oano yataHaSorama (tropical:) [expl. in art. HSrm]. (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.
[Hence,] tzbRb also signifies He (a man) became filled with rage, or wrath. (TA.)
8: see 1, last sentence.
AzdbRt Alqirobapu The water-skin became full (K, TA) to its head. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. zabozaba He was angry: or he was put to flight in war. (K.)

zubRN The penis; the male organ of generation; (S, A, Msb, K;) in the dial. of El-Yemen: i. e. absolutely: (TA:) or peculiarly of a human being: (IDrd, A, K:) or of a boy, in the dial. of El-Yemen: (T, TA:) or of a gazelle, or an antelope: (Eth-Tha'álibee, TA:) said by IDrd to be a genuine Arabic word: (TA:) dim. zubayobN↓; and sometimes zubayobapN↓, with the fem. p, as being a piece (qiToEapN) of the body: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OazobaAbN (Msb, K) and OazubRN and [of mult.] zababapN, (K,) the last extr. [with respect to rule]. (TA.)
And The beard; (S, K;) in the dial. of ElYemen: (S:) or the fore part thereof; (K;) in the dial. of some of the people of El-Yemen. (TA.)
And The nose; (Sh, K;) as some say; in the dial. of El-Yemen. (Sh, TA.)
And A sort of dates of El-Basrah; mentioned by Meyd; as also zubRu rubRaAHK or rubaAHK. (TA.)
zubRu AlqaADiI, which is one of the faults of a thing that is sold, is explained by the lawyers as [The condition of] that whereof the fruit quickly falls (MF.)
Also pl. of OazabRu. (A.)

zababN Down; syn. zagabN: (A, K:) and, in a man, (K, A, *) abundance of hair, (S, A, K,) and length thereof: (S:) or, in a man, abundance of hair in the ears and eyebrows: and abundance of hair on the fore arms and the eyebrows and eyes: (TA:) and in a camel, abundance of hair on the face and under the lower jaw: (K:) or in the ears and on the eyes. (TA.)

zabaAbN A species of rat which is large and deaf: or which has red hair: (K:) or which has red and beautiful hair: (TA:) or which is without hair: (K:) or a species of field-rat, of large size: one thereof is called zabaAbapN: (TA:) or this signifies a deaf rat: (S:) or a deaf rat of the desert: (A:) and its pl. is zabaAbN, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. of which it is the n. un.,] (S, TA,) and [its pl. is] zabaAbaAtN. (TA.) The Arabs make it the subject of a prov.: (S:) they say, Oasoraqu mino zabAbapi [More thievish than a zebábeh]. (S, A, TA. [Another reading is mentioned in the TA in art. znb; namely, ranaAbap; which is there said, on the authority of Ibn-'Abd-Rabbih in the Eiqod, to signify a rat, or mouse.]) And they also liken to it an ignorant person. (S, TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, OanaA waQllRehi UicFA mivolu AlRatiI OuHiyTa bihaA faqiyla zabAabo zabaAbo HatRaI daxalato juHorahaA vumRa QHotufira EanohaA faQjoturRa birijolihaA facubiHato, i. e. [I, by Allah, in that case, were] like that animal, namely, the she-hyena, which has been surrounded, and to which it has been said Zebáb! Zebáb! [until it has entered its hole, and then the earth has been dug away from it, and it has been dragged by its hind leg, and slaughtered:] meaning, I will not be like the she-hyena that is decoyed to its death: for that animal probably eats the zbAb, as it does the field-rat. (TA.)
Also i. q. saAEK [A messenger, or a messenger on a beast of the post: and a collector of the poor-rates: &c.]. (CK: but omitted in the TA, and in my MS. copy of the K.)

zabiybN Dried grapes; or raisins: and also dried figs: (K:) said by AHn to have been used in this latter sense by an Arab of the desert: (TA:) a coll. gen. n.; masc. and fem.: (Msb:) n. un. with p. (S, Msb.)

Also The froth, or foam, of water: (K, TA:) and of a camel's mouth: (L in art. lqH:) and the poison in the mouth of a serpent. (K.) zabiybapN [is the n. un., and] signifies (tropical:) A collection of froth, or foam, in the mouth of a person speaking, or talking, much: (A, * K:) [or the dual] zabiybataAni signifies two collections of froth, or foam, (S,) or of spittle, (K,) or of dry spittle, (TA,) in the sides of the mouth, (S, K,) where the lips meet, next the tongue. (TA.) You say, gaDiba favaAra lahu zabiybataAni (tropical:) He was angry, and there appeared two collections of froth, or foam, in the two sides of his mouth. (A, TA.) zabiybataAni, in a serpent, signifies (assumed tropical:) Two black small spots above the eyes: (S, K, and Mgh in art. XjE:) or two small spots next the mouth thereof: (TA:) or two collections of froth, or foam, in the two sides of the mouth thereof (TA, and Mgh ubi suprà) when it is angry. (Mgh.) And in a dog, Two black small spots above the eyes: (K:) or two things above the eyes, resembling the zanamataAni [see ranamapN] of a camel: or two pieces of flesh in the head, resembling two horns: or two fangs projecting from the mouth: and other explanations are given by the interpreters of strange words [occurring in the traditions]. (TA.)
zubayobN a dim. of zubRN, q. v. (Msb.)
Also a shortened dim. of OazabRu, q. v. (Ham p. 140.)
zabiybapN n. un. of zabiybN. (S, Msb) [See the latter throughout.]
Also (tropical:) A small purulent swelling or pustule, that comes forth upon the hand, (S, A, K, TA,) like what is termed EarofapN. (TA.)
zubayobapN a dim. of zubRN, q. v. (Msb.)
zabiybiIRN [now vulgarly called zabiyb] A beverage made from zabiyb [or raisins] (Mgh, K) by steeping them in water. (K.)
See also what next follows.
zabRaAbN A seller of zabiyb [or raisins]; as also zabiybiIRN↓. (K.)
zabozabN A sort of ship or boat: (S, K:) a small ship or boat: pl. zabaAzibu. (Msb.)
Also A certain beast, resembling the cat: (K:) it is an animal black and white, short in the fore and hind legs. (Dmr, TA.)

OazabRu Downy: (K:) and, applied to a man, having much hair: (A, K:) or having much and long hair: (S, TA: [but accord. to the former, it seems to be applied in this sense to a camel:]) or, applied to a man, having much hair in the ears and eyebrows: and having much hair on the fore arms and the eyebrows and eyes: (TA:) or, thus applied, having much hair on the chest: (Msb:) and, applied to a camel, having much fur: or having much fur on the face: (A:) or having much hair on the face and under the lower jaw: (K:) or, in the ears and on the eyes: (TA:) or having much hair on the face and body: and zubayobN↓ is a shortened dim. thereof: (Ham p. 140:) fem. zabRaMCu, applied to a woman as meaning having
much hair in the eyebrows and on the fore arms and the hands: (A:) and to an ear as meaning having much hair: (TA:) pl. zubRN. (A.) It is said in a prov., kulRu OazabRa nafuwrN [Every one, of camels, that has much hair on the face &c. is wont to take fright, and run away at random]: for the camel thinks what he sees upon his eyes to be a person seeking him, and consequently takes fright, and runs away at random: (A:) the camel to which this epithet applies is seldom, or never, other than nfwr; because there grow upon his eyebrow small hairs, and when the wind strikes them he takes fright, and runs away at random. (S, TA.)

AlOazabRu is a name of One of the devils: (K, TA:) mention is made in a trad. of a certain devil named OazabRu AlEaqabapi: (K, TA:) but in the L, and in the Seeret El-Halabee, it is written Uizobu AlEaqabapi: and it is said to be a serpent. (TA in art. Azb.)
AlzRabRaMCu The Aisot [i. e. podex, or anus], (K, TA,) with its hair. (TA.)
EaAmN OazabRu (tropical:) A year abundant in herbage. (S, A, Msb, K.)
yawomN OazabRu: see OaHaSRu, in two places.
jayoXN OazabRu (assumed tropical:) An army having many spears. (Ham p. 259.)

masoOalapN zabRaMCu caAtu wabarK (tropical:) A dubious and difficult question: likened to the she-camel that [has much hair and fur upon the face &c., and consequently] is wont to take fright, and run away at random. (TA.)

And daAhiyapN zabRaMCu (tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune, hard to be borne, severe, (A, K, TA,) and abominable; like XaEoraMCu (TA) and waboraMCu. (S and A and TA in art. XEr.) Hence the prov., jaMCabiAlXRaEoraMCi AlzRabRaMCi [He brought to pass that which was a calamity hard to be borne, &c.] (TA.)
muzibRN: see what follows.
muzabRibN and muzibRN↓ Possessing much wealth. (K.)

1. zabadahu, (As, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
zabuda
, (As, S, A, Msb,) inf. n. zabodN, (As, Msb,) He fed him with, or gave him to eat, zubod [i. e. fresh butter]. (As, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.)

And hence, (Mgh,) zabadahu, (As, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) or zabada lahu, (K, [app. a mistranscription, for its aor. is there mentioned immediately after without the prep.,]) aor.
zabida
, (As, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) the verb in the sense here following being thus distinguished from that in the sense preceding, (As, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (As, S, Mgh,) (tropical:) He gave him a gift: (As, A, Mgh, Msb:) or he gave him somewhat, a little, not much, (S, K,) of property, (S,) or of his property. (K.)
[Hence also,] zabadotuhu DarobapF, or ramoyapF, (tropical:) I struck him a blow, or shot or cast at him a missile, hastily, or quickly; as though feeding him with a piece of fresh butter. (A, TA.)

zabadato siqaMCahaA, (S, A,) or zabada AlsRiqaMCa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (A,) She agitated her milk-skin, (S, A,) or he agitated the milk-skin, (K,) in order that its butter might come forth, (S, K,) or until its butter came forth. (A.)

And zabadotu AlsRawiyqa [app. I put, or added, fresh butter to the meal of parched barley, like as one says samanotu AlTRaEaAma and Oadamotu Alxuboza &c.], aor. Oazobiduhu, (A, TA,) with kesr; (A;) and AlsRawiyqa tazabRadotu↓. (TA. [Both these phrases are mentioned together, as though to indicate that both signify the same: but Ibr D thinks that the latter means I swallowed the swyq like as one swallows fresh butter: in my copy of the A, it is written tazabRadati AlsRawiyqu, which is evidently wrong: perhaps the right reading is tazabRada AlsRawiyqu; and the verb in this phrase, quasi-pass. of that in the former phrase.]

2. zbRd Xidoquhu, (S, K,) inf. n. tazobiydN; (K;) and tzbRd↓; both signify the same [i. e. The side of his mouth had froth, or foam, appearing upon it; like zabRaba and tazabRaba]: (S, K:) and tzbRd↓ said of a man, [like tazabRaba,] He being angry, froth, or foam, appeared upon each corner of his mouth. (TA.) See also 4, in two places.

zabRadati AlquTona, (A, L,) inf. n. as above, (S,) She separated, or loosened, the cotton [with her fingers, or by means of the bow and wooden mallet], (S, * L, A,) and prepared it well for spinning. (L.)
3. fulaAnN yuzaAbidu fulaAnFA (tropical:) Such a one speaks in like manner as does such a one. (A, TA.)

4. Azbd, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. UizobaAdN, (Msb,) said of wine, or beverage, (S,) or of the sea, (A, Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) or of the sea when in a state of commotion, (S, * A,) and of a cookingpot, and of the mouth of a braying camel, (A,) [&c., see zabadN,] It frothed, or foamed, or cast forth froth or foam: (S, * A, Msb, K:) and [in like manner] zbRd↓, inf. n. tazobiydN, said of milk, it [frothed, or foamed; or] had froth, or foam, upon it. (A.)

[Hence,] said of the sidor [or lote-tree], (S, A, K,) (tropical:) It blossomed; (S, K, TA;) i. e. (TA) it put forth a white produce like the froth, or foam, upon water. (A, TA.) And, said of the qataAdi [or tragacantha], (assumed tropical:) It put forth its leaf (xuwSap), and its wood, or branch, became strong, or hard, and its rind, or outer covering, coalesced, and it blossomed; as also zbRd↓. (L.)
Also (tropical:) It became intensely white. (A, TA.)
5: see 1:
and see also 2, in two places.

tzbRdhu (assumed tropical:) He swallowed it (K) like as one swallows a piece of fresh butter: (TA:) or he took the clear, or pure, or choice, part of it. (K, TA.) Of anything of which the clear, or pure, or choice part has been taken, one says, tuzubRida. (TA.)

[Hence,] tzbRd Alyamiyna (assumed tropical:) He took the oath hastily; was hasty in taking it. (AA, S, K.) It is said in a prov., tazabRadahaA HacRaMCa (assumed tropical:) He swallowed it [i. e. took it, namely, an oath, hastily,] like as one swallows butter. (TA in art. Hc.)

zabodN [originally an inf. n.,] (tropical:) A gift. (S, A, Mgh, Msb.) So in the saying (S, TA) of Mo- hammad, (TA,) mentioned in a trad., UinRaA laA naqobalu zaboda AlmuXorikiyna (tropical:) [Verily we will not accept the gift of the believers in a plurality of Gods]. (S, TA.) And so in the saying, nahaI Eano zabodi AlmuXorikiyna (tropical:) (A, Mgh, Msb) i. e. [He (Mohammad) forbade] the acceptance of the gift [of the believers in a plurality of Gods]. (Msb.)

zubodN [Fresh butter of the cow or buffalo or sheep or goat;] what is produced by churning from milk (Mgh, Msb) of cows [or buffaloes] and of sheep or goats; what is thus produced from camels' milk being termed jubaAbN, not zubodN; (Msb;) the zubod of samon before it is clarified over the fire; (L;) [i. e. butter before it is clarified over the fire;] the zubod [in the CK, erroneously, zabad] of milk; (S, K;) what is extracted from milk; (M;) and zubRaAdN↓ signifies the same as zubodN: (K:) zubodapN↓ is a more particular term, (S, M, L, Msb,) meaning a piece, bit, portion, or somewhat, of zubod: (L:) and zubodu AllRabani signifies also the froth (ragowap) of milk [if this be not a mistake occasioned by finding AlzRubodu expl. as meaning zabadu AllRabani instead of zubodu AllRabani]. (L.) qado SarRaHa AlmaHoDu Eani AlzRubodi [The clear milk has become distinct from the fresh butter] is a prov., relating to the appearance of the truth after information that has been doubted. (L.) And Airotajanati AlzRubodapu↓ is another prov. [expl. in art. rjn]. (L.)

zubodapN↓ has for its pl. zubadN, which is metonymically applied to (tropical:) The choice, or best, portions, [or what we often term the cream (by which word the sing. also may be rendered) of anything; as, for instance,] of discourse, or of a story or the like. (Har p. 222, q. v.)

[And it also means (assumed tropical:) An issue, or event: (see an ex. voce maxaDa:) generally, such as is relishable, or pleasing. Hence, app.,] one says, AlEumuri kaAna liqaAWuka zubodapa↓ (tropical:) [The meeting with thee was emphatically the event of life; meaning, the most relishable, or pleasing, event of life]. (A, TA.)

zabadN Froth, foam, spume, or scum: (L:) it is of water, (S, L, K,) &c.; (K;) of the sea, (A, Msb,) &c., like ragowapN [in signification]; (Msb;) and of a cooking-pot; (A;) and of a camel, (S,) [i. e.] of a braying camel's mouth, (A,) or the white foam upon the lips of a camel when he is excited by lust; (TA;) and of the cud; and of spittle; (L;) and [the scum, or dross,] of silver: (S:) zabadapN↓ is a more particular term [meaning a portion, or somewhat, thereof]: (S:) the pl. of zabadN is OazobaAdN. (A, TA.)
taxarRama zabaduhu: see 5 in art. xrm, in two places.
zubodapN: see zubodN, in four places.
zabadapN: see zabadN.
zubodiIRN [Butyraceous: a rel. n. from zubodN]. See xaXoxaAXN.

zabaAdN [Civet;] a certain perfume, well known: the lawyers and the lexicologists err in saying that it is a certain beast, [meaning the civet-cat,] from which the perfume is milked: (K:) or this assertion is not to be reckoned as a mistake, the word being tropically thus applied: so says El- Karáfee: and Z and other authors worthy of confidence thus apply it [as a coll. gen. n.]: Z also mentions a saying in which zabaAdapN↓ is applied [as a n. un.] to an animal of the kind from which the perfume is obtained: (TA:) this animal is the cat, (K,) i. e. the wild cat, which is like the tame, but longer and larger, and its hair inclines more
to blackness: it is brought from India and Abyssinia: (TA:) the perfume above mentioned is a fluid, or matter, exuded, (raXaHN, thus in the TA and in my MS. copy of the K, but in the CK wasaxN [i. e. dirt],) resembling black viscous dirt, (TA,) which collects beneath the animal's tail, upon the anus (Almaxoraj), (K,) and in the inner sides of the thighs also, as says Ed-Demámeenee: (TA:) [see also zuhomN:] the beast is taken, and prevented from struggling, and the said exuded fluid or matter, or dirt, (raXaH, or wasax, accord. to different copies of the K,) collected there, is scraped off with a piece of the exterior part of a cane, (K,) or, more commonly, with a spoon, (TA,) or with a piece of rag, (K,) or a thin [silver coin such as is called] diroham. (TA. [Other accounts of this perfume, which are less correct, I omit.])
See also zubRaAdN.
zubaAdN, like guraAbN [in measure], Fresh butter (zubod) that has become bad, or spoiled, in the churning: or, as some say, thin milk. (TA voce AixotalaTa, q. v.) [See also zubRaAdu AllRaban, below.]
zabaAdapN: see zabaAdN.

zubRaAdu AllRabani [The watery part of milk;] that [part] in which is no good, of milk. (S, K. [See also zubaAdN.]) It is said in a prov., AixotalaTa AlxaAviru biAlzRubRaAdi (S) [The thick milk became mixed with the thin watery part: or] (tropical:) the good became mixed with the bad: relating to a case of difficulty, and applied to the mixture of truth with falsehood. (L. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 434: and see AixotalaTa.])
See also zubodN.

zubRaAdN and zubRaAdaI↓ A certain plant, (S, K,) growing in the plains, or soft land, having broad leaves, and a [pericarp such as is called] sinofap: it sometimes grows in hard ground, is eaten by men, and is good, or pleasant: AHn says that it has small, contracted, dust-coloured leaves, like those of the marozanojuwX, and its branches, or twigs, spread out: and he adds, AZ says that the zubRaAd, as also zabaAd↓, the latter like saHaAb [in measure], is of the [kind of plants called] OaHoraAr [pl. of HurRN, q. v.]: (TA:) [some say that it is the psyllium. (Freytag's Lex.) See, again, AixotalaTa.]
zubRaAdaI: see the next preceding paragraph.
zaAbidN Possessing, or a possessor of, zubod [or fresh butter]; (L;) as also muzodabidN↓. (K.)
baHorN muzobidN [A frothing, or foaming, sea; or] a tumultuous, frothing, or foaming, sea. (S, A.)
[Hence,] OaboyaDu muzobidN (tropical:) Intensely white. (A, TA.)
muzodabidN: see zaAbidN.

1. zabara AlbiYora, (A, TA,) [aor.
zabura
, and perhaps
zabira
also,] inf. n. zaborN, (S, K,) He cased the well, or walled it internally, with stones. (S, A, K.)

zaborN also signifies The disposing a building, or construction, one part upon another; (K;) [as is done in casing a well;] and in this sense likewise it is an inf. n., of which the verb is zabara. (TK.)
And zabarahu biAlHijaArapi, (TA,) inf. n. zaborN, (K,) He threw stones at him; or pelted him with stones. (K, TA.)

And [hence, perhaps, or] from zabara in the first of the senses expl. above, because him whom you restrain from error you strengthen like as a well is strengthened by its being cased, (TA,) zabarahu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
zabura
(S, Mgh, Msb, K) and
zabira
, (Ks, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He chid him; or checked, restrained, or forbade, him with rough speech: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) he prevented, hindered, or withheld, him: (S, Mgh, K:) he forbade, or prohibited, him: (K:) he repelled him with strength. (MF in art. hzbr.) You say, zabarahu Eani AlOamori He restrained him with rough speech, or forbade and prevented him, from doing the thing. (TA.) And zabara AlsRaAYila He chid and repelled the beggar with rough speech. (TA.)

zabara, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
zabura
and
zabira
, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, He wrote (S, A, Msb, K) a writing, or book: (A, Msb:) or he wrote it firmly, skilfully, or well: (TA:) and he inscribed, or engraved, upon stones: (Az, TA:) and tazobirapN↓, also, is syn. with kitaAbapN, like zaborN, (S, K,) and xaTRN: As says, I heard an Arab of the desert say, OanaA OaEorifu tazobiratiI, meaning xaTRiI and kitaAbatiI [i. e. I know my writing, or handwriting]: (S:) and Fr says, It is either an inf. n. of zabRara↓, meaning he wrote, though I know not the verb with teshdeed, or it is a simple subst. like tawodiyapN: (TA:) thus zabara is syn. with cabara: (A 'Obeyd, T and S in art. cbr:) [and so, perhaps, is zabRara↓ with cabRara.]
And zabarotuhu signifies also I read it, or recited it; [or did so with a low, or faint, voice;] like cabarotuhu [q. v.]. (As, TA.)

zaborN is also syn. with kalaAmN [as meaning The act of speaking, or speech as a subst.]: (K:) [SM says,] thus it is found in all the copies: but [he adds] I have not found any authoritative ex. of it, so it requires consideration. (TA.) [Accord. to the TK, however, one says, saOalotuhu famaA zabara liI bizaborK, meaning I asked him, and he spoke not to me a speech, or sentence]

Accord. to the K, zaborN is also syn. with SaborN [meaning The being patient, or patience]: one says, maA lahu zaborN walaASaborN: ISd says, This is mentioned by IAar; but in my opinion, the meaning here is EaqolN. (TA. [See zaborN below.]) [Or, as syn. with SaborN, it may be an inf. n.: for, accord. to the TK, one says, lm yzbr Elyh, meaning He did not endure it with patience (lamo yaSobiro).]
zabura, inf. n. zabaArapN, He (a ram) was, or became, bulky. (Lth, TA.)
2: see 1, in two places.
4. Azbr He (a man, TA) was, or became, large in body. (K.)
And He was, or became, courageous, brave, or strong-hearted. (K.)
Oazobarotuhu, inf. n. UizobaArN, I rendered him (a ram) bulky. (Lth, TA.)
5. tzbRr He (a man) quaked, or trembled, by reason of anger. (TA. [See also Q. Q. 4.])
Q. Q. 1. zaOobara (S, A, K) and zawobara (K) [and app. zayobara (see muzaOobirN)], said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, A, K,) Its ziYobir [or nap] came forth; (S, K; *) it had ziYobir. (TA.)

Also the first, [and app. the second and third likewise,] He made a garment, or piece of cloth, to have its ziYobir [or nap] come forth. (K.) [This verb and other similar words with hemzeh next after the z are mentioned in the K in a separate art. before art. zbr.]
Q. Q. 4. AizobaOarRa It (fur, or soft hair, and a plant, or herbage) grew forth. (S, K, TA.)
It (hair) bristled up. (S, A, K.)
He (a dog [and a horse]) bristled up his hair. (S, K.) Marrár Ibn-Munkid El-Handhalee says, (S, TA,) describing a horse, (TA,)
[And he is of a yellowish red colour on the occasion of his bristling up his hair, and of a dark bay colour as long as he does not bristle up his hair]. (S, TA.)
Also He (a cat) had abundance of hair. (TA.)
And He (a man) prepared for evil, or mischief: (K, TA:) or became affected by a quaking, or trembling, and a bristling-up of the hair. (TA)
zaborN Stones. (K.)
[The stone casing of the interior of a well: see juwlN.

And hence,] (tropical:) Understanding, intellect, or intelligence, (S, A, K,) and judgment, (TA,) and self-restraint: (S, A:) originally an inf. n. [accord. to some; but this is evidently a mistake, as is shown by phrases in which it is coupled with juwlN]. (S.) One says, maA lahu zaborN (tropical:) He has not understanding, or intellect, or intelligence, nor self-restraint: (S, A:) or judgment: or understanding to be relied upon. (TA.) And lahu zaborN wajuwlN: and maA fawoqa huwa mazobuwrN↓ Aljuwli minohu waSulobN maA taHota AlzRabori mina Aljuwli: see juwlN. One says also of the wind, when it veers, or shifts, and does not continue to blow from one point, layosa lahaA zaborN (tropical:) [It has not steadiness]. (TA.)
See also zibirRN.

ziborN [A thing] written; as also zabiyrN↓: (K:) [or] a writing, or book; (S;) as also zabuwrN↓, of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (S, Msb, K,) like rasuwlN: (Msb, TA:) zabuwrN signifying any writing or book: or any divine book with which it is difficult to become acquainted: or a book that is confined to intel-lectual science, exclusive of legal statutes or ordinances: (TA:) AlzRabuwru↓ signifies particularly the Book [of the Psalms] of David: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and also, and lugapu AlzRabuwri, the Syriac [or Hebrew] language: (Mgh:) the pl. of ziborN is zubuwrN; (S, K;) and the pl. of zabuwrN↓ is zuburN. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [xxi. 105], walaqado katabonaA fiI mino baEodi QlcRikori QlzRabuwri↓, meaning And we have written in the book sent down to David, after the taworaAp [or Book of the Law revealed to Moses]: (Aboo-Hureyreh, TA:) Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr read
AlzRubuwr, [pl. of AlzRiboru,] and said that it means the Book of the Law revealed to Moses (AltwrAp) and the Gospel and the Kur-án [together]; and that Alckr means what is in heaven: (TA:) and some also read zubuwrFA in the Kur iv. 161 and xvii. 57. (S, TA.)
zabarN, syn. with zawobarN &c.: see ziYobirN.

zuborapN A piece of iron: (S, Msb, K:) or a big piece of iron: (TA:) pl. zubarN (S, Msb, K) and zuburN. (S, K.) The former pl. occurs in the Kur xviii. 95. (S.) It is also said in the Kur [xxiii. 55], fataqaTRaEuwA Oamorahumo bayonahumo zuburFA, (S, TA,) and zubarFA; (TA;) meaning qiTaEFA, (S, TA,) in both cases; (Fr;) [i.e., But they have become divided, in their state, among themselves, into parties:] or he who reads zuburFA makes it pl. of zabuwrN↓, not of zuborapN; for the measure fuEolapN does not assume the measure fuEulN in the pl.; and the meaning is, they have made their religion [to be founded upon] various books: and zubarN is pl. of zuborapN: or it may be also pl. of zabuwrN↓, and originally zuburN, being changed therefrom, like as some of the Arabs are related to have said judadN for the pl. of jadiydN, which is originally and regularly jududN; after the same manner as when one says rukabaAtN for rukubaAtN, and gurafaAtN for gurufaAtN: and this opinion is strengthened by AA's allowing the reading zuburFA and zuborFA and zubarFA; zuborFA being a contraction of zuburFA, like as EunoqN is of EunuqN. (IB, TA.)
The anvil (K) of a blacksmith. (TA.)

The upper part of the back, next the neck; or the part between the two shoulder-blades; or the part where the neck is joined to the back-bone; syn. kaAhilN: (K:) or the place of the kAhl: (S:) or a certain thing rising from the kAhl: (TA:) pl. in this sense, OazobaArN; or this is a pl. pl., as though it were pl. of zubarN, and this were pl. of zuborapN in this sense. (TA.) One says, XadRa liloOamori zuboratahu He strengthened his kaAhil and his back for the affair. (TA.)

Also, hence, (S,) The accumulation, or mass, of hair which is between the shoulder-blades of the lion; (S in art. lbd;) [the mane of a lion;] the collection of hair (Lth, A, K) between the shoulderblades of the lion &c., (K,) or upon the place of the kaAhil [expl. above], and upon the elbows, of the lion; (Lth, A;) and any hair in a similar collected state. (Lth, TA.)

And [hence,] AlzRuborapu (tropical:) A certain asterism; (K;) two bright stars [d and q], (S, K,) in the kaAhil [or part of the back next the neck], (K,) or which are the kaAhilaAni, (S,) of Leo; (S, K;) one [namely the Eleventh] of the Mansions of the Moon: (S, K:) [also called AlxaraAtaAni: see this word: and see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:] it is of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) [This description is incorrect if applied to the constellation as at present figured; but doubtless correct when applied to it as figured by the Arabs. Kzw, in his description of Leo, says that they are two stars, on the belly, and on the projecting part of the haunch-bone, of Leo.]
Also The breast, or what projects of its upper part, (syn. SudorapN,) of any beast. (TA.)
zibirRN, applied to a lion, (S, TA,) and to a man, (TA,) Strong; (AA, S, K, TA;) as also zaborN↓. (K.)
zabuwrN: see ziborN, in four places; and see zuborapN, in two places.
zabiyrN: see ziborN.
Applied to a ram, Bulky: (Lth, TA:) or large in the zuborap [q. v.]: or compact. (TA.)
Applied to a man, Strong: and also acute, sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent. (TA.)
Also A calamity, or misfortune; (Fr, K;) and so ↓, zawobarN, (Mohammad Ibn-Habeeb, TA,) which has been said to have this meaning in a verse of Ibn-Ahmar cited below voce ziYobirN. (TA.)
And Black mud; or black fetid mud. (Sgh, K.)
zaOobarN: see the next paragraph.
zuWoburN: see the next paragraph.

ziYobirN (S, and K in art. zObr, in the CK [erroneously] written ziYobar,) and ziYoburN, (S, K,) sometimes thus pronounced, (S,) or this, which is mentioned by IJ and ISd, is incorrect, (K, * TA,) and zuWoburN↓ and zuwburN↓ and zawobarN↓, (K in arts. zObr and zbr,) as also zagobarN or zigobarN (as in two different copies of the K in art. zgbr) or zigobirN (as in another copy of the K and in the O and TA in the same art.) and zagoburN (accord. to a copy of the K in that art.) or zigoburN, (O and TA in that art., and so accord. to one copy of the K,) [The nap, or villous substance, upon the surface of a garment, or piece of cloth;] what is upon the surface of a new garment, or piece of cloth, like what is upon the surface of [the kind of cloth called] xazR; (S, TA;) the ziYobir of [the kind of cloth called] xazR, and of a qaTiyfap, and of any garment, or piece of cloth; (Lth, TA;) the zgbr of a garment, or piece of cloth; (AZ, TA;) or what appears of the daroz [q. v., here meaning nap, or villous substance,] of a garment, or piece of cloth. (IJ, K.) [Hence] one says, cahabati AlOayRaAmu biTaraAwatihi wanafaDato ziYobirahu (tropical:) [lit. Days took away its freshness, and shook off its nap]; meaning its age became old. (A, TA.) And Oaxacahu bizawobarihi↓ (S, A, K) and zaOobarihi↓ (S, K) and zabarihi↓, (K,) as also zagobarihi, (S, and K * in art. zgbr,) and zanawobarihi↓, incorrectly written in the K zabawobarihi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He took it altogether, (S, A, K,) leaving nothing of it. (S.) Ibn-Ahmar says,

L.foreign: waUino qaAla EaAwK mino maEadRK qaSiydapF

sense.s: i. e. (assumed tropical:) [And if a howler of Ma'add utters an ode in which is a fault,] it is attributed to me altogether, (S, * L,) when I have not been the author of it: (L:) the last word, accord. to Aboo-'Alee [El-Fárisee], being imperfectly decl. because made a proper name for the qSydp, and therefore combining the two qualities of being determinate and being of the fem. gender: so he said in answer to a question of IJ: but some say that the said word there means a calamity, or misfortune: and IB says that it is a proper name for a bitch (klbp [if this be not a mistranscription]), of the fem. gender. (TA. [In one copy of the S, I find only the last three words of this verse: in another, it commences thus: UicaA qaAla gaAwK mino tanuwxa: in the TA, the former reading is given, except that gaAwK is put in the place of EaAwK.]) One says also, rajaEa bizawobarihi↓ (assumed tropical:) He returned disappointed, or unsuccessful; (TA;) without having obtained anything; (K, TA;) and without having accomplished his want. (TA.)
zawobarN: see zabiyrN:
and see also ziYobirN, in four places.
zuwburN: see ziYobirN.
zanobariIRN: see art. znbr.
zinobaArN: see art. znbr.
zunobuwrN: see art. znbr.
Oaxacahu bizanawobarihi: see ziYobirN.

Oazobaru and mazobaraAniIRN↓ (the latter written in [some of] the copies of the K, [not in all of them, for in the CK it is written as above,] muzobirN, which is a mistake, TA) Large in the zuborap [q. v.]: (S, K:) the former applied to a man, and the latter to a lion: (S:) or, accord. to ISd, Khálid Ibn-Kulthoom is in error in saying that the latter is an epithet applied to the lion; and that the correct word is marozubaAniIRN: the fem. of the former is zaboraMCu. (TA.)
Also the former, Annoying, or hurting. (Sgh, K.)

qado haAjato zaboraMCu [Zebrà has become excited], (S,) or haAjato zaboraMWuhu His anger has become excited, is said of any man when this has been the case: (TA:) [it is said that] Zebrà was a clamorous and foul-tongued slave-girl of ElAhnaf Ibn-Keys; and when she was angry, he used to say, qd hAjt zbrMC: and it became a proverb. (S, TA.)
tazobirapN: see 1.
mizobarN A writing-reed; (S, A, K, TA;) a reed with which one writes. (TA.)
mazobarapN: see art. znbr.
mazobaraAniIRN: see Oazobaru.
biYorN mazobuwrapN A well cased, or walled internally, with stones. (S.)
See also zaborN.

muzaOobirN and muzaOobarN (S, K) and muzawobirN↓ and muzayobirN↓, or muzawobarN↓ and muzayobarN↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) the third and fourth and the fifth and sixth said by Fr to be dial. vars. of the first and second, (Sgh, TA,) A garment, or piece of cloth, having nap (ziYobir) upon it: (S, K:) [or the second and fifth and sixth, having its nap made to come forth:] or the first is applied to a man [as meaning making to have its nap come forth; and so the third and fourth]: and the second, to a garment or a piece of cloth [as having the second of the meanings expl. above; and so the fifth and sixth]. (TA.)
muzawobarN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muzayobarN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Q. 1. zaboraja He embellished, beautified, adorned, or decorated, a thing. (TA.)

ziborijN Embellishment, ornament, or decoration; consisting in variegated, or figured, work; or in jewels, or gems; (S, K, TA;) and the like: (S, TA:) embellishment, ornament, or decoration, of weapons: (TA:) and anything beautiful. (Th, TA.) [Hence,] ziboriju AldRunoyaA The vanities and finery of the present world or state of existence. (TA, from a trad. of 'Alee.)
Also Gold: (S, K:) so some say. (S.)

And Thin clouds, in which is a redness: (Fr, S, K:) or clouds spotted in the surface with blackness and redness: or light clouds which the wind sweeps away, or disperses: or red clouds: but AZ says that the first of these is the correct signification: and clouds spotted like the leopard, seeming to be such as will give rain: and thin clouds, in which is no water. (TA.)

muzaborajN Embellished, adorned, or decorated: applied as an epithet to ziborijN [either in the first or second of the senses expl. above, as is indicated in the S; and also as meaning clouds, as is likewise indicated in the S: in each case merely heightening the signification]. (S, K.) You say also saHaAbN muzaborajN [app. meaning Variegated clouds]. (TA.)

zabarojadN [The chrysolite; a certain green diaphonous gem;] a well-known gem; (S, Msb, K;) as also zabarodajN; (TA;) i. q. zumurRucN; (S and K in art. zmrc;) or said to be so; (Msb;) [but this appears to be a mistake;] or it is a kind of zumurRuc: (TA:) the mine in which it receives its being is in the mine of the zmrRc, with which it is found; but it is very rare, more so than the zmrRc: at the present period, the year 640 [of the Flight], none whatever of it is found in the mine: some species of it are of a dark green colour; some, light green; and some, of a middling hue of green, of a good water, and very transparent, and these are the best and the most costly species thereof. (ElTeyfáshee, in De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., i. 267, q. v.)
zabarodajN: see the next preceding art.

AlzRawobaEapN The name of a certain devil; (Lth, K;) to which some add, insolent and audacious in pride and rebellion: (TA:) or a certain chief of the jinn, or genii: (S, K:) said to be one of those, nine or seven in number, spoken of in the Kur-án [xlvi. 28], as listening to the Kur-án. (TA.)

And hence, zawobaEapN, (S, K,) and (K,) or as some say, (S, TA,) OumRu zawobaEapK, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or OumRu zawobaEapa, (as in other copies of the K,) and, (K,) as the children of the Arabs of the desert call it, (Lth,) Oabuw zawobaEapK, or Oabuw zawobaEapa, (accord. to different copies of the K,) i. q. UiEoSaArN; (Lth, S, K;) i. e. A whirlwind of dust [or sand] rising into the sky; (TA;) a wind that raises the dust [or sand] and rises towards the sky as though it were a pillar: (S:) [I have measured several of these whirling pillars of dust or sand, with a sextant, in circumstances peculiarly favourable to accuracy, in Upper Egypt, and found them from five hundred to seven hundred and fifty feet in height:] it is said [in the present day] that in the zwbEp is a devil, insolent and audacious in pride and rebellion. (K.)
zawaAbiEu [is the pl., and also] signifies Calamities, or misfortunes. (TA.)

1. zabaqa, (IF, S, Msb, K,) aor.
zabiqa
(A 'Obeyd, S, K) and
zabuqa
, (K,) inf. n. zaboqN, (TA,) He plucked out (IF, S, Msb, K) his hair, (IF, S,) or the hair, (Msb,) or his beard. (K.)
zabaqato biwaladihaA She (a woman) cast forth her child. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)
Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He mixed a thing with (bi) another thing. (K.)
He made a man to enter into (fiI) a thing, and a house, or tent, or chamber. (IKh, TA.)
He confined a man (As, A 'Obeyd, IF, K) in a prison. (TA.)
He straitened a man. (TA.)
He made fast, or bound or tied fast or firmly, a sheep, or goat, and a lamb, or kid, round the neck, with a cord; like rabaqa biHabolK. (IKh, TA.)
Also He broke a thing. (TA.)
And He opened a lock. (TA.)
2. zbRq, inf. n. tazobiyqN: see its syn. zaOobaqa, in art. zObq.
5. tzbRq He ornamented, or adorned, himself; like tzlRq. (Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. zlq.)

7. Anzbq He entered (IKh, IF, S, K) into a house, or tent, or chamber; (IKh, IF, K;) and he entered into it and concealed himself: (TA:) [quasi-pass. of zabaqa, or] formed by transposition from Anzqb. (S, TA.) And [simply] He hid, or concealed, himself. (TA.)
And Anzbq fiI AlHibaAlapi He became caught, or entangled, in the snare. (Lh, TA.)
maA OagonaI zaboqapF He, or it, did not stand, or serve, instead of anything. (TA.)
zibiqRaAnapN A man very evil, bad, unjust, mischievous, or corrupt: and a woman narrow in disposition. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)
liHoyapN zabiyqapN (K, TA, in the CK zayobaqapN] A beard plucked out; as also mazobuwqapN↓. (K.)
zanobaqN, mentioned in the S and Msb in this art., and said in the latter to be of the measure fanoEalN: see art. znbq.
ziybiqN: see ziYobiqN, in art. zObq.
zaAbuwqapN An angle of a house: or the like of a dagal [q. v.] in a house (K, TA) or building, (TA,) in which are turning [or zigzag] angles: (K, TA:) so says Lth. (TA.)
Oazobaqu One who plucks out the hair of his beard, because of his foolishness, or stupidity. (El-Wezeer Ibn-El-Maghribee, TA.)
muzabRaqN: see muzaOobaqN, in art. zObq.
liHoyapN mazobuwqapN: see zabiyqapN.
muzayobaqN: see muzaOobaqN, in art. zObq.

1. zabala, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
zabula
, (Msb,) or
zabila
, (K,) inf. n. zubuwlN and zabolN, (Msb,) He dunged, or manured, (S, K,) land, (S,) or seed-produce; (K;) he put land into a good state for sowing, with zibol and the like. (Msb.) [In a copy of the M, in art. smd, this verb is written zabRala↓, which I believe to be post-classical.]

And zabala, inf. n. zabolN; and Azdbl↓; He bore, carried, or took up and carried, a thing; as also zamala and Azdml. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN Xadiydu AlzRaboli liloqirobapi Such a one is strong to bear, or carry, or take up and carry, the water-skin. TA.)
And It (a place, or ground,) held, or retained, water. (TA.)
2. zbRl: see 1. [It is thus commonly pronounced in the present day in the sense first assigned above to zabala.]
8. Azdbl: see the first paragraph.

zibolN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and zabiylN↓ (K) i. q. sirojiynN (S) or siroqiynN (Mgh, K, TA) [Dung of horses or other solid-hoofed animals, or fresh dung of camels, sheep and goats, wild oxen, and the like; used for manure]; and the like thereof. (TA.)
And the former, i. q. HaqiybapN [i. e. A bag, or receptacle, in which a man puts his travellingprovisions; and any other thing that is conveyed behind him on his beast: &c.]. (AA, TA.)
zubolapN A morsel, gobbet, or mouthful. (IAar, K.)
zabalapN: see zibaAlN, in two places.
zubaAlN: see the next paragraph.

zibaAlN A thing that the ant will carry in its mouth: (S, K, TA: [in some of the copies of the K, in the place of AlnRamolapu is put AlnRaHolapu, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake:]) or as much as the gnat will carry. (TA in art. rzO.) Hence the saying, maA OaSaAba mino fulaAnK zibaAlFA and zubaAlFA↓ He obtained not from such a one anything. (IDrd, K, TA.) And maA razaOotuhu zibaAlFA I did not take from him, or it, anything: (S:) and maA razaOotuhu zabalapF↓ means the same: (K:) and in like manner, maA OagonaI Eanohu zabalapF↓ [He, or it, did not stand him in stead of anything; or profit him at all]. (TA.) Hence also a saying of Ibn-Mukbil cited in art. rzO, conj. 8. (S, TA.) [See also zubaAlapN.]

zabiylN (S, Msb, K) and zibRiylN↓ (S, K) and zinobiylN↓ (S, Msb, K) and zanobiylN↓, (K, TA,) the last mentioned by Sgh, on the authority of Fr, (TA,) A [basket of palm-leaves, such as is called] mikotal, (Msb,) or qufRap: or a jiraAb: or a wiEaMC, (K, TA,) in which things are carried: (TA:) a thing well known: (S:) pl. (of the first, Msb) zubulN (Msb, K) and zubolaAnN, (K,) and (of the ↓third, Msb)
zanaAbiylu. (Msb, TA.) One says, Einodahu zubulN mino tamorK and zanaAbiylu↓ [With him are palm-leaf-baskets of dates]. (TA.)
For the first, see also zibolN.
zubaAlapN Sweepings. (Msb in art. kns.)

[And hence, Anything; like zibaAlN and zabalapN.] One says, maA fiI AlUinaMCi, (S,) or AlbiYori, (K,) and AlsRiqaMCi, (TA,) zubaAlapN, i. e. [There is not in the vessel, or the well, and the water-skin or milk-skin,] anything. (S, K, TA.)
zabRaAlN A collector of zibol: (Msb:) one whose occupation is to carry zibol. (TA.) [In the present day it means A scavenger, or dustman.]
zibRiylN: see zabiylN.
zaAbalN and zaAbilN (S, K) and zaOobalN and zaOoblN, but mostly without C, (K,) [applied to a man,] Short. (S, K.)
ziYobilN A calamity, or misfortune: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) pl. zaMbilu. (TA.)
zinobiylN and zanobiylN, and the pl. zanaAbiylN: see zabiylN, in four places.
mazobalapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and mazobulapN (S, Msb, K) A place of zibol: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) a place where zibol is thrown down: (M, K:) pl. mazaAbilu. (TA.)

1. zabanahu, (Msb, TA,) and zabana bihi, (TA,) aor.
zabina
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. zabonN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) He pushed it, or thrust it; or pushed it, or thrust it, away; (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K, * TA;) namely, a thing: (Msb, TA:) or a thing from another thing. (M, * TA.) You say of a she-camel, tazobinu HaAlibahaA She pushes, or thrusts, or she pushes, or thrusts, away, her milker. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) And zabanato, (S,) or zabanato bivafinaAti rijolihaA, (TA,) She (a camel) struck with her stifle-joints (TA) on the occasion of being milked: zabonN being [generally] with the stifle-joints; and rakoDN, with the hind leg; and xaboTN, with the fore leg. (S, TA.) And tazobinu waladahaA Eano DaroEihaA birijolihaA She (a camel) pushes, or thrusts, away her young one from her udder with her hind leg. (M, TA.) And zabanahumo He pushed, or thrust, them away; put them away, or removed them from their place. (TA.) And of war, or battle, (Harob,) one says, tazobinu AlnRaAsi, meaning (tropical:) It dashes men [one against another], and pushes, or thrusts, them. (S, TA.)

And zabanota EanRaA hadiyRataka wamaEoruwfaka, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) Thou hast turned away from us thy present and thy bounty, or favour: accord. to Lh, properly meaning thou hast turned them away from thy neighbours and acquaintance to others: or, accord. to the A, (tropical:) thou hast withdrawn, and withheld, from us thy present &c. (TA.)

zabonN also signifies The selling any fruit upon its trees for [other] fruit by measure: (K:) whence AlmuzaAbanapu↓ (see 3): it has been forbidden, because of the fraud, or deceit, and the ignorance, attending it: and is thus termed because either of the two parties, when he repents, repels the other [if able to do so] from the obligation that he has imposed upon him. (TA.)

3. zAbnhu, (K,) inf. n. muzaAbanahN, (TA,) i. q. daAfaEahu [He contended, or strove, with him in pushing, or thrusting, or in pushing, or thrusting, away; or he pushed him, &c., being pushed &c. by him; or he pushed against him]. (K.)

muzaAbanapN signifies [also] The selling dates (S, Mgh, Msb, K) in their fresh ripe state (S, K) upon the heads of the palm-trees for dried dates (S, Mgh, Msb, K) by measure; (Mgh, Msb;) which is forbidden, because it is a sale by conjecture, [or] without measuring and without weighing: (S, TA:) it is from AlzRabonu; because it leads to contention and mutual repulsion: (Mgh:) and in like manner, the selling any fruit upon its trees for fruit by measure: see 1, last sentence: (TA:) accord. to Málik, any selling or buying of a thing by conjecture, not knowing its measure nor its number nor its weight, for something named of that which is measured and weighed and numbered: or the selling of a thing known for a thing unknown of its kind: or the selling of a thing unknown for a thing unknown of its kind: or a buying and selling in which is a mutual endeavour to endamage, or overreach, (bayoEu mugaAbanapK,) in a kind in which endamaging, or overreaching, is not allowable; (K;) because, in this case, he who is endamaged, or overreached, desires to annul the sale, and he who endamages, or overreaches, desires to make it take effect, so they repel one another, and contend. (TA.)
4. AzbnwA buyuwtahumo They removed their tents from the road, or way. (TA.)
5: see 10, in two places.
6. tzAbnwA i. q. tdAfEwA [They contended, or strove, together, in pushing, or thrusting, or in pushing, or thrusting, away; or they pushed, &c., one another; or pushed against one another]. (TA.)
7. AnzbnwA They removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance. (K.)

10. Astzbnhu He made him a zabuwn; [i. e. treated him as such;] meaning a simpleton, or fool; one much, or often, endamaged, or overreached, defrauded, or deceived; as also tzbRnhu↓: (Mgh:) or Astzbnhu and tzbRnhu↓ are like Aisotagobanahu and tagabRanahu [both app. meaning he esteemed him gabiyn, i. e. weak in judgment, and therefore liable to be endamaged, or overreached, defrauded, or deceived; like as AstDEfhu and tDERfhu both signify “ he esteemed him DaEiyf, i. e. weak ”]; or like AisotagobaAhu and tagabRaAhu [both app. meaning he esteemed him unintelligent, or one having little intelligence]. (TA.)
zabonN A tent, or house, (bayotN,) standing apart from the [other] tents or houses: (K:) as though it were pushed from them. (TA.)
See also zabanN.
maqaAmu zabonK A narrow standing-place, upon which a man cannot stand by reason of its narrowness and slipperiness. (TA.)
[In one place in the CK, AlzRabonu is erroneously put for AlzRabinu.]
zibonN: see zabanN.
Also A want, or thing wanted: you say, qado Oaxaca zibonahu mina AlmaAli, i. e. [He has taken] what he wanted [of the property], (K,) and mina AlTRaEaAmi [of the food]. (TA.)

zabanN A side; a lateral, or an adjacent, part or tract or quarter: (K:) [and so, app., zabonN↓ and zibonN↓: for] you say, HalRa zabonFA mino qawomihi, with fet-h, [as well as zabanFA, with two fet-hahs,] and zibonFA, with kesr, meaning He alighted aside, or apart, from his people, or party; as though he were thrust from their place: scarcely ever, or never, used otherwise than as an adv. n. [of place] or as a denotative of state. (TA.)
Also A piece of cloth [shaped] after the fashion of the tent (EalaI taqoTiyEi Albayoti), like the Hajalap [a kind of curtained canopy prepared for a bride]. (K.)
zabinN, (K, TA,) like katifN, (TA, [AlzRabonN in the CK being a mistranscription for AlzRabinu,]) Vehement in pushing, or thrusting; and so zubunRN↓. (K, * TA.)
ziboniyapN: see zabaAniyapN.
ziboniIRN: see zabaAniyapN.
zubunRN: see zabinN.
zubunRapN The hind leg of a she-camel: (TA:) the hind legs of the she-camel are called zubunRataAhaA (K, TA) because she pushes, or thrusts, with them. (TA.)

zabuwnN One who pushes, or thrusts, or who pushes, or thrusts, away, [or who pushes &c. much or vehemently, or who is wont to push &c.,] a thing. (Msb.) A she-camel that pushes, or thrusts, or that pushes, or thrusts, away, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or that kicks, or strikes, and pushes, &c., (S, TA,) her milker, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) with her hind leg (Msb) [or with her stifle-joint: see 1]: or that is wont, or accustomed, to push, &c., her milker. (TA.) Hence, (A,) one says HarobN zabuwnN (S, A, Msb, K) meaning (tropical:) A difficult, or stubborn, war or battle; likened to the she-camel termed zbwn: (A, TA:) or that dashes men [one against another], and pushes, or thrusts, them: (S:) or in which one portion pushes, or thrusts, or pushes or thrusts away, another, by reason of multitudinousness: (K:) or it is thus called because it repels the valiant men from advancing, through fear of death. (Msb.)

As meaning gabiIRN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) Unintelligent, or having little intelligence], and HariyfN [syn. with muEaAmilN, and hence, as will be seen from what follows, app. here used in the sense of (assumed tropical:) a dealer with others in buying and selling, a meaning which muEaAmilN often has, though, as I have shown in art. Harf, I do not know any authority for assigning this meaning to HariyfN], (S, K, [the latter explanation thus written in my copies of the S and in my MS. copy of the K and in the CK, but in the TA, and hence in the TK, xryf, which has no meaning, that I know of, appropriate in this instance,]) it is post-classical, (K,) not of the language of the people of the desert: (S:) it signifies (tropical:) a simpleton, or fool, who is endamaged, or defrauded, (yugobanu,) much;
by a tropical attribution [of the meaning of a pass. part. n. to a word which has properly the meaning of an act. part. n.; because the person thus termed is as though he were pushed, or thrust, away]: (Mgh:) it signifies also (assumed tropical:) a purchaser; because he pushes away another from the thing that is sold; [or because he is often duped;] and in this sense, [a sense in which it is commonly now used, or as meaning a customer, and also a dupe,] it is a post-classical word, not of the language of the people of the desert. (Msb.) [The pl. now commonly used is zabaAYinu, and some say zabuwnaAtN.] It is said in a post-classical prov., AlzRabuwnu yaforaHu bilaA XaIoCK [which I would render (assumed tropical:) The dupe rejoices without anything, or at nothing]: (Meyd:) or AlzRabuwnu yaforaHu biOadonaI XaIoCK, meaning [(assumed tropical:) The dupe rejoices at the least, or the meanest, thing: or] the dealer (AlmuEaAmilu), or the purchaser (AlmuXotariI), as the word signifies in the dial. the people of El-Basrah. (Har p. 76, q. v. [The editors of the sec. ed. of De Sacy's Har, to which reference is here made, say, (Notes, p. 90,) “ Nous pensons que le mot Alzbwn, dans l'acception qu'il prend dans ce proverbe dérive du chaldéen זַבֵּן 'vendre.'” (This verb is written in the Lex. of Gesenius זְבַן.) See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., pp. 186 — 190.]

Also A well in which is a receding in its mavaAbap [or place where the water collects, or place reached by the water when it returns and collects after one has drawn from it, &c.; (see art. vwb;) as though its casing were pushed back in that part]. (K.)
And [An inner vest; so in the present day; pl. OazobinapN;] a thing that is cut so as to fit the body, and worn. (TA.)

zubaAnaI is the sing. of which zubaAnayaAni is the dual. (Mz, 40th nwE.) zubaAnaI AlEaqorabi signifies The horn [or claw] of the scorpion: (Msb:) its two horns [or claws] are called zubaAnayaA AlEaqorabi; (S, K;) because it pushes with them. (TA.)

And AlzRubaAnayaAni, (Ibn-Kunáseh, S, Kzw,) or zubaAnayaA AlEaqorabi, (K,) [the former the more common,] (assumed tropical:) The two horns [or claws] of Scorpio; [which, like the constellation Leo, the Arabs extended much beyond the limits that we assign to it, and which they thus made to include a portion of Libra;] (Kzw;) two stars, widely separated, (Ibn-Kunáseh, Kzw,) [that rise] before AlUikoliyl [q. v.]; (Ibn-Kunáseh;) between which (Ibn-Kunáseh, Kzw) is the measure of a spear (rumoH [q. v.]), more than the stature of a man, (Ibn-Kunáseh,) [or,] in appearance, the measure of five cubits: (Kzw:) two bright stars, (S, K,) in, or upon, (K,) the two horns [or claws] of Scorpio: (S, K:) [a and g of Libra, accord. to those who make AlnRawoC to mean “ the auroral setting; ” and perhaps the same, or α and β of Libra, accord to those who make AlnRawoC to mean “ the auroral rising: ”] one of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, Kzw,) namely, the Sixteenth Mansion. (Kzw. [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.]) The saying

[lit. His moon bit the extremities of the claw of Scorpio], cited by IAar, is expl. as meaning “ he is uncircumcised, except the part from which the qamar has contracted; ” his qulofap being likened to the zubaAnaI [and his kamarap to the qamar]: and he is related to have said that he who is born when the moon is in Scorpio is unprosperous: but Th says, I asked him respecting this saying, and he disallowed it, and said, No, but he is a low, or mean, or sordid, person, who does not give food in winter; and when the moon [in winter] bites the extremities of the zubaAnaI, [i. e. enters Scorpio,] it is most intense cold. (TA.)
See also zabaAniyapN.
zabaAnK: see the next paragraph.

zabaAniyapN is a pl., of which the sing. is ziboniyapN↓, (Akh, Zj, S, K,) as some say, or zabaAnK↓, (Akh, S,) or zubaAnaI↓, like sukaAraI, (TA,) or zaAbinN↓, (Akh, S,) or riboniIRN↓, (Ks, K,) the pl. of this last being originally zabaAniIRu, the p [in zabaAniyapN] being substituted for the [last] I: (Bd in xcvi. 18:) but the Arabs hardly, or in nowise, know this [attribution of a sing. to zabaAniyapN], holding it to be a pl. having no sing., like OabaAbiylu and EabaAdiydu. (Akh, S.) With the Arabs [of the classical age] it signifies The XuraT [app. in the earlier sense of the braves of an army, or in the later sense of the armed attendants, officers, or soldiers, of the prefect of the police]: (S:) this is the primary signification: (Bd in xcvi. 18:) the sing. being syn. with XuroTiIRN: and also signifying the mutamarRid [i. e. one who exalts himself, or is insolent and audacious, in pride and in acts of rebellion or disobedience, &c.,] of the jinn, or genii, and of mankind: (K:) and i. q. XadiydN [i. e. strong, &c.]: (Secr, K:) each of these two significations [and the first also] being from the meaning of “ pushing, ” or “ thrusting. ” (TA.)

AlzRabaAniyapu signifies also Certain angels, [the tormentors of the damned in Hell,] so called because of their thrusting the people of the fire thereto; (Katádeh, S, Msb; *) the angels mentioned in the Kur [lxvi. 6] as gilaAZN XidaAdN, (Zj,) i. e. rough in speech or in disposition, strong in deeds or in make. (Bd.)

[zabRaAnN is said by Freytag to signify a foot (“ pes ”), as on the authority of J; as though he had found it expl. by the word rijol: but this is a mistake: it is said in the S that zabRaAnN is the name of a man (Aisomu rajulK).]

zibRiynN One striving to suppress the urine and ordure: (K, * TA: [the word, with the article Al, is expl. by mudaAfiEu AlOaxobavayoni: see 3 in art. dfE, and see also Oaxobavu:]) such is said in a trad. to be one of those from whom prayer will not be accepted; or, as some relate it, it is the zinRiyn, with n [in the place of the b]: (TA:) or it means one withholding them against his will. (K.)
One says also, maA bihaA zibRiynN, meaning There is not in it [i. e. the house, AldRaAr,] any one: so says Aboo-Shubrumeh. (TA.)
zabRuwnapN Pride; syn. kiborN. (S.)

And [hence, probably,] rajulN cuw zabRuwnapK i. q. maAniEN jaAnibahu [app. meaning A man who defends his honour, or reputation: see jaAnibN]: (S, TA:) or a man who defends what is behind his back (maA waraMCa Zahorihi [perhaps meaning his household: see ZahorN]). (TA, and so in a copy of the S.)

Also, and zubRuwnapN↓, The neck; (IAar, K;) as in the saying xuco biquruwnihi wabizabRuwnatihi [Take thou hold of his horns and his neck]: (IAar, TA:) or zabRuwnapN may signify the ear; and the pl. zabRuwnaAtN, the head and neck of a horse, by a metonymy, because the ears are therein. (Ham p. 58, q. v.)
zubRuwnapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zaAbinN: see zabaAniyapN, first sentence.
zaAbinapN An [eminence such as is termed] Oakamap, (K, TA,) raised high (TA) in a valley that bends, or turns, from it; (K, TA;) as though it pushed it, or thrust it, away. (TA.)

1. zabaAhu, aor. yazobiyhi, (S, K,) inf. n. zaboIN, (S,) i. q. Hamalahu [He bore it, carried it, took it up and carried it, conveyed it, &c.]; (S, K;) namely, a thing; (S;) as also AizodabaAhu↓; thus accord. to the T and S and M; (TA; [accord. to one of my copies of the S, i. q. AHtmlhu, which is often syn. with Hamalahu];) or OazobaAhu↓; thus in the copies of the K: (TA:) or the first and ↓last signify he bore upon his back a heavy burden: (JM:) and hence the saying of Kaab, bicelika faqulotu lahu kalimapF Ouzobiyhi↓ (JM, TA) i. e. [(assumed tropical:) And I said to him a saying,] disquieting, or disturbing, him, (JM, TA, *) [by reason of that:] because, when a thing is borne, or carried, it is removed from its place. (JM.)

Also, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He drove, urged, or incited, him; (K, TA;) and so zbRAhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tazobiyapN; (TA;) and AzdbAh↓. (K.) [And i. q. daEaAhu.] You say, maA zabaAhumo UilaI hecaA, i. e. maA daEaAhumo Uilayohi [What drew, led, induced, caused, constrained, or drove, them to this? or What hath led, &c.?]. (JM, TA.) And zabRaI↓ lahu XarRFA, inf. n. tazobiyapN, i. e. daEaAhu [He drew, or caused, evil to him]. (TA.) And lahu zabRayotu↓, inf. n. tazobiyapN, I prepared [app. evil] for him. (TA.) And zabaAhu biXarRK, (K, TA,) or bimakoruwhK, (TA,) He smote him with evil. (K, TA.)

2. zbRI, inf. n. tazobiyapN, accord. to the K, He spread flesh-meat upon a zuboyap as meaning a hill, or an elevated piece of ground, which the water did not overflow: but accord. to ISd, he threw flesh-meat into a zuboyap as meaning a hollow dug in the ground, in which one roasts, or broils, for himself, and bakes bread. (TA.)
See also 5.
And see 1, in three places.
4: see 1, in three places.
5. tzbRI zuboyapF He made a pitfall for a lion (S, Mgh, K) or a wolf; (Mgh;) as also zbRAh↓, inf. n. tazobiyapN. (K.) A rájiz says,
[And by no means be thou of those who have been beguiled; like him who has made a pitfall for a lion or a wolf, and then has himself been trapped]. (S, * Mgh.)

And tzbRI fiI AlzRuboyapi, accord. to ISd, signifies the same as tazbRaAhaA [app. in a sense different from that expl. above; meaning He concealed himself from the objects of the chase in the hollow made for that purpose: or he fell into the zuboyap, like taradRaI fiI AlzRuboyapi]. (TA.)
6. tzAbI He walked with a stretching of himself, or with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait, and with slowness. (T, K, TA.)
And He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently; (K, TA;) and disdainfully. (TA.)
8. AizodabaAhu: see 1, in two places.

zuboyapN A hill, or an elevated piece of ground, which the water does not overflow: (S, K:) pl. rubFI. (S, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a prov., balaga AlsRayolu AlzRubaI [The torrent reached the tops of the hills which they do not usually overflow]: (S, TA:) or AlzRubaI is here pl. of AlzRuboyapu in the sense next following: [but the meaning is virtually the same:] (Meyd:) the prov. is applied to a thing, or an affair, or a case, exceeding the ordinary bounds or limit. (Meyd, TA.)
A pitfall for a lion (S, Mgh, Msb, K) or a wolf (Mgh) &c., (Msb,) dug in a high place, (S, Mgh, Msb,) for which reason it is thus called: (S:) pl. as above. (Msb.)
A hollow dug in the ground, in which a sportsman conceals himself [from the objects of the chase]. (TA.)
A hollow dug in the ground, in which one roasts, or broils, for himself, and bakes bread. (ISd, TA.)
A well: so where it is said in a trad. of an Arab of the desert, taradRaI fiI zuboyapK [He fell into a well]. (Mgh.)
The excavation made by ants; which they make not save in a high place. (TA.)
Some include this word among those that have contr. significations. (TA.)
OuzobiIRN Quickness, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (S, K:) [originally OuzobuwIN,] of the measure OufoEuwlN. (S)
A certain mode of going, or pace, (S, M, K,) of camels: (M, TA:) accord. to As, OazaAbiIRu, which is its pl., signifies various modes of going or pace. (S.)

Evil: (AZ, S:) or a great evil: (K:) and a great, momentous, or terrible, thing or affair: (AZ, S, K:) pl. as above. (AZ, S.) One says, laqiytu minohu AlOazaAbiIRa I experienced from him, or it, evils; and great, momentous, or terrible, things. (AZ, S.)
And i. q. EajabN [app. as meaning A wonderful thing]. (TA.)
And The sound of a bow; (JM, TA; *) its musical ringing, or plaintive, sound. (JM.)
OaroDN zatinapN: see zayotuwnN, in art. zyt.

1. zajRahu, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
zajuja
, (S,) inf. n. zajRN, (S, A, Msb, K,) He pierced him, or thrust him, (i. e. a man, S, Msb,) with the zujR [or pointed iron foot of the spear]; (S, A, Msb, K; *) and cast at him with it: and zajRa also signifies he pierced, or thrust, with haste. (TA.) And zajajotuhu biAlrRumoHi I cast at him with the spear. (A, and Ham p. 147.)

[Hence,] zajRa biAlXRaIoCi (tropical:) He cast, or threw, the thing from himself: (A:) or zajRa biAlXRaIoCi mino yadihi, aor.
zajuja
, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) (tropical:) he cast, or threw, the thing from his hand. (K, * TA.)

[And hence,] zajRN signifies also (tropical:) The running or the ostrich. (K, TA.) You say of the ostrich, zajRa birijolayohi, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He ran, (A, TA,) throwing out his legs. (TA.)
[Hence also,] nazalonaA biwaAdK yazujRu AlnRabaAta (tropical:) We alighted in a valley putting forth herbage; as though casting it from itself. (A, TA.)
See also 4.

zajRa, sec. pers. zajijota, aor.
zajaja
, inf. n. zajajN, It (an eyebrow) was, or became, narrow and long: (TK:) or arched: (MA:) [or narrow and long and full and arched: see zajajN below.]
2: see 4.

zajRajato HaAjibahaA, (S, A,) or zjRj HaAjibahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. tazojiyjN, (TA,) She, or he, made her, or his, eyebrow narrow and long: (S, K:) [or made it arched: (see 1, last sentence:) or made it narrow and long and arched: (see zajajN below:)] or clipped the redundant portions of the hair thereof: or lengthened it [in appearance] with Uivomid [i. e. antimony, or ore of antimony, or a black collyrium; like as the ancient Egyptians were accustomed to do, as appears from their paintings and sculptures; and like as some of the Arab women still do; extending a black line towards the ear, and also a similar line from the outer angle of the eye]. (TA.) In the following verse of the poet Er-Rá'ee,

[the last of these significations may be intended; so that it may be rendered, When the females content with their husbands, or with their beauty, &c., shall go forth (or went forth) one day, and shall lengthen (or lengthened) with black collyrium the eyebrows and the eyes: or] kaHalona is meant to be understood before AlEuyuwnaA. (S.)

Hence, from tazojiyHu AlHawaAjibi as signifying “ the clipping of the redundant portions of the hair of the eyebrows, ” zjRj mawoDiEahaA, occurring in a trad., referring to a hole made in a piece of wood in which a thousand deenars and a writing had been inserted, is expl. as meaning He made even, and adjusted, the place thereof: or, accord. to IAth, it may be that the hole was in the end of the piece of wood, and so it may mean he made a zujR [q. v.] upon the place thereof, to hold it fast, and to preserve what was in it. (TA.)

4. AzjR AlrRumoHa; (IAar, ISk, S, A, K;) and zjRjhu↓; (A, TA;) and zajRahu↓, aor.
zajuja
, inf. n. zajRN; (Msb;) and zajRaAhu; (TA;) He put, or made, a zujR [q. v.] to the spear. (IAar, ISk, S, A, Msb, K.)
8. AizodajRa, said of the eyebrow, It reached to the outer extremity (cunaAbaI) of the eye. (K.)
And, said of herbage, Its intervening spaces became closed up. (TA.)

zujRN [The pointed iron foot, or heel, or shoe, of a spear;] the iron at the lower extremity of a spear; (S, A, Msb, K;) i. e. the iron which is fixed upon the lower extremity of a spear, and with which the spear is stuck into the ground: the iron which is fixed upon its upper extremity, and with which one pierces, being called sinaAnN: (ISd, TA:) pl. [of mult.] zijaAjN and zijajapN (S, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OazojaAjN and OazijRapN, (TA,) or this last is not allowable, (S, Msb, TA,) accord. to ISk. (Msb.) Zuheyr says,

[And he who refuses to yield to the points of the iron feet of the spears shall yield to the upper extremities thereof mounted with every sharp spear-head]: ISk says, he means that he who refuses to yield to a small thing will encounter a great thing: and Khálid Ibn-Kulthoom says, they used to meet their enemies, when they desired peace, with the iron feet of their spears turned towards them; and if they refused peace, they turned their spears' heads to them, and combated them. (TA.) [By a synecdoche, the pl.] zijaAjN is also used to signify Spears, altogether. (Ham p. 147.)

Hence, as being likened to the zujR of the spear, (L,) (tropical:) The extremity of the elbow, (S, L, K,) which is pointed: (L:) or the part [or joint] between the lower extremity of the os humeri and the extremity of the ulna at the elbow: (T in art. Abr:) or [simply] the elbow. (A.) You say, AitRakaOa EalaI zujRayohi (tropical:) He leaned upon his elbows: and AitRakaWuwA EalaI zijaAji maraAfiqihimo (tropical:) [They leaned upon the extremities of their elbows]. (A.)
[Hence also, (tropical:) A tush, or canine tooth:] zijaAju AlfaHoli signifies (tropical:) the tushes of the stallion-camel. (A, K.)
[Hence also a signification mentioned by Golius on the authority of Meyd, (assumed tropical:) An iron pivot (“ subscus ferrea ”) round which a mill-stone turns.]
Also An arrow-head: (IAar, K:) pl. zijajapN and zijaAjN (K) and OazijRapN. (TA.)

zajajN Narrowness and length in the eyebrows: (S, K:) or narrowness and archedness of the eyebrows: (A:) or archedness thereof: (MA:) or narrowness and length and fulness and arched-
ness thereof. (TA.) [See 1, last sentence.]
Also, in an ostrich, (assumed tropical:) Length of the shanks, and width of step. (L.)
And in camels, (assumed tropical:) Width, or wideness, (rawaHN) in [the space between] the hind legs. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) Wideness of a solid hoof: which is a fault. (TA in art. Sr.)
zujujN Darts, or javelins, (HiraAbN,) furnished with iron heads: (K:) its sing. is not mentioned. (TA.)
[It is also expl. in different copies of the K as meaning HamiyrN muqotatilapN or muqatRalapN or muqotalRapN: the first I regard as the right reading; i. e. Asses (wild asses) fighting one another.]

zujaAjN and zajaAjN and zijaAjN, (AO, S, Msb, K,) the first of which is that used by the seven readers [of the Kur-án], (Msb,) and the last is the least common, (TA,) words of well-known meaning; (S, Msb, K;) [Glass: pieces of glass: glassvessels:] glass flasks or bottles; syn. qawaAriyru: (TA:) and [glass] drinking-cups or bowls: (AO, TA:) pls. of zujaAjapN↓ (AO, S) and zajaAjapN↓ and zijaAjap↓: (AO:) or [rather] these are the ns. un. (Msb.) In the Kur [xxiv. 35], zujaAjap↓ means A lamp, syn. qinodiyl,(Lth, Bd, Jel,) of zujaAj [i. e. glass]. (Bd.)
zajaAjN, with fet-h, also signifies The berries of the clove-tree; syn. HabRu Alqaranofuli. (Ktr, TA.)
zujaAjapN and zajaAjapN and zijaAjapN: see the next preceding paragraph; the first, in two places.
The last also signifies The art, or occupation, of making zujaAj [i. e. glass, glass vessels, &c.]. (TA.)
zujaAjiIRN (Msb, K, TA) [and zajaAjiIRN and zijaAjiIRN, the former in the CK, and both implied in the K and in the Msb,] A seller of zajaAj [i. e. glass, glass vessels, &c.]. (Msb, K.)
zajRaAjN A maker, or manufacturer, of zujaAj [i. e. glass, glass, vessels, &c.] (Msb, K.)
AlzRajRaAjapu (assumed tropical:) The anus; because it emits (tazujRu) wind and excrement. (TA.)

OazajRu, applied to a man, (S, A,) Having narrow and long eyebrows: (S, K:) or having narrow and arched eyebrows: (A:) [or having arched eyebrows: see zajajN:] or having narrow and long and full and arched eyebrows: (TA:) fem. zajRaMCu, (A, K,) applied to a woman: (A:) [pl. zujRN:] and one says also OazajRu AlHawaAjibi [meaning the same]. (L.) It is likewise applied to the eyebrow [as meaning Narrow and long: or narrow and arched: &c.]: (A, TA:) and so muzajRajN↓: (TA:) or the former signifies an eyebrow narrow and long [&c.] naturally: and ↓the latter, rendered so artificially. (MF.) And AlOazajRu is a name for The eyebrow [itself] in the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

Also, applied to a male ostrich, (assumed tropical:) Long in step: (S, K:) or longlegged and long in step: (L:) or that runs throwing out his legs: (TA:) or having white feathers above his eyes: (K:) fem. zajRaMCu: (S:) and pl. zujRN (K.) And, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Long-legged. (L.)
Also, applied to a solid hoof, (assumed tropical:) Wide. (TA in art. Sr. [See zajajN, last sentence.])
muzajRN A spear having a zujR [q. v.] affixed to it. (ISk, S.)
mizajRN A short spear, like the mizoraAq, (S, K, TA,) having at its lower extremity a zujR [q. v.]: and sometimes used as meaning one that transpierces, or passes through, quickly. (TA.)
mizajRapN An instrument with which the eyebrow is made such as is termed OazajRu [or narrow and long, or narrow and arched, &c.]. (TA.)
muzajRajN: see OazajRu in two places.
mazojuwjN Pierced, or thrust, with the zujR [q. v.] of a spear. (S, TA.) And Cast at therewith. (TA.)
Also A large bucket (garobN) not made round, but having its two lips [or opposite edges] put together, and then sewed. (K.)

1. zajarahu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
zajura
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. zajorN, (S, A, Msb,) He chid him, by a cry, by his voice, or by reproof: (S, * K, * TA:) he checked him, restrained him, or forbade him, with rough speech: (TA:) or prevented, hindered, restrained, or withheld, him: or forbade, or prohibited, him: [by any kind of cry or speech:] as also Azdjrhu↓; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) the latter originally Aztjrhu: (Msb, TA:) Eano kacaA from [doing] such a thing: (A, * Mgh, TA:) and Eani AlsRuwoCi from evil. (TA.)

zajara Alkaloba, (K,) and AlsRabuEa, (TA,) and zajara bihi (K,) (assumed tropical:) He cried out to, or at, the dog, (K,) and the beast of prey, (TA,) in order that he might forbear, refrain, or abstain. (K, TA.) [See a tropical ex. voce HinowN.]

zajara AlbaEiyra (tropical:) He incited the camel to quickness: (TA:) he drove, or urged, the camel, (S, K, TA,) and incited him with a peculiar cry, so that he became excited, and went on: (TA:) he said to the camel Hawobi: and zajara AlnRaAqapa (assumed tropical:) He said to the she-camel Halo: (AZ, TA:) and zajara Alganama (tropical:) He (a pastor) cried out to, or at, the sheep or goats: (A, Mgh, TA:) and in like manner, to or at, a horse or the like, and a camel, and a beast of prey, with a high, or loud, voice, and vehemently: (TA:) and AlrRiyHu tazojuru AlsRaHaAba (tropical:) [The wind drives the clouds]. (A.)

zajorN signifies The driving away with crying or a cry: and by subsequent applications, sometimes, (assumed tropical:) the driving away: and sometimes (assumed tropical:) the crying, or crying out, or a cry. (B, TA.)

zajara AlTRaAYira, (K,) aor.
zajura
, inf. n. zajorN; (TA;) and Azdjrhu↓; (K;) (tropical:) He chid the bird, auguring evil from it. (K, TA.)

And zajara AlTRayora (tropical:) He threw a pebble at the birds, and cried out; and if, in flying, they turned their right sides towards him, he augured well from them; but if their left sides, evil. (A.)
