Hence, (A,) zajorN also signifies (tropical:) The auguring from the flight, alightingplaces, cries, kinds, or names, of birds: (S, A, K:) you say, huwa yazojuru AlTRayora He augurs from the flight, &c., of birds: (A:) or zajorN signifies the auguring well from a bird's or some other thing's sunuwH [or turning the right side towards one, or the contrary], and evil from its buruwH [or turning the left side towards one, or the contrary]. (Zj.) And zajara guraAba Albayoni means (assumed tropical:) He went away, departed, or journeyed. (Har p. 308.)

[Hence,] it also signifies (tropical:) The practising of divination: (K:) or a species thereof: you say, zajarotu OanRahu yakuwnu kacaA wakacaA I have divined that it is so and so. (S, L.) [See also zaAjirN]
zajarato bimaA fiI baTonihaA (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) cast forth what was in her belly. (K, TA.)

6. tazaAjaruwA Eani Almunokari [They checked, restrained, or forbade, one another, with rough speech; or] they prevented, hindered, or withheld one another; or they forbade, or prohibited, one another; from abominable, foul, or evil, conduct. (A, Msb.)

7. Anzjr and Aizodajara↓ He, being chidden, by a cry, by the voice, or by reproof; or being checked, restrained, or forbidden, with rough speech; (TA;) or being prevented, hindered, restrained, or withheld; or being forbidden or prohibited; refrained, forbore, or abstained; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) Eano kacaA from [doing] such a thing. (Mgh, TA.)
Qzodujira↓, in the Kur liv. 9, means He was driven away. (TA.)
Anzjr He (a dog) became urged, or incited, by a cry, to pursue the game. (Mgh.)
8. Aizodajara, for Aizotajara, trans. and intrans.: see 1 and 7; each in two places.
Q. Q. 1: (accord. to the S). zanojara: see art. znjr.
zajorN inf. n. of 1. (S, A, Msb.)
A crying at camels [&c.], and an urging or inciting of them. (TA.)
A cry by which one chides, i. e., either checks or urges, a beast &c.; like Saho to a man, and Eadaso to a mule, &c. (The lexicons, passim.)
See also what next follows.

zajarN (Az, O, K) and zajorN↓ (IDrd, O, K) Large fish, (K,) [i. e.] a species of large fish, (IDrd, O,) with small scales: (TA:) IDrd says, thus called by the people of El-'Irák, but I do not think the appellation to be genuine Arabic: (O:) pl. zujuwrN. (O, K.)
zajorapN A cry. (Mgh.)

zajuwrN (tropical:) A she-camel that will not yield her milk abundantly until chidden: (A, K, TA:) or that yields her milk abundantly to her young one if beaten, but does not if let alone: (TA:) or (K, TA, but accord. to the CK “ and ”) a she-camel that knows [her young one] with her eye, but repudiates it with her nose [when she smells it]: (S, K:) and a she-camel that inclines to the young one of another, and not to her own, but only smells it, and refuses to yield her milk to it; syn. EaluwqN. (K.)
It is also applied, metaphorically, as an epithet to war. (A, TA.)
[zajRaArN One who chides, &c., much, or often.]
zaAjirN [act. part. n. of 1].

[Hence,] kafaI
biAlquroMni zaAjirFA (tropical:) [The Kur-án suffices as a chider, checker, restrainer, or forbidder]. (A, TA.) And AlzRaAjiru (assumed tropical:) The exhorter, on the part of God, in the heart of the believer; i. e. the light shed into it, [or what we term the light of nature,] that invites him to the truth. (KT.)
AlzRaAjiraAtu, in the Kur xxxvii. 2, means (tropical:) The angels who are the drivers of the clouds. (K, * TA.)

zaAjirN also signifies (tropical:) A diviner; because, when he sees that which he thinks to be of evil omen, he cries out with a high, or loud, and vehement, voice, forbidding to undertake the thing in question. (Zj, TA.)
Oabuw zaAjirK (assumed tropical:) The crow; because one augurs by means of it. (Har p. 662.)

[zaAjirapN a subst. formed from the epithet zaAjirN by the addition of p. Its pl. occurs in the saying,] karRirato EalaI samoEihi AlmawaAEiZu waAlzRawaAjiru (tropical:) [Exhortations, and chiding or restraining speeches, were repeated in his ears]. (A, TA.)
zinojiyrN and zinojiyrapN: see art. znjr.

Oazojaru A camel having a looseness in the vertebræ of his back, arising from disease, or from galls, or sores, produced by the saddle: (O, K: *) [or having a fracture in his back;] like Oaxozalu. (O.)
mazojarN [A place of zajor, i. e. chiding, &c.].

[Hence,] huwa minRiI mazojara Alkalobi, an elliptical phrase, meaning (tropical:) [He is, in relation to me, or minRiI is here used in the sense of EinodiI, i. e., in my estimation,] as though he were in the mzjr of the dog; (Sb, TA;) [i. e., as though he were to be chidden like the dog, and driven away;] said by Z to be tropical. (TA.)
mazojarapN [A cause of zajor, i. e. chiding, &c.: a noun of the same class as maboxalapN &c.; pl. mazaAjiru]. A poet says,

L.foreign: mano kaAna laA yazoEumu OanRiI XaAEiru

sense.s: i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He who will not assert that I am a poet, let him approach me:] preventing causes forbid him. (TA.) And one says, cikoru QllRehi mazojarapN lilXRayoTaAni (tropical:) [The remembrance, or the mention, of God is a cause of driving away the devil]. (A, TA.)

muzodajarN, in the Kur liv. 4, (Bd, TA,) is [an inf. n.,] syn. with AizodijaArN, (Bd,) meaning (assumed tropical:) Depulsion, and prevention, or prohibition, from the commission of sinful actions; (TA;) or from punishment: or it there means a threatening: and some read mazRajarN, changing the d into z, and incorporating it [into the preceding letter]. (Bd.)

1. zajila, (MA, K,) aor.
zajala
, (K,) inf. n. zajalN, (MA, K, KL, and Har p. 240,) He uttered his voice, or a cry; or made a sound, or cry: (MA, KL:) or he raised his voice, (K, Har,) to evince emotion. (Har.)

[It seems to be indicated in the K that it signifies also He played, or sported: and He, or it (i. e. a company of men), raised cries, shouts, noises, a clamour, or confused cries or shouts or noises: and He trilled, or quavered, and prolonged his voice; or prolonged it, and modulated it sweetly. See the next paragraph.]

zajalN inf. n. of zajila: (MA, K:) [and used as a simple subst:] i. q. SawotN [as an inf. n., meaning The uttering of the voice, or of a sound, or cry: or, as a simple subst., a voice, sound, or cry]: (S:) or a high, or loud, voice: such have the angels when celebrating the praises of God: (TA:) [and] a vehement sound. (Ham p. 627.) [Hence,] saHaAbN cuw zajalK Clouds having a thundering: (TA:) [and] so saHaAbN zajilN↓. (S.)
A clamour; or a confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises, or of crying or shouting or noise. (K.)

[A low, or faint, sound: hence,] zajalu AljinRi means EaziyfuhaA [i. e. The low, or faint, sound of the jinn, or genii, that is heard by night in the deserts; and said to be a sound like drumming: or the sound of the winds in the atmosphere, imagined by the people of the desert to be the sound of the jinn]. (TA.)

A trilling, or quavering, and prolonging of the voice; or a prolonging of the voice, and modulating it sweetly. (K.) A poet likens it to the voice of one urging on camels by singing to them, and to the playing on a reedpipe. (Sb, TA.)
Also Play, or sport. (K.)
And A species of verse, well known; [a vulgar sort of unmeasured song or balled;] in this sense post-classical. (TA.)
zajilN Raising his voice; as also zaAjilN↓. (K.)
[Hence,] saHaAbN zajilN: see zajalN And gayovN zajilN Rain accompanied by the sound of thunder. (TA.) And nabotN zajilN A plant, or herbage, in which, or among which, the wind makes a sound. (K.)
zajolapN: see the next paragraph, in two places.
zujolapN The sound, or voice, or noise, of men; as also zajolapN↓. (K.)
And A company, a collection, or an assemblage: (K:) or a party, or company, of men, (S, K,) peculiarly: (TA:) as also zajolapN↓: (K:) pl. of the former zujalN. (S.)
zaAjilN: see zajilN.
It is also applied to a song, or singing, [meaning Loud,] in the saying,
[And he sings to her, or to them (probably referring to camels), with a loud song or singing]. (TA.)

1. zajaA, (S, K,) aor. yazojuw, (S,) inf. n. zajaMCN (S, K, and Ham p. 78) and zajowN (K and Ham) and zujuwRN, (K,) It (a thing) went, or became urged on or along, quickly. (Ham ubi suprà: there indicated by the context, but not expressed.)
It (a bad piece of money) passed, or had currency. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

It (an affair) was, or became, easy; and right, in a right state, or right in its direction or tendency. (K, TA.) Hence the trad., laA tazojuw SalaApN laA yuqoraOu fiyhaA bifaAtiHapi AlkitaAbi i. e. [A prayer in which the opening chapter of the Book (meaning the Kur-án) is not recited] will not be right. (TA.)
Also, inf. n. zajaMCN, said of the [tax called] xaraAj, It was, or became, easy of collection. (S.)

zajaMCN also signifies The acting with penetrative energy, and effectiveness, in an affair. (S, K.) One says, hecaA AlOamoru qado zajawonaA Ealayohi [app. meaning This affair, we have effected it, or accomplished it; like as one says, maDayonaA EalaI AlOamori]. (T, TA.) And EaTaMCN qaliylN yazojuw xayorN mino kaviyrK laA yazojuw [A small gift that is effective is better than much that will not be effective]. (S.)
One says also, DaHika HatRaI zajaA i. e. [He laughed until] his laughing became stopped, or cut short. (S, K. *)
See also what next follows, in two places.

2. zjRAhu, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. tazojiyapN, (S, TA,) He pushed it gently, (S, Msb, TA,) in order that it might go on; as also AzjAhu↓; and zajaAhu↓, aor. yazojuwhu, inf. n. zajowN: and this last, he drove it, or urged it on, gently; (TA;) [and so zjRAhu and AzjAhu↓, as will be shown by what follows:] or zajaAhu↓ signifies [simply] he drove it, or urged it on: and he pushed it: and so [app. in both of these senses] zjRAhu and AzjAhu↓. (K.) Hence, i. e. from zajRayotuhu meaning “ I pushed it gently, ” (Har p. 304,) one says, kayofa tuzajRiI AlOayRaAma (S, Har) i. e. kayofa tudaAfiEuhaA [How dost thou strive with the days in pushing them on, or making them to pass away?]: (S:) or kyf tadofaEuhaA [how dost thou push on the days? and thus may mean also kyf tdAfEhA]: (Har:) [or how dost thou make the days to pass away? for] zjRI AlOayRaAma means he made the days to pass away: (MA:) [or how dost thou pass the days? for it is also said that] tazojiyapN signifies the passing [one's] days. (KL.) [zjRI AlOayRaAma may be well rendered He made the days to pass away by means of exertion; and so dafaEahaA and daAfaEahaA. Har (ubi suprà) uses the phrase OuzajRiI OayRaAmFA musowadRapF as meaning I push on evil and hard days.] AzjI↓ AlXRaIoCa, also, inf. n. UizojaMCN, is expl. by Az as signifying daAfaEa biqaliylihi [app. meaning He strove to push on life, or to repel want or the like, with little of the thing]: and accord. to a saying heard by him from a man of the tribe of Fezárah, nuzajRiIdunoyaAnaA [or the correct reading may be nuzojiI↓, and accord. to either reading the phrase may be rendered We strive to push on life, or to repel want &c., with little of our worldly possessions,] means we content ourselves in respect of our worldly possessions with scanty sustenance. (TA. [See also 5.]) One says also AlUibila Oazojayotu↓ I drove the camels. (S.) And waladahaA Albaqarapu tuzojiI↓ The [wild] cow drives her young one. (S.) AlrRiyHu AlsRaHaAba tuzojiI↓ The wind drives along the clouds: (S:) or drives along gently the clouds; as also tuzajRiyhi, but in an intensive sense. (Msb.) In like manner, saHaAbFA yuzojiI↓ is said of God, in the Kur [xxiv. 43]: and in the same [xvii. 68], rabRukumu QlRaciI lakumu Qlofuloka fiI AlbaHori yuzojiI↓ [Your Lord is He
who driveth along for you the ship in the sea]. (TA.) And a poet says,
i. e. [I drove him with speech, and] urged him on: for AizodajaAhu signifies saAqahu [like zajRaAhu &c.]. (TA.)
And zjRI HaAjatiI He made easy the attainment of my want. (TA.)
zjRI AlrRumoHa i. q. OazajRahu q. v. in art. zj. (TA in that art.)
4: see 2, in ten places. AzjI also signifies He made money, or bad money, to pass, or be current. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
5. tazajRayotu bikacaA I contented myself with such a thing: a rájiz says,
[Content thyself with what is sufficient of thy worldly possessions]. (S. [See also 2.])
8: see 2, near the end of the paragraph.

OazojaI More penetrating and effective in an affair than another: (S, K:) so in the saying, fulaAnN OazojaI bihecaA AlOamori mino fulaAnK [Such a one is more penetrating and effective in this affair than such a one]. (S, K. *)
muzojFI, applied to a horse [or other beast], That is driven, or urged on, (yzjI, [i. e. yuzojaI,]) in his pace, by little and little. (Ham p. 158.)

A small, or scanty, thing; (S, Er-Rághib, TA;) or such as is mean, or paltry; that may be pushed and driven away because of the little account that is made of it. (Er-Rághib, TA.) biDaAEapN muzojaApN means Small, or scanty, merchandise; little in quantity: (S, K:) and so it is said to mean in the Kur [xii. 88]: or, as in some copies of the S, little, or mean, or paltry, merchandise: (TA:) or mean, or paltry, merchandise, rejected by every one to whom it is offered: (A, TA:) or merchandise wherewith the days are pushed on (tudofaEu [i. e. made to pass away by means of exertion]) because of its scantiness: (Msb, TA: [for muzojaApN bihaA:]) or, accord. to the shereef El-Murtadà, merchandise driven along portion after portion, scantily and feebly: (TA:) or merchandise in respect of which a lowering of the price is demanded on account of its badness (fiyhaA UigomaADN); (Th, TA;) not in perfect condition: (Th, K, TA:) thus, too, it is expl. as used in the Kur: and some say that what is there mentioned consisted of fruit of the terebinth-tree, or of Sanawobar [app. here meaning pine-cones]: some say, of commodities of the Arabs of the desert, wool, and clarified butter: and some say, of deficient pieces of money. (TA.)

muzajRFI Weak: so termed because of his lagging behind, and requiring to be urged on: (Ham p. 441:) or anything not perfect in nobility, nor in any other praiseworthy quality: or, as some say, one driven to generosity against his will: (TA:) and also, (TA,) applied to a man, i. q. muzalRajN [q. v., app. here meaning deficient in manliness, or manly virtue, or the like]. (S, TA.) [AlzRamaAnu AlmuzajRaI, a phrase used by Har, is expl. (p. 429) as meaning HaqRuhu Oano yuzajRiyhi AlnRaAsu, i. e. Time that requires men to push it on, or to make it to pass away by means-of exertion.]
mizojaMCN A man who urges on much the camel, or beast, that he rides. (TA.)

1. zaHRahu, (S, L, K,) aor.
zaHuHa
, (S, L,) inf. n. zaHRN; (L;) and zaHozaHahu↓; (L;) He removed him, or it, from his, or its, place: (S, L, K:) and he pushed, or thrust, away, him, or it: (L, K:) or the latter, he removed him, or it, far away; placed, or put, him, or it, at a distance, far away, or far off: (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb:) and the former signifies also he drew, dragged, or pulled, away, him, or it, in haste. (L, K.) You say, zaHozaHahu↓ Eanohu He removed him, or it, far away; (S, K;) or pushed, or thrust, away; and removed; him, or it; (TA;) from it; (S, K;) i. e. from his, or its, place. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [iii. 182], Eani AlnRaAri waOudoxila AljanRapa faqado faAza famano zuHoziHa↓, i. e. [And he] who shall be removed [from the fire of Hell], or removed far away [therefrom, and made to enter Paradise, shall attain good fortune]. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. zaHozaHa: see above, in three places:
and see also the paragraph here following.

R. Q. 2. tazaHozaHa He, or it, removed, or became removed; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) and (Mgh, Msb) removed, or became removed, far away: (Mgh, Msb, K:) and accord. to Es-Semeen, zaHozaHa↓ is likewise used in an intrans. sense, as well as a trans.; but MF says that its use in an intrans. sense is strange. (TA.) You say, daxalotu EalaI fulaAnK fatazaHozaHa liI Eano majolisihi, i. e. [I went in to such a one, and] he removed [for me from his sitting-place]. (Mgh, Msb. *)

zaHozaHN Distance: so in the saying, huwa bizaHozaHK minohu [He, or it, is at a distance from him, or it]. (S, K.) Az says that, accord. to some, this is a reduplicative word from zaAHa, aor. yaziyHu, meaning taOaxRara; and some hold it to be from AlzRawoHu meaning “ the driving vehemently, ” as also AlcRawoHu. (TA.)
zaHozaAHN Distant; remote. (K.)

mutazaHozaHN A place to which one removes, or may remove, [in an absolute sense, as is implied in the A, or] far away. (Ham p. 655.) One says, maAliI Eanohu mutazaHozaHN [There is not for me any place to which to remove from him, or it]. (A.)

1. zaHara, aor.
zaHara
, and
zaHira
, (K,) inf. n. zaHiyrN (A, K) and zuHaArN and zuHaArapN, (K,) He emitted the voice, (K, * TA,) or (K, TA, in the CK “ and, ”) the breath, with a moaning; (A, K;) [or he breathed hard; as appears from what follows;] in work, or labour, or in difficulty. (TA.) You say, samiEotu lahu zaHiyrFA [I heard him breathe hard; or emit the voice, or the breath, with a moaning]. (A.) And of a woman bringing forth, you say, zaHarato, aor.
zaHara
and
zaHira
, inf. n. zaHiyrN, She breathed hard. (S.)
[Hence,] zaHara said of a niggardly man, (assumed tropical:) He, being begged of, deemed the begging grievous, or troublesome, (K, TA,) and moaned thereat. (TA.)

zaHara, (A, K,) aor.
zaHara
and
zaHira
, (K,) inf. n. zaHiyrN (S, A, K) and zuHaArN (S, K) and zuHaArapN; (K;) [and app. zuHira also; (see mazoHuwrN;)] and tzHRr↓; (A, K;) and zHRr↓, inf. n. tazoHiyrN; (K;) [all signify] He was, or became, affected with a looseness of the bowels: (S, A:) or with a violent looseness of the bowels, and with a griping pain in the belly, and a discharge of blood. (K.)
And zaHarato bihi OumRuhu, and Eanohu tzHRzt↓, (tropical:) His mother brought him forth. (A, K.)
zaHarahu biAlrRumoHi, accord. to the K, signifies He broke, or clave, his head with the spear: but IDrd says that this is not of established authority. (TA.)
zuHira, like EuniIa, He was, or became, niggardly, or tenacious. (K.)
2: see 1.

zHRr AlnRaAqapa, inf. n. tazoHiyrN, He put a ball (kurap) into a nose-bag (mixolaAp), and inserted it into the vulva of the she-camel whose young one had died during the period between the time [that should have been that] of bringing him forth and a month of the last part thereof, [i. e. during the last month of her proper period of gestation,] and left it for a night, having stopped up her nose, then drew forth the ball, having prepared another young camel, which he then showed to her, the nose being still stopped up, whereupon she thought that it was her young one, and that she had at that time brought it forth, then he unstopped her nose, and brought it near, and she affected it, and yielded her milk. (K, TA.)
3. zAHrhu (tropical:) He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility, (A, K, TA,) and behaved angrily (Ainotafaxa) to him. (TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.

huwa yatazaHRaru bimaAlihi XuHFA (assumed tropical:) [He yields his property with pain, (app. from tazaHRarato said of a woman in child-birth,) by reason of niggardliness]; as though he moaned, and strained himself; or moaned, being niggardly. (TA.)
zuHarN: see zaHRaArN.
zaHorapN [inf. n. of un. of zaHara; An emission [of the voice or] of the breath with a moaning: (A:) [or a hard breathing: (see 1:) it is said to be] like zaforapN [q. v.]. (TA.)
zaHoraAnu: see zaHRaArN.
zuHaArN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.

Also] A certain disease that affects the camel, (K, TA,) in consequence of which he suffers from a violent looseness of the bowels, until, or so that, the extremity of his rectum turns inside-out, and nothing comes forth from it. (TA.)
zaHRaArN [One who breathes hard; (this meaning being indicated, though not expressed, in the S;) or who emits the voice, or the breath, with a moaning: see 1, first sentence.

And hence,] (assumed tropical:) Niggardly; tenacious; who moans on being
begged of; (TA; [in which it is said to be with damm; but this is a mistake, occasioned by an incorrect point in the L;]) as also zuHarN↓ and zaHoraAnu↓ and mazoHuwrN↓. (K, * TA.) A poet says,

[I see thee to have combined begging and covetousness, and in poverty to be niggardly, with moaning]: (S, TA: in the former thus, in two copies, in the present art. and in art. An: in the TA zuHRaArFA:) OunaAnFA is said by IB to be [here] an inf. n. of OanRa, like OaniynFA. (TA.)
mazoHuwrN A man affected with a looseness, or with a violent looseness, of the bowels, and with a griping pain in the belly, and a discharge of blood. (A, * TA.)
See also the next preceding paragraph.

1. zaHafa, aor.
zaHafa
, inf. n. zaHofN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and zuHuwfN (Msb, K) and zaHafaAnN, (K,) He, or it, (an army, Mgh, Msb, * or a company of men, Msb) walked, marched, or went on foot, Uilayohi [to him, or it]; (S, K;) and [generally] did so by little and little; (accord. to an explanation of zaHofN in the TA;) crept, or crawled, along; or went, or walked, leisurely, or gently: (Mgh:) and tzHRf Uilayohi↓, (S, K,) as also AzdHf↓, (K,) i. q. tmXRI, (S, K,) i. e. he walked [with slow steps, or] heavily, with an effort, to him, or it: (TK:) and miXoyapu zaHafaAnK means a gait in which is a heaviness of motion. (TA.) One says of a child, before he walks, (S, Msb, K,) or before he stands, (T, TA,) yazoHafu [He drags himself along] (S, Msb, K) EalaI AlOaroDi [upon the ground], or EalaI Qsotihi [upon his posteriors]: (TA:) or zaHafa alone, said of a child, he went along slowly, by little and little, upon his posteriors: (Bd in viii. 15:) and to the zaHof of children is likened the marching of two bodies of men going to meet each other for fight, when each of them marches gently, or leisurely, towards the other, before they draw near together to smite each other: and one says likewise of a child, before he walks, EalaI yatazaHRafu↓ AlOaroDi, or, as in the T, EalaI baTonihi, i. e. he drags himself along [upon the ground, or upon his belly]. (TA.)
zaHafa AldRabaA [The young locusts not yet winged] went on, or forwards: (S, O, K:) maXaI in this explanation in the K should be maDaI, as in the S and A. (TA.)
zaHafa said of an arrow, (assumed tropical:) It fell short of the butt, and then slid along to it. (S, * Msb.)

Also, said of a camel, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
zaHafa
, inf. n. zaHofN and zuHuwfN, and zaHafaAnN, (TA,) He became fatigued, and dragged his foot, or the extremity of his foot; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also OazoHafu↓: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or this latter signifies he (a camel) became fatigued, (K, TA,) and stood still with his master: and raAHilatuhu mina AlUiEoyaMCi OazoHafato↓ His saddle-camel stood still from fatigue: or, accord. to El-Khattábee, correctly, OuzoHifato Ealayohi: (TA:) or this is a mistake, occurring in the Fáïk; and it is correctly with fet-h: (Mgh:) and accord. to the T, zaHafa signifies he (a camel) became fatigued, so that he stood still with his master: (TA:) or, as some say, zaHafa said of one walking, or marching, [i. e., of a man and of a beast,] (Msb, TA,) accord. to AZ, whether fat or lean, (Msb,) aor.
zaHafa
, inf. n. zaHofN and zaHafaAnN, or, as AZ says, zaHofN and zuHuwfN, (TA,) signifies, (Msb,) or signifies also, (TA,) he became fatigued, (Msb, TA,) in walking, or marching. (TA.)
And zaHafa AlXRajaru (tropical:) The trees became in a state of gentle motion, by the influence of the wind. (TA.)
zaHafa AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. zaHofN, He dragged the thing along gently. (TA.)
2. zHRf Albayota biAlzRaHRaAfapi [He swept the house, or chamber, with the zHRAfp, q. v.]. (TA.)
3. zaAHafuwnaA, inf. n. muzaAHafapN, They fought with us. (TA.)
4: see 1, in the latter half, in two places.
OazoHafa said of a man means His camel, or his horse or the like, became fatigued. (S.)
AzHf lanaA banuw fulaAnK The sons of such a one became a zaHof to us, (K, TA,) i. e., an army marching to us to fight with us. (TA.)
And AzHf fulaAnN Such a one attained to the utmost of that which he sought, or desired. (K, * TA.)
AzHf said of long journeying, It fatigued the camels. (TA.)
AzHft AlrRiyHu AlXRajara (tropical:) The wind put the trees into a state of gentle motion. (TA.)
5: see 1, in the former half, in two places.
6. tzAHfwA They drew near, one to another, in fight. (IDrd, Z, K.) They walked, or marched, one to, or towards, another; as also AzdHfwA↓. (TA.)
8. AzdHf [originally AizotaHafa]: see 1, first sentence: and see also 6.

zaHofN An army, or a military force, marching by little and little, or leisurely, to, or towards, the enemy, (S, A, K, TA,) or heavily, by reason of their multitude and force: (A, TA:) or a numerous army or military force; an inf. n. used as a subst.; (Mgh, Msb;) because, by reason of its multitude, and heaviness of motion, it is as though it crept, or crawled, along: (Mgh:) accord. to Az, from zaHafa EalaI Qsotihi, said of a child: (TA:) not applied to a single individual: (IKoot, Msb:) pl. zuHuwfN. (Msb, TA.)
And hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) A swarm of locusts. (TA.)
farRa mina AlzRaHofi, occurring in a trad., means He fled from war with unbelievers; and from encountering the enemy in war. (TA.)

UicaA laqiytumu QlRaciyna kafaruwA zaHofFA, in the Kur [viii. 15], means, accord. to Zj, zaAHifiyna, i. e. [When ye meet those who have disbelieved] marching by little and little [in consequence of their great number, to attack you]. (TA.)
zaHofapN [inf. n. of un. of 1; A walk, &c.].

naAru AlzRaHofatayoni The fire of the XiyH and the OalaMC; because it quickly blazes in them [and then subsides]; (S, K;) so that one walks, or creeps, from them [and back to them]: (S:) or the fire of the Earofaj; (M, A;) because it quickly takes effect upon it; so that when it blazes, those who warm themselves at it walk, or creep, from it; then it soon subsides, and they walk, or creep, back to it: (M, TA:) and the like is said by IB; wherefore, he adds, it is called Oabuw sariyEK. (TA.) It was said to a woman of the Arabs, “ Wherefore do we see you to be scant of flesh in the posteriors and thighs? ” and she answered, OarosaHatonaA naAru AlzRaHofatayoni [The fire of the XiyH and the OalaMC, or of the Earofaj, has rendered us scant of flesh in the posteriors and thighs]. (S.)
zuHafapN, (K,) or zuHafapN zuHalapN, A man (TA) who does not travel about in the countries: (K, TA:) so in the Moheet. (TA.)
zaHuwfN: see zaAHifN, in two places.
[Also, accord. to Freytag, occurring in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning Going along slowly.]

zaHRaAfapN, in the dial. of Egypt, signifies maA yuzaHRafu bihi Albayotu [i. e. The thing, generally a palm-branch, with which the house, or chamber, is swept, to remove the dust and cobwebs from the roof and walls]. (TA.)
zaHanofafapN One who creeps along (yazoHafu) upon the ground, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) either from fatigue or old age. (TA.)
Also A man (TA) whose heel-tendons nearly knock against each other. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.)
zaAHifN [part. n. of 1; Walking, &c.].
(tropical:) An arrow that falls short of the butt, and then slides along to it: (S, * Msb, TA: *) pl. zawaAHifu. (Msb.)

A camel fatigued, and dragging his foot, or the extremity of his foot; (K;) as also zaAHifapN↓, in which the p is added to denote intensiveness: (Msb:) or the latter is applied, in the sense expl. above, to a she-camel; (S, K;) and so zaHuwfN↓; (K;) or this last signifies a she-camel that drags her hind legs or feet: and muzoHifN↓, applied to a he-camel, has the former of these meanings: (S:) [see also saHuwfN, said to be a dial. var. of zaHuwfN:] the pl. of zaAHifapN↓ is zawaAHifu; (S, Msb, K;) and the pl. of zaHuwfN↓ is zuHufN. (TA.) Also Fatigued and motionless; whatever it be, whether lean or fat; and so muzoHifN↓. (TA.) And, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, [simply] Fatigued; (TA;) and so muzoHifN↓; applied to a camel: (K:) or the latter, so applied, signifies fatigued, and standing still with his owner: the former is applied to the male and to the female; and its pl. is zawaAHifu: it is said to be also the name of a certain camel; but Th denies this. (TA.)
zaAHifapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
mazoHafN: see mazoHafapN.
muzoHifN: see zaAHifN, in three places.
saHaAbN muzoHifN (tropical:) Clouds moving slowly, because carrying much water; likened to fatigued camels. (TA.)

mazoHafapN a n. of place, sing. of mazaAHifu, (TK,)
which signifies The places of the creeping of serpents; (S, K, TA;) and the marks, or tracks, of the passage thereof: (TA:) and mazoHafN↓, likewise signifies the mark, or track, of a serpent, upon the ground; like masoHafN. (TA in art. sHf.)
mazaAHifu also signifies The places of fighting of a party, or people. (TA.)
And (tropical:) The places of pouring [of the water] of the clouds; (TA;) the places where falls the rain of the clouds. (K, TA. [In the CK, AlsRaHaAbu is erroneously put for AlsRaHaAbi.])

mizoHaAfN A camel wont, or accustomed, to become fatigued, (S, K, TA,) and to drag his foot, or the extremity of his foot, (S,) or to stand still with his owner: (TA:) or (tropical:) a she-camel that quickly becomes attenuated, or chafed, or abraded, or worn, in the sole of the foot: (A, TA:) pl. mazaAHiyfu (S, TA) and mazaAHifu. (TA.)

1. zaHala, (S, K,) aor.
zaHala
, (K,) inf. n. zuHuwlN (S, K) and zaHolN (Ham p. 125) and mazoHalN, (S,) He removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance; (S, K, TA, and Ham ubi suprà;) and went back or backwards, drew back, receded, or retreated; (TA;) Eano makaAnihi [from his place]; as also tzHRl↓. (S, K.) Hence, in a trad., AizoHalo EanRiI faqado nazaHotaniI, meaning [Remove thou, &c., from me,] for thou hast exhausted me of what I possessed. (TA.) And yazoHalu Eani AlOamuwri (K, TA, in the CK AlOamori,) He removes, withdraws, or retires far away, from affairs. (TA.)
And He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote. (TA.)

And zaHala Eano maqaAmihi, aor.
zaHala
, (K,) inf. n. zaHolN and zuHuwlN and mazoHalN, (TA,) It (a thing, TA) quitted its station, or standing-place; (K, TA;) as also tazaHowala↓: (K:) in some copies of the K, in the explanation of this phrase, zalRa is put in the place of zaAla. (TA.)
And zaHalato She (a camel) held back, hung back, or lagged behind, in her course, or journeying. (K.)
And zaHala He (a man, TA) was, or became, fatigued, tired, or jaded. (K, TA.)
2: see what next follows.
4. AzHlhu He removed him, or it, far away; as also zHRlhu↓, inf. n. tazoHiylN. (K.)
And AzHlhu Uilayohi (tropical:) He, or it, constrained him to betake himself, or repair, or have recourse, to him, or it. (K, TA.)
5: see 1, first sentence.

Q. Q. 1. zaHowalahu Eano makaAnihi He made him, or it, to slip (OazalRahu, [probably a mistranscription for OazaAlahu he removed him, or it, like as zalRa is put in some copies of the K in the place of zaAla in a case mentioned above,]) from his, or its, place. (TA.)
Q. Q. 2. tazaHowala [quasi-pass. of Q. Q. 1]: see 1.
zaHilN and ziHoliylN↓ Removing, withdrawing, or retiring to a distance; (S, K, TA;) and going back or backwards, drawing back, receding, or retreating; (TA;) from a place. (S, K, TA.)
zuHalN A man who removes, withdraws, or retires far away, from affairs, (K, * TA,) whether they be good or evil: (TA:) fem. with p. (K.)

zuHalu, imperfectly decl., (S, K,) like Eumaru, (S,) because it is a proper name and deviates from the original form [which is app. AlzRaAHilu, reg. part. n. of 1], (Mbr, TA,) [The planet Saturn;] a certain star, of those called AlxunRasu; (S, K;) so called because it is remote; and said to be in the Seventh Heaven. (TA.) gulaAmu zuHala [The young man, or slave, of Saturn] is [a surname of] Abu-l-Kásim the well-known astronomer or astrologer. (K.)
zuHalapN A man who does not travel about in the countries. (K.) [See also zuHafapN.]
And A certain beast that enters its hole with its hinder part foremost. (K.)
ziHalRN A camel that drives far away the [other] camels, pressing against them so as to remove them, in the coming to water, and then drinks. (K.)
zuHoluwlN: see the next paragraph.
Also Light in body. (TA.)
ziHoliylN: see zaHilN.
Also Quick, or swift: (K:) mentioned by Sb, and expl. by Seer. (TA.)
And A place that is strait and slippery, consisting of smooth stones; as also zuHoluwlN↓: (K:) and so ziHoliyfN. (Aboo-Málik, TA.)

naAqapN zaHuwlN A she-camel which, when she comes to the watering-trough, and the driver (AlcRaAYidu, in the copies of the K erroneously written AlrRaAYidu, TA) strikes her face, turns her rump to him, and ceases not to recede until she comes to the water-ing-trough. (Lth, K, * TA.)
And EuqobapN zaHuwlN [in the CK erroneously written EaqabapN, A stage of a journey] far-extending. (K, TA.)
zayoHalapN A proud and self-conceited gait. (K.)
mazoHalN an inf. n. of zaHala. (S, TA.)
And also A place to which one removes, withdraws, or retires far away. (S, TA.) Ibráheem Ibn-Kuneyf En-Nebhánee says,

L.foreign: wamaA liQmoriYK EamRaA qaDaI QllRehu mazoHalu

sense.s: i. e. And there is not, for a man, a place to which to go far away from that which God has decreed. (Ham p. 125.) And one says, UinRa liI Einodaka lamazoHalFA, meaning munotadaHFA [i. e. Verily there is, for me, with thee, ample scope, or freedom, or liberty]. (S, TA.)
Q. 1. zaHolafahu, (S, K,) inf. n. zaHolafapN, (S,) He rolled him, or it, down or along. (S, K.)
And He pushed, impelled, repelled, or drove away, or back, him, or it. (S, K.) [Hence,] one says, zaHolafa QllRehu EanRaA XarRaka May God put away, or ward off, from us thy mischief. (TA.)
zaHolafa lifulaAnK OalofFA He gave to such a one a thousand. (Sgh, K.)
zaHolafa AlUinaMCa He filled the vessel. (Sgh, K.)
zaHolafa fiI AlkalaAmi He hastened, or was quick, in speech. (Sgh, K.)
Q. 2. tazaHolafa He, or it, rolled down or along. (S, * K, * TA.) One says, yatazaHolafuwna fiyhi [They roll down it]; namely, a smoothed descending, or sloping, place. (IAar, T, S.)
And He, or it, became pushed, impelled, repelled, or driven away or back. (S, K.) [Hence,] El-Ajjáj says,

[And the sun had almost become near to setting, and to turning yellow; I repelling it with the palm of the hand in order that it might be warded off; tazaHolafaA being for tatazaHolafa]. (S.) See also the next paragraph.
One says also tazaHolafati AlXRamosu meaning The sun inclined to setting: or declined from the meridian, at midday. (TA.)
zuHoluwfN Smooth rock: to which is likened the portion of flesh and sinew bordering the backbone, when fat. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)
ziHoliyfN A slippery place. (TA.) [See also what next follows: and see ziHoliylN.]

zuHoluwfapN The traces of the sliding of children from the top to the bottom of a hill: (As, S, K:) of the dial. of the people of El-'Áliyeh: in the dial. of Temeem, with q [in the place of f]: (S:) or [a sloping slide, or rolling-place; i. e.] a smoothed descending, or sloping, place; (IAar, S, K;) because they roll down it (yatazaHolafuwna fiyhi): (S:) or a slippery place of a mountain of sands, upon which children play; and likewise on smooth rock: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) pl. zaHaAliyfu and zaHaAlifu. (S.)
zaHaAlifu a pl. of zuHoluwfapN. (S.)
HumurN zaHaAlifu AlSRuqoli Asses having smooth and fat bellies. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)
Also Small dawaAbR [i. e. reptiles, or insects], having legs, that walk, resembling ants: (K:) or, as in the O, having legs resembling ants. (TA.)
[mutazaHolifN, accord. to Freytag, occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning Smooth, applied to rock.]
Q. 1. zaHolaqapN [inf. n. of zaHolaqa] The rolling [a thing] down; syn. daHorajapN. (S, K.) You say, zaHolaqa AlHajara, i. e. daHorajahu [He rolled down the stone]. (TK.)
Q. 2. tazaHolaqa He, or it, rolled down; syn. tadaHoraja: (S, K:) or he slid, or slipped, upon his posteriors. (TA.)
ziHoliqN A violent wind. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
ziHoliyqN: see the next paragraph.

zuHoluwqapN i. q. zuHoluwfapN; (S, * K;) meaning [A sloping slide, or rolling-place; or] the traces of the sliding of children from above to below: (TA:) of the dial. of Temeem: pl. zaHaAliyqu: (S:) which likewise signifies slippery places; as also ziHoliyqN↓. (TA.)
And (tropical:) A grave: (K, TA:) because one slips into it. (TA.)

And i. q. OurojuwHapN; i. e. [A seesaw;] a piece of wood [or a plank] which children lay upon an elevated place, and a number sit upon one end of it, and a number upon the other [end]; and when one of the two parties is heavier, the other rises, and threatens to fall; whereupon they [app. who are looking on] call out to them, OalaA xalRuwA OalaA xalRuwA [Now leave ye! now leave ye what ye are doing!]. (K. [See also OurojuwHapN.])
muzaHolaqN [Rolled down: see Q. 1.
And] Smooth. (TA.)

1. zaHamahu, (Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
zaHama
, inf. n. zaHomN (Msb, K) and zaHomapN (Msb) and ziHaAmN, with kesr; (K; [but see what here follows, and see also zaHomapN below;] and zAHmhu↓, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. muzaAHamapN (Msb, TA) and ziHaAmN; (Msb;) i. q. DaAyaqahu [i. e. He straitened him, meaning, in this instance, by pressure; and properly, being in like manner straitened by him]: (K in explanation of zaHamahu, and TA in explanation of zAHmhu:) or i. q. dafaEahu [he pushed him, or repelled him]; generally meaning [he pushed against him] in a strait, or narrow, [or crowded,] place: (Msb in explanation of zaHamahu, and app. in explanation of zAHmhu also:) [or i. q. daAfaEahu, which often signifies the same as dafaEahu; but more properly, he pushed him, &c., being pushed, &c., by him: for] zaHamaniIa AlnRaAsu means daAfaEuwniI [i. e. The people pushed against me; or pushed me, &c., being pushed, &c., by me;] in a strait, or narrow, [or crowded,] place: (Mgh:) [or pressed, crowded, or thronged, me:] and muzaAHamapN is syn. with mudaAfaEapN: (TA in art. dfE:) AizodaHamahu↓ in the place of zaHamahu is a mistake. (Mgh.) One says, zaHama Alqawomu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA The people straitened one another; syn. taDaAyaquwA; [or pressed, crowded, or thronged, one another;] in a sitting-place, or place of assembly: (Msb:) as also AzdHmwA↓, (Msb, K, * TA,) in whatever place it be; (Msb;) and tzAHmwA↓. (K, * TA.) One may also use the pass. form of zaHama, i. e. zuHima [meaning He was straitened, by pressure; &c.]; and that of zaAHama, i. e. zuwHima↓ [meaning the same]. (Msb.)
zaHima zuHomapF↓ He gobbled a gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful: so in the “ Nawádir; ” as also zahimahaA. (TA.) 3: see above, in two places.

[Hence,] one says, zaAHama EalaI AlrRiYaAsapi waOaraAdahaA (assumed tropical:) [He strove for headship, or command, and desired it]. (IAar, TA in art. rOs.) [And hence the prov. zaAHim biEawodK Oawo daEo: see art. Ewd.]

[Hence, likewise,] zAHmhu also signifies (assumed tropical:) He treated him, or behaved towards him, with roughness, rudeness, hardness, harshness, or ill-nature. (TA. [I find this explanation noted down by me as taken from the TA, but without any reference to the art. from which I obtained it. It is not in the present art.])
zAHm Alxamosiyna He (a man, TA) approached, (K, TA,) and reached, or attained, (TA,) the [age of] fifty [years]; (K, TA;) as also zaAhamahaA. (TA.)
6: see 1, and 8.
tzAHmt AlOamowaAju and AzdHmt↓ The waves dashed against each other. (TA.) See a verse cited below, voce zaHomN.

8: see 1, in two places; and see also an ex. in a verse cited below, voce zaHomN. One says also, AzdHmwA EalaI kacaA and Ealayohi tzAHmwA↓ [They pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together, upon, or against, such a thing]. (S.)
Hence, by way of metaphor, AzdHm AlguramaMCu (tropical:) [The creditors were, or became, numerous and pressing]. (Msb.)
See also 6.

zaHomN [originally an inf. n.,] i. q. qawomN muzodaHimuwna [A party, or company of men, straitening one another by pressure; pushing, pressing, crowding, or thronging, one another; i. e. a press, crowd, or throng]. (K, * TA.) A poet says,

[He brought a crowd with a crowd, and they pressed, one against another, like the dashing together of the waves when the waves beat one another]: he uses [here] an inf. n. not conformable to the verb. (ISd, TA.)

zuHomN, with damm, a name of Mekkeh: (K, * TA:) so says Th: but ISd says that the name commonly known is ruHom [or OumRu ruHomK or OumRu AlrRuHomi]: (TA:) or it is OumRu AlzRuHomi [probably, I think, a mistranscription for OumRu AlrRuHomi]. (K, TA.)

zaHomapN [an inf. n. of zaHamahu accord. to the Msb] i. q. ziHaAmN↓ [likewise an inf. n. of zaHamahu accord. to the K, and of zaAHamahu accord. to the Msb: both signify A straitening, pushing, pressing, crowding, or thronging]. (S.)
zaHomapu AlwilaAdapi The moaning, or hard breathing, (zaHorap,) with which the child comes forth; as also zajomap and zakomap. (K in the present art. and in art. zjm.)
zuHomapN A gobbet, morsel, or mouthful. (TA.) See 1, last sentence.
ziHaAmN: see zaHomapN.

mizoHamN i. q. kaviyru AlzRiHaAmi or Xadiyduhu [i. e. One who straitens, pushes, presses, crowds, or throngs, much or vehemently]. (K.) Hence, manokibN mizoHamN [A shoulder that pushes vehemently]. (TA.)
huwa sayRidu qawomihi gayoru muzaAHamK i. q. gayoru mudaAfaEK, (K in art. dfE, q. v.)

muzaAHimN, (T, TA,) or Oabuw muzaAHimK, (T, K, TA,) or Aibonu muzaAHimK, (M, TA,) The elephant: (T, M, K:) and a bull having horns: so in the T, on the authority of IAar: (TA:) or a bull having the horns broken. (M, K, TA)
muzaAHimN is also the name of A certain horse. (K, * TA.)

1. zaxRahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
zaxuxa
, inf. n. zaxRN, (TA,) He pushed him, or thrust him, (S, A,) or made him to fall, (K,) into a depressed place, or a deep hollow or cavity: (S, A, K:) [or he pushed him, or thrust him, in any manner; for] zaxRN signifies, accord. to IDrd, any pushing, or thrusting. (TA.) You say, zuxRa fiI AlnRaAri, (A,) or zuxRa bihi fiI AlnRaAri, He was pushed, or thrust, and thrown, or cast, into the fire [of Hell]. (TA.) And zuxRa fiI qafaAhu (A, TA) He was pushed, or thrust, on the back of his neck: or he was pushed, or thrust, on the back of his neck, and expelled. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of Aboo-Moosà, mano yatRabiEi AlquroMna yahobiTo bihi EalaI riyaADi AljanRapi wamano yatRabiEohu AlquroMnu yazuxRa fiI qafaAhu HatRaI yaqocifa bihi fiI naAri jahanRama [Whosoever follows the Kur-án as his guide, it will make him to alight upon the gardens, or meadows, of Paradise; and whomsoever the Kur-án follows as a punisher, it will push, or thrust, upon the back of his neck, until it shall cast him into the fire of Hell]. (S.) One says also of lambs or kids, tuzaxRu, meaning They are driven; and impelled from behind them. (TA.) And of a driver, zaxRa AlUibila He drove the camels quickly, and urged them on. (TA.)

[Hence,] zaxRa bibawolihi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He cast forth his urine; (K, TA;) and propelled it. (TA.) And zaxRato biAlmaMCi, and zaxRati AlmaMCa, She (a woman) ejected the [seminal] fluid. (TA. [See zaxRaAxapN.])
Hence also, (TA,) zaxRa AlmaroOapa, (S, * A, * K,) aor. as above, (S, A,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He compressed the woman; (A, K;) as also zaxozaxahaA↓, (K,) inf. n. zixozaAxN. (TA.)
And zaxRahu biAlrRumoHi i. q. zajRahu [He pierced him, or thrust him, with the pointed iron foot of the spear]; like zalaxahu. (TA in art. zlx.)

And zaxRa, (K,) and zaxRa binafosihi, (TA,) [as though meaning “ he propelled himself, ”] He leaped: (K, TA:) thus, sometimes a man leaps a nahor [here meaning a rivulet for irrigation], putting his misoHaAp in the middle of it. (TA.)
And zaxRa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He went quickly; [as though propelling himself:] (TA:) he (a driver) went, or journeyed, a violent, or rigorous, pace. (K, TA.)

zaxRa, (S, K,) [aor., accord. to analogy,
zaxixa
,] inf. n. as above, (S,) He (a man) was, or became, angered, or enraged. (S, K. [See also zaxRapN.])

zaxRa Aljamoru, (S, A, K,) in some copies of the K, erroneously, Alxamoru, (TA,) aor.
zaxixa
, (S, K,) with kesr, (S,) and
zaxuxa
, with damm, [which is anomalous,] (TA,) inf. n. zaxiyxN (S, * A, * K) and zaxRN, (K,) The live coals glistened: (K:) or glistened vehemently: (S, A:) and in like manner, AlHariyru [the silk]. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. zaxozaxa AlmaroOapa: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
zaxRN: see the next paragraph.
zaxRapN: see mazaxRapN.

Also, (S, L,) and zaxRN↓, (L,) [or the former is a simple subst. and the latter is an inf. n., (see 1, last sentence but one,)] Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; and anger, or rage: (S, L:) but zaxRapN is said to have been heard in this sense only in a verse of Sakhrel-Gheí. (TA.)

zuxRapN The young ones of sheep or goats: of the measure fuEolapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; like quboDapN and gurofapN; so called liOanRahaA tuzaxRu, i. e. because they are driven, and impelled from behind them: from these, it is said in a trad. that no contribution to the poor-rates is to be taken. (TA.)
zaxRaMCu: see what next follows.
zaxRaAxapN A woman who ejects the [seminal] fluid on the occasion of jimaAE; (K, TA;) as also zaxRaMCu↓. (TA.)
mazaxRapN The vulva of a woman; (K, TA;) because it is the place of AlzRaxRu. (TA. [See zaxRa AlmaroOapa.])
And (tropical:) A wife; (S, A, K;) as though she were the place of AlzRaxRu; (TA;) as also mizaxRapN↓ and zaxRapN↓. (K.)
mizaxRapN: see what next precedes.

1. zaxara, (S, A, K,) aor.
zaxara
, inf. n. zaxorN and zuxuwrN (K) and zaxiyrN, so in the A, (TA,) It (the sea) became full; or rose, and became full; as also tzxRz↓: (K:) or both, said of the sea, its flow, or tide, rose, or became full: (JK, A:) or the former, [or each,] said of the sea, it increased, and its water became abundant, and its waves rose. (TA.)
It (a valley) flowed with much water, which rose high: (S, K:) it flowed copiously, and its torrent became full: or it flowed with abundance of water, and its waves rose. (TA.)

zaxarati Alqidoru, (K,) aor.
zaxara
, inf. n. zaxorN, (TA,) The cooking-pot boiled, or began to do so: (K, TA:) and in like manner, AlHarobu [war, or the war; i. e. raged, or began to do so]. (A, * K.) And zaxara Alqawomu The people, or party, became in a state of commotion for the purpose of going forth to execute some affair, (AA, JK, K, TA,) or for war. (JK, A, K.)
[zaxarati AlrRiyHu The wind blew strongly, or vehemently. (Freytag, from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen.)]
zaxara said of a plant, or herbage, It became high, or tall; (A, K;) and so said of anything. (JK.)

And, said of a man, He boasted (As, A, K) bimaA Einodahu [of what he possessed], (As, K,) or bimaA layosa Einodahu [of what he did not possess]; (A;) as also tazaxowara↓: (K:) or this latter signifies he magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently; and threatened. (TA.)
zaxara, (K,) inf. n. zaxorN, (TA,) He filled a thing. (K.)
It (the herb, or herbage,) fattened, and rendered comely, the cattle. (JK, K.)
He caused a man to be affected with emotion [app. by reason of mirth or joy]; syn. OaToraba. (JK, K.)
zaxarati AlrRiyHu AlsRaHaAba The wind drove along the clouds. (JK.)

zaxara AldRiqRa i. q. OacoraAhu fiI AlrRiyHi [He threw, or scattered, the fine part, or particles, (accord. to the TK the flour and bran,) in the wind], (JK, K, TA,) with the micarRap [or instrument with which grain is scattered]. (TA.)
See also what next follows.
3: zaAxarotuhu fazaxarotuhu↓ I vied with him in boasting, and surpassed him, or overcame him, therein. (JK, A, K. *)
5: see 1, first sentence.
Q. Q. 2. tazaxowara: see 1.

zaxorapN [Fulness of the sea]. One says, raOayotu AlbiHaAra falamo Oara Oagolaba minohu zaxorapF waAljibaAla falamo Oara OaSolaba minohu SaxorapF [I have seen the seas, but I have not seen one more surpassing in fulness than he is in bountifulness; and the mountains, but I have not seen one more firm in rock than he is in heart]. (A.)
zuxoriIRN, applied to a plant, or herbage, &c., (TA,) Tall; (JK, K, TA;) as also zuxaAriIRN↓. (JK.)
zixoriyRapN, (JK,) or zixoriyapN, like hiboriyapN, (O, TA,) A plant, or herbage, full-grown; (IDrd, JK, O, TA;) as also zixoriyrN↓. (JK.)
zixoriyrN: see what next precedes.
[zaxuwrN A wind blowing violently. (Freytag, from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen.)]
zaxowarN: see the next paragraph.
zuxaAriIRN A plant, or herbage, full-grown, full of juice, luxuriant, or abundant and dense, (K, TA,) and in blossom; (TA;) as also zaxowariIRN↓ and zaxowarN↓. (K, TA.) See also zuxoriIRN.
makaAnN zuxaAriIRu AlnRabaAti [A place having its plants, or herbage, full-grown, full of juice, luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and in blossom]. (S.)

And zuxaAriIRu AlnRabaAti The blossoms, and the beauty and brightness, of plants, or herbage. (K.) [Hence,] Oaxaca zuxaAriyRahu It (a plant, or herbage,) blossomed: (JK:) or became luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and put forth its blossoms; as also junRa, inf. n. junuwnN: (As, TA:) or obtained its full supply of moisture: (A, TA:) or acquired its due degree of beauty and brightness: (TA:) or became tall. (A.) Also It (any affair, or thing,) became complete, or perfect, and in a sound, or good, state. (A, TA.) And Oaxacati AlOaroDu zuxaAriyRahaA The land had tall herbage: (A, TA:) when such is the case, it is termed OaroDN zaAxirapN↓. (TA.)
zaxowariIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.
kalaAmN zaxowariIRN Speech in which is self-magnification, pride, haughtiness, or insolence, (JK, K, TA,) and threatening. (TA.)
zaxRaArN: see the next paragraph.

zaAxirN A sea full, or flowing with much water, and rising high: (S, TA:) and a valley flowing with a copious and high tide of water: and zaxRaArN↓, also, is applied as an epithet to a sea [in a similar, but intensive, sense]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN baHorN zaAxirN wabadorN zaAhirN (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is a full sea, meaning bountiful, and a shining full moon, meaning illustrious]. (A, TA.) The saying of the Hudhalee, describing a woman,

means Liberal with the food of the belly in the time of hunger, when [the vein is full, and] the blood and the tempers are excited: or it means, and her lineage is high; for the vein of the generous flows fully with generousness. (S, TA.) One says also Eiroquhu zaAxirN meaning (assumed tropical:) He is generous, increasing [in generosity], or abounding [therein]. (AO, S, K, TA.) And zaAxirN signifies High nobility. (AA, K.)
See also zuxaAriIRN, last sentence.
Also Rejoicing, joyful, glad, or happy. (A, K.)
[zaAxirapN a subst. from zaAxirN, rendered such by the affix p.] zawaAxiru [is its pl., and] signifies Watercourses; or channels of water. (JK.)
And Herbs: so in the saying, Aikotahalato zawaAxiru AlwaAdiI [The herbs of the valley became tall, full-grown, or of their full height and in blossom]. (A, TA.)

Oazoxaru [More, and most, full, &c.]. One says, huwa mina AlbuHuwri OazoxaruhaA wamina Albuduwri OazoharuhaA (assumed tropical:) [He is, of the seas, the most full, meaning, of the bountiful, the most bountiful; and of the full moons, the most shining, meaning, of the illustrious, the most illustrious]. (A, TA.)

Q. 1. zaxorafapN signifies The adorning, ornamenting, decorating, or embellishing, of a thing, (KL, and Har p. 3,) primarily, with zuxoruf, i. e. gold: (Har ib.:) and hence, (Har,) the adorning, &c., of falsehood, or a lie: (KL, Har:) and the falsifying or adulterating [of speech &c.]. (KL.) You say, zaxorafa Albayota, inf. n. zaxorafapN, He adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished, the house, or chamber, &c.; and rendered it complete: and zuxorifa is said of anything as meaning It was adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished. (TA.) And zaxorafa AlkalaAma He arranged, or rightly disposed, or put into a right or proper state, the speech, or language: (TA:) and i. q. raqRaXahu [i. e. he embellished it; generally meaning, with lies]. (S, A, K, in art. rqX.) [This verb is mentioned and explained by Freytag as on the authority of the K, in which it is not found in this art.]
Q. 2. tazaxorafa He (a man) adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished, himself. (TA.)
zuxorufN Gold: (Fr, S, M, K:) so in the Kur xvii. 95: and this, accord. to ISd, is the primary meaning. (TA.)

Then applied to Any orna-
ment, decoration, or embellishment: (ISd, TA:) anything adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished: (Ham p. 784:) and particularly applied to the decorations, and pictured works, in gold, with which the Kaabeh was ornamented in Pagan times. (TA.) The colours of the plants or herbage, of land, (K, TA,) red and yellow and white: its ornature, consisting in blossoms and flowers: or its perfection: so in the Kur x. 25. (TA.) And The furniture, or utensils, of a house or tent. (TA.)

Anything varnished, or embellished with a false colouring, or falsified, is likened thereto [and so termed]. (S, TA.) [Hence,] zuxorufu Alqawoli The ornature of speech; (TA;) the fair appearance, or comeliness, of speech, produced by the embellishing with lies: (K, TA:) so in the Kur vi. 112: (TA:) or it there means varnished falsehoods. (Bd.)
[Its pl.] zaxaArifu signifies The lines, or streaks, [that are seen on the surface] of water. (S, K.)
And Ships: (T, K:) or ornamented, or decorated, ships: (M, TA:) or the ornature of ships, with which they are decorated. ('Eyn, TA.)

Also Certain insects that fly upon the water, (T, O, K,) having four legs, resembling the common fly; (O, K;) small flies, having four legs, that fly upon the water: (M, TA:) the sing., zuxorufN, is expl. by Kr [in the Munjid] as meaning a kind of flying thing. (TA.)
muzaxorafN Adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished: (S, TA:) [&c.: see the verb.]

1. zarRa, aor. yazurRu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. zarRN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He buttoned a shirt [&c.]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) as also zrRr↓, inf. n. tazoriyrN; (Mgh; [and so in the present day;]) or the latter verb [relates to several objects, or means he buttoned a shirt &c. with many buttons; for it] has an intensive signification. (Msb.) You say, Auzoruro Ealayoka qamiySaka, and zurRahu, and zurRihi, and zurRuhu, Button upon thee thy shirt. (S.)

(assumed tropical:) He narrowed his eyes [as when one draws together the edges of a vest in buttoning it]. (K, * [in which, in this instance, as in others, only the inf. n. of the verb zarRa is mentioned,] and TA.)
(tropical:) He collected, or drew together, vehemently, or forcibly. (A, Msb, K *)
zarRahaA [referring to the pieces of cloth composing a tent] He made in them what are called OazoraAr [pl. of zirRN, q. v.]. (TA.)

And zarRa, aor. as above, (S, A, TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, K,) (tropical:) He drove away. (S, A, K, TA. [In the TA, the inf. n. is expl. by AlXRakRu as well as AlTRarodu; but the former is a mistranscription for AlXRalRu, the reading in the S.]) One says, huwa yazurRu AlkataAYiba biAlsRayofi (tropical:) He drives away the troops with the sword. (S, A.)
(tropical:) He bit another. (S, * A, K. *)
(assumed tropical:) He pierced, or thrust, another, (K, TA,) with a spear. (TK.)
He plucked out hair. (K, * TA.)
He shook goods, or household furniture, or the like, to remove dust &c. (O, K: * only the inf. n. is mentioned in the latter.)
zarRa, (K,) aor. yazirRu, (TA,) He increased in intelligence, (K, TA,) and in probations, or experiences. (TA. [See also zarira, below, in this paragraph.])

Also, aor. yazirRu, inf. n. zariyrN, It (a spear-head) gleamed, or glistened. (A.) And zarRato Eayonuhu, aor. tazirRu, (S,) inf. n. zariyrN, (S, K,) His eye gleamed, or glistened. (S, K. *) And EayonaAhu tazrRaAni fiI raOosihi His eyes gleam, or glisten, in his head. (Fr, S, * A, TA.)
zarira, like samiEa, [by rule zarRa, sec. pers. zarirota, aor. yazarRu,] He acted wrongfully, injuriously, or unjustly, to his adversary, or antagonist. (K.)
And He became intelligent after having been foolish, or stupid. (K. [See also a signification of zarRa, above.])
2: see 1, first sentence:
and see also 4.
3. zArRhu, (A,) inf. n. muzaArRapN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He bit him, being bitten by him. (S, * A, K. *)
4. AzrRhu, (A'Obeyd, S, Msb,) and zrRrhu↓, (A,) He put OazoraAr [i. e. buttons, or, as some say, loops for buttons,] upon it, namely, a shirt [&c.]. (A'Obeyd, S, A, Msb.)
5. tzrRr It (a shirt [&c.]) had OazoraAr [i. e. buttons, or, as some say, loops for buttons,] put upon it. (S, TA.)
R. Q. 1. zarozara, (S, K,) inf. n. zarozarapN, (TA,) He (a zurozuwr [or starling]) uttered a cry, or cries. (S, K.)
He (a man) kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of the zurozuwr. (IAar, K, TA.)
zarozara biAlmakaAni He continued, or remained fixed, or stationary, in the place. (K.)
R. Q. 2. tazarozara He, or it, was, or became, in a state of motion, or commotion. (K.)
zarRN an inf. n. of zarRa [q. v.]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K. *)
See also zirRN.
zurRN: see what next follows.

zirRN, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) and zurRN↓, (ISk,) app. in the same sense, (Az,) and zarRN↓ has been also mentioned, but this is doubtful, (MF,) A button (IAar, A, Msb, TA) of a shirt, (IAar, S, A, Msb, K,) and of other things, as, for instance, of a curtain: (MF, TA:) or the loop into which a button is put: (ISh:) the latter, accord. to Az, is the right meaning: (TA:) [but the former is that to which the word is generally applied:] the former is also called ziyrN, by a change of the first r: (IAar:) pl. [of pauc.] OazoraArN (S, A, Msb, K) and [of mult.] zuruwrN. (K.) [Hence the saying,] huwa Oalozamu liI mino zirRiI liEurowatihi [He is more fast to me than my button to its loop]. (A.) And OaEoTaAniyhi bizirRihi (tropical:) He gave it to me altogether. (A.)
AlzRirRu [The star ξ of Gemini;] one of the two stars called AlhanoEapu. (Kzw.)

zirRN also signifies (tropical:) A certain piece of wood at the upper extremity of the pole of a tent: (A, K: *) pl. OazoraArN: (TA:) the upper end of the tent-pole is inserted into it: (L:) or the AzrAr of a tent (xibaMC) are certain pieces of wood which are sewed into the upper parts of the pieces of cloth which compose the tent, the lower ends of which [pieces of cloth] are upon the ground: and zarRahaA signifies “ he made in them [namely the said pieces of cloth] such pieces of wood. ” (TA.)

(tropical:) The socket in which the head of the upper bone of the arm turns; (A, K; *) resembling the half of a nut: (A:) or the head itself of that bone: (TA:) and the extremity of the hip-bone, in the socket. (K.)

(assumed tropical:) A certain small bone, (K,) resembling the half of a nut, (TA, [but this is probably a misplaced insertion, from the A, ubi suprà,]) beneath the heart, of which it is the support. (K.)
(tropical:) The edge, (K,) or each of the two edges, (TA,) of a sword. (IAar, K, TA.)

One says, UinRahu lazirRN mino OazoraAri AlUibili (S, * A, K *) (tropical:) Verily he is one who keeps close to the camels; (A;) a good pastor of them. (S, A, K. [Accord. to the A, it seems to be from zirRN signifying “ a button. ”]) You term also zirRu maAlK (assumed tropical:) One who drives camels, or the like, vehemently; accord. to some; but the preceding meaning, given in the K, is the more correct: (TA:) or it signifies one acquainted with the right management thereof; (K, TA;) who manages them well; (TA;) as also maAlK zurozuwru↓. (K.)

zirRu AldRiyni (assumed tropical:) The support, or prop, of the religion; (Abu-l-'Abbás, K;) like the small bone called zirR, which is the support of the heart: (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA:) applied, in a trad., to 'Alee: in another relation, it is zirRu AlOaroDi, meaning he between whom and the earth is a mutual dependance, and without whose existence one would repudiate the earth and mankind: or, accord. to Th, he by whom the earth becomes firm, like as a shirt does by means of its zirR [or button]. (TA.)
zarRapN Intellect, or intelligence. (O, TA.)
zirRapN The mark left by a bite: (K, TA:) or, as some say, a bite itself. (TA.) And A wound with the edge of a sword. (TA.)
J says, When camels are fat, you say, bihaA zirRapN: but this is a mistake for bahaA zirapN, (Sgh, K,) which is pl. of buhozuwrapN. (TA in art. bhzr.)

zariyrN, applied to a man, (O, TA,) Light, or active; and sharp, or acute, of mind, with quickness of perception, and of intelligence, understanding, sagacity, skill, or knowledge; as also zarozaArN↓; (O, K; [in the CK, AlzakiIRu is erroneously put for AlcRakiIRu;]) which is also expl. as signifying light, or active, and quick; (TA;) and zuraAzirN↓, (K,) of which the pl. is zaraAziru. (TA.)
Also A certain plant, (O, K.) having a yellow blossom, (O,) with which one dyes: (O, K:) in this sense, a Pers., or foreign, word. (O.)
zurozurN: see zurozuwrN.
zarozaArN: see zariyrN. Accord. to As, it signifies A man whose eyes glisten. (TA.)
zurozuwrN [The starling;] a certain bird, (IDrd, S, O, K,) as also zurozurN↓, (IDrd, O, K,) resembling the lark: pl. zaraAziyru. (TA.)

marokabN zurozuwrN A narrow mrkb [or animal, or thing, upon which one rides or is carried; accord. to the TK, meaning a beast; for it is there added that one says
HimaArN zurozuwrN, meaning a narrow ass]. (O, K. *)
zurozuwru maAlK: see zirRN last sentence but one.
zuraAzirN: see zariyrN.
mizarRN An ass [app. meaning a wild ass] that bites much. (S, * TA.)
mazoruwrN is used by El-Marrár El-Fak'asee as meaning A she-camel's nose-rein; because it is plaited and tied. (S.)

1. zarobN [as an inf. n.] signifies The constructing a zariybap, (K, TA,) i. e. an enclosure of wood, (TA,) for sheep, or goats: (K, TA:) you say, zarabotu Alganama, aor. OazorubuhaA, inf. n. zarobN: (TA:) [or this, I think, is a mistake for what here follows:] zarabotu liloganami, aor. Oazorubu, inf. n. zarobN (Ks, S:) [i. e. I constructed an enclosure of wood for the sheep or goats: this meaning is plainly indicated, though not expressed, in the S and TA:] but in some copies of the K, in the place of binaMCu AlzRariybapi liloganami, as explaining AlzRarobu, we find bnAt Alzrybp Algnm [meaning that banaAtu AlzRariybapi↓ signifies sheep, or goats]. (TA.)
And zaraba Albahoma fiI zarobihaA or zariybatihaA He put the bhm [i. e. lambs or kids, or young lambs or kids,] into their place [or enclosure of wood]. (A. [And the like is said in the Ham p. 195.])

zariba, aor.
zaraba
, (K, TA,) said of water, (TA,) It flowed; (K, TA;) like sariba. (TA.)
7. Anzrb Albahomu fiI AlzRarobu The bhm [i. e. lambs or kids, or young lambs or kids,] entered into the zrb [or enclosure of wood]. (A, TA. *)
And Anzrb AlSRaAYidu (S, TA) fiI qutoratihi (TA) (assumed tropical:) The hunter, or sportsman, entered into his lurking-place. (S, TA.)
9. AzrbR, inf. n. AizoribaAbN, It (a plant, or herb,) became yellow, or red, while having in it greenness. (K, TA.)
zarobN A place of entrance. (AA, S, A, K.)

And hence, accord. to AA, (S,) the same word, (S, A, K,) and zirobN↓, (ISk, S, K,) as some pronounce it, (ISk, S,) and zariybapN↓, (S, A, K,) (assumed tropical:) The place of sheep or goats; (A, K, TA;) [i. e.] an enclosure of wood for sheep or goats: (S:) [said in the TA to be tropical; but not so accord. to the A:] pl. of the first (A, K) and second (K) zuruwbN, (A, K,) and of the last zaraAYibu. (A.)

And, as being likened thereto, (A,) zarobN and zariybapN↓ signify also (tropical:) The lurking-place (qutorap) of a hunter, or sportsman, (S, A, K,) or of an archer, or a shooter: (TA in explanation of the former word:) both signify a well [or pit] which the hunter, or sportsman, digs for himself that he may lie in wait therein for the game. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
zirobN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also A channel in which water flows; (K;) and so zarobN↓. (TA.) It is said in a rejez of Kaab,

She passes the night between the channel of water and the concealing, or protecting, place: meaning that she is fed in the enclosures for camels &c., [fiI AlHZAYr, thus I read for AlHDAYr (an evident mistranscription) in the TA,] and among the tents, or houses; not in the pasture-land. (TA.)

zirobiIRN and zurobiIRN, (K,) or, accord. to the L [and the A], on the authority of IAar, zarobiyRapN↓, also said to be written zirobiyRapN and zurobiyRapN, (TA,) are sings. of zaraAbiIRu↓, (K, TA,) which signifies namaAriqu [app. as meaning Small pillows]: (S, A, K:) and carpets: or any things which are spread, and upon which one leans, or reclines: (A, K:) the like of this is said by Zj in explaining a phrase in which it occurs in the Kur lxxxviii. 16: or, accord. to Fr, it signifies carpets (TanaAfis) having a fine nap, or pile: (TA:) also, [particularly,] (A,) carpets (quTuwE, A, or TanaAfis, Har p. 377) of the fabric of El- Heereh; and the like thereof in fabric: (A, and Har ubi suprà:) or zrbyRp↓ signifies [simply] a carpet (TinofisapN): and a carpet (bisaAT) having a nap, or pile: and a [piece of leather that is spread upon the ground, such as is called] niTaE: and the like thereof in make. (TA. [See also the last sentence of this paragraph.]) [Hence,] one says, AlbagoDaMCi bayonahumo mabovuwvapN zaraAbiIRu↓ (tropical:) [The embellished coverings of vehement hatred are spread between them; i. e. vehement hatred concealed by fair professions &c. subsists between them]. (A.) The following saying, of Artáh Ibn-Suheiyeh,

L.foreign: wanaHonu banuw EamRK EalaI caAti bayoninaA

sense.s: is expl. by En-Nemiree as meaning (assumed tropical:) [And we are sons of a paternal uncle, but] upon our enmity is a comely covering beneath which it is latent; [therein are vehement hatred and envious competition;] zaraAbiIRu signifying [properly] carpets of sundry colours: (Ham p. 196:) it is also said to mean, in this instance, (assumed tropical:) [concealed] enmities, and sayings that give pain; [the former of these two meanings being] from zarabotu Albahoma fiI AlzRariybapi, i. e. Oadoxalotuhu: [the latter of them app. suggested by another reading, namely, zaOaAnibu in the place of zaraAbiIRu; mentioned and thus explained in the Ham ubi suprà: the poet, therefore, is supposed to have meant, upon our state of union, or concord, (cAt bynnA having two contr. significations,) have supervened concealed enmities, &c.:] or, as some say, the reading in the deewán of Artáh is zaraAYibu, as though pl. of zariybapN↓, which is likewise made to denote enmity because it is made to enter (tuzorabu, i. e. tudoxalu,) into the heart; or which may be metaphorically applied to a place of enmity latent in the bosom, from the same word as signifying the “ place in which are put lambs, or kids, and sheep, or goats: ” or, supposing the right reading to be zaraAbiIRu↓, the poet may very properly mean, upon the vacant space between our tents, or houses, are carpets (TanaAfis and busuT) spread for us, and we sit thereon, near together in the places, but with the hearts remote: (idem p. 195:) but with the reading zaOaAnibu, mentioned above, occurs another variation, thus: EalaI caAka bayonanaA zaOaAnibu; meaning, notwithstanding that, between us are sayings that give pain. (Idem p. 196.)

wayolN lilzRarobiyRapi↓, occurring in a trad., is said to mean (tropical:) Wo to those who go in to lords, or princes, and, when they say what is evil, or say anything, say, He has spoken truth: such persons being likened, in respect of their variable conduct, to one of the zaraAbiIR mentioned above in the first sentence of this paragraph; or to sheep, or goats, which are thus called in relation to the zarob, i. e. the enclosure to which they repair, because they are obsequious to the lords, or princes, and follow their steps with the submissiveness of sheep or goats to their pastor. (TA.)

Accord. to El-Muärrij, (TA,) zaraAbiIRu↓ is applied to plants, as meaning Such as have become yellow, or red, while having in them greenness: (K, TA:) and when they saw the colours in carpets and other articles of furniture that are spread, they likened them to such plants. (TA.)
zarobiyRapN and zirobiyRapN and zurobiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

[Golius, finding the second and third of these words expl. by the Pers. XAdrwAn, (which is often applied by Arabs in the present day to “ an artificial fountain that throws up water, ”) has erroneously, as Freytag has observed, supposed that they may signify “ Euripus, fons in altum saliens. ”]
zariybapN: see zarobN, in two places: and see 1, first sentence.
Also (assumed tropical:) The lurking-place of a beast of prey. (S, K.)
See also zirobiIRN.
zaraAbiIRu: see zirobiIRN, in five places.

ziroyaAbN, (in the CK zirobAb,) an arabicized word, (K, TA,) from [the Pers.] zaro Mbo, the hemzeh [in Mbo, for OaAbo,] being changed into I, (TA,) Gold: (IAar, K:) or the water thereof [i. e. water-gold; which may be deemed the more correct, as agreeing with the original]. (K.)
And Anything yellow. (K.)

Also A certain black singingbird; (MF, TA;) called also Abw zwlq, [app. a mistranscription for Abw zryq, as in Freytag's Lex., i. e. Oabuw zurayoqK,] accord. to the book entitled “ Mantik et-Teyr. ” (TA.)
mizoraAbN i. q. mirozaAbN [q. v., said to be not a chaste word]. (K.)
mazorubaAnN: see marozubaAnN, in art. rzb.
Q. 1. zarojanapN (as an inf. n. TK) i. q. taxaArujN [q. v.]: (K) one says, zarojanuwA, meaning taxaArajuwA. (TK.)

And The being deceitful, wicked, dishonest, or dissimulating, and mischief-making; or very deceitful &c.: and the act of deceiving, deluding, beguiling, circumventing, or outwitting: (K:) one says, zarojanahu, meaning He deceived him, deluded him, &c. (TK.)

zarajuwnN, (S, K,) which is also written zurojuwnN, like EuSofuwrN, is mentioned in art. zrj and also in
the present art. by the author of the K, though he charges J with error in mentioning it in this art. because muzarRajN is used by a rájiz as meaning “ intoxicated: ” whereas J is not in error, but is right, in doing thus; for the n is radical accord. to the generality of the lexicologists and the authors on inflection, like the s in qarabuwsN; and the rájiz above referred to elided the n in forming muzarRajN because he imagined it to be augmentative: (MF in art. zrj:) it signifies Wine; (S, K;) and is a Pers. word, (As, Sh, Seer, S,) originally zrkwn, [i. e. zaroGuwno,] (Sh, TA,) meaning “ goldcoloured: ” (As, Sh, Seer, S:) or it signifies, (S, Mgh,) or signifies also [like as does EinabN, of which the primary signification is “ grapes ”], (K,) the grape-vine; (ISh, S, Mgh, K;) n. un. with p; (ISh, TA;) and pl. zaraAjiynu: (Mgh:) it has this meaning in the dial. of Et-Táïf: (ISh, TA in art. zrj:) or the shoots of a grape-vine: (Mgh, K:) thus in the dial. of Et-Táïf and ElGhowr: (TA in the present art.:) or a shoot that is planted, of a grape-vine. (AHn, TA.)
Also A certain red dye. (El-Jarmee, S, K.)

And Water that remains or stagnates, or collects, or remains long and becomes altered, or becomes yellow and altered, in a rock: (K in art. zrj:) or clear water that remains or stagnates, &c., in a mountain. (MF, TA.)

1. zarida, aor.
zarada
, (S, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. zarodN, (S, L, Msb,) or zaradN; (TA; [but this I find not in any other lexicon;]) or zarada, (A, Mgh,) or this also, aor.
zaruda
, inf. n. zarodN and zaradaAnN; this latter form of the verb being mentioned by IDrd in the Jm, and ISd in the M, and IKtt in the Af'ál; but it is disapproved by Th, and asserted by his expositors to be vulgar; (TA;) and Aizodarada↓, (S, * A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. AizodiraAdN (S, A) and muzodaradN; (A, TA;) and tzrRd↓; (A, TA;) and AizodaAra, mentioned by 'Amr El-Mutarriz, but this is the most strange; (TA;) He swallowed (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) a morsel, or mouthful, (S, A, Msb, K,) or water, (Mgh,) [and medicine; for] you say dawaMCN SaEobu Almuzodaradi↓ [A medicine difficult to swallow]. (A, TA.) And one says of a man swearing, HaSRaMCa tazarRadahaA↓ and tazabRadahaA HacRaMCa (tropical:) [He swallowed it; meaning, took it hastily; i. e. the oath]. (A, TA.)

zaradahu, aor.
zaruda
(S, K) and
zarida
, (TA, and so in a copy of the S, as well as
zaruda
,) or zarada Haloqahu, (A, TA, [in my copy of the A written zarRada,]) inf. n. zarodN, (S,) He strangled him, or throttled him, or squeezed his throat; syn. xanaqahu, (S, K,) or EaSara Haloqahu. (A.) And zaradahu He took him, or seized him, by his throat. (TA.)

zarada AldRiroEa, (K,) inf. n. zarodN, (S, A,) He fabricated the coat of mail, by inserting the rings one into another; i. q. saradahaA: (K:) AlzRarodu is like AlsRarodu, meaning the inserting (tadaAxul [an intrans. inf. n. here used as though it were trans., as is shown in the S in art. srd,]) of the rings of a coat of mail, one into another: (S:) [or, as Z says,] zarodu AldRiroEi means saroduhaA, because the coat of mail consists of narrow, or close, rings: (A:) the z is said to be a substitute for s. (L, TA.)

2. zrRd Eayonahu EalaI SaAHibihi (tropical:) He was angry with his companion, and looked sternly, austerely, or morosely, at him; i. e. he contracted his eye in looking at him, and did not open it until he had satisfied it with gazing at him. (A, TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.
8. Aizodarada, inf. n. AizodiraAdN and muzodaradN: see 1, in two places.
zarodN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

zaradN, (S, A, K,) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (A,) A coat of mail; (S, A, K;) as also zarodN↓, which is an inf. n. used as a subst. [and therefore used as a sing. and a pl., and applied, as is also zaradN to anything made of mail, a piece of mail, and rings in general, like sarodN, q. v.], (A,) and zaradiyRapN↓: (mentioned as syn. with diroEN in art. drE in the Msb and in the TA, on the authority of IAth:) the pl. of zarodN↓ is zuruwdN. (TA.) [See also raforafN and mgofarN.]
zaridN Quick in swallowing: (K:) but in the Nawádir el-Aaráb, food that is soft, and quick in descending [in the throat]. (TA.)

zurodapN [The quantity that is swallowed at once; like juroEapN and buloEapN;] a morsel, or small mouthful: so in the saying, ZanRa fulaAnN OanRiI zurodapN lahu (tropical:) [Such a one thought that I was a morsel for him]. (A, TA.)
zarodaAnN A guest: as though he throttled his companion. (A, TA.)

zaradaAnN The vulva of a woman: (K, TA:) accord. to some, (TA,) so called because it swallows (yazodaridN), or because it compresses (yazorudu [in the CK yazodaridu again]), (K, TA,) i. e. yaxonuqu, (TA,) the Ouyuwr, by its straitness. (K, TA.)
zaradiyRapN: see zaradN.

ziraAdN (S, K) and mizoradN↓ (K) A cord by which the throat of a camel is compressed, in order that he may not eject his cud therefrom and bespatter his rider. (S, K.) The former word is also expl. in the K by mixonaqapN, [in some copies of the K mixofafap,] which signifies the same. (TA.)
ziraAdapN The art of fabricating coats of mail; (A, TA;) as also siraAdapN. (TA.)
zarRaAdN A strangler or one who throttles, or squeezes the throat; syn. xanRaAqN. (A, TA.)
And A fabricator of coats of mail; (S, A, K;) as also sarRaAdN. (TA.)
mazoradN [The place of strangling or throttling; like muzarRadN↓; meaning] the fauces; (S, K, TA;) the throat, or gullet. (TA.)
mizoradN: see ziraAdN.

muzarRadN: see mazoradN. One says, Oaxaca bimuzarRadihi, like Oaxaca bimuxanRaqihi, [properly He, or it, seized his throat, or throttled him, or choked him,] meaning (tropical:) he, or it, straitened him. (A, TA.)
mazoruwdN Strangled, throttled, or having his throat squeezed. (TA.) And, applied to the fauces [or throat], Squeezed, or compressed. (S.)
Q. 1. zarodamahu, (S, K,) inf. n. zarodamapN, (TA,) He squeezed his throat: (S, K:) or he throttled him; or strangled him: (K:) as also zarodabahu. (TA.)
And He swallowed it. (K.)
zarodamapN inf. n. of the verb above. (TA.)

Also The place of swallowing: (S, K:) or the galoSamap [or epiglottis]: (K:) or, as some say, it is [the part] beneath the Huloquwm [or windpipe: or, app., the part beneath the head of the Hlqwm]: and in it, or upon it, is set the tongue: some say that the word is Pers. [in origin; app. holding it to be arabicized from the Pers. zarodamano, which signifies the “ windpipe ”]. (TA.)
ziraATN: see siraATN.

1. zaraEa, aor.
zaraEa
, (K,) inf. n. zaroEN (S, TA) and ziraAEapN, (TA,) He sowed, or cast seed; (S, K, TA;) as also AizodaraEa↓, (S, Msb, K,) originally AizotaraEa, the t being changed into d in order that it may agree with the z, (S, K,) for d and z are pronounced with the voice as well as the breath, whereas t is pronounced with the breath only: (S, TA:) [or the latter verb, as appears from an explanation of it to be found below, may signify he sowed for himself.] They say, mano zaraEa HaSada [He who sows reaps]. (TA.) And [they use this verb transitively, saying,] zaraEotu AlburRa waAlXRaEiyra [I sowed wheat and barley]: and in like manner, zaraEotu AlXRajara [I sowed the trees; or sowed the seeds which should produce the trees: or it may signify I planted the trees]. (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed.) And zaraEa AlHubRa laka fiI Alquluwbi karamuka waHusonu xuluqika (tropical:) [Thy generosity and the goodness of thy disposition have sown love for thee in the hearts]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., mano kaAnato lahu OaroDN faliyazoraEohaA Oawo liyamonaHohaA OaxaAhu faUino OabaI faliyumosiko OaroDahu [Whoso hath land,] let him sow it [or let him lend it, or give it, to his brother; and if he refuse, let him retain his land]. (TA.)

zaraEa AlOaroDa, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. zaroEN, (Msb,) signifies [also] (tropical:) He ploughed up, or tilled, or cultivated, the land, or ground, for sowing. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence [the saying in a trad.], UicaA zaraEato hecihi AlOumRapu nuziEa minohaA AlnRaSoru (tropical:) When this nation shall employ itself altogether with agriculture and the affairs of the present world, and turn away from warring against unbelievers and the like, aid shall be withdrawn from it. (Mgh.)

zaraEahu QllRehu signifies God caused it, or made it, to grow, vegetate, or
germinate; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and, to increase; (Mgh;) namely, AlHarova [the seed-produce]. (Mgh, Msb;) The verb is properly thus used of divine affairs, exclusively of human: (Er-Rághib:) and hence the saying in the Kur [lvi. 63-4], OafaraOayotumo maA taHoruvuwna OaOanotumo tazoraEuwnahu Oamo naHonu AlzRaAriEuwna (S, * Er-Rághib) Now think ye, what ye sow, do ye cause it to grow, or are We the causers of growth? (Bd:) or, as some say, do ye cause it to increase, or are We the causers of its increase? the Harov [or sowing] being ascribed to them, and the zaroE [or causing to grow] exclusively to God: when the latter is ascribed to a man, it is because he is an agent as a means of making to grow; as when you say, OanobatRu kacaA (assumed tropical:) I was a means of causing such a thing to grow. (Er-Rághib.) [In like manner,] you say, zaroEFA AizodaraEa↓, meaning (tropical:) [He raised seed-produce, i. e., was a means of causing it to grow,] for himself, in particular. (TA.)

[Hence,] one says, with respect to a child, zaraEahu QllRehu (tropical:) May God render him sound and strong; syn. jabarahu: (S, K, TA:) like as one says Oanobatahu QllRehu: and in like manner, zaraEa QllRehu waladaka liloxayori (tropical:) [May God render thine offspring sound and strong, or rather, cause thine offspring to grow up, for the doing, or enjoyment, of what is good]. (TA.)

[Hence also,] zuriEa lahu baEodu XaqaAwapK (tropical:) [An increase was made for him after adversity; or] he obtained property after want; for the verb in this instance is like EuniIa. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

3. muzaAraEapN is of the measure mufaAEalapN, [denoting a mutual action,] from AlzRiraAEapu, (Mgh,) and its signification is well known; (S;) i. e. (tropical:) The making a contract, or bargain, with another, for labour upon land, [to till and sow and cultivate it, as is indicated in the Mgh and Msb,] for a share, or portion, of its produce, (Msb, K, TA,) the seed being from the owner of the land. (K, TA.) [You say, zaAraEahu (tropical:) He made with him a contract, or bargain, such as is above described; and in like manner, xaAbarahu, and Mkarahu. The doing this is forbidden, because of the uncertainty of the result.]

4. AzrE It (a plant, or herbage,) had, or became in the state of having, zaroE [i. e. produce of its seed; i. e. it grew from its seed]: (TA:) and, said of zaroE [or seed-produce], it became tall: (K:) or, as some say, it produced its leaves: and it attained to the proper time for its being reaped. (TA.)
