zilofN A meadow; syn. rawoDapN; (TS, K;) and so zalafapN↓: (IB, TA:) thus the latter is expl. as occurring in a trad. relating to Ya-jooj and Ma-jooj, in which it is said, vumRa yurosilu QllRehu maTarFA fayagosilu AlOaroDa HatRaI yatorukahaA kaAlzRalafapi [Then God will send rain, and it will wash the earth so that it will leave it like the meadow]: but in this instance, several other meanings are assigned to it: see zalafapN below. (TA.)
zalafN: see zulofapN, in two places:
and see also zalafapN, in five places.
zulufN: see its accus. case voce zulofapN, near the end of the paragraph.

zulofapN i. q. qurobapN [i. e. Nearness, with respect to rank, degree, or station]; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also zulofaI↓, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) and zalafN↓. (IDrd, O, K.) [It would seem that it means also Nearness with respect to place or situation: for SM immediately adds,] hence, in the Kur [lxvii. 27], falamRaA raOawohu zulofapF, [as though meaning But when they shall see it in a state of nearness: but] Zj says that the meaning is, but when they shall see it (i. e. the punishment) near (qariybFA): and several authors say that zulofapN is sometimes used in the sense of qariybN, as is stated in the 'Ináyeh. (TA.) And Station, rank, grade, or degree; as also zulofaI↓, (S, O, K, TA,) and zalofN↓, (TS, K,) and zalafN↓: (K, TA:) pl. of the first zulafN: (S, * TA:) or (K) zulofaI↓ is a quasi-inf. n.; (S, K;) and such it is in the saying in the Kur [xxxiv. 36], wamaA OamowaAlukumo walaA OawolaAdukumo biQlRatiI tuqarRibukumo EinodinaA zulofaI, as though meaning QzodilaAfFA [i. e. And neither your riches nor your children are what will bring you near to us in advancement: but here it may be well rendered, in station]: (S:) accord. to Ibn- 'Arafeh, zulofaI signifies the bringing very near: (TA:) the saying of Ibn-El-Tilimsánee that it is pl. of zulofapN is very strange, and unknown; the correct pl. of this last word being zulafN. (MF, TA.)

Also A portion (S, K) of the first part (S) of the night, (S, K,) whether small or large: so accord. to Th: or, accord. to Akh, of the night absolutely: (TA:) pl. zulafN and zulafaAtN (S, K) and zulufaAtN and zulofaAtN: or zulafN signifies the hours, or periods, (saAEaAt,) of the night, commencing from the daytime, and the hours, or periods, of the daytime, commencing from the night: (K:) and its sing. is zulofapN. (TA.) wazulafFA mina AllRayoli, in the Kur [xi. 116], means And at sunset and nightfall (the magorib and the EiXaMC): (Zj, TA:) some read zulufFA↓, with two dammehs; which may be a sing., like HulumN; or a pl. of zulofapN, like as busurN is of busurapN, with damm to the s in each: [but this is not a parallel instance; for busurN is a coll. gen. n. of which busurapN is the n. un., and the latter is not of the same measure as zulofapN:] and some read zulofFA↓, which is a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of zulofapN, like as durRN is of durRapN; (K, TA;) or pl. of zaliyfN↓, like as qurobN is of qariybN, and gurobN of gariybN: (TA:) and some read zulofaI↓, in which the alif [written I] is a denotative of the fem. gender. (K, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

zalafapN A full [reservoir of water such as is called] maSonaEap: (S, K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] zalafN↓: (S:) so, accord. to Sh, in the trad. mentioned voce zilofN: (TA:) or zalafN↓ signifies full watering-troughs, (K,) as pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of zalafapN: (TA:) or a full watering-trough. (K.) Also A [bowl such as is called] SaHofap: (K;) and so zulofapN↓; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) of which the pl. is zulafN: (TA:) or a full SaHofap; and its pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is zalafN↓. (Lth, TA.) Also A green [vessel of the kind called] UijRaAnap: (K:) so says AO: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] zalafN↓; and mazaAlifu↓ likewise signifies green OajaAjiyn [app. as an anomalous pl. of zalafapN or of zalafN, like as maXaAbihu is of XabahN]; both, also, mentioned on the authority of AO. (TA.)

Also A mother-of-pearl-'shell, or an oyster-shell; syn. SadafapN: (K:) Kt says that AlzRalafap in the trad. mentioned above voce zilofN has been expl. as meaning the maHaArap, i. e. the Sadafap; but he adds, I know not this explanation, unless a pool of water be called mHArp because the water returns (yaHuwru) to it and collects in it. (TA.)

Also A smooth rock: (K:) so, too, said to mean in the same trad.: and some read Alzlqp. (TA.) And Rugged ground. (K.) And Swept ground. (K.) And An even part of a soft mountain. (K.) Pl. (K) [or rather coll. gen. n.] in all these senses (TA) zalafN↓. (K.)
See also zilofN.

Also A mirror: (O, K: [in the CK, AlmaroOapu is put in the place of AlmiroMpu:]) [like zalaqapN:] mentioned by IB on the authority of Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, and by Sgh on that of Ks: and so, too, it is said to mean in the trad. mentioned above; the earth being likened thereto because of its evenness and cleanness: (TA:) or the face thereof; (K;) as is said by IAar. (TA.)
zulofaI: see zulofapN, in four places.

EuqobapN zaluwfN [A stage of a journey] far-extend-
ing: (O, K:) so says IF. (O.) [In the CK, EaqabapN is erroneously put for EuqobapN.]

zaliyfN Advancing; or going forward, or before. (O, K. [It is said in the TA that AlmutaqadRimu as the explanation of AlzRaliyfu is erroneously put in the copies of the K for AltRaqadRumu: but this assertion is app. itself erroneous.]) See zulofapN, near the end of the paragraph.

[Oazolafu expl. by Golius as on the authority of the KL, and by Freytag after him, as meaning Parvo naso præditus ejusque recto ac parvo mucrone, is a mistake for Oacolafu, thus written in my copy of the KL.]
[OazolafapN and OazolafaI expl. by Freytag as meaning Copia parva, cœtus hominum parvus, as on the authority of El-Meydánee, are app. mistakes for OazofalapN and OazofalaI.]

mazolafapN Any town (qaroyapN) that is between the desert and the cultivated land: pl. mazaAlifu: (S, * K:) the latter is syn. with baraAgiylu, signifying the towns (bilaAd) that are between the cultivated land and the desert; (S;) or, between the desert and the baHor [i.e. sea or great river]; such as El-Ambár and El-Kádiseeyeh. (M, TA.)
[The pl.] mazaAlifu also signifies Places of ascent; or steps, or stairs, by which one ascends: (K:) because they bring one near to the place to which he ascends. (TA.)
For the pl. mazaAlifu, see also zalafapN.

1. zaliqa, aor.
zalaqa
, (K,) inf. n. zalaqN; (TA;) and zalaqa, aor.
zaluqa
, (K,) inf. n. zaloqN; (TA;) He slipped; syn. zalRa; (K, TA;) for which calRa is erroneously put in [some of] the copies of the K. (TA. [See also 5.]) And zaliqato rijoluhu, (S,) or Alqadamu, (Msb,) aor.
zalaqa
, inf. n. zalaqN, (S, Msb,) His foot, (S,) or the foot, (Msb,) slipped, (S,) or did not remain firm, or fixed, in its place. (Msb.) The former is also said of an arrow, [app. as meaning It slid along the ground,] like zahiqa [q. v.]. (JK in art. zhq.)
zaliqa bimakaAnihi and zalaqa, He was, or became, disgusted by, or with, his place, or he loathed it, and removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance, from it. (K, TA.)
zalaqato, said of a she-camel, She was, or became, quick, or swift. (O, TA.)
zalaqahu: see 4.

zalaqahu Eano makaAnihi, aor.
zaliqa
, (K,) inf. n. zaloqN, (TA,) He removed him from his place. (K, TA.) Hence the reading of Aboo-Jaafar and Náfi', [in the Kur lxviii. 51,] waUino yakaAdu QlRaciyna kafaruwA layazoliquwnaka biOaboSaArihimo, meaning [And verily they who have disbelieved almost] smite thee with their evil eyes so as to remove thee from thy station in which God has placed thee, by reason of enmity to thee. (TA. [Or this reading may be rendered agreeably with the common reading: see 4.])

zalaqa raOosahu, (S, K,) aor.
zaliqa
, inf. n. zaloqN, (S,) He shaved his head; as also Azlqhu↓; and zlRqhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tazoliyqN: (S:) IB says that, accord. to 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, it is only zabaqahu, with b; and that AlzRaboqu means the plucking out; not the shaving: but accord. to Fr, one says of him who has shaved his head qd zlqh, [whether with or without teshdeed is not shown,] and Azlqh. (TA.)
2. zlRq, [inf. n. tazoliyqN,] He made a place slippery, (K, TA,) so that it became like the mazolaqap; and thus too though there be no water therein. (TA.)

Accord. to the O and K, [the inf. n.] tazoliyqN also signifies The anointing the body with oils and the like, so that it becomes like the mazolaqap; to which is added in the O, and though it be without water: but this is a confusion of two meanings; one of which is the first expl. above in this paragraph; and the other is, the anointing the body with oils and the like; as in the L and the Tekmileh. (TA.)
See also 4.
And see 1, last sentence.
zlRq AlHadiydapa He made the iron thing to be always sharp. (K.)
rlRqhu bibaSarihi, inf. n. as above, He looked sharply, or intently, at him, or it. (Ez-Zejjájee, TA.)
See also 2, last sentence, in art. dlS.

4. Azlqhu He made him to slip; as also zalaqahu↓. (K.) All the readers except those of El-Medeeneh read, [in the Kur lxviii. 51,] waUino yakaAdu QlRaciyna kafaruwA layuzoliquwnaka biOaboSaArihimo, meaning [And verily those who have disbelieved] almost make thee to fall by their looking hard at thee, with vehement hatred: so accord. to El-'Otbee: or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) [almost] smite thee with their [evil] eyes: (TA:) [it is also said that] Azlq fulaAnFA bibaSarihi means (tropical:) he looked at such a one with the look of a person affected with displeasure, or anger: (K:) or so naZara UilaI fulaAnK faOazolaqahu bibaSarihi: (Jm, TA:) and in this sense, also, is expl. the saying in the Kur mentioned above. (TA.) One says also Azlq rijolahu, (S,) or Alqadama, (Msb,) He made his (another's) foot to slip, (S,) or he made the foot not to remain firm, or fixed, in its place; and so zalRaqahaA↓. (Msb.)

Azlqt, said of a camel, (S, K, TA,) and of a mare, (TA,) She cast her young one; syn. OasoqaTato; (S, TA;) or OajohaDato [q. v.]: (K:) or she (a mare) cast forth her young one completely formed: or, as some say, [her fœtus] not completely formed: (JK:) and you say also, Azlqt bijaniynihaA, like OamolaSato bh [q. v.]: (Abu-l- 'Abbás, TA in art. mlS:) or Azlqt waladahaA is said of a female [of any kind], and means she cast forth her young one before it was completely formed. (Mgh.)
See also 1, last sentence.

5. tzlRq He, or it, slipped, or slid, along; (KL;) like tzlRj. (S and TA in art. zlj. [See also 1.]) One says, tzlRqt AlgudRapu bayona Aljilodi waAllRaHomi [The ganglion slipped about between the skin and the flesh]. (M in art. dyS.)
[Also It was, or became, smooth, or slippery: a signification indicated in the M, in art. mls, where it is coupled with AisotawaI.]
He anointed his body with oils and the like. (JK.)

He ornamented, or adorned, himself; (Aboo-Turáb, K, TA;) as also tzbRq: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) and led an easy, and a soft, or delicate, life, so that his colour, and the exterior of his skin, had a shining, or glistening. (K, TA.)
zaloqN: see the next paragraph.

makaAnN zalaqN, (S,) or zalaqN [alone], (K,) which is originally an inf. n., (S,) and zaliqN↓ and zaloqN↓ (K) and zalaAqapN↓ and mazolaqN↓ and mazolaqapN↓, (S, K, TA, [the last two erroneously written in the CK mizolaq and mizolaqap,]) all signify the same; (K;) A slippery place; a place on which the foot does not remain firm, or fixed. (S, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xviii. 38], fatuSobiHa SaEiydFA zalaqFA, i. e., [So that it shall become] smooth ground, with nothing in it, or with no plants in it: or, accord. to Akh, such that the feet shall not stand firmly upon it. (TA.) A poet says, (TA,) namely, Mohammad Ibn-Besheer, (Ham p. 551,)

L.foreign: famano EalaA zalaqFA Eano girRapK zalajaA

sense.s: [Appoint for thy foot, before the stepping, its place upon which it shall fall, or, as in the Ham p. 522, simply its place, (mawoDiEahaA,)] for he who goes upon a slippery place, in consequence of inadvertence, slips]. (TA.)
zalaqN also signifies The rump of a horse or similar beast. (S, K, TA.)
zaliqN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Applied to a man, Quickly angry (O, K) at what is said. (O)

And, (T, S, K,) as also zumaliqN↓ (T, S, and K in art. zmlq) and zumRaliqN↓ and zumaAliqN↓, (S, and K in art. zmlq,) applied to a man, (T, S,) Qui semen emittit quum verba mulieri facit, sine congressu: (T, TA:) or qui semen emittit ante initum. (S, K.)
zalaqapN A smooth rock; (K;) as also zalafapN. (K in art. zlf.)
And, (AZ, K,) as also the latter word, (AZ, TA,) A mirror. (AZ, K. [In the CK, AlmaroOapu is erroneously put for AlmiroMpu.])
naAqapN zaluwqN A quick, or swift, she-camel; (AZ, K;) as also zaluwjN. (AZ, TA.)
And EuqobapN zaluwqN [and zaluwjN and zaluwxN, in the CK, erroneously, EaqabapN,] A far-extending [stage of a journey]. (K, TA.)

zaliyqN i. q. siqoTN [meaning A young one, or fœtus, that falls from the belly of the mother abortively, or in an immature, or imperfect, state, or dead, but having the form developed, or manifest]. (S, K.)
zalaAqapN: see zalaqN.
zulRayoqN The smooth peach; (S, K;) called in Pers. Xiyfotaho ranoG. (S.)
zumaliqN and zumRaliqN and zumaAliqN: see zaliqN.
ziyHN zayolaqN A wind swift in its passage. (Kr, TA.)
AlzRaAluwqu the name of a shield belonging to the Prophet; meaning That from which the weapon slips off, so that it does not wound the bearer. (TA.)
Oazolaqu (K in art. dlS) Hairless and glistening in body. (TK in that art.)
mazolaqN: see zalaqN.
mazolaqapN: see zalaqN. [Hence,] one says, huwa EalaI mazolaqapi AlbaATili [He is on the slippery way of false religion or the like]. (MF voce jaAdRapN, q. v.)
mizolaAqN i. q. mizolaAjN, (K,) a dial. var. of the latter word, [q. v.,] meaning The thing by means of which a door is closed, or made fast, and which is opened without a key. (S, K.)
Also A mare [or other female (see 4)] that often casts her young; (S, K;) i. e., that usually does so; and applied in this sense to a camel. (TA.)
Q. 1. zaloqama He swallowed a gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful. (TA.)
[The inf. n.] zaloqamapN signifies [also], accord. to IB, The being wide, broad, or ample. (TA.)
zuloqumN The sea; from zaloqamapN meaning as expl. above; as also qulozumN. (IKh, TA.)
zuloquwmN i. q. HuloquwmN [The windpipe]. (IDrd, S in art. zqm, L, and K.)
Also The xuroTuwm [i. e. nose, or fore part thereof,] of a dog: and of a beast of prey: and, accord. to IAar, [the proboscis] of an elephant. (TA.)

1. zalama, (aor.
zaluma
, inf. n. zalomN, TK,) He cut off one's nose [and app. anything projecting, or prominent: see 2: and see also 8]. (ISh, K.)
(assumed tropical:) He made his gift little, or small, in quantity or amount; (S, K;) [as though he cut off something from it;] in [some of the copies of] the S, [but not so in mine,] zlRm↓. (TA.)
He filled (S, K) a water-ing-trough, or tank, (S,) or a vessel; (K;) as also zlRm↓, inf. n. tazoliymN. (AHn, K.)

2. zlRm AlsRahoma, (S, K, *) inf. n. tazoliymN, (K,) He cut [or pared] the arrow, and made its proportion or conformation, and its workmanship, good: (S:) [he shaped it well:] or he made it even and supple. (K.) And zulRima is said of anything as meaning Its edges were pared off. (TA.) [Hence,] zlRm AlrRaHaI He made the mill-stone round, and took from its edges. (K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,

[Like the mill-stones of Rakd (a mountain so called) which the picks have rounded by taking from their edges]: he likens the foot of the camel to a mill-stone from the edges of which the maEaAwil have taken, (S, TA,) and which they have made even. (TA.) And zalRamotu AlHajara signifies I cut the stone, and prepared it properly for a millstone. (TA.)
See also 1, in two places.
zlRm gicaMCahu (assumed tropical:) He made his food, or nutriment, bad, [i. e. fed him ill,] (K, TA,) so that his body became small. (TA.)
8. Aizodalama He cut off one's head. (ISh, K.) And He extirpated one's nose. (K.)
zalomN or zulomN, whence the phrase huwa AlEabodu zalomFA: see zalomap.

zalamN and zulamN↓ An arrow without a head and without feathers: pl. OazolaAmN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) which was applied to those [divining-] arrows by means of which the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance sought to know what was allotted to them: (S, K:) they were arrows upon which the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance wrote “ Command ” and “ Prohibition; ” (Mgh, Msb;) or upon some of which was written “ My Lord hath commanded me; ” and upon some, “ My Lord hath forbidden me; ” (Har p. 465;) or they were three arrows; upon one of which was written “ My Lord hath commanded me; ” and upon another, “ My Lord hath forbidden me; ” and the third was blank; (Bd in v. 4;) and they put them in a receptacle, (Mgh, Msb,) and when any one of them desired to make a journey, or to accomplish a want, (Mgh,) or when he desired to perform some affair, (Msb,) he put his hand into that receptacle, (Mgh, Msb,) and took forth an arrow; (Msb;) and if the arrow upon which was “ Command ” [or “ My Lord hath commanded me ” (Har ubi suprà)] came forth, he went to accomplish his purpose; but if that upon which was “ Prohibition ” [or “ My Lord hath forbidden me ” (Har)] came forth, he refrained; (Mgh, Msb;) and if the blank came forth, they shuffled them a second time: (Bd ubi suprà:) or, as some say, the AzlAm were white pebbles, upon which they thus wrote, and by means of which they sought to know what was allotted to them in the manner expl. above: (Har ubi suprà:) or, accord. to Az, the AzlAm [were arrows that] belonged to Kureysh, in the Time of Ignorance, upon which were written “ He hath commanded ” and “ He hath forbidden, ” and “ Do thou ” and “ Do thou not; ” they had been well shaped (zulRimato) and made even, and placed in the Kaabeh, the ministers of the House taking care of them; and when a man desired to go on a journey, or to marry, he came to the minister, and said, “ Take thou forth for me a zlm; ” and thereupon he would take it forth, and look at it; and if the arrow of command came forth, he went to accomplish that which he had purposed to do; but if the arrow of prohibition came forth, he refrained from that which he desired to do: [it is said that] there were seven of the arrows thus called with the minister of the Kaabeh, having marks upon them, and used for this purpose: (Jel in v. 4:) and sometimes there were with the man two such arrows, which he put into his sword-case; and when he desired to seek the knowledge of what was allotted to him, he took forth one of them. (TA.) Some say that the OazolaAm are The arrows of the game called Almayosir: but this is a mistake. (TA.) The seeking to obtain the knowledge of what is allotted to one by means of the AzlAm is forbidden in the Kur v. 4. (TA.)

Hence, OazolaAmu Albaqarapi (tropical:) The legs of the [wild] ox or cow: likened to the arrows called AzlAm because of their slenderness: or, accord. to the A, because of their strength and hardness. (TA.) [Hence, likewise,] the former of the two words (zalamN) signifies also (assumed tropical:) A strong and light or active boy: pl. as above: (TA:) [app. because] a poet likens [such] a boy to an arrow of the kind thus called. (S, TA. *)

Also, both words, (K,) the latter on the authority of Kr, (TA,) A cloven hoof: (K:) accord. to some, peculiarly of the ox-kind: (TA:) or the [projecting] thing that is behind it: (S, K:) pl. as above. (K, * TA.)
And the latter of the same two words, (AA, S,) or each of them, (K,) [The hyrax Syriacus;] one of the [animals called] wibaAr [pl. of waborN]: pl. as above. (AA, S, K.)
zulamN: see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.

huwaAlEabodu zalomapF and zulomapF↓ and zalamapF↓ and zulamapF↓, [the last omitted in some copies of the K,] (S, K,) and also with n in the place of the l, (S and K in art. znm) (assumed tropical:) He is one whose proportion, or conformation, (S, K,) or whose cut, (K,) is that of the slave: (S, K:) or he is the slave in truth: (Ks, S:) or he resembles the slave as though he were he: (Lh, K:) it is as though one said, hw AlEbd mazoluwmFA↓, i. e. he is the slave, being thus created by God, so that every one who looks at him sees the characteristics of the slaves impressed upon him: and it is a prov. applied to him who is low, ignoble, or mean: (Meyd:) [i. e.,] one says thus in disapproval (fI Alnkrp [i. e. fiI AlnRakarapi] or fI AlnRakirapi): (Lh: so in different copies of the S:) and in like manner one says of the female slave [hiIa AlOamapu zalomapF &c.]: (Lh, S, K:) As said, huwa AlEabodu zalomapu, using the nom. case, without tenween; but IAar said, hw AlEbd zalomapF, using the accus. case, with tenween: so in the handwriting of 'Abd-Es-Selám El-Basree: (TA:) and accord. to Lh, one says, yaA fataI hecaA AlEabodu zalomFA↓, (so in some copies of the S,) or zulomFA↓, (so in other copies of the S, and in the TA,) with damm, (TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) This is the slave in proportion, or conformation, and in cut, O young man: (S, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, truly. (TA.)
zulomap: see the next preceding paragraph.

zalamapN [A kind of wattle]: zalamataA AlEanozi means the zanamataAni of the she-goat: (K:) or, accord. to Kh, zalamapN signifies a certain appertenance of goats; a thing hanging from their Huluwq [here meaning throats, externally,] like the [kind of ear-ring called] quroT; the animal having two of such things: if an appertenance of the ear, it is called zanamapN, [q. v.,] with n. (S, TA.) See also Oazolamu.
See also zalomap.
zulamap: see zalomap.
zaliymN: see muzalRamN.
naAIN zulaAmiIRN: see zunaAmiIRN, in art. znm.

Oazolamu (K) and muzalRamN↓, (A'Obeyd, K,) as also [Oazonamu and zanimN and] muzanRamN [applied to a camel], (TA,) Having the end of the ear cut, (A'Obeyd, K,) a [portion termed] zalamap↓ or zanamap being left [hanging] to it: (A'Obeyd, TA:) this is done only to camels of generous race, (A'Obeyd, K,) and to sheep or goats: the fem. of the first is zalomaMCu: (K:) [see also zanimN: or] Oazolamu, fem. as above, is applied to a goat, as meaning having what are termed zalamataAni [dual of zalamapN expl. above]. (S.)

AlOazolamu AljadaEu signifies The mountain-goat; (K;) agreeably with the original meaning; (TA;) and so AlmuzalRamu↓: (K:
[in the CK, wa is erroneously omitted between the words AlwaEilu and AlSRagiyru AljuvRapi:]) and AlzRalomaMCu signifies The female mountain-goat. (Kr, K.)

And also, i. e. AlAzlm AljcE, (K,) because it is [as though it were] always jacaE, not becoming old, (TA,) (tropical:) Time, or fortune, (S, K,) that is hard, or rigorous, (K,) in its course, (TA,) abounding with trials (K) and deaths: accord. to Yaakoob, so called because deaths hang upon it, and follow it. (TA.) They said, OawodaI bihi AlOazolamu AljacaEu and AlOazonamu AljacaEu, [q. v.] i. e. (assumed tropical:) Time, or fortune, [&c.,] destroyed it; relating to a thing that has gone, and passed, and of which one has despaired. (TA.) [See also art. jcE.]
AlzRalomaMCu also signifies The female of the hawk kind. (Kr, K.)

muzalRamN, applied to an arrow, (S, K, TA,) like zaliymN↓, (S, K,) Cut [or pared], (ISk, S,) and made good in its proportion or conformation, and its workmanship: (ISk, S, K:) [well shaped:] or made even and supple: (TA:) and in like manner the former, with p, applied to a staff (EaSFA). (S.)
See also Oazolamu, in two places.
Also (i. e. muzalRamN) (assumed tropical:) Short [as though cropped] in the tail. (ISk, TA.)

(assumed tropical:) Small in body: (K: [in the CK, wa is erroneously omitted before the words explaining this meaning:]) and so muzanRamN: (IAar, TA:) and the former, rendered small in the body by being badly fed: (TA:) or [simply] badly fed. (S.)

Applied to a man, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Light, (TA,) or, like muqacRacN, made light, (S,) in form, figure, or person: so says ISk: (S, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) short, light, or active, and Zariyf [app. as meaning either elegant in form, or clever]; (M, K;) likened to a small arrow: (M:) and, with p, applied to a woman as meaning (assumed tropical:) not tall; like muqacRacapN. (S.)
And (assumed tropical:) Small [or scanted]; applied to a gift. (TA.)
mazoluwmN: see zalomap.
zilRiyRapN [expl. in art. zl, q. v.,] sing. of zalaAliIRu. (K.)

1. zamRahu, (K,) aor.
zamuma
, inf. n. zamRN, (TA,) He tied, or bound, it: fastened it; or made it fast. (K.)

zamRa AlbaEiyra, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) He attached, (ISk,) or put, (Mgh,) or tied, or fastened, (Msb,) to the camel, (ISk, Mgh, Msb,) the zimaAm [q. v.], (ISk, Mgh,) or his zimaAm; (Msb;) he put in the camel's burap, or his xizaAm, [each meaning a nose-ring,] or his xiXaAXap, [or xiXaAX, a wooden thing fixed in the bone of the nose,] the zimaAm, and tied it, or fastened it, in order to restrain him thereby; (Har p. 329;) i. q. xaTamahu: (S, K:) and zamRama↓ AljimaAla [He attached OazimRap (pl. of zimaAm) to the camels], (TA,) or AljimaAlu zumRima↓ [The camels had OazimRp attached to them]; (S) with teshdeed because relating to several objects. (S, TA.)

Hence, zamRa nafosahu (assumed tropical:) He restrained, or withheld, himself. (Mgh.) And zumRati AlOalosinapu (assumed tropical:) The tongues were restrained, or withheld. (Har p. 329.) And maA OatakalRama bikalimapK HatRaI OaxoTimahaA waOazumRahaA (assumed tropical:) [I say not a saying until I qualify it to be used with cogency or efficiency]. (TA.)
Hence also, (Mgh,) zamRa AlnRaEola, (S, Mgh, TA,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He attached a zimaAm [q. v.] to the sandal; (S, Mgh, TA;) as also AlnEl AzmR↓. (Mgh, TA.)

[Hence likewise,] zamRa biOanofihi, said of a camel, (assumed tropical:) He raised [his nose, and consequently] his head, by reason of a pain in it. (K.) And the same phrase, (S, K,) said of a man, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He elevated his nose, from pride; (K;) or he magnified, or exalted, himself; or was proud; (S, K; *) as also AizodamRa↓; (K;) and zAmR↓, inf. n. muzaAmRapN. (TA.)

And zamRa biraOosihi (tropical:) He raised his head; (K, TA;) inf. n. as above: (TA:) [and so zamRa raOosahu: for] you say, Oaxaca AlcRiYobu saxolapF raOosahu facahaba bihaA zaAmRFA↓, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The wolf took a newborn lamb or kid, and went away with it] raising [his head], (S, TA,) or zamRFA↓ i. e. raising with it his head: (TA:) and you say of the wolf, zamRahaA and AizodamRahaA↓, both meaning the same, (S, K,) i. e. He took it, namely, the new-born lamb or kid, raising his head, or its head, (accord. to different copies of the K,) with it. (TA.)
zamRa Alqirobapa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He filled the water-skin. (K, TA.)

zamRati Alqirobapu, [aor., accord. to rule,
zamima
,] inf. n. zumuwmN, (tropical:) The water-skin became full: thus the verb is intrans. as well as trans. (K, TA.)
And zamRa said of a camel's tush, (assumed tropical:) It rose. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) He went forward, or onward; or before, or ahead; (S, K, TA;) as some say, (TA,) in journeying: (S, K, TA:) in this sense, the inf. n. is zamRN. (TA.)
Also, (inf. n. zamRN, A'Obeyd, TA,) He spoke, or talked. (A'Obeyd, K, TA.)
One says also of the sparrow, yzmR biSawotK lahu DaEiyfK [app. yazimRu, as it is intrans., meaning The sparrow chirps with a feeble voice peculiar to it]: and thus do large hornets. (TA.)
2: see 1, second sentence, in two places.
3: see 1.

You say also, xarajotu maEahu OuzaAmRuhu, and OuxaAzimuhu, i. e. OuEaAriDuhu [meaning (assumed tropical:) I went forth with him taking a different way from his until we both met in one place: see xaAzamahu]. (TA.)
4: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.
7. AnzmR It was, or became, tied, or bound; fastened; or made fast. (K.)
8: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.
One says also, AzdmR AlXRaIoCa Uilayohi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He stretched forth the thing to him. (TA.)

R. Q. 1. zamozamapN [as inf. n. of zamozama, and also as a simple subst.,] A distant sounding or sound, such as is confused and continued. (K.) You say, of a thing, zamozama, meaning It made a distant sound, confused and continued: and samiEotu zamozamapF I heard a distant sound, confused and continued. (TK.)

The sounding, or sound, of thunder: (AZ, S:) or the consecutive reiteration of the sound of thunder; which is the best kind of sounding thereof, and the surest symptom of rain. (M, K.) One says, AlrRaEodu yuzamozimu The thunder sounds with consecutive reiteration. (TK.) Accord. to AHn, the zamozamap of thunder is [The sounding thereof] when it is not loud and clear. (TA.)

The speaking, or speech, of the Magians, on the occasion of their eating, (S, IAth,) with a low voice: (IAth:) or the gibbering, or uttering gibberish or jargon, one to another, of the Persians, or other foreigners, (taraATunu AlEuluwji,) over their eating, while they are [in a manner] speechless, not making use of tongue nor of lip [so as to articulate]; it being a sound which they roll in their noses and their fauces, but such that they understand one another: (K:) or zamozama, said of a Magian, means He affected, or constrained himself, to speak, on the occasion of eating, while closing his mouth: whence the saying, waQnohawohumo Eani AlzRamozamapi [And forbid ye them from the affecting, &c.]. (Mgh.)
The crying [or roaring], or the cry [or roar], of the lion. (K.) You say of him, zamozama [He cried, or roared]. (TA.)
It is also [The uttering, or utterance, of a sound, or of the voice,] from the chest, when it is not clear. (TA.)

Also The crying [or whinnying or neighing], or the cry [or neigh], of the horse: [see muzamozimN:] so in the saying, Hawola AlSRilRiyaAni AlzRamozamapu [Around the SlRyAn (a kind of plant, or herbage,) is whinnying or neighing]: (Meyd:) this is a prov., applied to a man who hovers round about a thing, and does not make apparent his desire: (Meyd, TA:) or to a man who is served for the sake of his wealth: (Meyd:) the SlRyAn is one of the most excellent kinds of pasture: and the prov. means that the cries and clamour that one hears are for the desire of what is to be eaten and enjoyed: Z says, (TA,) the SlRyAn is cut for the horses that do not quit the tribe; (Meyd, TA;) and they neigh, or whinny, (tuzamozimu, and tuHamoHimu,) around it: (TA:) some relate it otherwise, saying Hawola AlSRulobaAni [around the crosses], pl. of SaliybN; and AlzRamozamapu [they say] means the crying, or cry, of the worshipper thereof. (Meyd.)
zamozama also signifies He kept, guarded, or took care of, a thing. (TA.)
And zamozamotu AlmaAla, inf. n. zamozamapN, I collected together the cattle, or property, and drove back, or put back, the outer ones, or outer portions, of what had become scattered thereof. (TA.)
R. Q. 2. tazamozama, said of a camel, He brayed; syn. hadara. (K. [See also R. Q. 1, which has nearly the same meaning.])
tazamozamato bihi XafataAhu His lips moved with it. (TA.)
zamRN [an inf. n. used in the sense of an act. part. n.]: see zaAmRN:
and see also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

zamam is thought by ISd to be used only as an adv. n.: (TA:) [but see what follows.] wajohiI zamama bayotihi means My face is towards his house. (K.) An Arab of the desert said, laA waQlRaciI wajohiI zamama bayotihi maA kaAna kacaA wakacaA, meaning [No, by Him]
towards whose house [is my face, it was not thus and thus, or such and such things did not happen]. (S.)
One says also, daAriI mino daArihi zamamN, (S,) or daAriI zamama daArihi, (K, TA, in the CK zamamu,) (tropical:) My house is near to his house. (S, K, TA.)
And Oamoruhumo zamamN (assumed tropical:) Their affair, or case, is conformable to the just mean; like OamamN: (S, K:) or easy, not exceeding the due measure, bound, or limit. (Lh, TA.)

zimaAmN A thing with which one ties or binds, fastens, or makes fast: (K:) meaning [the noserein of a camel; i. e.] the cord that is tied to the burap [or xizaAm, each meaning nose-ring of a camel], or to the xiXaAX [or wooden thing fixed in the bone of the nose], and to which, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) i. e. to the end of which, (S, TA,) is tied the miqowad [or leading-rope]: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and (afterwards, Msb) also applied to the miqawod (S, Msb, TA) itself: (Msb:) pl. OazimRapN. (Msb, K.) [See also xiTaAmN.] It is said in a trad., laA zimaAma walaA xizaAma fiI AlUisolaAmi [There shall be no nose-rein nor nosering by which to lead a man in El-Islám]: meaning a practice of the devotees of the Children of Israel, who used to attach rings and reins to the noses, like as is done to the she-camel in order that she may be led thereby. (TA.)

[Hence,] zimaAmu AlOamori (assumed tropical:) That by means of which the thing, or affair, subsists, and is conducted, or managed, and ordered. (TA.) And OaloqaI fiI yadihi zimaAma Oamorihi (assumed tropical:) [He put in his hand, or power, the means of conducting his affair, or the conduct of his affair]: and yuSRarifu OazimRapa AlOumuwri (assumed tropical:) [He disposes as he pleases the various means of conducting the affairs]. (TA.) And huwa EalaI zimaAmK mino Oamorihi (assumed tropical:) He is on the point of accomplishing his affair. (TA.) And AlnRaAqapu zimaAmu AlUibili (assumed tropical:) [The she-camel is the leader of the other camels]: said when she goes before them. (TA.) And huwa zimaAmu qawomihi (assumed tropical:) [He is the leader of his people, or party]: and humo OazimRapN qawomihimo (assumed tropical:) [They are the leaders of their people, or party]. (TA.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 261 and 503; and see Quatremère's Hist. des Sultans Mamlouks, vol. i., sec. part, pp. 65 and 66.]

zimaAmu AlnRaEoli (assumed tropical:) [The zmAm of the sandal] is the thing to which the XisoE is attached, or tied: (S:) or the thong that is between the middle toe and that next to it, to which the XisoE is attached, or tied: [but for the latter of these explanations, it seems that we should read the thong that is between the middle toe and that next to it: or the thong to which the XisoE is attached, or tied: the XisoE being the thong that passes through the sole, and between two of the toes, and to which the XiraAk is attached: for it appears that the term zimaAm is applied by some to the thong called by others the XiraAk, extending between the leg and the toes: and by some, to what is called by others the XisoE, or qibaAl: to the latter as being likened to the cord that is tied to the camel's nose-ring; and to the former as being likened to the leading-rope which is tied to that cord: it being] a metaphorical term, from the zimaAm of the camel: (Mgh:) it is [said to be] the thong lies upon the back [meaning upper side] of the foot, [extending] from, or [consisting] of, the fore part of the XiraAk, lengthwise: [for the term XiraAk (q. v.) is sometimes used in a larger sense than that above assigned to it:] or it is like the qibaAl, [which is expl. in the same manner as the XisoE, i. e., as] being between the middle toe and that next to it: (Har p. 539:) [and thus it is expl. by J and Mtr and F in another art.;] the qibaAl of the sandal is its zimaAm, (S, and Mgh and K in art. qbl,) i. e. its thong which is (Mgh in that art.) between the middle toe and next to it. (S and Mgh and K in that art.)
zamRamN or zamRamu: see zamozamN.
zumRaAmN Tall herbs, (K,) rising above such as are termed luEaAE. (TA.)

zamozamN Copious, or abundant, water; as also zumaAzimN↓: (K:) [or] the latter, (Kz, TA,) [and app. the former also,] and zumazimN↓, (IKh, TA,) and zamozaAmN↓, (Kz, TA,) brackish water; i. e. such as is between salt and sweet. (IKh, Kz, TA.)

Also, (accord. to some copies of the S and K,) or zamozamu, (accord. to other copies of the same, and accord. to the Msb,) imperfectly decl., because of the fem. gender and a proper name, (Msb,) the name of The well of Mekkeh, (so in a copy of the S and in the Msb,) or a certain [celebrated] well in Mekkeh, (so in another copy of the S,) [i. e.] a certain well adjacent to the Kaabeh; (K;) so called [because its water is somewhat brackish, or] because of the copiousness of its water; (JM;) as also zumazim↓ [i. e. zumazimN or zumazimu], (IAar, TA,) and zumaAzimN↓ [or zumaAzimu], and zamRamN↓ or zamRamu, (accord. to different copies of the K,) the last (zamRam) on the authority of IAar. (TA.) The names of this well, collected from trads. and lexicons, have been found to amount to more than sixty. (TA.)

zamozam [with or without tenween] is also the name of A celebrated well at El-Medeeneh, which is regarded as a means of obtaining a blessing, and the water of which is drunk and transported [like that of the more celebrated well of the same name at Mekkeh]. (TA.)

zamozamN or zamozamu (accord. to different copies of the S, [used by a poet with tenween, but probably by poetic license, for it is app. a fem. proper name, and therefore imperfectly decl.,]) is also A name of, or for, a she-camel, like EayoTal. (S.)
zimozimN: see zimozimapN, in two places.
zumazimN or zumazimu: see zamozamN, in two places.

zamozamapN [inf. n. of R. Q. 1 (q. v. passim); and also used as a simple subst., of which the pl. is zamaAzimu]. You say raEodN cuw zamaAzima and hadaAhida [Thunder having confused and continued, or murmuring, sounds, heard from a distance]. (TA.) And zamaAzimu AlnRaAri The sounds of the blazing of fire. (TA.)

zimozimapN A company, or collection, (S, K,) of men, (S, TA,) whatever it be: (TA:) or any collection; as also zmzwm [i. e. zumozuwmN↓]: (Ham p. 233:) or fifty, (K,) and thereabout, (TA,) of camels, and of men; (As, K;) as also DimoDimapN; (As, TA;) neither of which words is formed by substitution from the other: (TA:) pl. zmAzm [i. e. zamaAzimu], (Ham ubi suprà,) and [coll. gen. n.] zimozimN↓, (S, * TA,) occurring in the saying of a rájiz, (S,) Aboo-Mohammad El-Fak'asee, (TA,)

[When companies draw near to companies]. (S, TA.) Also A distinct number of jinn, or genii: or of beasts of prey. (K.) And A herd of camels among which are no young ones, or little ones; and so zimoziymN↓: (K:) or, accord. to EshSheybánee, zimozimN↓ and zimoziymN↓ signify large, big, or bulky, camels. (S.)

saHaAbN zamozaAmN Clouds thundering, but not loudly and clearly. (AHn, TA.) [Accord. to one passage in the TA, zamozaAmN seems to be expl. by IKh as meaning Thundering much: but the passage appears to be incorrectly transcribed.]
See also zamozamN.

zumozuwmN The best, or excellent, or choice, of camels: or a hundred thereof. (K.) And The best of a people; (K, TA;) the choice, best, or most excellent, portion thereof: in one copy of the K, [and so in the CK,] XarRuhumo is put in the place of sirRuhumo. (TA.)
See also zimozimapN.
zimoziymN: see zimozimapN, last sentence, in two places.
zumaAzimN or zumaAzimu: see zamozamN, in two places.

zaAmRN [act. part. n. of zamRa]. zaOamRahaA [meaning Attaching a zimaAm to her] occurs used by poetic license for zaAmRahaA, because of the concurrence of two quiescent letters; like AisowaOadRato for AisowaAdRato. (S.)

(assumed tropical:) Magnifying, or exalting, himself; or elevating his nose, from pride: (S, TA:) [and in like manner zamRN↓:] one says, zaOayotuhu zamRFA (assumed tropical:) I saw him magnifying, or exalting, himself, &c., not speaking: (TA:) pl. of the former zumRamN. (S, TA.)
See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
Also, accord. to El-Harbee, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Fearing, or afraid; syn. faziEN. (TA.)
ziyzamN: see what next follows.

ziyziymN a word imitative of The low, or faint, sound of the jinn, or genii, that is heard by night in the deserts; (TA in this art. and in art. zym;) and so ziyzamN↓: (IAar, K * and TA in art. zym:) Ru-beh says,
[Thou hearest therein a low, or faint, sound of the jinn by night]. (TA.)
AlUizomiymu One of the nights called layaAliI AlmuHaAqi [meaning the last three nights of the lunar month]. (K.)

And The decrescent moon in the last part of the [lunar] month, (K,) when it becomes slender and bow-shaped: Dhu-r-Rummeh uses it in this sense without the article Al: and Th says
that UizomiymN is one of the names of the [moon when it is termed] hilaAl. (TA.)
UibilN muzamRamapN: see what next follows.
baEiyrN mazomuwmN A camel having a zimaAm attached to him; syn. maxoTuwmN: and UibilN muzamRamapN↓ camels having OazimRap attached to them; syn. muxaTRamapN. (TA.)
farasN muzamozimN fiI Sawotihi A horse quavering, or trilling, his voice, [or whinnying or neighing,] and prolonging it. (A'Obeyd, TA.)

zumaAwarodN, (S and K in art. wrd,) or zamaAwarodN, as in the Commentaries on the Keshsháf, (MF,) or zumRaAwarodN, (MA,) an arabicized word, vulgarly bazomaAwarodN, (S,) or buzomaAwarodN, (K,) and the vulgar appellation is correct, agreeing with the Pers. original, (Shifá el-Ghaleel,) [which is bazomaAwarodN, or] P\xQ698YmAwrd, (MA,) A certain kind of food, composed of eggs and flesh-meat: (K:) or thin paste folded together, with flesh-meat within: or the kind of food called luqomapu AlqaADiI, [i. e. small, light, spongy balls, generally about the size of walnuts, made of leavened dough, and eaten with honey poured over,] and also called luqamapu Alxaliyfapi, and narojisu AlmaAYidapi, and muyasRarN, and muhayRaON; and in Khurásán called nawaAlah: (MF:) or nwAlhC bzrGAn: (MA:) [or, as Golius says, on the authority of Meyd, a kind of food made of fine flour, bruised almonds, and honey.]

1. zamuta, aor.
zamuta
, inf. n. zamaAtahu, He was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (A, K.)

5. tzmRt i. q. tawaqRara [He showed, exhibited, or manifested, gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness; or he endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be grave, staid, &c.]. (A.) One says, maA OaXadRa tazamRutahu [How great is his show of gravity, &c.! or his endeavour, or constraint of himself, to be grave, &c.!]. (Fr, S.)

zamiytN Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm, (IAar, S, A, K, TA,) in his sitting-place: (IAar, TA:) pl. rumataMCu, (A,) or zmt [app. zumotN or zumutN, if not a mistranscription for zumataMCu, which I rather think it to be]. (TA.)
zimRiytN Very grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm: (S, K, TA:) forbearing, or clement; quiet; of few words; like SimRiytN: or, as some say, silent. (TA.)
fulaAnN Oazomatu AlnRaAsi Such a one is the most grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm, of men. (S.)

1. zamaxa, (S, K,) or zamaxa biOanofihi, (L,) aor.
zamaxa
, (K,) inf. n. zamoxN, (L,) He exalted, or magnified, himself; was proud; (S, L, K;) behaved proudly, haughtily, or vainly; (S, L;) elevated his nose, from pride; (L;) i. q. Xamaxa, or Xamaxa biOanofihi. (TA.)
zamaxN: see zamuwxN, in two places.
zimoxN or zimaxN The tree called sumRaAq; as also ZimoxN or ZimaxN. (TA in art. Zmx; but there written without any syll. signs.)

EuqobapN zamuwxN [in the CK EaqabapN] (JK, A, K) and zamaxN↓ (K) (tropical:) [A stage of a journey] far-extending, (K,) hard, or difficult. (AZ, IAar, JK, K.) One says, saAra EuqobapF zamuwxFA (tropical:) [He journeyed a long and hard stage]. (A.)

And niyRapN zamuwxN (A, and L in art. Xmx) and zamaxN↓, like XamuwxN and XamaxN, (L in that art.,) (tropical:) A distant, far-reaching, or faraiming, intention, purpose, or design. (A, and L ubi suprà.)
zaAmixN i. q. XaAmixN [Proud, &c.]; (S, K;) or XaAmixN biOanofihi [elevating his nose, from pride]: (A, L:) [pl. zumRaxN.]
OunuwfN zumRaxN i. q. XumRaxN [Noses elevated, from pride]. (S, A.)
[Hence,] jibaAlN lahaA OunuwfN zumRaxN, (A, TA,) i. e. TiwaAlN (tropical:) [Mountains having tall, or long, prominences]. (TA.)
And kayolN zaAmixN (tropical:) Full measure. (JK, A, K.)

1. zamara, aor.
zamira
and
zamura
, inf. n. zamorN (S, Msb, K) and zamiyrN (Msb, K) and zamaraAnN; (ISd, TA;) and zmRr↓, inf. n. tazomiyrN; (K;) He [piped, or] played upon (lit. sang in) a reed; (K;) he blew in a mizomaArN. (S, * A, Msb. *)

[Hence,] zamara AlnRaEaAmu, (S, K,) and zamarati Alhayoqapu, (A,) or AlnRaEaAmapu, (TA,) aor.
zamira
, inf. n. zimaArN (S, A, K) and zumaArN, (TA,) (tropical:) The ostriches, (S, K,) and the she-ostrich, (A, TA,) cried, or uttered their, or her, cry. (S, A, K, TA.) [Said only of the females, or a female:] of the male ostrich one says only EaArRa. (S, TA.)
And zamara biAlHadiyvi (tropical:) He published, or divulged, the story. (A, K.)
And zamara fulaAnFA bifulaAnK He excited, or incited, such a one against such a one. (A, * K, TA.)

zamira, (S, K,) aor.
zamara
, (K,) inf. n. zamarN, (S,) He had little hair, (S, * K, * TA,) and little wool. (K, * TA.)
Also, [hence,] inf. n. as above, (S,) or zamaArapN and zumuwrapN, (TA,) (tropical:) He (a man, S, TA) had little muruwoCap [i. e. manliness, or manly virtue]. (S, K.)
And zamira maAluhu, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) His property became little, or scanty. (TA in art. qfr.)
2: see 1, first sentence.
10. Astzmr (tropical:) He was, or became, abject, or ignominious, or weak, and small in body, and lean; being abased or brought low. (A, TA.) [See also the part n., below.]
zamorN: see zumorapN.

zamirN Having little hair; (S, A, K;) and having little wool: fem. with p. (A, K.) You say SabiIRN zamirN A child having little hair: and XaApN zamirapN [A sheep, or goat, having little wool or hair]: and ganamN zawaAmiru [Sheep, or goats, having little wool or hair]: (A, TA:) and naAqapN zamirapN A she-camel having little fur: and nabotN zamierN [app. meaning A plant having few leaves]. (Ham p. 683.) And XaEarN zamirN [Scanty, or thin, hair]. (A, TA.)
Also, [hence,] (S, K,) or zamiru AlmuruwoCapi, (A,) (tropical:) A man (A) having little muruwoCap [i. e. manliness, or manly virtue]. (S, A, * K.)
And zamiru AlmaAli (assumed tropical:) A man having little, or scanty, property. (AZ, TA in art. qfr.)
And EaTiyRapN zamirapN (tropical:) A scanty, or small, gift. (A, * TA.)
Also Good singing: (Th, TA:) [and] so zamiyrN↓. (Az, O, TA.)
And Goodly in countenance. (K.)

zamorapN A company, or congregated body, of men; (S, K;) as also zawomarN↓: (TA:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) a party in a state of dispersion: (K:) pl. zumarN: (S, A, K:) you say, jaAWuwA zumarFA They came in parties in a state of dispersion, one after another: (A:) some say that zumorapN is from zamorN↓ [originally an inf. n., (see 1, first sentence,) and hence] signifying “ sound, ” because a company of men is not without sound: others, that it signifies a company of few persons; from XaApN zamirapN: (MF:) but the former is the proper derivation, and is confirmed by what is said in the B. (TA.)
zamuwrN: see the next paragraph.
zamiyrN Short; (Kr, K;) applied to a man: (TA:) pl. zimaArN. (Kr, K.)
And Beautiful; applied to a boy, or young man; (AA, Th, O, K;) as also zawomarN↓ (AA, O, K) and zamuwrN↓. (K.)
See also zamirN.
zimaArapN The act [or art] of [piping, or] playing upon the reed [or mizomaAr]. (K.)

zamRaArN (As, S, A, Msb, K) and zaAmirN↓, (As, S, K,) but the latter is rare, (K,) or scarcely ever used, (S,) or it is not allowable, (Msb,) applied to a man; and zaAmirapu↓, (S, Msb, K,) but not zamRaArapN, (S, Msb,) applied to a woman; (S, Msb, K;) A [piper, or] player upon a reed; (K;) one who blows in a mizomaAr. (S, * A, Msb. *)

Also zamRaArapN, (assumed tropical:) A fornicatress, or an adulteress: (Th, A'Obeyd, Az, S, K:) so in a trad., in which it is said nahaI Eano kasobi AlzRamRaArapi He prohibited the gain of the fornicatress: (Th, A'Obeyd, Az, S:) so called because she publishes her business: (Th:) some say that the correct word is here ramRaAzap, because such a woman makes signs with her lips and her eyes and her eyebrows: Az says that he holds the former to be the right; and Abu-l- 'Abbás Ahmad says that the latter is wrong, and that the former signifies a beautiful prostitute: but Az adds that the trad. may mean as above, or he prohibited the gain of the female singer, as AHát relates on the authority of As. (TA.)
zamRaArapN [fem. of zamRaArN, q. v.
Also] i. q. mizomaArN, q. v. (K.)
And (tropical:) A saAjuwr [i. e. collar, or collar of iron,] (O, A, K, TA) that is put upon the neck of a dog. (TA.)

And metaphorically used as meaning (tropical:) A jaAmiEap; (A, TA;) [i. e.] A [shackle for the neck and hands, such as is called] gulR. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A bar of iron (EamuwdN) between
the two rings of the [shackle called] gulR: (M, O, K:) so termed because of its sound. (O.)
Also A she-ostrich. (Har p. 408.)
zaAmirN; and its fem., with p: see zamRaArN.
zawomarN: see zumorapN:
and see also zamiyrN.
Also Playing; or a player. (O.)
muzamRarN (assumed tropical:) Shackled [with a zamRaArp]. (O, TA.)

mizomaArN A musical reed, or pipe; (S, * A, Msb, * K, * TA;) what is called in Persian naAIo [now generally meaning a flute]; (marginal note in a copy of the KT;) as also zamRaArapN↓, (K,) [which latter, by many pronounced zumRaArap, and generally so pronounced in Egypt, is applied to a double reed-pipe, figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians,] and mazomuwrN↓ and mazomuwrN↓, (IAth,) the latter like magoluwqN and magoruwdN: (TA:) pl. of the first, (S, A,) and of the last two, mazaAmiyru. (S, * A.) It is related in a trad., that Mohammad, on hearing Aboo-Moosà El-Ash'aree reciting, said to him, laqado OuEoTiyta mizomaArFA mino mazaAmiyri Mli daAwuwda (tropical:) [Verily thou hast been gifted with a pipe like that of David himself]; likening the sweetness of his voice and melody to the sound of the mizomaAr; (TA;) as though he had musical pipes in his throat: or mzAmyrMl dAwwd is here the same as mazomuwraAt daAwuwd: (A:) for,

mazaAmiyru daAwuwda also signifies [The Psalms of David;] what David used to sing, or chant, (yataganRaI bihi, in the CK yutaganRaI bh,) of the Psalms: (K:) and to such is likened the utmost sweetness of voice in reciting: and Ml is said to be here redundant or pleonastic; meaning the person: (TA:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) mzAmyr dAwwd signifies kinds of prayer, or supplication: it is pl. of mizomaArN and of mazomuwrN↓ or muzomuwrN. (So in different copies of the K.)
mazomuwrN and muzomuwrN: see mizomaArN, in two places.
musotazomirN (tropical:) Shrinking, and abject, or ignominious, in his own estimation. (K, TA.) [See also its verb.]
zumurRudN: see the next article.

zumurRucN (T, S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and zumurRacN, (Az, TA,) and accord. to some zumurRudN, with the unpointed d (TA,) or, accord. to IKt, this is a mistranscription, and As says that it is correctly written with the pointed c (Msb,) [The emerald: accord. to some] i. q. zabarojadN; (Sudot;, L, Msb, K;) but Et-Teyfáshee [rightly] says that the zbrjd is a different kind of stone: [see this word:] and Ibn-Sá'id El-Ansáree says that the mine of the zbrjd is said to be near to that of the zmRrc: (TA:) several authors say that the zmRrc differs from the zbrjd in being more green: (MF, TA:) it is an arabicized word [from the Pers. zumorudo]: (S, L, Msb, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (Msb.)

1. zamiEa, aor.
zamaEa
, inf. n. zamaEN, He became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or he became bereft of his reason or intellect; in consequence of fear: (S, Msb, * K: *) he feared, or was afraid: (K:) he was impatient; or had not sufficient strength to bear what befell him, and found not patience: (L:) he became disquieted, disturbed, agitated, flurried, or in a state of commotion. (Lh.)

zamaEati AlOaronabu, aor.
zamaEa
, (TA,) inf. n. zamaEaAnN, (Lth, K, TA,) The hare was light, or active, and quick, or swift: (Lth, K, TA:) and AzmEt↓ it ran, (S, TA,) and was light, or active. (TA.) And zamaEa, aor.
zamaEa
, inf. n. zamaEaAnN, He went slowly. (ISk, S, K.) Thus the verb has two contr. significations. (K.) And He went with short steps; as also tzmRE↓. (TA.)
2: see the next paragraph.

4. OazomaEotu AlOamora, and OazomaEotu EalaI AlOamori; (S, K;) the former accord. to Ks.; the latter accord. to Kh, but disallowed by Ks; both, however, are authorized by Fr, as meaning the same, like OajomaEotuhu and OajomaEotu Ealayohi; (S;) and OazomaEotu bihi; (TA;) I determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair: (Fr, S, K:) my determination, resolution, or decision, became fixed upon the affair, (Lth or Kh, S, TA,) to execute it, or perform it, of necessity: (Lth, TA:) or I kept constantly, firmly, steadily, steadfastly, or fixedly, to the affair: syn. vabatRu Ealayohi: (K:) and zamRaEotu↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, [in the CK written without teshdeed,]) followed by EalaI before the object, inf. n. tazomiyEN, (TA,) signifies the same: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K:) AzmE may be formed by transposition from Ezm, or the z may be a substitute for j (IF.) You say, AzmE Almasiyra [and EalaI Almasiyri] He determined, resolved, or decided, upon going, journeying, or departing. (Mgh.)
See also 1.

AzmEt AlHubolapu (assumed tropical:) [The grape-vine, or its branch,] became large in its zamaEap, i. e. knot, or gem, [see zamaEN,] (ISh, K, TA,) and its fruit-stalk was near to coming forth. (ISh, TA.)

And AzmE AlnRabotu The herbage made its first appearance in a scattered state: (S:) or was not all of it equal, or uniform, but consisted of scattered portions, (K, TA,) at its first appearance, (TA,) one part surpassing another. (K, TA.)
5: see 1, last sentence.
zamaEN; see zamaAEN.

Also pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of zamaEapN↓, which [is the n. un. of the former, and] signifies A certain excrescence bekind the cloven hoof: (AZ, S, Msb, * K:) or a thing like the nails of sheep or goats, in the part between the shank and foot; every leg having upon it two of the things thus termed (zamaEataAni), as though they were formed of pieces of horn: (Lth, K:) or a certain excrescence projecting above the hoof of the sheep or goat: (TA:) or the pendent hairs in the kinder part of the kind leg, or kind foot, of the sheep or goat, and of the gazelle, and of the hare: (K:) [the pl. of zamaEapN↓ is zamaEaAtN (occurring in the S and K in the present art., and in the K in art. zwd &c.), and] the pl. of zamaEN is zimaAgN: (AZ, S, K:) see zamuwEN.

Hence, as being compared to the zamaE of the cloven hoof, (L,) zamaEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The lower, or baser, or the lowest, or basest, or the refuse, of mankind: (S, L, K:) pl. OazomaAEN. (L.) One says, huwa mino zamaEihimo, meaning (assumed tropical:) He is of the last of them; (S, L;) and of their followers. (L.)
Also, i. e. zamaEN The hairs behind the fetlock [-joint]; (K;) and so zamaEaAtN [pl. of the n. un. zamaEapN↓]. (TA.)

Also (tropical:) Knots, gems, or buds, in the places whence the racemes of the grape-vine come forth: (ISh, K, TA:) accord. to Et-Táïfee, (L in art. kmH,) [the n. un.] zamaEapN↓ signifies the knot, or gem, in the place whence the raceme of grapes grows forth: (L ubi suprà, and TA:) or, as some say, the berry when it is like the head of a young ant; and the pl. is zamaEaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] zamaEN: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) the gem of a leaf: (L in art. kmx:) and zamaEu Alkaromi (assumed tropical:) The leaves that cover what is within them of the raceme of the grape-vine. (TA voce kaAfuwrN.)
Also (assumed tropical:) An excrescence, or a redundance, (ziyaAdapN,) in the fingers or toes: and the epithet [applied to him who has such] is OazomaEu↓. (K.)
And Scattered portions of herbage, here and there; like portions of clouds in the sky. (TA.)
zamaEapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

zamaAEN Penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in the performance of an affair, and determination, resolution, or decision, to do it; (L, K;) as also zimaAEN↓ and zamaEN↓: (K:) and courage, such that when one has determined, resolved, or decided, upon an affair, he does not turn from it: (K:) and good judgment, with boldness to undertake affairs, (K, TA,) such that when one purposes an affair, he acts with a penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in performing it: (TA:) or courage, and great boldness: (S:) and quickness, and hastiness. (S, K.)
zimaAEN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zamuwEN: see zamiyEN.

Also A hare that runs with short steps, as though it ran upon its zamaEaAt↓, (As, T, S, K,) i. e. the pendent hairs on the kinder parts of its kind legs: (T, TA:) or such as, when it approaches its habitation, goes upon its zamaEap, (K, TA,) and with short steps, (TA,) in order that its foot-marks may not be traced: (K, TA:) and (K, TA, but in the CK “ or ”) such as is quick, or swift, and brisk, or sprightly. (K, TA.)

zamiyEN A man sharp, vigorous, or effective, in determination, resolution, or decision: (Mgh:) a courageous man, who, when he has determined, resolved, or decided, upon an affair, does not turn from it: (Lth, K: [in the CK, yazomaEu is a mistake
for yuzomiEu:]) and having good judgment, with boldness to undertake affairs, (K, TA,) so that when he has purposed an affair, he acts with a penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in performing it: (TA:) or zamiyEu AlrRaOoIi signifies a man having good judgment: (S:) and zamiyEN signifies also quick; (K;) quick, and hasty; (S;) and so zamuwEN↓: (S, K:) pl. of the former zumaEaMCu. (S, K.)
huwa OazomaEu minohu He is more sharp, vigorous, or effective, in determination, resolution, or decision, than he. (Mgh.)
See also zamaEN, last sentence but one.

OanaA muzomiEN EalaI OamorK, [or muzomiEN OamorFA, or both, and muzomiEN biOamorK, I am determining, resolving, or deciding, upon an affair: or] my determination, resolution, or decision, is fixed upon an affair. (Kh, S.) [See 4.]
zimikRN: see the following paragraph.

zimikRaI, (Fr, S, K,) with kesr to the z and m, (K,) like zimijRaI [in measure and in meaning, app. from the Pers. zimojiI], (S,) [in the O erroneously written zimakRaI,] and zimikRN↓, (Fr, K, TA,) like filizRN, (TA,) [in the O erroneously written zimakR, and in the CK zamak,] and zimikRMCu↓, (TA,) The place of the growth of the tail of a bird: (Fr, S, K:) or the root of the tail of a bird: (M, K:) or the whole tail of a bird: (K:) or sometimes, accord. to Lth, the tail itself is called zmkRI when it is short (UicaA qaSura), (O, TA, *) or, as in some copies [of his book, meaning the 'Eyn], when it is clipped (AcA quSRa). (TA.)
zimikRaMCu: see the preceding paragraph.

1. zamala, aor.
zamula
and
zamila
, inf. n. zamaAlN, He ran, (K, TA,) and went along quickly, (TA,) leaning, or bearing, on one side, raising his other side; (K, TA;) as though he were bearing upon one leg; not with the firmness of him who bears upon both of his legs. (TA.)

And zamala (K, TA) fiI maXoyihi and Eadowihi, aor.
zamula
, (TA,) inf. n. zamolN and zamaAlN [the latter accord. to the CK zimaAlN but said in the TA to be with fet-h like the former,] and zamalaAnN (K, TA) and zamalN, (TA as from the K, [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,]) said of a horse or similar beast, (K, TA,) or of a wild ass, (TA,) He was as though he limped, by reason of his briskness, or sprightliness, (K,) or as though bearing upon his fore legs, by reason of pride, or self-conceit, and briskness, in his going and his running. (TA.)

zamalahu, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. zamolN, (TA,) He bore it, or carried it; namely, a thing: (Mgh, Msb:) and Aizodamalahu↓ (S, K,) originally Aztmlh, (TA,) signifies the same; or he took it up and carried it, or he raised it upon his back; syn. AiHotamalahu; (S, K;) at once; (K;) namely, a load: (TA:) like zabalahu and Azdblhu. (TA in art. zbl.)

And zamalahu, (IDrd, K,) aor.
zamula
, inf. n. zamolN, (TA,) He made him to ride behind him, (IDrd, K,) EalaI AlbaEiyri on the camel: (IDrd:) or he rode with him [on a camel, in a maHomil,] so as to counterbalance him; (K, TK:) and so zAmlhu↓, (Mgh,) inf. n. muzaAmalapN, (S,) he rode with him so as to counterbalance him (S * Mgh) on a camel, (S,) in the maHomil. (Mgh.)

[And zamala gayorahu, aor.
zamula
, He followed another:] see zaAmilN.

2. zmRlhu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. tazomiylN, (Msb, K,) He wrapped him (S, Mgh, Msb, K *) fiI vawobihi [in his garment], (S, K, *) or fI viyaAbihi [in his garments], (Mgh,) or bivawobihi [with his garment]. (Msb.)
[Hence, app.,] tazomiylN signifies also The act of concealing. (IAar, K.)
3: see 1, last sentence but one.
muzaAmalapN also signifies The requiting with beneficence. (AA, TA in art. Hml.)

5. tzmRl (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and AizRamRala, (Mgh, K,) the latter of the measure AifRaERala, (K,) [a variation of the former,] and Aizodamala↓, (TA,) He wrapped himself (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) biviyaAbihi [with his garments], (S,) and so tzmRl alone, (TA,) or fiI viyaAbihi [in his garments], (Mgh, TA,) or bivawobihi [with his garment]. (Msb.)
6. tzAmlwA i. q. trAjzwA [i. e. They recited verses, or poetry, of the metre termed rajaz, which is also termed zamal, one with another; or vied in doing so]. (TA.)
8. Aizodamala: see 5.
Aizodamalahu: see 1.
Q. Q. 1. zawomala, (TK,) inf. n. zawomalapN, (K,) He drove camels. (K, TK.)
zimolN A load, or burden. (K.) It occurs in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) A load of knowledge. (TA.)
[Household-goods; or furniture and utensils. (Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees.) See also OazomalN.]
maA fiI juwaAliqika UilRaA zimolN means There is not in thy sack save a half. (AA, K.)
See also zamiylN.
And see zumRalN.
zamalN The kind of verse, or poetry, [more commonly] termed rajaz: [hence,] a poet says,

L.foreign: laA yugolabu AlnRaAziEu maA daAma AlzRamalo

sense.s: [The drawer of water will not be overcome as long as the zml continues]; meaning, as long as he recites [or chants] the verse termed rajaz [or zamal], he is strong enough to work: thus it is related on the authority of AA: another reading is AlrRamalo: both are correct as to meaning. (IJ, TA.)
zamilN and zumalN: see zumRalN.

zumolapN A company of persons travelling together, or with whom one is travelling; (AZ, K;) as also zawomalapN↓: (En-Nadr, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) a company or a collection [in an absolute sense]. (K, TA.)

zimolapN Luxuriant, or abundant, and dense [palmtrees such as are termed] jabRaAr: [AljumRAr in the CK is a mistranscription:] and a collection of wadiIR [i. e. small young palm-trees, or shoots cut off from palm-trees and planted]: and young palm-trees exceeding the reach of the hand: (K, TA:) all on the authority of El-Hejeree. (TA.)
zamalapN: see OazomalN, in two places.
zimaAlN A limping in a camel. (K.)
And A wrapper that is put over a raAwiyap [or leathern water-bag]: pl. zumulN and OazomilapN: (Az, K:) you say valaAvapu OazomilapK. (Az, TA.)

zamiylN One who rides behind another (IDrd, S, K) on a camel (IDrd, TA) that carries the food and the household-goods or furniture and utensils; (TA;) and zimolN↓ signifies the same, (K,) and so does mazomuwlN↓: (IDrd, TA:) or one who rides behind another on a horse or similar beast: (TA:) or one who rides with another in a maHomil so as to counterbalance him. (Mgh.) It is metaphorically used in the saying, Oanota faArisu AlEilomi waOanaA zamiyluka (tropical:) [Thou art the horseman of science, or knowledge, and I am he who rides behind thee]. (TA.)

Hence, A travelling-companion (Mgh, TA) who assists one in the performance of his affairs. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yufaAriqu rajulN zamiylahu, i. e. [A man shall not separate himself from] his travelling-companion. (Mgh.)
zamiylaAni means Two men engaged in work upon their two camels: when they are without work, they are called rafiyqaAni. (K.)
zumayolN and zumayolapN: see zumRalN.
zimoyalRN: see what next follows.

zumRalN (S, K) and zumalN↓ and zimolN↓ [said in the CK to be like EidapN, but correctly like EidolN,] and zamilN↓ and zumayolN↓ (K) and zumRayolN↓ and zumRaAlN↓ (S, K) and zimoyalRN↓ and zumayolapN↓ and zumRayolapN↓ (K, or this is fem., S) and zumRaAlapN↓ (K) Cowardly, weak, (S, K, TA,) low, mean, or contemptible; who wraps himself up in his house, or tent; not rising and hastening to engage in warfare; indolently refraining from aspiring to great things. (TA.) [See also UizomiylN. Accord. to J,] zumRayolapN↓ signifies Weak as a fem. epithet. (S.)
zumRaAlN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zumRayolN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zumRaAlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zumRayolapN: see zumRalN, in two places.

zaAmilN, applied to a horse or similar beast, (K, TA,) or to a wild ass, (A' Obeyd, TA,) That is as though he limped, by reason of his briskness, or sprightliness. (A' Obeyd, K, TA.) [Hence, app., the name of] The horse of Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-Mirdás Es-Sulamee. (K.)
Also One who follows (yazomulu↓, [in the CK yuzamRilu,] i. e. yatobaEu,) another. (K.)

zaAmilapN A camel (S, Mgh, Msb, K) or other beast
(K) used for carrying (S, Mgh, Msb, K) the goods, or furniture and utensils, of a man (S, Mgh, Msb) travelling, (Mgh, Msb,) and his food; (S, Mgh;) the p denoting intensiveness: (Msb:) or a she-camel upon which are carried the goods, or furniture and utensils, of the traveller: (Har p. 130:) from zamala “ he bore, or carried, ” a thing: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. zawaAmilu. (TA.) [See also zawomalapN.]

Afterwards used to signify The Eidol [properly half-load] in which is the pilgrim's travelling-provision, consisting of biscuit, or dry bread, and fruit (vmr [app. a mistranscription for tamor i. e. dates]), and the like. (Mgh.)

zawomalapN Camels having their loads upon them: (IAar, M, K: * [in the K, waAlEiyri should be waAlEiyru, or rather waAlUibilu:]) and so laTiymapN: EiyrN signifies “ camels laden or not laden: ” (IAar, M:) zawaAmilu may be either its pl. or pl. of zaAmilapN [q. v.]. (TA.)
See also zumolapN.
huwa Qbonu zawomalatihaA means He is a knower of it; (IAar, K;) i. e., of the affair. (IAar.)
And Aibonu zawomalapa, also, means The son of the female slave. (IAar, K.)
OazomalN A sound: (As, S:) or any mixed, or confused, sound: or a sound proceeding from the prepuce of a horse or similar beast: (K:) it has no verb. (TA.) A poet says,

L.foreign: watasomaEu mino taHoti AlEajaAji lahaA QzomalaA

sense.s: [The gums of the horses water in the adjacent tracts thereof, and thou hearest, beneath the dust, a sound attributable to them]: he means OazomalaA, but suppresses the C, as is done in wayolumRihi [for wayolN liOumRihi]. (S.) OazaAmiylu AlqisiIR means The sounds of the bows: AazAmyl being pl. of OazomalN, with I to give fulness to the sound of the vowel preceding it. (TA.) And OazomalapN↓ signifies The twanging sound of a bow. (K, TA.)

taraka OazomalFA and OazomalapF↓ and zamalapF↓ He left a family, or household. (K.) And xaraja fulaAnN waxalRafa Oazomalahu [Such a one went forth, and left behind him his family, or his family and his cattle]: and xaraja biOazomalihi He went forth with his family and his camels and his sheep or goats, not leaving behind him aught of his property. (AZ, TA.)

[Hence, app.,] Oaxacahu biOazomalihi [in one of my copies of the S, Oazomalahu,] He took it altogether; (S, K;) namely, a thing. (S.) And He took it with its OavaAv [or utensils and furniture]; as also biOazomulihi↓ and Oazomalatihi↓ (K) and zamalatihi↓. (L, TA.)
And EiyaAlaAtN OazomalapN↓ i. e. Numerous [families or households]. (S, K. *)
OazomulN, whence Oaxacahu biOazomulihi: see the next preceding paragraph, last sentence but one.
OazomalapN: see OazomalN, in four places.
UizomawolN: see OuzomuwlapN.

UizomiylN A shoemaker's knife (S, K, TA) with which he cuts the leather. (TA.) [In the TA, in art. crb, it is expl. as meaning A shoemaker's UiXofaI with which he sews: but this I have not found elsewhere.]
Also An iron (K, TA) like the new moon [in shape], (TA,) that is put at the end of a spear, for the purpose of catching wild oxen. (K, * TA.)
And The [implement called] miToraqap [q. v.]. (K.)

Applied to a man, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A great, or vehement, eater; likened to the [shoemaker's] knife: (TA:) or strong: and also weak; (K, TA;) low, mean, or contemptible: (TA: [like zumRalN:]) thus having two contr. significations. (K.)

OuzomuwlapN (AA, S, K) and (S, K) some say (S) UizomawolapN, (S, K,) the latter accord. to As and Sb and Ez-Zubeydee, (TA,) and UizomawolN↓, (S, TA,) which is said by IJ to be quasi-coordinate to jirodaHolN, because the w in it is not a letter of prolongation, for the letter before it is with fet-h, (TA,) applied to a mountain-goat and to one of other animals, Vociferous: (AA, S, K, TA:) or the first, [or, app, any of the three,] applied to a mountain-goat, such as, when he runs, leans, or bears, on one side: so accord. to AHeyth: Fr explains the first or second as applied to a horse, meaning that runs swiftly: and in like manner to a mountain-goat. (TA.)

muzamRalapN A certain thing in which water is cooled: of the dial. of El-'Irák: (K:) applied by the people of Baghdád to a green [jar such as is called] jarRap or xaAbiyap, in the middle whereof is a perforation, in which is fixed a tube of silver or lead, whence one drinks; so called because it is wrapped (tuzamRalu i. e. tulafRu) with a piece of cloth of coarse flax, or some other thing, between which and the jar is straw: it is in their houses in the days of summer: the water is cooled in the night by means of the [porous earthen bottles called] barRaAdaAt; then it is poured into this mzmRlp, and remains in it cool. (Har p. 548.)
mazomuwlN: see zamiylN.
muzRamRilN, originally mutazamRilN, A man wrapped with [or in] his garments: occurring in the Kur lxxiii. 1. (TA.)
Q. 1. zamolaqa, inf. n. zamolaqapN, He did the act denoted by the epithet zumaliqN expl. in art. zlq voce zaliqN. (TA.)
zamolaqapN in asses is like hamolajapN [i. e. The going an easy and a quick pace] in a horse. (TA.)

zumaliqN and zumRaliqN↓ and zumaAliqN↓ are expl. in the S in art. zlq [q. v., voce zaliqN]: in the K, in the present art., agreeably with the opinion of Aboo- 'Obeyd. (TA.) [The first is said in the TA, voce vatRN, to be syn. with EicoyawoTN, q. v.]
The first is also applied to an ass, as meaning Fat; whose back is even by reason of the fat. (Lh, TA.)

zumoluwqN A boy, or young man, light, or active, upon whom his pursuer can hardly lay hold by reason of his lightness in his running, and his going this way and that, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully; as also zumaAliqN↓: thus expl. by Az, on the authority of one of the Arabs: also said to signify light, or active, and inconstant, unsteady, or fickle; and so zumRaliqN↓ and zumaAliqN↓. (TA.)
zumaAliqN: see zumaliqN:
and see also zumoluwqN, in two places.
zumRaliqN: see zumaliqN:
and see also zumoluwqN.

1. zamina. aor.
zamana
, inf. n. zamanN (Msb, K) and zamaAnapN (S, * Msb, K) and zumonapN, (K,) He (a man, S, Msb) had, or was affected with, a malady of long continuance, (Msb,) or what is termed zamaAnapN, expl. below: (K:) he was, or became, afflicted [with what is so termed]: (S:) or he was, or became, crippled. (TK.)

3. EaAmalahu muzaAmanapF (S, K) and zimaAnFA (Lh, TA) [He bargained, or made an engagement, with him, to work, for a time], (S, K,) from AlzRamanu. (S,) is like muXaAharapF [and XihaArFA] (S, K) from AlXRahoru. (S.)

4. Azmn [He, or it, continued a long time;] a long time passed over him, or it, (K, * TA,) i. e. a thing. (TA.) You say, Azmn biAlmakaAni He remained, staid, dwelt, or abode, a long time (zamaAnFA) in the place. (TA.)
And [hence,] Azmn EanRiI EaTaAWuhu (tropical:) His gift [was a long time kept back from me, or] was slow, or tardy, in coming to me. (TA.)

Azmn fulaAnFA He (God) made such a one to be such as is termed zamin, i. e. affected with a protracted disease; (Msb, TA;) or crippled, or deprived of the power to move or to stand or to walk, by disease, or by a protracted disease: or made him to be affected with what is termed [zamaAnapN, expl. below, as meaning] EaAhapN [&c.]. (TA.) It is said also of a disease [as meaning It deprived him of the power to move &c.]. (TA in art. EDb.)
zamanN an inf. n. of zamina [q. v.]. (Msb, K.)
And a simple subst. [meaning Continuance for a long time,] from Oazomana in the first of the senses assigned to it above; and so zumonapN↓, with damm. (IAar, TA.)

Also, and zamaAnN↓, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the former a contraction of the latter, (Msb,) A time, whether little or much; (S, Msb, K;) thus accord. to Er-Rághib; (TA in art. dhr;) as being a space capable of division: (Msb:) and so says El-Munáwee: (TA:) a time considered with respect to its beginning and its end: (Er-Rághib, MF voce OamadN:) or i. q. EaSorN [as meaning a space, or period, of time]: (M, K:) [often meaning, without any addition to qualify it, a long time; as in an instance of the usage of the latter word above: (see 4:) what follows here applies to each of these words:] zamaAnN differs in some respects from MnN and from OamadN: Sh asserts it to be syn. with dahorN; but AHeyth says that this is a mistake: (TA:) [it is so, however, sometimes, accord. to several authorities, as has been shown in art. dhr; and particularly as meaning fortune, or fate:] IAth says that it is applied to the whole of what is termed AldRahoru [as meaning time], and to a
portion thereof: AHeyth says that it is the zmAn [i. e. season] of fruit, of ripe dates, and of heat and cold: and that it may be [a period of] two months [as meaning any one of the six seasons of the solar year] to six months [as meaning the half-year often termed summer and the half-year often termed winter]: (TA:) [thus] it is applied to any one of the four quarters of the year; (Msb, TA;) the first of which [in the order in which they are commonly mentioned by the Arabs, i. e. autumn,] is called by the Arabs [of the classical age] AlrRabiyEu, but vulgarly Alxariyfu; called by the former name because the first rain is therein, giving growth to [the herbage called] the rabiyE; and called by the latter name because the fruits are gathered therein; and it commences when the sun enters Libra: the second [i. e. winter] is called AlXRitaMCu; and commences when the sun enters Capricornus: the third [i. e. spring] is AlSRayofu, vulgarly called AlrRabiyEu; and commences when the sun enters Aries: the fourth [i. e. summer] is AlqayoZu, vulgarly called AlSRayofu; and commences when the sun enters Cancer: (Msb:) * * The two following tables exhibit the principal divisions of the Arabian Calendar. The latter of them shows the places of the months in relation to the solar year at the period when they received the names by which they are here designated.

row.cell: Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.
Together called by some AlXRitaMCu and AlrRabiyEu.

sense.s: it is also applied to the time, or period, of the reign, rule, prefecture, or the like, of a man: [and to the life-time of a man:] with the philosophers, it signifies the measure of the motion of the ninth (or greatest) sphere (Alfalak AlOaTolas): (TA:) [and there are various other explanations belonging to the conventional language of the schools, not to the proper language of the Arabs: (see the “ Dict. of the Technical Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans: ”)] the pl. (of zamanN, Msb) is OazomaAnN and OazomunN and (that of zamaAnN, Msb) OazominapN. (S, Msb, K.) [The dim. of zamanN, i. e. zumayonN, see below.] In the following trad., UicaA taqaAraba lamo takado ruWyaA AlmuWomini takocibu AlzRamaAnu↓ [When the time becomes contracted, the dream of the believer will scarcely ever, or never, be false], what is meant is the end of time; and the approach of the resurrection; because when a thing becomes little, its extremities contract: or what is meant is the day's and the night's becoming equal; for the interpreters of dreams assert that the times [of dreams] most true of interpretation are the season of the breaking forth of the blossoms and that of the ripening of the fruit, which is when the day and the night become equal: or what is meant is the coming forth of El-Mahdee, when the year will be like the month, and the month like the week, and the week like the day, and the day like the hour, deemed short because deemed delightful: (K in art. qrb:) or it alludes to the shortness of lives and the scantiness of blessings. (TA in that art.) In another trad. it is said, kaAnato taOotiynaA OazomaAna xadiyjapa, meaning [She used to come to us] in the life-time [lit. times] of Khadeejeh. (TA.) And one says also, maA laqiytuhu muco zamanapK↓, meaning mc zamaAnK↓ [i. e. I have not met him for a long time past: but in this case, accord. to the more approved usage, one should say muco zamanapN and muco zamaAnN, or munocu zamanapK and munocu zamaAnK]. (Lh, K, * TA.) (For authorities, and further information, see the words here mentioned, and more particularly nawoCN and rabiyEN; under the latter of which it is said that the third and last of the Six Seasons are called by some, respectively, AlrRabiyEu AlvRaAniI and AlrRabiyEu AlOawRalu; and also that the appellations of the 3rd and 4th months are differently pronounced by different persons; and that some exclude the wasomiIR from the rains called AlrRabiyEu: and for the Calendar of the Mansions of the Moon, see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.) The months are said to have received the names here given to them from Kiláb Ibn-Murrah, an ancestor of Mohammad, about two centuries before El-Islám. These months were lunar; and from this period, with the view of adapting their year to the solar, the Arabs added a month, which they called AlnRasiIoCu, at the end of every three years, until they were forbidden to do so by the Kur-án (ch. ix.): but the months still retrograded through the seasons, though much more slowly. The abolition of the intercalation was proclaimed by Mohammad at the pilgrimage in the tenth year of the Flight.

zaminN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and zamiynN↓, (K, TA,) applied to a man, (S, Msb, TA,) Having, or affected with, a malady of long continuance; (Mgh, Msb, TA; *) as also muzomanN↓; (Har p. 182;) or crippled, or deprived of the power to move or to stand or to walk, by disease, or by a protracted disease: (TA:) or having what is termed zamaAnapN [expl. below], i. e. EaAhapN: (K, TA:) or afflicted [with what is so termed]: (S:) pl. zaminuwna, (K, TA,) of the former, (TA,) and zamonaI, (Msb, K, TA,) [likewise] of the former, (Msb,) or of the latter, as also zamanapN. (TA.)
[Hence,] huwa faAtiru AlnRaXaATi zaminu AlrRagobapi (tropical:) [He is remiss in respect of briskness or promptness, powerless in respect of desire]. (TA.)
zumonapN: see zamanN, second sentence.
zamanapN A space, or period, or a long space or period, of time. (TA.) See also zamanN, last sentence.
zamaAnN: see zamanN, third sentence, and again in two places in the latter part of the paragraph.
zamiynN: see zaminN.

zumayonN [dim. of zamanN]. You say, laqiytuhu caAta AlzRumayoni, meaning thereby taraAxiI Alwaqoti; (S, K;) [i. e. I met him some time ago;] like as one says caAta AlEuwayomi, meaning bayona AlOaEowaAmi: (S:) or meaning fiI saAEapK lahaA OaEodaAdN [in a time consisting of some, or several, subdivisions]: (TA:) or caAta AlzRumayoni means muco valaAvapN OazomaAnK [three seasons ago; or, app., three or more, to ten; (agreeably with an explanation of caAta AlEuwayomi voce cuw;) by AzmAn being app. meant periods of two, or three, or six, months]; (T in art. cuw;) and the like is said by IAar. (TA in art. SbH.)
zamaAnapN an inf. n. of zamina [q. v.]. (S, * Msb, K.)

[Used as a simple subst.] it signifies also A disease, or an evil affection, syn. MfapN, (S,) or EaAhapN, (K,) in animals: (S:) [and particularly, in a man, a disease of long continuance: or such as cripples, or deprives of the power to move or to stand or to walk: (see zamina and zaminN:)] or want of some one or more of the limbs, or members; and privation of the powers, or faculties. (Har p. 315.) And i. q. dahorN [app. as meaning An evil event or accident, a misfortune, or a calamity]. (KL.)
Also Love. (K.)
