[saAEapN zamaAniyRapN A while; an indefinite short time; as distinguished from saAEapN falakiyRapN, which is an astronomical hour: and so, often, saAEapN alone.]
muzomanN: see zaminN.
muzominN Of long continuance; of long standing; over which a long time has past. (TA.) [You say maMCN muzominN Stale water.] And suEaAlN muzominN [Chronic cough]. (K voce maSoTakaA.)
Q. 1: see the next paragraph.
Q. 4. AizomaharRato They (the stars) shone, (S, K,) and were intensely bright. (TA.)
It (the eye) became red by reason of anger, (K,) on the occasion of some distressing event; (TA;) as also zamoharato↓. (AZ, S, K.)
AzmhrR It (the face) grinned, so as to display the teeth; or became contracted, with a stern, an austere, or a morose, look. (K.)
It (a day) became intensely cold. (K.)

zamohariyrN Intense cold. (S, K.) Such is prepared by God as a punishment for the unbelievers in the latter state. (TA.) In the Kur lxxvi. 13, zamohariyrFA means Hurting cold: (Bd:) or [simply] cold: (Jel:) or, accord. to some, it there has the meaning next following. (Bd, Jel.)
The moon; (K;) in the dial of Teiyi. (TA.)
muzomahirRN Laughing so as to show the teeth: (K:) from the likeness to the shining of stars. (TA.)
Angry: (K:) or violently angry. (S.)
1: see 4, in five places.

zanRa EaSabuhu, [aor., accord. to rule,
zanina
, or the sec. pers. may be zaninota, and the aor.
zanana
, and the inf. n., in this case, rananN, which see below, but the TK makes its aor. to be
zanuna
, and the inf. n. zanRN,] His sinews dried up. (K.)
zanRa facanRa means Hqn fqTr [which may be rendered He kept in, or retained, his urine, and then dribbled it, or his urine was kept in, or retained, and then dribbled]. (TA. [See zinRiynN.])

4. Oazonanotuhu I thought him to possess good or evil; as also zananotuhu↓, aor.
zanuna
, inf. n. zanRN: or both mean I imputed, or attributed, to him good or evil: (Msb:) or fulaAnFA bixayorK zanRa↓ or biXarRK he thought such a one to possess good or evil; like OazanRahu; syn. ZanRahu bihi: (K:) or, accord. to Lh, one says, Oazonanotuhu bimaAlK and bixayorK I thought him to possess [property and (as appears from what is said below on his authority) wealth]: but zananotuhu↓ is what the vulgar say, and is wrong. (TA.) And Oazonanotuhu biXaIoCK, (S,) or bikacaA, (K,) and also bkcA zananotuhu↓, (Har p. 112,) [and accord. to Golius Aizotananotuhu↓, mentioned by him as from the S, but not found therein by Freytag, nor by me in either of my copies,] I suspected him of a thing, or of such a thing: (S, K, and Har ubi suprà:) [but] Lh says, laA yakuwnu AlUizonaAnu fiI Alxayori [app. meaning that OazanRa is not said in relation to that which is good: see what is cited on his authority above]. (TA.) And AznRhu biAlOamori He suspected him of the thing, or affair; like OaZanRahu. (S.) And huwa yuzanRu bikacaA [He is suspected of such a thing]. (S.) Hassán says,
i. e. [Chaste, staid,] she is not suspected of evil: [in which tuzanRu may be from zunRato↓ or from OuzinRato:] but some restrict themselves to the quadriliteral verb [AznR]. (Msb.)
8: see 4.
zanRapN A suspicion: whence the saying, Oabuw zanRapK↓ XarRN minohu Oaxuw zanRapK The ape, or baboon, or monkey, (Alqirodu,) worse than he is the person who has conceived a suspicion: (A, TA:) [for]

Oabuw zanRapK, (so in three copies of the S and in my MS. copy of the K,) or Abw zinRapK↓, (thus in the CK and TK and JM, [in the second and third of which it is expressly said to be “ with kesr, ” which, however, the author of the K should have added, accord. to his usual practice, if he meant it to be thus,]) signifies Alqirodu. (S, K.)
Oabuw zinRapK: see what next precedes, in two places.

maMCN zananN, and miyaAhN zananN, [which suggests that zananN is an inf. n. used as an epithet,] A water, and waters, small in quantity, and narrow: (K:) [for] zananN signifies strait, or narrow; like zanaMCN and zaniIRN [which do not belong to this art.]: (TA:) or maMCN zananN means [a place of water] of which one knows not whether there be in it water or not. (K.)
ZilRN zanaAnN Short [or contracted] shade; like zanaMCN [mentioned in art. znO]. (K.)
zunaAnaI A fluid like mucus, that falls from the noses of camels: (K:) but the more approved word is cunaAnaI. (TA.)
zanaAniIRN A man who suffices for himself, without any other. (K.)
zanRaAnN One who opines, or conjectures, much; i. q. ZanRaAnN. (TA.)
zinRiynN One suppressing his urine and his ordure: occurring in a trad.: or, as some say, it is zibRiynN, [q. v.,] with b. (TA. [But see 1, and see also what here follows.])

OazanRu One suppressing his urine [or his ordure]; syn. HaAqinN: such is one of the persons forbidden, in a trad., to act as UimaAm to others. (TA in art. nSr: mentioned also, but not expl., in the present art. in the TA.) [See also the next preceding paragraph.]

1. zanaOa fiI Aljabali, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
zanaAa
, (Msb, K, *) inf. n. zanoCN and zunuwoCN, (S, Msb, K,) He ascended the mountain. (S, Msb, K.)

zanaOa Uilayohi, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) inf. n. zunuwoCN (S, K) and zanoCN, (K,) He (a man, S) had recourse to it (a thing, TA) for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging. (S, K.)

And He approached it, or drew near to it; (K, TA;) namely, a thing. (TA.) [Hence,] zanaOa Alxamosiyna, (S,) or liloxamosiyna, inf. n. zanoCN, (TA,) He drew near to the [age of] fifty [years]. (S, TA.)
zanaOa said of the shade, (S, K,) It became short; (S;) it contracted, shrank, or drew together. (K.)
Said of a place, (TA in art. znw,] It was, or became, strait, or narrow; and zanaA, without C, inf. n. zunuwRN, is a dial. var. thereof in this sense. (ISd, K, TA; all in art. znw.)

Said of the urine, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
zanaAa
, (S, TA,) or
zanuAa
, (Msb,) inf. n. zunuwoCN (S, Msb, TA) and zanoCN, (TA,) It became retained, or suppressed. (S, Msb, K, TA.)
Also He, or it, clave to the ground. (K.)
He hastened, or made haste. (K.)
And He was, or became, affected with a lively emotion, either of joy or of grief; syn. Tariba. (K.)
See also 2, in two places: and see 4.

zanaOa is also expl. in the K as signifying xanaqa [He throttled, or strangled]: but [SM says,] I have not found any of the leading lexicologists to have mentioned this, unless it be a mistranscription for Haqana [a meaning assigned to this verb below: see 4]. (TA.)

2. zanRO Ealayohi, inf. n. tazoniYapN, He straitened, or oppressed, him; made strait, or close, to him; (S, K, TA;) as also Elyh zanaOa↓. (TA.) The verb occurs without C, written zanRaI, by poetic license, in a saying of a rájiz cited in art. Xdx, as an ex. of the word XaAdixapN. (S.) And Ealayohi AlHijaArapa zanaWuwA↓ occurs in a trad. as meaning They made the stones strait, or close, to him, or upon him. (TA.)
4. AznOhu fiI Aljabali He made him to ascend the mountain. (Msb, K, * TA.)
AznOhu also signifies OalojaOahu: (S, K, TA:) so in the saying, AznOhu UilaI AlOamori [He constrained him to have recourse to, or to do, the thing]. (TA.)
AznO bawolahu He retained, or suppressed, his urine; (Msb, K; *) as also zanaOahu↓; the latter verb being trans. as well as intrans. (Msb.)
zanaMCN Straitness, or narrowness; syn. DiyqN. (S. [So in my copies: perhaps a mistranscription for DayRiqN, a meaning mentioned in the next sentence.])
Strait, or narrow; syn. DayRiqN: you say makaAnN zanaMCN [A strait, or narrow, place]: and biYorN zanaMCN [A narrow well]: so in the Fáïk. (TA.)
Short (S, K) and compact, or contracted: (K:) applied to a man: and to shade. (S.)

Retaining, or suppressing, his urine; (S, Msb, K;) as also zaAniYN↓. (Msb.) So in a trad. in which it is said that a man is forbidden to pray when he is znMC; (S, TA;) or where it is said that the prayer of one who is zaAniY↓ will not be accepted: (Msb:) or the latter word in this case means one who is ascending a mountain; because he has not full power [to pray], or because he is straitened by being out of breath. (TA.)
Also, [app. because of its narrowness,] A grave. (TA.)
zaniIoCN A small skin for water or milk. (K.) [See also zaniIRN, in art. znw.]
zaAniYN: see zanaMCN, in two places.

OazonaOu More, or most, strait: so in the saying kaAna laA yuHibRu mina AldRunoyaA UilRaA OazonaOahaA [He used not to love, of worldly enjoyments, or blessings, save the more, or most, strait thereof]. (MF.)
Q. 2. tazanobara EalayonaA He behaved proudly, or haughtily, to us, (K, * TA,) and frowned, or looked sternly, austerely, or morosely. (TA.)
AlzRanobaru The lion. (K.)
zunoburN Small, or young, (K, TA,) and light, or active: applied to a boy. (TA.)
See also zunobuwrN.
zanobariIRN Large, or bulky; applied to a ship: (K:) you say safiynapN zanobariyRapN a large, or bulky, ship: (TA:) or zanobariyRapN signifies a sort of large, or bulky, ship. (S in art. zbr.)
Also Heavy; applied to a man. (K.)
zinobaArN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

zunobuwrN [The hornet, or hornets; a large sort of wasp;] a stinging kind of fly; (K;) a certain kind of flying thing that stings; (T, TA;) i. q. daborN, (S,) or dubuwrN; (TA;) and zunobuwrapN↓ signifies the same, (K,) [or app. is the n. un.,] and so does zinobaArN↓; (S, K,) a dial. var. mentioned by ISk: (S:) [being a coll. gen. n.,] znbwr is [sometimes] made of the fem. gender: the pl. is zanaAbiyru: (S:) and AlzRanaAbiyru sometimes means the flies of the meadows or gardens (cubaAbu AlrRawoDi). (Ham p. 324.)
Also A young ass that is able to bear burdens. (K.)
And A large rat: pl. zanaAbiru, occurring in poetry [app. for zanaAbiyru]. (TA.)

Also, [as an epithet,] Light, or active; clever, or ingenious; (K, TA;) mentioned by Abu-l-Jarráh, from a man of the Benoo-Kiláb, and he adds that it means light, or active; (TA;) quick in reply; (K, TA;) and so zunoburN↓. (K.)

Also, and zinbiyrN↓ and zinobaArN↓, A certain tree, (K, TA,) of large size, (TA,) resembling the dulob [or plane-tree], (K, TA,) but not wide, the leaves of which are like those of the nut-tree in appearance and scent, having blossoms like those of the EuXar [q. v.], white tinged [with another colour], and having a fruit exactly like the olive, which, when fully ripe, becomes intensely black and very sweet, and is eaten by men like ripe dates, has a stone like that of the gubayoraMC [or fruit of the service-tree], and dyes the mouth like as does the mulberry: it is planted. (TA.)

Also, the same three words, A species of the tiyn [or fig], called by the people of the towns and villages the tiyn HulowaAniIR; (IAar, K, TA;) one of the strange trees of the desert: pl. zanaAbiyru. (IAar, TA.)
zinobiyrN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zunobuwrapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Oaxacahu bizanawobarihi is like Oaxacahu bizawobarihi, (K, TA,) meaning He took it altogether; mentioned in art. zbr. (TA.)

OaroDN mazobarapN A land abounding with zanaAbiyr [or hornets, pl. of zunobuwrN; the n being rejected in its formation]: (S in art. zbr, and K:) similar to OaroDN maEoqarapN and mavoEalapN, meaning caAtu EaqaAriba and vaEaAliba. (S.)

zanobaqN [mentioned in the S and Msb in art. zbq] Oil of jasmine: (S, K:) or this is called duhonu AlzRanobaqi, and is of the dial. of El-'Irák; (Az, TA;) [for] it is said that zanobaqN signifies the jasmine [itself]: (Msb:) or, as some say, it is a certain flower, which is put into Xayoraj [i.e. oil of sesame, or, as being likened thereto, because of its clearness, white oil before it becomes altered], and the like, and of which is [thus] made an [odoriferous] oil; like as is done with other species of flowers. (MF.) [In the present day, this name is applied to several species of plants: namely, Mogorium sambac of Juss., Lam., Desfont.:
Nyctanthes sambac of Linn.; nyctanthes undulata in notis Amœn. academ. 4, p. 449: (Delile, Flor. Aegypt. Illustr., no. 8:)
and Iris germanica of Linn.; or Iris sambac of Forsk.: (Idem, no. 26:)
also the lily.]
Also The [musical reed, or pipe, called] zamRaArap, (AA, T, TA,) or mizomaAr. (Aboo-Málik, K.)
OumRu zanobaqK Wine: (IAar, K, and T in art. Am:) or wine such as is termed fayohajN and qinodiydN. (IAmb, TA in art. fhj.)
zanobaAqN A certain herb, or leguminous plant, hot, burning, or biting, to the tongue, and that causes headache. (K.)
zinobiylN and zanobiylN dial. vars. of zabiylN, mentioned in art. zbl [q. v.]: pl. zanaAbiylu. TA.)

AlzRanoju and AlzRinoju, (AA, S, Msb, K,) the latter being a dial. var. of the former, (Msb,) both of them chaste, (TA,) [but the latter is the more common,] and AlzRunuwju↓ (S, K) and Almazonajapu↓, (K,) A certain nation of the blacks; (S, Msb, K;) [the inhabitants of the country called by us “ Zanguebar, ” including the “ Zingis ” of Ptolemy, near the entrance of the Red Sea, and a large portion of inner Africa:] their country is beneath, and to the south of, the equinoctial line; and beyond them is [said to be] no habitation, or cultivation: [sometimes applied to the Negroes absolutely; for] some say that their country extends from the western parts of Africa nearly to Abyssinia, [comprehending the whole of Nigritia properly so called, or at least the whole of the countries of the Negroes known to the Arabs of the classical ages,] and that part of it is on the Nile of Egypt: (Msb:) the n. un. is zanojiIRN↓ and zinojiIRN, (AA, A'Obeyd, ISk, S, K,) like as ruwmiIRN is of ruwmN: (TA:) and OazonujN↓ occurs as a broken pl., meaning the divisions and subtribes [of that nation]: so says AAF, and so in the M. (TA.)
zanojiIRN and zinojiIRN [of which the latter is the more common, A man, and a thing, of, or belonging to, or relating to, the zanoj or zinoj]: see the preceding paragraph.
AlzRunuwju: see the first paragraph.
OazonujN: see the first paragraph.
Almazonajapu: see the first paragraph.

zanojabiylN [Ginger; amomum zinziber;] a certain plant growing in the country of the Arabs, in the land of 'Omán, (AHn, TA,) and in El-Yemen also; (TA;) well known: (S:) [or the root thereof;] a certain root, or roots, (accord. to different copies of the K,) creeping beneath the ground; (K, TA;) burning, or biting, to the tongue; (TA;) growing like the stalks of the papyrus, (K, TA,) and the raAsan [mentioned below]: there is no wild sort of it; nor is it a tree that is eaten fresh like as herbs, or leguminous plants, are eaten; but it is used in a dry state; and its conserve is the best of conserves; and the best thereof is what is brought from the country of the Zinj and China: (TA:) it has a property that is heating, or warming, digestive, lenitive in a small degree, strengthening to the venereal faculty, (K, TA,) clearing to the phlegm, (TA,) sharpening to the intellect, (K * TA,) and exhilarating: (TA:) if mixed with the moisture of the liver of the goat, and dried, and pulverized, and used as a collyrium, it removes the film [upon the eye], and obscurity of the sight. (K, TA.)

It is mentioned in the Kur, where it is said, [lxxvi. 17 and 18,] kaAna mizaAjuhaA zanojabiylFA EayonFA fiyhaA tusamRaI salosabiylFA [The admixture whereof shall be znjbyl, a fountain therein named Selsebeel]: i. e. it shall have the flavour of znjbyl [or ginger], which the Arabs esteem very pleasant: it may mean that znjbyl is [essentially] in the wine of Paradise: or that it is the admixture thereof: or that it is a name for the fountain whence this wine is taken, and which is named Selsebeel also. (Az, O, TA.) As some assert, (ISd, TA,) it means also Wine [absolutely]. (S, ISd, K.)

zanojabiylu AlkilaAbi A certain herb, or leguminous plant, the leaves of which are like [those of] the xilaAf [or salix Aegyptia], and the twigs are red: it clears the [discoloration of the face termed] kalaf, and the [spots in the skin termed] namaX; and it kills dogs; (K;) wherefore it is named in relation to them. (TA.)

zanojabiylu AlEajami i. q. AlOuXoturogaAzu [a word of Persian origin, now applied by Arabs to A species of carline thistle]. (K.) [Accord. to Freytag, Horminum, or salvia silvestris: but this, I believe, is what is called in Pers. OuXoturogaAn.]
zanojabiylu AlXRaAmi i. q. AlrRaAsanu [Inula helenium, common inula, or elecampane]. (K.)

Q. 1. zanojara, (Lth, K,) inf. n. zanojarapN, (S in art. zjr,) He [fillipped, or] struck the thumb upon, or against, the middle finger with the fore finger: (S in art. zjr:) or he fillipped with the nail of his thumb and that of his fore finger: (Lth, A, K: *) you say zanojara lahu, meaning he put the nail of his thumb upon that of his fore finger, and then fillipped with them to him, (Lth, A, *) saying walaA mivola hecaA [Nor, or not even, the like of this will I give thee]; (Lth;) meaning thus, walaA OuEoTiyka mivola hecaA. (A.) The subst., (S,) or the name of this [action], (Lth,) is zinojiyrN↓. (Lth, S.)
zinojiyrN [A fillip, such as is described above]: see what immediately precedes.
A nail-paring: as also zinoqiyrN: both foreign words introduced into the Arabic language: mentioned in the T among quadriliteral-radical words. (TA.)

A
whiteness [or white speck] seen on the nails of young persons; (AZ, K;) likewise called fuwfN and waboXN; (AZ, TA;) as also zinojiyrapN↓. (AZ, K.)

Accord. to IAar, ↓this last signifies What the end of the thumb [or of the thumb-nail] takes from the extremity of the tooth when a man [presses the former against the edge of an upper front tooth and suddenly lets it go forward, and] says, maA laka EinodiI XaIoCN walaA ciho I have not anything for thee: not even this: (TA:) [i. e. it means anything; always used in a negative phrase.]
zinojiyrapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

zunojuforN A certain dye, [or pigment,] well known, (K,) of a red colour, with which one writes as well as dyes; [namely, cinnabar:] its virtue is similar to that of white lead; or, as some say, of XaAdanoj [a kind of stone, used medicinally, from the Persian XaAdonaho]: it is of two kinds, native and factitious: the native is [formed by] the transition of a sulphureous substance into quicksilver: [it is a sulphureous ore of quicksilver:] the factitious [is what is called vermilion, and] is of various sorts. (TA.)

1. zanixa, aor.
zanaxa
(S, K,) inf. n. zanaxN, (S,) said of oil, (S K,) and clarified butter, (JK, L,) and food, (L,) It was, or became, altered [for the worse] (S, K, TA) in odour; (TA;) [stinking, rancid,] bad, or corrupt; like sanixa. (JK.)
And, said of a lamb, or kid, He raised his head in sucking, by reason of choking, or of dryness of the fauces. (K.)
zanixN, applied to oil, (S, K,) and clarified butter, and food, (L,) Altered [for the worse] (S, K, TA) in odour; (TA;) [stinking, rancid, bad, or corrupt; like sanixN: see 1.]
UibilN zanixapN Camels having their bellies straitened, by reason of thirsting (Kr, K, TA) time after time. (Kr, TA.)

1. zanada AlnRaAra, aor.
zanida
, He produced fire [with a zanod and zanodap]. (A, TA.)
[Hence,] zanaduwA naAra AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) [They kindled the fire of war]. (A, TA.)
See also 2.

zanida, aor.
zanada
, (K,) inf. n. zanadN, (TK,) He (a man, TA) thirsted. (K.)
zanidato, inf. n. zanadN, said of a she-camel, Her womb came forth on her giving birth. (L.)
2. znRd, inf. n. tazoniydN, He made his zanod to produce fire. (K.)
He lied. (K.)

He filled (K, TA) a water-skin, or milk-skin; (TA;) as also zanada↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. zanodN; and in like manner a watering-trough, and a vessel: and he filled his water-skin, or milk-skin, so that it became like the zanod, i. e. [hard, or firm, being] full. (TA.)
[He made, or rendered, narrow. You say,] lilofarasi manoxirN lamo yuzanRado The horse has a nostril which was not made narrow when he was created. (A, TA.)

[He straitened, or scanted; made strait, or scanty: see the pass. part. n. Hence, app.,] znRd EalaI Oaholihi [He straitened, or scanted, his family; made their circumstances, or subsistence, strait, or scanty, to them;] he was hard, severe, or rigorous, to his family. (L.)
He punished beyond his right. (K, TA.)
He charged with niggardliness: (TA:) or he, or it, made, or rendered, niggardly, mean, or sordid. (KL.)

zunRidati AlnRaAqapu, inf. n. tazoniydN, The she-camel, having a [tumour of the kind called] qaron in her vulva, had her vulva perforated on every side, and leathern thongs inserted in the holes and tied tight: (ISh, TA:) or tazoniydN [as inf. n. of zunRidato] signifies a she-camel's having the vulva perforated with small sharp-pointed pieces of wood, and then tied with [threads or strings of] hair: this is done when her womb comes forth after her having given birth; (S, K;) on the authority of IDrd, with n and I. (S.)
See also the next paragraph.
4. Aznd, (K,) said of a man, (TA,) i. q. zaAda [He exceeded, &c.]. (K, TA.)

[Hence, app.,] maA yuzoniduka OaHadN Ealayohi, as also mA yuzanRiduka↓, i. q. maA yaziyduka [meaning No one is more sufficient for thee than he: see art. zyd]: (K:) or no one exceeds him to thee in excellence. (TA.)
Aznd fiI wajaEihi i. q. rajaEa [i. e. He relapsed in his pain.] (K.)

5. tznRd He was, or became, straitened, or embarrassed, and contracted in his bosom: (A:) he was, or became, straitened, or embarrassed, so as to be unable to reply, or to answer: and he was angry; (A, K;) and was incensed. (TA.) The saying of 'Adee,

L.foreign: UicaA Oanota faAkahota AlrRijaAla falaA talago
waqulo mivola maA qaAluwA walaA tatazanRadi

sense.s: [When thou jestest with men, be not altogether foolish, but say like as they have said, and be not straitened, &c.,] some relate with I [in the last word, saying tatazayRadi: see art. zyd]. (TA.)

zanodN [A piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire;;] the upper one of the two pieces of stick, or wood, (EuwdaAni, S, M, L, K, or xaXabataAni, L,) with which fire is produced [in a manner described below]; (S, M, L, K;) of the masc. gender; (Msb;) [or masc. and fem.: (see miyqaAdN, in art. wqd:)] and zanodapN↓ is the appellation of the lower one thereof, (S, M, L, K,) in which is the notch, or hollow, (furoDap, M, L, or faroD, A in art. frD,) or in which is a hole (vaqob, S), [whence the fire is produced;] and this is fem.: (S, M:) one end of the zanod is put into the faroD of the zanodap, and the zanod is then [rapidly] twirled round, in producing fire: (A in art. frD:) [the best kind of zanod is made of EafaAr; and the best kind of zanodap↓, of marox: (see these two words:)] the dual zanodaAni is applied to the two together; (S, M, L;) [and so, very often, is the sing. zanodN:] one should not say zanodataAni; (S, M, L, K;) for it is a well-known rule that predominance is to be attributed to the masc.: (MF:) the pl. [of mult.] is zinaAdN↓, (S, M, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) which is also syn. with zanodN, (Kr, L,) and zunuwdN (L) and [of pauc.] OazonudN and OazonaAdN, (S, M, L, K,) the last anomalous [accord. to general opinion because the medial radical is not an infirm letter]; (TA;) and pl. pl. OazaAnidu. (L.) Hence one says, UinRahu lawaAriI AlzRanodi, (TA,) or waAriI AlzRinaAdi, (A,) (tropical:) [lit. He is one whose zanod produces fire, or whose zinaAd produce fire,] alluding to generosity and other commended qualities [of the person to whom it is applied]. (TA.) And warato bika zinaAdiI (tropical:) [lit. My znAd have, or has, produced fire by thy means], (S, A, K,) said by thee to one who has aided, or assisted, thee. (S, K.) And OanaA muqotadiHN bizanodika wakulRu xayorK EinodiI mino Einodika (tropical:) [lit. I am one who produces fire by means of thy znd, and all the good in my possession is from thee]. (A.) [Hence also,] laA yarudRu bukaAIa zanodFA (assumed tropical:) [My weeping will not bring as a return for it so much as a znd; i. e. it will not avail aught]. (Ham p. 83.) And zanodaAni fiI muraqRaEapK: see art. rqE. And zanodaAni fiI wiEaMCK (assumed tropical:) [Two pieces of stick, or wood, for producing fire, in a bag or the like]: a prov. denoting lowness, ignobleness, meanness, or weakness; and applied to two weak persons together. (Meyd.) And layosa fiI jafiyrihi gayoru zanodayoni: see art. jfr.

Hence, (A,) (tropical:) Each of the two bones of the fore arm; [the radius and the ulna;] (A, Mgh, L;) one of which is more slender than the other: the extremity of the znd next the thumb is called kuwEN, and that of the znd next the little finger is called kurosuwEN: the rusog [or wrist] is the place of junction of the zanodaAni, and the part where the hand of the thief is cut off: (L:) in this sense masc.; but improperly made fem.: (Mgh:) the two bones above mentioned are called the zanodaAni as being likened to the zndAn with which fire is produced. (A, Mgh. *) And in some one or more of the dialects, AlOaEolaI mino AlzRanodayoni is The saAEid [q. v.]; and AlOasofalu mina AlzRanodayni, the ciraAE [q. v.]. (L and TA in art. sEd.) [Also] The part of the fore arm which is divested of flesh: of the masc. gender: pl. zunuwdN. (Msb.) And (L) The part where the extremity of the fore arm joins to the hand [on the side of the thumb and also on the side of the little finger, as is shown by what follows]: there are two parts called together zanodaAni; (S, L, K;) the kuwE and the kurosuwE. (S, L.)
Also A certain thorny tree. (K.)

zanadN A durojap (K, TA) consisting of a stone wrapped up in pieces of rag (TA) which is stuffed into a she-camel's vulva, when she is made to take a liking to the young one of another: (K:) it has a string attached to it; and when it distresses her, they pull it out, and she imagines that she has brought forth a young one: so say AO and others. (TA.)
zanodapN: see zanodN, in two places.
zinaAdN: see zanodN; of which it is a pl., and with which it is also syn. [In the present day it is commonly applied to A steel for striking fire: and has for its pl. OazonidapN.]

muzanRadN [Made, or rendered, narrow]. You say vawobN muzanRadN A garment, or piece of cloth, of little width. (S, K.) And mazaAdapN muzanRadapN [A leathern water-bag] narrow, but long; [such that] when thou seest that there is somewhat in it, [thou lookest again, and] lo, there is nothing in it. (A, TA.)
A small, scanty, gift. (A, TA. *)

Narrow; (S, K;) niggardly; (S, A, K;) tenacious; (TA;) who will not confer a small benefit: (A:) low, ignoble, mean, or sordid: (TA:) charged with niggardliness, and held to be little: (Ham p. 178:) and i. q. daEiIRN [i. e. one whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; or an adopted son; &c.]. (K.) And A man quick in becoming angry. (L.)

Q. 2. tazanodaqa [He adopted, or held, or professed, the tenets of the zinodiyq;] he was, or became, a zinodiyq: (S, * K, * TA:) [generally,] he was, or became, a muloHid [i. e. deviater from the right religion, or an impugner of religions], and without religion; (KL;) [a disbeliever in the world to come and in the Deity, or the unity of the Creator: (see zanodaqapN:) and an asserter of the endlessness of time: see zinodiyqN.]

zanodaqN, (Th, O, L, K, [in some of the copies of the K, and in my copy of the Msb, zinodiyqN, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake,]) and zanodaqiIRN↓, A man very niggardly or avaricious. (Th, O, L, K, Msb.)

zanodaqapN a subst from the verb above mentioned; (S, K;) [The adoption, or belief, or profession, of the tenets of the zinodiyq: generally, deviation from the right religion, or the impugning of religious, and the state of him who is without religion;] disbelief in the world to come and in [the Deity, or] the unity of the Creator: (T, Mgh, Msb:) [and the assertion of the endlessness of time: see zinodiyqN.]
Also i. q. DiyqN [as meaning Niggardliness, or avarice: see zanodaqN]. (L, TA.)
zanodaqiIRN: see zanodaqN.
zunoduwqN a dial. var. of SunoduwqN [q. v.]; (K;) like as qazodN is of qaSodN. (TA.)

zinodiyqN One who is of the vanawiyRap [or asserters of the doctrine of Dualism]: (S, O, K:) or one who asserts his belief in [the two principles of] Light and Darkness: or one who does not believe in the world to come, nor in the Deity: (O, K:) or one who does not believe in the world to come nor in the unity of the Creator: (T, Msb:) or one who conceals unbelief and makes an outward show of belief: (K:) an arabicized word, (S, Msb,) originally Pers., so they say, (Msb,) from AlzRanodu, which is a book belonging to them [i. e. the book of Zoroaster]: (PS:) [or from the Pers. zanodiyk, meaning magian, or fire-worshipper: and this seems to be its primary meaning; as De Sacy says in his “ Chrest. Ar., ” 2nd ed., ii. 274:] or, accord. to IDrd, it is an arabicized word from the Persian zinodah, (Mgh, [thus in my copy, app. for zanodaho, in which the h may be, as it is in many other instances, an affix denoting some kind of relationship,]) or zanoda kiro, (TA, as from the L, [but not very clearly written, and with an erasure, such as to suggest that the original and right reading may be zanodo Giyro, which may be rendered holder of the Zend, but]) which is expl. as meaning he [who] asserts his belief in the eternity, or the endlessness, of the present world: (Mgh, TA:) or it is arabicized from zano diyn i. e. woman's religion: (O, K:) or the right explanation is this: that it is a term of relation to the zanod, which is the book of Mánee the Magian, who was in the time of Bahrám the son of Hurmuz the son of Sáboor [or Shápoor], and who claimed to be successor to the Messiah, on whom be peace; and, desiring fame, composed this book, which he hid in a tree, and then took forth: AlzRanodu, in their language, is “ explanation; ” and he meant that this was the explanation of the book of Zará- dusht [or Zoroaster] the Persian; and in it he held that there are two gods, Light and Darkness, Light creating good, and Darkness creating evil: (TA:) or, accord. to the “ Mefáteeh el-'Uloom, ” zinodiyqN means a follower of Mánee, and also a follower of Mezdek, who (i. e. Mezdek) appeared in the days of Kubádh, and asserted that possessions and women were in common, and put forth a book which he called znd, which is the book of the Magians, that was brought by Zará- dusht, whom they assert to have been a prophet: and the companions of Mezdek were named in relation to [this] znd; which word, being arabicized, was converted into zinodiyqN: (Mgh:) Th says that zinodiyqN is not of the [genuine] language of the Arabs; (Mgh, TA;) and when the Arabs desire to express the meaning in which it is commonly used, (Mgh, * Msb, TA,) which is one who does not hold any religion, and who asserts his belief in the endlessness of time, (Msb,) they say muloHidN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) i. e. [a deviater from the right religion, or] an impugner of religions, (Msb,) and dahoriIRN: (Mgh, TA:) some say that it is from AlzRanodaqapu; because the zndyq straitens himself: (L, TA:) an Arab of the desert is related to have explained it as meaning one who looks much into things, or affairs: (Msb:) the pl. is zanaAdiqapN and zanaAdiyqu; (S, O, Msb, K;) the latter being the original pl., and the p of the former being a substitute for the suppressed I of the latter. (S, O.)
1. zanarahu He filled it; (K;) namely, a vessel, and a water-skin. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

2. znRrhu; (Msb;) or zanarahu↓, (K,) inf. n. zanorN; (TA;) [but the former is more probably correct, as tznRr, mentioned below, is its quasi-pass.; or perhaps each is correct;] He put upon him a zunRaAr [or waist-belt]. (Msb, K.)

znRr Eayonahu UilaIRa (assumed tropical:) He looked hard at me: so in the “ Nawádir: ” (TA: [see also the act. part. n., below:]) or znRr UilaIRa biEayonihi (tropical:) [he looked minutely at me]: and zanRarato Eayonuhu (tropical:) his eye looked minutely. (A.)
5. tzRnr He (a Christian [or Jew or Sabian or Magian]) bound a zunRaAr [or waist-belt] upon his waist. (A, Msb.)
(tropical:) It (a thing) became slender, or narrow, (A, K,) so as to be like a zunRaAr. (A.)

zunRaAr (S, A, Msb, K) and zunRaArapN↓ (A, K) and zunRayorN↓ (K) The thing [meaning waist-belt] that is upon the waist of the Christian (S, * A, * Msb, *K) and Magian; (K;) the thing which the cimRiIR [or free non-Muslim subject of a Muslim government, who pays a poll-tax for his freedom and toleration, i. e., Christian, Jew, or Sabian,] binds upon his waist: (T, TA:) [accord. to the K, from tazanRara “ it became slender, or narrow: ” but the reverse is implied in the A: see 5: and it is more probably derived from the Greek ζωνάρη, as observed by Golius, or ζωνάριον, as suggested by Freytag:] pl. zanaAniyru. (A, Msb.)
See also zinRiyrN.
zunRayorN: see zunRaArN.
zinRiyrN, (T, TA,) or zinRiyrapN↓, as also zunRaArapN↓, (TA,) sing. of zanaAniyru, (T, TA,) which signifies Pebbles: (IAar:) or small pebbles. (A'Obeyd, Kr, ISd, K.)
Also zinRiyrN and zunRaArN↓ (Kr,) or zinRiyrapN↓ and zunRaArapN↓, (TA,) Certain small flies (Kr, K) that are in HuXuwX [i. e. gardens, or privies]. (Kr, TA.)
zunRaArapN: see zunRaArN:
and see zinRiyrN, in two places.
zinRiyrapN: see zinRiyrN, in two places.
muzanRarapN A woman tall, and large in body. (K, TA.)
fulaAnN muzanRirN UilaIa biEayonihi (assumed tropical:) Such a one is looking hard at me, and making the eye to project: so in the “ Nawadir. ” (T, TA. [See also the verb, 2.])

1. zanaqahu, (JK, S, O, K,) namely, a mule, (JK, O,) or a horse, (S, K,) aor.
zaniqa
, (O, TA,) inf. n. zanoqN, (JK, TA,) He put a ring in the thin skin beneath the part under his lower jaw, and then attached to it a cord: (JK, O, K:) this ring is put to the head of the refractory mule; and is called zinaAqapN↓: (JK, O, TA:) or he put a zinaAq↓ in the part under his lower jaw, in the skin: (S, O:) every cord with which a beast is tied, [attached to a ring or otherwise] in the skin beneath the part under the lower jaw, is called zinaAqN↓ [or zinaAqapN↓]: (O, TA:) in the K, zunaAqN, like guraAbN; but this is wrong: (TA:) what is in the nose, pierced, is called EiraAnN. (O, TA.)

Also, (IDrd, K,) aor.
zaniqa
and
zanuqa
, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (KL,) He bound his legs by means of the XikaAl [or zinaAq, q. v.]; namely, a mule's; (IDrd, K;) and in like manner, a horse'. (TA.) [This meaning alone I find in the KL, given on the authority of the Mj: but Golius says, as on the authority of the KL likewise, that it signifies also He fitted a shoe to a horse's foot; followed by an accus.]

And zanaqa, (IAar, O,) or zanaqa EalaI EiyaAlihi, aor.
zaniqa
; (K;) and Aznq↓; and znRq↓, (IAar, O, K,) inf. n. tazoniyqN; (IAar, O;) (assumed tropical:) He straitened his household,
by reason of niggardliness or poverty. (IAar, O, K.) And zanaqotu EalaI fulaAnK, and Oazonaqotu↓, I straitened such a one. (JK.)
2: see above, last sentence but one.
4: see 1, last two sentences.
zanaqN The place of the zinaAqN [or zinaAqap]. (S, K.)
The thin part of an arrow-head: pl. zunuwqN. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, K.)
zunuqN: see zaniyqN.
zanaqapN A narrow sikRap [or street]. (S.)
A narrow part of a valley. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O.)

A bend in a wall; or in a sikRap [or street]; (Lth, JK, O;) or in a side of a house; or in a narrow, or very narrow, road of a valley, [so I render fiI Euroquwbi waAdK, (see EuroquwbN,)] in which is what resembles a place of entrance and a twisting or winding: a subst. in all these senses, having no verb. (Lth, O.)
zinaAqN: see 1, in two places.
Also i. q. XikaAlN [i. e. Hobbles for a horse or the like, having a rope extending from the shackles of the fore feet to those of the hind feet]. (TA.)

And The kind of ornament called mixonaqapN [i. e. a necklace, or the like]; (S, O, K; [in this sense correctly said in the K to be like kitaAbN;]) a certain ornament for women, (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O,) of silver. (Ibn-' Abbád, O.)
zaniyqN [in its primary acceptation is app. syn. with mazonuwqN in the first of the senses assigned to the latter below:

and hence,] (tropical:) Firm, strong, or sound; (JK, O, K, TA;) applied to judgment, or an opinion, (JK, O, TA,) and an affair, and management, or exercise of forecast or forethought. (TA.) And zunuqN↓ [which is app. its pl., or EuquwlN zunuqN,] (assumed tropical:) Perfect understandings or intellects. (IAar, O, K.)
zinaAqapN: see 1, in two places.
mazonuwqN Tied, or bound, with the zinaAq [q. v., or with the zinaAqap]. (TA. [See also zaniyqN.])
And (assumed tropical:) Suffering a suppression of the urine. (TA.)
Almazonuwqu is the name of A horse of ' Ámir Ibn-Et- Tufeyl: (S, K:) and of a horse of ' Attáb Ibn-El-Warkà. (TA.)
2. tazoniymN [inf. n. of znRm] The cutting a small portion of the ear of a camel or other animal, and leaving it hanging thereto. (KL. [See zanamapN.])
[And hence,] The act of marking with a sign or token. (KL. [See also the same word as a subst. properly so termed, expl. below.])
And The conjoining any one with a people, or party, to which he does not belong. (KL.)
zanRamuwA UilaIRa hecaA AlxaSomu, (inf. n. tazoniymN, TA,) They sent to me this adversary in order that he might contend in an altercation, dispute, or litigate, with me. (K.)

4. Aznm AlXRajaru (tropical:) The tress had a zanamap↓ (K, TA) [i. e. an excrescence] resembling the zanamap of the XaAp [app. here meaning sheep as well as goat; though sheep are said in the S, and in one place in the TA, to have no zanamap]. (TA.)
zanamN The [projecting] thing that is behind the cloven hoof; also called zalamN; (S, K;) of which it is a dial. var. (S.)

zanimN A camel having a zanamap↓, i. e. a thing [or portion] of the ear cut (S, K) and left hanging down [therefrom], (S,) which is done to camels of generous race (S, K) only; (S;) as also Oazonamu↓ and muzanRamN↓: fem. zanimapN and zanomaMCu↓ and muzanRamapN↓: (S, K:) pl. of pauc. Oazonumu and zanimaAtN. (Yákoot, TA.) [See also Oazolamu.]

DaAYinapN zanimapN (assumed tropical:) A ewe that is held in high estimation; [not signifying having a zanamap, as meaning “ having a kind of wattle; ”] for [it is asserted that] the sheep has no zanamap; that pertaining only to the goat. (S. [But see zanamapN.])

huwa AlEabodu zanomapF and zunomapF↓ and zanamapF↓ and zunamapF↓ (S, K) i. q. zalomapF &c., (K,) He is one whose proportion, or conformation, is that of the slave: or, as Ks says, (or Lh, TA,) the meaning is, truly. (S.) [See also zalomap.]
zanomataA Alfuwqi: see zanamapN.
zunomap: see what next precedes.
zunomapN also signifies A certain tree, having no leaves, as though it were the zanamap of the XaAp [app. here meaning sheep as well as goat: see zanamapN]. (TA.)
zanamapN of the ear of a camel: see zanimN: but accord. to El-Ahmar, it is a mark made by cutting off a portion of the ear. (TA.)

[Of the ear of a man, it is app. The antitragus and also a small prominence of the antihelix immediately above the antitragus: for it is said that] zanamataA AlOucuni signifies two small things (hanataAni) next to the XaHumap [or lobule], opposite to the watarap [an evident mistranscription for watidap i. e. tragus]. (K. [So in all the copies that I have seen.])

Also [A kind of wattle, i. e.] a thing, (Msb,) or piece of flesh, (TA,) hanging from the Haloq [here meaning throat, externally], (Msb, TA,) beneath each ear, (S and A and K in art. rEv,] of the XaAp [i. e., app., sheep as well as goat; though it is said in the S that “ the sheep has no zanamap; that pertaining only to the goat; ” app. because it is uncommon in sheep]. (TA.) [See also zalamapN; and see raEivato and raEovapN and raEovaMCu.]
To this is likened the zanamap of a tree: see 4. (TA.)
And [as the zanamap of the ear of a camel, or of a goat or sheep, serves to distinguish it,] it signifies also (assumed tropical:) A mark, sign, or token. (TA.)

zanamataA Alfuwqi (tropical:) The two edges [or cusps] of the notch of an arrow, (Msb, K, TA,) between which is put the bow-string; (Msb, TA;) as also Alfwq zanomataA↓; (K;) but the former is the more chaste: (TA:) also called XaroxaA Alfuwqi. (S in art. Xrx, and A and TA.)
See also OucunaA Alqalobi, voce OucunN.

AlzRanamapu also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (K, TA,) of which AHn had heard mention made, but remembered not any description: it is said to grow in plain, or soft, tracts, and in the form of the zanamap of the ear; to have leaves; and to be one of the worst of plants. (TA.)
See also zanomap.
zunamap: see zanomap.
zunaAmN A calamity, misfortune, or evil accident. (K.)
See also zunaAmiIRN.
zaniymN, applied to a goat, [and app. to a sheep also,] Having [two wattles, such as are termed] zanamataAni [of which see the sing., zanamapN]; as also muzanRamN↓. (TA.)

Also, and muzanRamN↓, (tropical:) One adopted among a people to whom he does not belong, (Fr in explanation of the former word as used in the Kur lxviii. 13, and S and K,) to which some add, (TA,) not being needed; as though he were a zanamap among them: (S, TA:) and i. q. daEiIRN [as meaning likewise one who is adopted among a people or by a person (though understood in some other sense by F)]; (Mbr, Mgh, Msb, TA;) conjoined [with them or him]: thus the former was expl. by I 'Ab as used in the Kur ubi suprà: (Mbr, TA:) but Az says that the latter word has only the meaning assigned to it above, voce zanimN as an epithet applied to a camel. (TA.) And the former word, (tropical:) Base, ignoble, or mean; known by his baseness, ignobleness, or meanness, (S, K, TA,) or his evil character, (K, TA,) like as the XaAp [i. e. sheep or goat] is known by its zanamap: (S, TA: [in the latter of which is added, “ because the cutting of the ear is a mark: ” but by its znmp is here meant “ its wattle; ” for the cutting of the ear of the camel is a mark of generous race:]) thus expl. by 'Ikrimeh as used in the Kur ubi suprà. (S.) And (assumed tropical:) The son of an adulteress or a fornicatress. (TA.)
Also A commissioned agent, a factor, or a deputy. (TA.)
AlOabadRu AlzRaniymu The lion. (M and K in art. bd, q. v.)

naAIN zunaAmiIRN A nAI [or flute], so called because invented by zunaAm↓, a skilful zamRaAr [or player upon the musical reed] in the service of Er-Rasheed and El-Moatasim and El-Wáthik: vulgarly called zulaAmiIR; said by Esh-Shereeshee to be thus miscalled by the common people of the West. (TA.)
Oazonamu, and its fem. (zanomaMCu): see zanimN.
AlOazonamu AljacaEu i. q. AlOazolamu AljacaEu [q. v.]; (K, TA;) meaning (tropical:) Time, or fortune, to which trials are appendant: or, as some say, hard, or rigorous, in its course. (TA.)
See also what next follows.
OazonamiIRN A camel of those called AlOazonamiyRapu; thus called in relation to [a sub-tribe (baTon) of banuw yarobuwEK or of tamiym named] banuw Oazonama↓. (IAar, TA.)
tazoniymN inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. (TA.)
And also a subst. like tanobiytN and tamotiynN, signifying A certain mark of camels. (TA.)
muzanRamN, and its fem. (with p): see zanimN.
See also zaniymN, in two places.
Also Small in body; like muzalRamN. (IAar, TA in art. zlm.)
Also The young ones of camels. (S, K.)

And A certain
stallion [-camel]; (S, K;) accord. to some, who read thus, in a verse of Zuheyr,

[Sundry spoils consisting of the young camels the offspring of Muzennem]: (S:) thus A'Obeyd read, instead of UifaAlK muzanRami, in which the latter word is used for muzanRamapK, [by poetic license,] because UifaAlN is of a measure common to masc. and fem. words. (EM p. 120.)
1. zanaA, [aor. yazonuw,] inf. n. zunuwRN, It was, or became, strait, or narrow; a dial. var. of zanaOa; (ISd, K, TA;) said of a place. (TA.)

2. znRI Ealayohi He straitened, or oppressed, him; made strait, or close, to him: (ISd, K:) it occurs thus, without C, by poetic license, for zanRaOa, in a saying of a rájiz cited in art. Xdx, as an ex. of the word XaAdixapN. (S in art. znO.)
znRI also signifies He (a man) became lax in his joints. (TA in art. zn.)
zanaMCN: see what next follows, and also art. znO.

zaniIRN Strait, or narrow; (K;) as also zanaMCN↓: (TA in art. znO from the Fáïk; and in art. zn:) the former mentioned in this sense by IAar; (TA;) applied to a bag, or other receptacle. (K, TA.) [See also zaniIoCN, in art. znO.]
zinawiIRN rel. n. from zinFI: see the next article.

1. zanaI, aor. yazoniI, inf. n. zinFI [often written zinFA] and zinaMCN, (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) the latter an inf. n. of 3 (S, Mgh, Msb, K) also, (S, Mgh, K,) but said by some to be a dial. var. of the former, (Msb,) the former being of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, (Lh, S, Msb, TA,) and the latter of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem, (Lh, TA,) or of the people of Nejd, (S, Msb, TA,) He committed fornication or adultery; (El-Munáwee, Er-Rághib, TA;) bihaA with her: (MA:) but accord. to El-Munáwee, [it seems to be properly a dial. var. of zanaOa as meaning he mounted; for he says that,] in the proper language of the Arabs, AlzRinaA signifies the mounting upon a thing; and in the language of the law it signifies the commission of the act first mentioned above: it is [thus] syn. with fajara: and in like manner one says of a woman [zanato]: (TA:) znRI↓, inf. n. tazoniyapN, also signifies the same: (TA:) and so does zAnI↓, inf. n. muzaAnaApN and zinaMCN: (K:) one says of a woman, tuzaAniI↓, inf. n. muzaAnaApN and zinaMCN, meaning tubaAgiI [i. e. She commits fornication or adultery; or prostitutes herself]. (S.) It is said in a prov., laA HuSonuhaA HuSonN walaA AlzRinaMCu zinaMCN [Her continence is not continence, nor the fornication, or adultery, that she commits, fornication, or adultery]: applied to him who does not remain in one state, or condition; neither in good nor in evil: (Meyd:) or to him who refrains from doing good and then is excessive [therein], or from evil and then is excessive therein; not continuing to pursue one way. (TA.) [See also zanoyapN.]

2. znRAhu, inf. n. tazoniyapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) He said to him yaA zaAniI [O fornicator or adulterer]: (S, TA:) or he imputed to him AlzRinaA [i. e. fornication or adultery]; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) and so zAnAhu↓, accord. to the copies of the K; but in the M, AznAhu↓, which, it is there said, has not been heard except in a trad. of the daughter of El- Hasan. (TA.)
See also 1.
And see 2 in art. znw.
3. zaAnaAhaA, inf. n. muzaAnaApN and zinaMCN, [He committed fornication or adultery with her.] (Mgh, Msb.)
See also 1, in two places.
And see 2.
4: see 2.
zinFI, often written zinFA: see the next paragraph, in two places.

zanoyapN A single act of AlzRinaI [i. e. fornication or adultery]: (Msb, TA:) and zinFI↓ is [used in the same sense, (though properly an inf. n., not of un.,) as is shown by its being] dualized: they say zinayaAni: (TA:) [but this is post-classical:] thus using the dual of zinFI, the lawyers say, qacafahu bizinayayoni [He reproached him with two acts of fornication or adultery]: (Msb, TA:) but [in this instance, and] in the saying Xahida EalaI zinaACayoni↓, [which is dual of zinaMCN, properly an inf. n. like zinFI,] or zinayayoni, [He testified, or gave decisive information, respecting two acts of fornication or adultery,] the right word is zanoyatayoni. (Mgh.) One says also, huwa Qbonu zanoyapK, and sometimes zinoyapK↓, (K,) but the former is the more chaste, (Az, TA,) meaning Qbonu zinFI↓ [i. e. He is a son of fornication or adultery]: (K:) or huwa waladu zanoyapK and zinoyapK↓, (Mgh, Msb,) and lizanoyapK [huwa] and lizinoyapK↓, (Mgh,) with fet-h and with kesr, [meaning as above, or wulida lizanoyapK He is, or was, born of fornication or adultery,] contr. of waladu riXodapK and liriXodapK, (Mgh,) or contr. of huwa liriXodapK: (Msb:) or huwa lizinoyapK↓ and lizanoyapK, [He is the offspring of fornication or adultery,] contr. of liriXodapK and liraXodapK: (S:) accord. to Fr, one says, huwa ligayRipK and lizanoyapK and ligayori raXodapK, [all meaning the same, and] all with fet-h: accord. to Ks, however, one may say zinoyap↓ and riXodap, with kesr, but gayRap only with fet-h: (TA:) ISk says that znyp and gyRp are both with kesr and fet-h. (Msb.)
zinoyapN [accord. to analogy signifies A mode, or manner, of fornication or adultery]. See the next preceding paragraph, in five places.
Also The last of a man's children; (K;) like as fijorapN signifies the “ last of a woman's children. ” (TA.)
zinaMCN [properly an inf. n., but having a dual assigned to it]: see an instance of its dual voce zanoyapN

zinawiIRN [meaning Of, or relating to, fornication or adultery] is the rel. n. from zinFI; (S, Msb;) the [radical] I being changed into w because three Is are deemed difficult of pronunciation: (Msb:) and the rel. n. from zinaMCN [having the same meaning] is zinaMYiIRN↓. (S.)
zinaAYiIRN: see what next precedes.
zanRaMCapN an appellation applied to A female ape (qirodapN). (S.)

zaAnK act. part. n. of zanaI: [signifying Committing fornication or adultery: and also a fornicator or an adulterer:] (Msb:) fem. zaAniyapN: (Kur xxiv. 2 and 3:) pl. masc. zunaApN, like quDaApN pl. of qaADK: (Msb:) [and pl. fem. zawaAnK.] yaA zaAniI said to a woman is correct as being [for yaA zaAniyapu, O fornicatress, or adulteress,] apocopated. (Mgh.)
zaAniyapN fem. of zaAnK [q. v.]
Applied to a man, it has an intensive meaning [i. e. One much addicted to fornication or adultery]. (Mgh.)

1. zahida fiyhi, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and Eanohu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
zahada
; (S, K;) [the most usual form of the verb;] and zahada, aor.
zahada
; (S, Msb, K;) which is the most approved form, though MF says otherwise; (TA;) and zahuda, aor.
zahuda
; (Th, K;) inf. n. zuhodN and zahaAdapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and zahodN; (Sb, TA;) He abstained from it; [meaning, from something that would gratify the passions or senses;] relinquished it; forsook it; shunned, or avoided, it; did not desire it; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) contr. of ragiba [i. e. of ragiba fiyhi], (S, K,) and i. q. ragiba Eanohu, (A, Mgh,) and lamo yuridohu, (Mgh,) and tarakahu and OaEoraDa Eanohu: (Msb:) or he abstained from it, meaning a thing of the lawfulness of which he was sure, so far as to take the least that was sufficient thereof, leaving the rest to God: (MF:) or zahaAdapN relates only to worldly things; and zuhodN, to matters of religion: (Kh, Msb, K:) or both signify the exercising oneself in the service of God, or in acts of devotion; as also tazahRudN↓: (KL:) he who makes a difference between zahida fiyhi and zahida Eanohu errs. (Mgh.)
zahaAdapN and zuhodN also signify [particularly The being abstinent in respect of eating;] the eating little. (A, TA.)
And zahada and Azhd↓ He straitened his household, by reason of niggardliness or poverty. (TA in art. znq.)

zahadahu, aor.
zahada
, (K,) inf. n. zahodN, (TA,) (tropical:) He computed, or determined, its quantity, measure, size, bulk, proportion, extent, amount, sum, or number; or he computed by conjecture its quantity or measure &c., or the quantity of its fruit; as also Azhdhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. UizohaAdN; and zhRdhu↓, inf. n. tazohiydN: all used in relation to palm-trees. (TA.) You say, zahadotu AlnRaxolu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) I computed by conjecture the quantity of the fruit upon the palm-trees. (Esh-Sheybánee, S, TA.) And zahadotu AlmaAla (assumed tropical:) I computed by conjecture the quantity, or amount, of the property; or the number of the camels or cattle. (JK.)

2. zhRdhu fiyhi [and Eanohu] He made him, or caused him, to abstain from it; to relinquish it; to forsake it; to shun, or avoid, it; or to be not desirous of it; (L, Msb;) i. q. zagRabahu Eanohu; (L;) trans. of zahida fiyhi: (Msb:) [i. e.] AltRazohiydu fiI AlXRaIoCi and Eanohu is the contr. of AltRarogiybu fiyhi. (S, K. *)

And AltRazohiydu is also (tropical:) syn. with AltRaboxiylu. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, AltRaboxiylu.]) One says, AlnRaAsu yuzahRiduwnahu and yubaxRiluwnahu (tropical:) [Men, or the people, impute to him, or accuse him of, niggardliness, or stinginess]. (A, TA.) And 'Adee. Ibn-Zeyd says,

L.foreign: wa lalobaxolapu AlOuwlaI limano kaAna baAxilFA
OaEaqRu wamano yaboxalo yulamo wa yuzohRadi

sense.s: i. e. (assumed tropical:) [And verily the first single act of niggardliness, of him who is acting in a niggardly manner, is most undutious to parents; (app. because generosity is what they enjoin above all things;) and he who is niggardly is blamed, and] is charged with being a niggard, a low or mean or sordid man. (TA.)
See also 1.

4. Azhd, (JK, L,) inf. n. UizohaAdN, (JK, S, L,) He was, or became, one whose property was not desired, because of its littleness; (JK, L;) he possessed little property, (S * L,) which, because of its littleness, was not desired. (L.)
See also 1.
Azhdhu: see 1, near the end.

5. tzhRd He manifested, or made a show of, zuhod [or abstinence, &c., generally meaning exercise in the service of God, or devotion]: (KL:) [and] he devoted himself to the service of God, or to religious exercises; or applied himself to acts of devotion. (S, Msb.) See also 1.

6. tzAhdwhu (assumed tropical:) They contemned, or despised, him, or it. (K.) It is said in a trad., of wine-drinkers, tzAhdwA AlHadRa, i. e. they contemned the HadR [or prescribed castigation]; held it in little, or mean, estimation; regarded it as a small thing. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

8. Aizodahadahu (assumed tropical:) He reckoned it little. (K.) You say, fulaAnN yazodahidu EaTaMCa fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one reckons little the gift of such a one. (ISk, S.) [See also what next precedes.]

zahodN (tropical:) A small quantity. (A.) You say, xuco zahoda maA yakofiyka (JK, S, K) (tropical:) Take thou the small quantity that is sufficient for thee: (A:) or as much as is sufficient for thee. (JK, S.)

zahadN (tropical:) The poor-rate; syn. zakaApN: (A, K:) mentioned by Aboo-Sa'eed, on the authority of Mubtekir El-Bedawee: so called, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, because of its littleness; the zkAp of property being the least portion of it; or, accord. to the A, because the fortieth part [which is its general proportion] is little. (TA.) So in the saying, maA laka tamonaEu AlzRahada (tropical:) [What aileth thee that thou refusest the poor-rate?]. (A, TA.)

OaroDN zahaAdN (assumed tropical:) Land that does not flow with water except in consequence of much rain: (S:) or land that flows with water in consequence of the least rain; (ISk, JK, and TA in art. HXd;) as also HaXaAdN; (ISk, TA in art. HXd;) [contr. of OaroDN ragaAbN: see also zahiydN.] And zahaAdu AltRilaAEi (assumed tropical:) The small water-courses. (L.)

zahiydN Who eats little; (T, K;) applied to a man; (T;) [and] so zahiydu AlOakoli; (S;) or zahiydu AlTRaEomi: (A:) and so zahiydN or zahiydapN, (as in different places in the T,) applied to a woman: contr. of [ragiybN and] ragiybapN. (T.) You say, fulaAnN zahiydN zaAhidN↓, i. e. [Such a one is abstinent, &c., and] a small eater. (A.)
(assumed tropical:) Small in quantity or number: (S, Msb, K:) so applied to a gift. (S.)
(assumed tropical:) Contemptible, despicable, mean, or paltry. (TA.)
(tropical:) A man who possesses, or does, little, or no, good. (A, TA.)

(assumed tropical:) A man (Lh, TA) narrow, or niggardly, in disposition; (Lh, K, TA;) as also zaAhidN↓; (K;) fem. of the former with p: (Lh, TA:) a low, ignoble, ungenerous, mean, or sordid, man; such that one does not desire what he possesses; as also zaAhidN↓. (L.)
huwa zahiydu AlEayoni, and lahu EayonN zahiydapN, (tropical:) He is content with little; contr. of huwa ragiybu AlEayoni and lahu EayonN ragiybapN. (A, TA.)

waAdK zahiydN (assumed tropical:) A narrow valley: (JK, K:) or a valley that takes, or receives, little water; (ISh, S, TA;) that is made to flow by a slight quantity of water, even as much as a she-goat voids into it, because it is even and hard: (ISh, TA:) contr. of waAdK ragiybN. (TA in art. rgb.) [See also zahaAdN.] And zahiydu AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) What is narrow, of land; and that from which much water does not come forth: pl. zuhodaAnN. (L.)
zihRiydN: see the next paragraph.

zaAhidN act. part. n. of zahida [i. e. Abstaining, or abstinent; relinquishing; forsaking; shunning, or avoiding; not desiring or desirous: and particularly abstaining from, or shunning, or retiring from, worldly pleasures; exercising himself in the service of God, or in acts of devotion; a devotee]: and zihRiydN↓ has a similar, but intensive, meaning [i. e. abstaining much, or very abstinent; &c.]: pl. of the former zuhRaAdN. (Msb, TA.) See also zahiydN, in three places.

muzohidN A man possessing little property, (JK, S, A,) so that one does not desire it. (JK.) It is said in a trad., OafoDalu AlnRaAsi muWominN muzohidN, meaning [The most excellent of men is a believer] possessing little property. (S, A.)

1. zahara zaharato, (S, A, K, &c.,) aor.
zahara
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. zuhuwrN, (S, K,) It (a star, TA, and the moon, and a lamp, and the face, K) shone, or glistened; (K, TA;) as also Azdhr↓: (K:) it (fire, S, A, K, and the sun, A) gave light; shone; or shone brightly: (S, A, K:) it (a thing) was clear in colour, and gave light, or shone, or shone brightly: (Msb:) and you say also, of the moon and of the sun, zahara [and zaharato], aor.
zahara
, inf. n. zahorN; and zahura [and zahurato, aor.
zahura
]. (TA.)
zahara AlzRanodu The piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire emitted shining fire; made its fire to shine. (TA.)

zaharato bika naAriI (S, A) [lit.] My fire hath become strong and abundant by means of thee: (S:) and zaharato bika zinaAdiI (T, K) [lit.] my pieces of stick, or wood, for producing fire have become powerful and abundant [in fire] by means of thee: (K:) meaning, (tropical:) my want hath been accomplished by means of thee: (T, TA:) like wariyato bika zinaAdiI. (S.)

zahara, aor.
zahara
; (Msb;) and zahira, aor.
zahara
, (K,) inf. n. zaharN; (TA;) and zahura; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He, or it, was, or became, white; (Msb, K;) and beautiful: (K: [so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K; but omitted in the TA:]) or of a bright white colour: (TA:) or of any shining colour: (AHn, R:) and zahara (assumed tropical:) it (a plant) was, or became, beautiful: (AHn, TA:) and zahira aor.
zahara
, (tropical:) he (a man) was, or became, white, or fair, in face. (Msb.)
See also 4, in two places.
zaharati AlXRamosu AlUibila The sun altered the camels. (K.)
4. Azhr He made a fire, (S, K,) and a lamp, (A,) to give light, to shine, or to shine brightly. (S, A, K.)

Oazoharota zanodiI [lit., Thou hast made my piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire to emit shining fire, or abundant fire; meaning, (tropical:) thou hast made me to accomplish my want: see 1]. (A.)

Azhr (AHn, T, S, M, A, Msb, [and so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, but SM says that in all the copies of the K it is written AizoharRa↓, like AiHomarRa,]) It (a plant, or herbage, S, K, &c., and a tree, TA) flowered, or blossomed; (AHn, T, S, Msb, &c.;) as also zahara↓, aor.
zahara
; (Msb;) and AzhArR↓. (AHn, K.)
Oazoharati AlOaroDu, and zaharat↓, The land abounded with flowers. (Zj, TA.)
8: see 1.

Aizodahara bihi, (originally Aizotahara, TA,) He took care of it, (S, A, K,) and was mindful of it: (A:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) he rejoiced in it; (IAth, K) his face became shining by reason of it: (IAth:) or he was mind ful of it: or [Aizodahiro bihi signifies be thou vigorous, sedulous, earnest, energetic, or diligent, in it; meaning, in the thing that I command thee to do; for] AlAizodihaAru biXaIoCK means [by implication] thy commanding thy companion to be vigorous, sedulous, earnest, energetic, or diligent, in the thing which thou commandest him to do: (K:) all which significations are from zahorapN in the sense of “ beauty, and brightness. ” (TA.) It is said in a trad. that Mohammad bequeathed to Aboo- Katádeh the vessel from which he performed ablution, and said to him, Aizodahiro bihecaA faUinRa lahu XaOonFA Take thou care of this, and do not lose it, (S, TA,) but be mindful of it, [for it is a thing of importance:] (TA:) or rejoice thou in this; let thy face become shining by means of it: (IAth:) or, accord. to Th, take it up; or charge thyself with it: and he says that this verb is Syriac: A 'Obeyd thinks it to be Nabathean or Syriac: Aboo-Sa'eed says that it is Arabic. (TA.)
9: and 11: see 4.

zahorN, a pl., (K,) or [rather a coll. gen. n.] like
tamorN, (Msb,) of which the sing., (K,) or n. un., (Msb,) is zahorapN↓, (Msb, K,) which latter signifies, as also zaharapN↓, A flower, or blossom, of a plant: (S, Msb, K:) or a yellow flower or blossom; (IAar, K;) and white flowers are called naworN: (IAar:) or a flower or blossom that has become yellow: (IAar, TA:) IKt says that the term zhrp is not applied to a flower until it becomes yellow: or it signifies an open flower or blossom; a flower or blossom before it opens being called buroEuwmN: (Msb:) pl. OazohaArN, and pl. pl. OazoAhiyru. (A, * K.) One says, kaOanRa zahora AlnRujuwmi zahoru AlnRujuwmi [As though the flowers of the herbs were the shining of the stars]. (A.)

Also zahorapN↓ (Th, K) and zaharapN↓, (K,) or the former only, (TA,) A plant: (Th, K:) but ISd thinks that Th, by this explanation, means the signification first given above: and MF disallows the meaning of a plant as unknown. (TA.)
zihorN A want. (K, TA.) So in the phrase, qaDayotu minohu zihoriI [I accomplished what I wanted of him, or it]. (TA.)
zahorapN: see zahorN, in two places.

zahorapu AldRunoyaA, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and zaharatuhaA↓, (AHát, M, K,) the former agreeable with the reading of verse 131 of chap. xx. of the Kur obtaining among the people of the Harameyn, and the latter with that generally obtaining in El-Basrah, (AHát, TA,) [but the latter is disallowed in the Msb, and by MF,] The beauty and splendour of the present world or life; (M, A, K;) its goodliness; (S, M, A, K;) its sweetness, or pleasantness; or the abundance of its goods, conveniences, or comforts; (S, M;) its goods; (Msb;) its finery, (Msb, TA,) or beauty and splendour, and abundance of good things. (TA.)
zuhorapN (assumed tropical:) Whiteness; (Yaakoob, S, K;) and beauty: (K:) whiteness, or fairness, characteristic of good birth: (S:) or bright whiteness: (TA:) or any shining colour. (AHn, R.)
zaharapN: see zahorN, in two places:
and zahorapN.
AlzRuharapu [The planet Venus;] a certain star, (S, Msb, K,) well known, (K,) white and brilliant, (TA,) in the third heaven. (K.)
AlzRuharu [the pl.]: see Oazoharu, near the end of the paragraph.
zaAhirN [Shining; &c. See 1.]
Applied to a zanod, or piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire, Emitting shining fire; making its fire to shine. (TA.)
Applied to a plant, (assumed tropical:) Beautiful: and to the complexion of a man, bright; shining: and i. q. Oazoharu, q. v. (TA.)
OaHomaru zaAhirN (assumed tropical:) Intensely red. (Lh, K.)
lifulaAnK dawolapN zaAhirapN (tropical:) [Such a one has a brilliant turn of fortune]. (A.)

yamoXiI AlzRaAhiriyRapa He walks with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an inclining of the body from side to side: (K, * TA:) occurring in the poetry of Aboo-Sakhr El-Hudhalee. (TA.)
Oazoharu Shining; giving light; bright. (Sudot;, K.) Hence, (TA,) AlOazoharu The moon. (S, K.) And AlOazoharaAni The sun and the moon. (ISk, S, A, K.)
(assumed tropical:) White; (S, K;) and beautiful: (K:) or of a bright white colour: (TA:) or of any shining colour: (AHn, R:) as also zaAhirN↓. (TA.)

(tropical:) A man white, or fair, in face: (Msb:) having a bright, or shining, face: (K:) having a white, or fair, and bright, or shining, face: (S:) a man having a white, or fair, complexion, characteristic of good birth: (Sh, S: *) or of a bright white or fair complexion, with a shining face: or mixed with redness: (TA:) and zahoraMCu a woman white, or fair, in face: (Msb:) having a bright, or shining, face: (K:) having a white, or fair, and bright, or shining, face: (S:) of a bright white or fair complexion intermixed with redness. (TA.)
(assumed tropical:) Bright, or shining, applied to an animal and to a plant. (AA.)
Applied also to water [app. as meaning Bright and clear] (TA.)
And i. q. HuwaAr [app. a mistranscription for HuwRaAraI, i. e. White, or whitened, applied to flour]. (TA.)
(assumed tropical:) A wild bull: and zahoraMCu a wild cow. (S, K.)
(assumed tropical:) A white lion. (K.)
A white ewer or jug, in which wine is made. (TA voce garabN.)
(assumed tropical:) Milk just drawn. (AA, K.)
AlzRahoraMCu is applied by Ru-beh to The white cloud (saHaAbap) lightning in the evening. (O, K.)
durRapN zahoraMCu (tropical:) A white and clear pearl. (TA.)
AlzRuhoru Three nights of the beginning of the [lunar] month: (TA:) or so AlzRuharu↓. (Har p. 299.)
Alyawomu AlOazoharu Friday. (O, K, * TA.)
AlzRahoraAwaAni [The two chapters of the Kur-án entitled] Albaqarapu and Mlu EimoraAna. (O, K.)
A camel parting his legs wide, cropping the trees. (K.)
mizoharN A certain musical instrument; (Msb;) the lute (Euwd) upon which one plays: (S, K:) pl. mazaAhiru. (Msb.)
One who makes the fire bright, and turns it over [to prevent its going out or becoming dull,] (yuqalRibuhaA, K and TA, in the CK yuwqiduhA,) for [the purpose of attracting] guests. (K.)
mazohuwrN, applied by El-'Ajjáj to the lamp of the darkness [i. e. the moon], Made to shine; from Oazoharahu QllRehu; like majonuwnN from OajanRahu: or, as some say, shining. (TA.)

1. zahaqato nafosuhu, and zahiqato, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) the latter preferred by IKoot and Hr, but the former by A'Obeyd, (TA,) aor.
zahaqa
, (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. zuhuwqN, (S, Mgh,) which is of both verbs, (S,) or this is of the former verb, and the inf. n. of the latter is zahaqN, (Msb,) [but in the K it seems to be indicated, by its being said of the latter verb that it is of the class of samiEa, that the inf. n. of this verb is zahoqN,] His soul went forth, passed forth, or departed: (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) it perished: it died: (TA:) nafosuhu Ainozahaqato↓ and AinozihaAqu AlrRuwHi are not of the [classical] language of the Arabs. (Mgh.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 55 and 86] watazohaqa Oanofusuhumo wahumo kaAfiruwna [And that their souls may depart while they are unbelievers]. (S.) The primary meaning of zuhuwqN is The going forth, passing forth, or departing, with difficulty. (Bd in ix. 55.)

[Hence,] zahaqa AlXRaIoCu (tropical:) The thing perished, passed away, or came to nought; (Msb, K, TA;) became null, void, or of no effect. (K, TA.) And zahaqa AlbaATilu (tropical:) What was false, or vain, passed away, or came to nought, (S, Msb, K, TA,) being overcome by the truth, or reality, or fact: or, accord. to Katádeh, by AlbATl is here meant the devil. (TA.)

And zahaqa AlsRahomu (S, Msb, K, TA) and zahiqa (Msb) (tropical:) The arrow passed beyond the butt, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and fell behind it: (TA:) or went swiftly: (Ham p. 23:) or the former has this meaning: and the latter is syn. with zaliqa [app. meaning it slid along the ground]. (JK.)

And zahaqa Alfarasu, aor.
zahaqa
, inf. n. zuhuwqN, (assumed tropical:) The horse preceded, went before, got before, outwent, or outstripped. (S, * Msb.) And zahaqati AlrRaAHilapu, inf. n. zuhuwqN (ISk, S, K) and zahoqN, (TA as from the K, [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,]) (tropical:) The saddle-camel preceded, went before, got before, outwent, or outstripped, the horses, or horsemen; (ISk, JK, * S, K, TA;) and Anzhqt↓ signifies the same. (JK.) And zahaqa fulaAnN, inf. n. zahoqN and zuhuwqN, (tropical:) Such a one preceded, went before, &c.; (K, TA;) or zahaqa bayona OayodiynaA (tropical:) preceded us, went before us, &c., and preceded, &c., the horses, or horsemen; (TA;) and Anzhq↓ signifies the same. (K.)

zahaqa said of a bone, (S, K,) aor.
zahaqa
, (K,) inf. n. zuhuwqN, Its marrow became compact and full; (S, K;) as also Azhq↓. (L, K.) And zahaqati AldRaAbRapu, with the same aor. and inf. n., The beast was, or became, marrowy in the utmost degree, its marrow-bones being compacted and full. (TA.)
Also, said of marrow, It was, or became, compact and full. (S, K.)
2: see 2 in art. zrq: and see 4 below.

3. zAhq AlHaqRu AlbaATila (TA [there expl. by zahaqah, a mistranscription, app. for Ozohaqahu↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) The truth, or reality, or fact, made what was false, or vain, to pass away, or come to nought.])

4. Azhq nafosahu He (God) caused his soul to go forth, pass forth, or depart. (Mgh, Msb.) The phrase Alqatolu UizohaAqN means (assumed tropical:) Slaughter is a cause of making the soul to come to nought, and to depart. (Mgh.)
[Hence,] Azhq AlbaATila (tropical:) He (God) caused what was false, or vain, to pass away, or come to nought. (S, K, TA.) See also 3.
And Azhq AlsRahoma (S, K) mina Alhadafi (K) (tropical:) He made the arrow to pass beyond the butt. (S, K, TA.)

And Azhqt AldRaAbRapu AlsRaroja (assumed tropical:) The beast shifted forward the saddle, and threw it upon its neck: (S, K:) and, or but, it is said to be with raMC: [i. e. one says also, or correctly, accord. to some, Oarohaqatohu:] a rájiz says,

[(assumed tropical:) I fear that she may shift it forward, and throw it upon her neck, or it may shift backwards]: [thus, says J,] cited to me by Abu-lGhowth, with zaAI. (S.) [Accord. to my copy of the KL, tazohiyqN↓, inf. n. of zhRq, signifies (assumed tropical:) The shifting backwards of a camel's saddle from his back: see 2 in art. zrq.]

And Azhq fiI AlsRayori
(assumed tropical:) He was quick [as though urging himself forward] in pace, or journeying. (K.)
Azhqhu also signifies He filled it; (S, O, K;) namely, a vessel: (S, O:) but accord. to the L, he overturned it; i. e. a vessel. (TA.)
See also 1, near the end.
7: see 1, in three places.

One says also Anzhqt AldRaAbRapu (assumed tropical:) The beast leaped, or leaped upwards, (S,) or went forward, or preceded, (O, K,) in consequence of beating, or taking fright. (S, O, K.) And The beast fell into a deep place, or from a mountain; or fell from a mountain and died; syn. taradRato. (TA. [See the next paragraph.])

zahaqN A low, or depressed, part of the ground. (S, O, K.) A hollow, or cavity, or deep hollow or cavity, in the ground; syn. wahodapN: (JK, TA:) sometimes, or often, beasts fall into it, and die. (TA. [See 7.])
zahiqN (tropical:) Light, and unsteady, or lightwitted; (S, K, TA;) applied to a man. (S.)
And A beast not exceeded in fatness. (TA.)
zahaqaI (assumed tropical:) A mare that precedes, or outgoes, the [other] horses, or the horsemen. (Sh, K.)
humo zuhaAqu miAYapK and zihaAqu mAYp i. q. zuhaMCu miAYapK, (K, * TA,) i. e. They are of the number of a hundred. (TA.)

zahuwqN (tropical:) A thing passing away, or coming to nought; or that passes away, or comes to nought; as also zaAhiqN↓. (K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xvii. 83], UinRa AlbaATila kaAna zahuwqFA, i. e. (tropical:) [Verily what is false, or vain,] is a thing that passes away, or comes to nought. (TA.)

(tropical:) A deep well; (JK, S, K;) as also zaAhiqapN↓; [in the TA zaAhiqN;] and in like manner both are applied to a place of destruction (matolafapN); (JK;) and to a matolafap [app. meaning a desert in which people perish] as meaning far-extending. (Ham p. 23.) And in like manner, (S,) the former is also applied [app. as an epithet] to a fajR [or road, or depressed road,] of an overpeering, or overhanging, mountain. (S, K.)
Also (tropical:) Light, or active; syn. xafiyfN. (JK.)
zaAhiqN Perishing, or dying. (Az, TA.)
See also zahuwqN, in two places.
(tropical:) An arrow passing beyond the butt, and falling behind it: (Mgh, TA:) whence the saying, in a trad., UinRa HaAbiyFA xayorN mino zaAhiqK [expl. in art. Hbw]. (TA.)

[(assumed tropical:) Preceding, or outgoing.] You say, jaMCa zaAhiqFA (assumed tropical:) He came before, or in advance of, the horses, or horsemen. (JK.) And raAHilapN zaAhiqapN (assumed tropical:) A saddlecamel preceding, going before, getting before, outgoing, or outstripping, the horses, or horsemen. (S.)
(assumed tropical:) A man put to flight: (S, O, K:) pl. zuhaqN, (so in my copies of the S,) or zuhRaqN, (so in the O,) or zuhoqN and zuhuqN, with damm and with two dammehs. (K.)
(tropical:) Water running vehemently: (JK, K, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a canal (xaliyjN) running swiftly. (TA.)

Applied to a beast (daAbRap), Fat, (JK, Az, S, K,) and marrowy: (S, K:) or marrowy, but not fat in the utmost degree: or having thin, or little, marrow: (TA:) and dry, or tough, (K, TA,) by reason of leanness; so says As: (TA:) and, (K,) or as some say, (JK,) very lean; (JK, K, TA;) Such that a foul odour is perceived arising from the meagreness of its flesh: (TA:) thus it bears two contr. meanings. (K.)

And, applied to marrow, Compact and full: (S, TA:) or, so applied, good in respect of fatness: and some say, i. q. raArN [i. e. in a melting state, or corrupt, by reason of emaciation; or thin; &c.]: so that [thus applied also] it bears two contr. meanings. (JK.) In the saying of a rájiz, (S, TA,) namely, 'Omárah Ibn-Tárik, (TA,)

accord. to Fr, it is in the nom. case, the poetry being what is termed mukofaO, [by which is here meant having one rhyme made to end with kesreh (which is substituted for fet-hah by poetic license) and another with dammeh,] the poet meaning [And a rope, or many a rope, tightly twisted, of the fur of she-camels, that were not aged ones, nor such as had their teeth fallen out by reason of extreme age, nor weak,] but whose marrow was compact and full: [or, agreeably with an explanation given above from the JK, zAhq may mean in a melting state, &c.:] another explanation is, that zAhq here means caAhib [going away]: (S, TA:) but, as Sgh says, the [right] reading is
[meaning but of a reddish, or yellowish, or dingy, white hue, of generous race, having compact and full marrow]. (TA.)

OuzohuwqapN sing. of OazaAhiyq in the phrase farasN caAtu OFzaAhiyqa (tropical:) A mare having wonderful, or admirable, qualities in running: (A, TA:) or this means a mare having a swift running. (S, K.)
One says also, jaMCa ti Alxayolu OazaAhiqa and OazaAhiyqa, meaning (assumed tropical:) [The horses, or horsemen, came] in troops in a state of dispersion. (A'Obeyd, TA.)
OazaAhiyqu is also the name of A horse of Ziyád Ibn-Hindábeh. (K.)
muzohaqN Slain. (El-Muärrij, S.)
muzohiqN Slaying, or a slayer. (El-Muärrij, S.)
And (assumed tropical:) A man quick [as though urging himself forward] in his pace, or journeying. (S, TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) Loquacious. (JK.)
mazohaqapN [A cause of the departure of the soul: a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN].

[Hence,] one says of a camel which others strive in vain to overtake, hecaA Aljamalu mazohaqapN liOarowaAHi AlmaTiIRi (tropical:) [This camel is one that takes away the breath of the other beasts, or saddle-camels]. (A, TA.)
rajulN mazohuwqN (assumed tropical:) A man who is straitened. (TA.)

1. zahima, inf. n. zuhuwmapN and zahamN, It stank: [in which sense zahuma, inf. n. zuhuwmapN, is mentioned by Freytag on the authority of the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen:] said of flesh-meat. (MA. [See also zuhuwmapN and zahamN below.]) And zahimato yaduhu (S, MA, K,) aor.
zahama
, (K,) inf. n. zahamN, (S, K,) His hand was, or became, greasy, (S, MA, K,) mina AlXRaHomi from the fat: (MA:) or had in it the odour of fat. (TA)
zahima; also signifies He suffered from indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach arising from food which it was too weak to digest: (JK, K:) said of a man. (JK.)

zahama, (K,) aor.
zahuma
, inf. n. zahomN, (TK,) It (a bone) was, or became, marrowy; had, or contained, marrow; as also Azhm↓. (K, TA.)
4: see what next precedes.

zuhomN Fat, as a subst.: (S:) or so zahamN↓; a particular term for it, not implying there being in it the odour of fat and stinking flesh-meat: (JK: [and the same is said in the TA in relation to the former word:]) or the latter signifies fat of a beast of prey: (TA:) or, as some say, flesh-meat that is raw, or not thoroughly cooked: (JK:) and the former, fat of a wild animal: or of the ostrich: or of horses: (K:) or, as some say, of a wild animal that does not chew the cud: (TA:) or in a general sense. (K.)

And The perfume known by the name of zabaAd [i. e. civet], which comes forth from the [cat called] sinRaworu AlzRabaAdi, from beneath its tail, in the part between the anus and the meatus urinarius. (K.)
Also A fetid odour. (K.) [See also zahamN and zuhuwmapN.]
zahamN The fetid odour of corpses or carcases. (TA. [See also 1, first sentence; and the last explanation of zuhomN; and see zuhuwmapN.])
And The remains of fat in a horse or similar beast (fiI daAbRapK). (TA.) See also zuhomN.
zahimN [part. n. of zahima]. You say, laHomN zahimN Stinking, fat, flesh-meat. (JK.) And yaduhu zahimapN His hand is greasy: (S, K:) or has in it the odour of fat. (TA.)
And Very fat; having much fat: or having some remains of fatness. (K.)
zuhomapN: see zuhuwmapN.

zahomaAnu Suffering from indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach arising from food which it is too weak to digest: (JK, K:) and zhmAn with damm [i. e. zuhomaAnN↓, with tenween, for, as is said in the S (voce EuroyaAnN), a word of the measure fuEolaAn has its fem. with p meaning, if an epithet,] signifies [the same, or] satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach; as also zuhomaAniIRN↓. (Z, cited by Freytag in his Arab. Prov., ii. 196.) And [hence, app.,] zahomaAnu, (Abu-n-Nedà, IAar, TA,) or zuhomaAnu↓, [imperfectly decl. (like the first word) as a proper name ending with An] (AHeyth, IDrd, S, TA,) or each, (K,) the name of A certain dog. (S, K, &c.) It is said in a prov., zaAduhu fiI baToni zahomaAna↓ In the belly of the dog zhmAn is his provision: applied to a man who has with him his apparatus, and what he needs: or, accord. to AA, the case was
this: a man slaughtered a camel, and divided it, and gave to [one whose name was] zhmAn his share, and then zhmAn returned to receive again with the [other] people; and it is applied to a man who seeks a thing when he has received once: (Meyd:) Z says that zahomaAnu is the name of a man who came to a people that had slaughtered a camel, and asked them to give him some food thereof, and they gave it him: then he returned to them, and they said to him thus, meaning “ Thou has had thy provision thereof, and it is in thy belly; ” and it is applied to any one who has received his share of a thing, and then come, after that, seeking it: or, as some relate it, it is with damm, [zuhomaAn↓] and is applied to one who is invited to a repast when he is satiated: or it relates to one suffering from indigestion: or zhmAn is the name of a dog; and it originated from the fact that a man prepared for himself some provision, and was unmindful of it, and a dog ate it; and it is applied to him for whom there is no share. (Z cited by Freytag ubi suprà.)
zuhomaAnN and zuhomaAnu: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
zuhomaAniIRN: see zahomaAnu, first sentence.

zuhuwmapN The odour of fat and stinking flesh-meat; (JK, K; [and mentioned also, but not explained, in the S;]) as also zuhomapN↓: (K:) or the latter signifies a fetid odour [in a general sense]: (S:) but accord. to Az, the former signifies the disagreeableness of odour, without the being fetid, or altered [for the worse]; such as the odour of lean flesh-meat, or the odour of the flesh of a beast of prey, or strong-smelling sea-fish; the fish of the rivers having no zhwmp. (TA.) [See also 1, first sentence; and ruhomN, last signification; and zahamN.]

1. zahaA, said of seed-produce, It increased, or augmented; received increase and blessing from God; or throve by the blessing of God: (JK, TA:) [or,] said of herbage, aor. yazohuw, inf. n. zahowN, it attained its full growth: (Msb:) or it put forth its fruit: or it became tall: (TA:) and, said of palm-trees, (naxolN, S, Msb, K, TA,) and likewise of plants, (TA,) aor. as above, (Msb, TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, Msb, TA,) they became tall; (K, TA;) became tall and fullgrown; or became of their full height, and blossomed; (TA;) and AzhI↓ signifies the same: (K:) or both signify they (i. e. palm-trees) showed redness, and yellowness, in their fruit; (S, Msb;) the latter verb mentioned by AZ, but [it is said that] As did not know it: (S: [see, however, what follows:]) or, as some say, the former signifies they put forth their fruit; and ↓the latter, as expl. next before: (Msb:) accord. to Abu-lKhattáb and Lth, one says of palm-trees (naxol) only yuzohiI; not yazohuw: and As [is related to have] said, [contr. to what has been asserted of him above,] that when redness appears in [the fruit of] palm-trees, one says AzhI. (TA.)
