And zahaA AltRamoru, (JK,) or Albusoru; and AzhI↓; (Mgh, K;) and zhRI↓, (K,) inf. n. tazohiyapN; (TA;) [The dates, or dates beginning to ripen,] showed their goodness by redness, and yellowness: (JK:) became red, and yellow: (Mgh:) became coloured. (K.) Hence the trad., nahaI Eano bayoEi vamari AlnRaxoli HatRaI yazohuwa, or yuzohiIa↓, [He forbade the selling of the fruit of the palm-trees until its becoming red or yellow], thus differently related. (Mgh.)
You say also, zahaA AlgulaAmu, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) The boy grew up; or attained to youthful vigour, or the prime of manhood. (K.)

And zahati AlXRaApu, (JK, S, K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., (JK, S,) The ewe, or she-goat, became large in her udder: (JK:) or secreted milk in her udder, and was near to bringing forth. (AZ, S, K. *)
And zahati AlrRiyHu The wind rose, blew, or became in a state of commotion. (S.)

And zahati AlUibilu, (JK, S, M, K,) aor. as above, (JK, M,) and so the inf. n., (S, M,) The camels journeyed, after coming to water, (JK, S, M, K,) a night or more, (JK, S, M,) so says A'Obeyd, (S,) or a night or two nights. (K.) And The camels passed along, (marRat,) so in the copies of the K, but correctly madRat [i. e. made much advance in journeying], as in the M, (TA,) in search of pasturage, after they had drunk, (K, TA,) not pasturing around the water. (TA.) The verb used in relation to camels is also trans., as will be shown below. (S, &c.)

zahowN [as inf. n. of the trans. v. zahaA, aor. yazohaI,] primarily signifies The act of raising, or elevating: and the act of shaking; or putting in motion, or into a state of commotion: whence zahaAhu AlsRaraAbu and zahati AlrRiyHu AlnRabaAta [both expl. in what follows]. (Har p. 171.) You say, zahati AlOamowaAju AlsRafiynapa The waves raised the ship. (TA.) And zahaA AlsRaraAbu AlXRaIoCa, aor. yazohaAhu, The mirage raised, or elevated, [to the eye,] the thing [seen in it or beyond it; or rather, made it to appear tall, and as though quivering, vibrating, or playing up and down; as is perhaps meant to be indicated by the citation above from Har]; syn. rafaEahu; written only [thus] with A [in the pret. and in the aor.]: (S:) and AlsRaraAbu yazohaI Alqubuwra waAlHumuwla The mirage is as though it raised the tombs and the women's camel-vehicles; or elevated them; expl. by the words kaOanRahu yarofaEuhaA. (TA.)

And zahaA AlmirowaHapa, said of a person fanning, He put in motion the fan; or put it into a state of commotion; as also zahRaAhaA↓. (TA.) And zahati AlriyHu AlXRajara, (S,) or AlnRabaAta, (K, * TA,) aor. tazohaAhu, (S, TA,) inf. n. zahowN, (K, TA,) The wind shook, or put in motion or into a state of commotion, (S, K, * TA,) the trees, (S,) or the plants, or herbage, after the dew or rain (gibRa AlnRadaI). (K, TA.)

And zahaAhu, (S, TA,) inf. n. zahowN; (K, TA;) and AzdhAhu↓, (S, TA,) inf. n. AizodihaMCN; (K, TA;) [not AzhAhu, as in the TK, followed by Freytag;] i. q. AisotaxafRahu: (S, K, * TA:) and tahaAwana bihi: (S:) [the former of these two explanations as meaning He, or it, incited him, or excited him, to briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness; or to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness: and the latter of them, or both of them, for the former is often syn. with the latter, as meaning he held him, or it, in little, or light, estimation or account, or in contempt; he contemned, or despised, him, or it: but of this latter meaning I do not remember to have met with any ex.:] and bihi AzdhI↓ signifies the same as AzdhAh (TA) meaning tahaAwana bihi. (JK.) You say, zahaAhu AlXRaIoCu and AzdhAhu↓, meaning [agreeably with the former of the two explanations in the sentence immediately preceding] AisotaxafRahu TarabFA: (Har p. 359:) and yazodahiyniI↓ as meaning [agreeably with the same explanation] yasotafizRuniI and yasotaxifRuniI: (Id. p. 131:) and Alqawoma AzdhI↓ as meaning [in like manner] AisotaxafRahumo mina AlTRarabi; and also as meaning He pleased the people, or party: (Id. p. 427:) and AizodahaAhu↓ also as meaning Hamalahu EalaI AlzRahowi [He incited him, or excited him, to pride, or conceit, or the like]: (Id. p. 131:) and zahaAhu Alkiboru (K) Pride rendered him self-conceited. (TK.) 'Omar Ibn-'Abee-Rabeea says,

meaning And when we discoursed together, and faces shone, beauty excited the possessors of them to levity (AisotaxafRa OarobaAbahaA) and prevented their veiling them with the qinaAE [or head-covering], by reason of self-admiration: or, as some say, the hA in zhAhA refers to a woman mentioned before, not to wjwh; and the meaning is, beauty excited her &c.: and thus the women of the Arabs used to do when they were beautiful: or you may consider the complement of lamRaA as suppressed; as though he said, when we did all that, we behaved with mutual familiarity, or the like; for the complements of lawo and lamRaA and Hiyna may be suppressed, and their vagueness by reason of their suppression is more forcible in respect of the meaning: Oano tataqanRaEaA means mino Oano tataqanRaEaA; for they often suppress the preposition with Oano: (Ham pp. 552-3:) [J gives two readings of this verse, accord to one of my copies of the S: one is with tanaAzaEaA in the place of taqaAwaDonaA, and OaXoraqato in the place of Oasofarato; which make no difference in the meaning: but this is omitted in my other copy: the other is as follows:]

[And when we agreed together, and I saluted, faces advanced, which beauty excited &c., or the possessors of which beauty excited &c.]. (S.) And hence their saying, bixadiyEapK fulaAnN laA yuzodahaI↓ [Such a one will not be incited, or excited, to briskness, &c., by means of deceit, or guile]. (S.) And AlfaraHu AzdhAhu↓, meaning AisotaxafRahu [Joy incited him, &c.]. (MA.) [And hence, perhaps, may be derived most of the following significations.]
zahaA AlTRalRu Alnawora The TlR [or fine drizzling rain] made the flowers, or blossoms, to increase in beauty of aspect. (TA.)
zahaA AlsRiraAja, (K,) aor. yzhwhu [perhaps a mistranscription for yazohaAhu], inf. n. zahowN, (TA,) He made the srAj [or lamp, or lighted wick,] to give a bright light. (K.)

zahawotu AlUibila
I made the camels to journey, after coming to water, (A 'Obeyd, JK, S, K,) a night or more, (A 'Obeyd, JK, S,) or a night or two nights. (K.) Thus the verb in relation to camels is trans. as well as intrans. (S.)
zahaA biAlsRayofu He made a sign with the sword by waving it, or brandishing it. (K, TA.)
zahaA biAlEaSaA He struck with the staff, or stick. (K.)

zahaA bimiAYapi riTolK He computed, or computed by conjecture, [to be of the weight of] a hundred pounds. (K.) You say, zahaAhu bimiAYapi riTolK meaning xrzh [a mistake for Hazarahu i. e. He computed it, &c., to be of the weight of a hundred pounds]. (TK. In the TA, zhA flAn bmAYp rTl, [AlXRaIoCa or the like being omitted by an oversight,] aor. yazohaAhu [which indicates an omission after flAn].) And zahawotu Alqawoma I computed, or computed by conjecture, the number of the people, or party. (JK.)

zuhiIa, (JK, S, K,) like EuniIa; (S, K;) and zahaA, (IDrd, S, K,) like daEaA, but this is rare, (K,) and was dissallowed by As in the sense of zuhiIa, (TA in art. nxw,) aor. yazohuw, inf. n. zahowN; (IDrd, S;) and OazohaI↓; (K;) said of a man, (JK, S,) He behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently; (S, K, * TA;) he was proud, vain, and boastful; (K;) or was pleased with himself, or self-conceited: (JK:) AzdhI [i. e. AuzoduhiIa↓], in like manner, means takabRara: (Har p. 264: [but this more properly signifies, as shown above by an explanation of AizodahaAhu, he was incited, or excited, to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness:]) the first of these verbs [may be originally pass. of zahaA in the phrase zahaAhu Alkiboru, mentioned before, but, as J says,] is one of a class of verbs used in the pass. form though having the sense of the act. form: in using it imperatively, you say, lituzoha yaA rajulu [Behave thou proudly, &c., O man; see art. t]; and like this is the aor. [used as an imperative] of every verb of which the agent is not named; for when it is reduced to its essential import, you thereby command something, other than the person whom you address, to affect, or befall, that person; and the third person of the [aor. used as an] imperative is never without l, as when you say, liyaqumo zayodN: (S, TA:) J also says, (TA,) I said to an Arab of the desert, of [the tribe of] Benoo-Suleym, What is the meaning of zuhiIa AlrRajulu? and he answered, The man was pleased with himself, or self-conceited: I said, Dost thou say, zahaA as meaning Aifotaxara [He gloried, or boasted, &c.]? and he answered, As for us, we do not say it. (S, TA.) One says also, zuhiIa fulaAnN bikacaA i. e. nuxiIa [Such a one gloried, or boasted, and magnified himself, or behaved proudly, by reason of such a thing]; as though meaning zahaAhu AlUiEojaAbu binafosihi [i. e. self-conceit elevated him by reason of such a thing]. (Har p. 171.)

And one says, zuhiIa AlXRaIoCu biEayonayoka or liEayonayoka The thing was beautiful in aspect in, or to, thine eyes. (S, accord. to different copies. [The meaning is there shown by what immediately precedes. In three copies of the S, I find the verb in this phrase thus written, zuhiIa; and only in the PS, zhA, for zahaA, which is the form given by Golius: Freytag writes the phrase zahaI AlXI bEynk.])
2: see 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph.
4: see 1, in four places, in the first three sentences:
and again, in one place, in the last quarter of the same paragraph.

maA OazohaAhu [meaning How proud, vain, boastful, or selfconceited, is he!] is from zahaA as syn. with zuhiIa; not from the latter of these two verbs, because the verb of wonder is not formed from a verb of which the agent is not named. (S.)
8. AizodahaI [originally AizotahaI]: see 1, as a trans. verb, in eight places. And AuzoduhiIa: see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph.
zahowN [is the inf. n. of zahaA (q. v.): and also has the significations here following.
] Pride [as implying self-elevation]: (JK, S, K:) vanity, or vain behaviour: (K:) boasting, or glorying: (S, K:) and wrongdoing, injustice, injuriousness, or tyranny. (TA.)

A false, or vain, saying; syn. baATilN; (S, K, and Ham p. 24;) a lie, or falsehood; (JK, S, K, and Ham * ubi suprà;) or an exaggeration in speech. (Ham ubi suprà.) You say, qaAla zahowFA [He said a false, or vain, saying, &c.]. (Ham ubi suprà.)
A beautiful aspect. (S, K.)
The blossoms, or flowers, of a plant. (Lth, K.)

The brightness of a plant (K, TA) by its becoming red or yellow; (TA;) as also zuhuwRN↓, (K, TA,) like EuluwRN, (TA,) [in the CK kAlzRahowi is here put in the place of kaAlzRuhuwRi,] and zahaMCN↓, (K, TA,) like saHaAbN, as the unrestricted mention of it requires, but in some of the copies of the K with damm [i. e. zuhaMCN]. (TA.)
Also, [or nabaAtN zahowN, as in the TK,] A plant beautiful and bright, (K,) or fresh. (TA.)

And Dates beginning to ripen (busorN) that are becoming coloured (mulawRinN), (so in some copies of the S and K, and in the Mgh, or mutalawRinN [which signifies the same], Har p. 416), or that have become coloured (mulawRanN); (so in other copies of the S and K;) as also zuhuwRN↓, (K, TA,) like EuluwRN, thus in the handwriting of Az in the T: (TA:) [here, again, in the CK we find kAlzRahowi put in the place of kaAlzRuhuwRi: or perhaps it should be kaAlzRuhowi↓; as appears from what follows in the next sentence:] in this sense, zahowN is an inf. n. used as a subst. (Mgh.) One says, when redness and yellowness appear in palm-trees, qado Zahara fiyhi AlzRahowu [Dates becoming, or become, red, or yellow, have appeared in them; i. e. fiI AlnRaxoli]: and the people of El-Hijáz say, AlzRuhowu↓, with damm: (S:) [Fei says,] the subst. from zahaA AlnRaxolu meaning “ the palm-trees showed redness and yellowness in their fruit ” is Alzhw [i. e. AlzRuhowu↓], with damm; and AHát says that this term is used only when the colour of the date has become free from admixture in redness or yellowness. (Msb.)
You say also vawobN zahowN A red and beautiful garment or piece of cloth: and viyaAbN zahowapN and zaAhiyapN↓ [red and beautiful garments &c.]. (JK.)
zuhowN: see the next preceding paragraph, latter half, in three places.
zuhaA AldRunoyaA The ornature, finery, show, pomp, or gaiety, of the present life or world. (K, TA.) The former noun [when indeterminate] is [with tenween, zuhFA,] like hudFI. (K.)
zahowapN A shining, glistening, or brilliancy; whatever be the colour. (TA.)
zahaMCN: see zahowN, in the former half of the paragraph.

zuhaMCN Number, or amount. (JK, Msb.) You say, kamo zuhaAWuhumo How many is their number? or how much is their amount? (Msb, TA:) or, the computation of them? (TA.) And humo zuhaMCu miAYapK [They are as many as a hundred;] they are the number, or amount, of a hundred; (El-Fárábee, S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) or their number, or amount, is a hundred: (Mgh:) and miAYapK zihaMCu↓, also, with kesr: (El-Fárábee, Msb:) but the saying of the [common] people humo zuhaMC EalaI miAYap is not [correct] Arabic. (Msb.)

Also A large number: whence in a trad. respecting the time of the resurrection, UicaA samiEotumo binaAsK mino qibali AlmaXoriqi OuwliI zuhaMCK i. e. [When ye hear of men coming from the direction of the east,] having a large number. (TA.)
And zuhaMCu AlXRaIoCi signifies The XaxoS [i. e. corporeal form or figure or substance, which one sees from a distance,] of the thing. (TA.)
zihaMCu miAYapK: see the next preceding paragraph.
zuhuwRN: see zahowN, in two places.
Also The redness of colour, and beauty, of garments or cloths. (JK.)
zaAhK [act. part. n. of zahaA].
UibilN zaAhiyapN Camels that will not pasture upon the [plants, or trees, termed] HamoDi: (ISk, S:) pl. zawaAhK. (TA.)
zaAhiI AllRawon Bright in respect of colour. (TA.) viyaAbN zaAhiyapN: see zahowN, last sentence.

OazohaI [meaning More, and most, proud, vain, boastful, or self-conceited, is, like maA OazohaAhu (q. v.), from zahaA as syn. with zuhiIa; not from the latter of these two verbs]. You say OazohaI mino guraAbK [More proud, &c., than a crow]; (S, Meyd;) because the crow, in walking, ceases not to go with a proud, or self-conceited, gait, and to look at itself: and mino waEilK [than a mountain-goat]: and mn TaAWuwsK [than a peacock]: and diykK and cubaAbK and vaworK and vaEolabK [a cock and a fly and a bull and a fox]: all these are provs. (Meyd.)

UinozahowN, in which each of the first two letters is augmentative, and which is said to be the only word of its kind except UinoqaHolN from qaHala, (MF, TA,) applied to a man, Proud, haughty, or insolent; (Lh, K;) as also muzodahFI↓ [which more properly means incited, or excited, to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness]; (Har p. 264:) pl. of the former Uinozahowuwna. (Lh, TA.) [See also what next follows.]

mazohuwRN, from zuhiI, applied to a man, Proud, haughty, or insolent; (S, TA;) [vain, and boast-
ful;] pleased with himself, or self-conceited. (TA.) [See also what next precedes.]
muzodahFI: see UinozahowN, above.

1. zuIRa EalayonaA, or ziIRa, (accord. to different copies of the S, in the TA zuIRa,) [from zawRN, originally zuwiwa, then zuwiIa, and then zuIRa or ziIRa,] or it is zuwiIa, (thus in some copies of the S,) It was decreed against us. (S.)

4. OazowaI, (K,) said of a man, (TA,) [from zawRN,] He came having with him another: (K, and T in art. tw:) mentioned by Az and Sgh on the authority of IAar: (TA:) opposed to OatowaI meaning “ he came alone; by himself. ” (T in art. tw.)

zawRN A pair, or couple; two coupled together; (S, K, TA;) [of men, and] of ships and other things; (TA;) i. q. zawojN: (K, and T in art. tw:) opposed to tawRN meaning “ one, and no more. ” (K, and TA in this art. and in art. tw.) You say, jaMCa fulaAnN zawRFA, meaning Such one came with his companion. (S.) [See also art. tw.]

AlzRawRu is also the name of A ship constructed by ElMutawekkil, (K, TA,) the 'Abbásee; in which he associated in drinking with the poet El-Boh- turee. (TA.) Accord. to the S, it is the name of a mountain in El-'Irák: but Aboo-Zekereeyà EtTebreezee, and after him the author of the K, deny this, and suppose J to have been led into error in asserting such to be the case by the following saying of the poet above mentioned:

[Nor have I seen a mountain like AlzRawR, that is made stationary at one time, and becomes led on at another time if thou draw it along with a leading-rope]: J, however, does not say that he took this from the poetry of El-Bohturee. (TA. [In the CK, in the verse above cited, Aico mA is put in the place of UimRaA.])

[J also says that,] accord. to As, zawRu AlmaniyRapi signifies What happens of decreed perdition or death: and zawRN is also said to signify a decree [of God]: (S, TA:) and in the M it is said that zawRN signifies perdition, or death: and zawRu AlmaniyRapi, the accidents, or calamities, of destiny or death: but accord. to the T, As said zawoCu AlmaniyRapi, withC (TA.)

2. zwRj XayoYFA biXaIoCK, and zwRjhu Uilayohi, [inf. n. tazowiyjN,] He coupled, or paired, a thing with a thing; united it to it as its fellow, or like. (TA.) So in the Kur [xliv. 54 and lii. 20], zawRajonaAhumo biHuwrK EiynK We will couple them, or pair them, [with females having eyes like those of gazelles:] (S, Mgh, K, TA:) the meaning is not the tazowiyj commonly known, [i. e. marriage,] for there will be no [such] tzwyj in Paradise. (MF, TA.) And so in the Kur [lxxxi. 7], waUicaA AlnRufuwsu zuwRijato And when the souls shall be coupled, or paired, or united with their fellows: (TA:) i. e., with their bodies: (Bd, Jel:) or, each with its register: (Bd:) or with its works: (Bd, TA:) or the souls of the believers with the Huwr, and those of the unbelievers with the devils: (Bd:) or when each sect, or party, shall be united with those whom it has followed. (TA.) And so in the phrase, zawRajotu UibiliI I coupled, or paired, my camels, one with another: (A:) or zawRajotu bayona AlUibili I coupled, or paired, every one of the camels with another. (TA.) So too in the Kur [xlii. 49], Oawo yuzawRijuhumo cukoraAnFA waUinaAvFA Or He maketh them couples, or pairs, males and females: or, accord. to AM, maketh them of different sorts [or sexes], males and females: for
tazowiyjN signifies [also] The making to be of different sorts or species [&c.]. (TA.)

zawRajotuhu QmoraOapF, (T, S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K,) thus the Arabs say accord. to Yoo (S, Mgh) and ISK, (Mgh,) making the verb doubly trans. by itself, [without a particle,] meaning I married him, or gave him in marriage, to a woman; (Msb, TA;) as also biQmoraOapK; (A, K;) Akh says that this is allowable [app. as being of the dial. of Azd-Shanooäh (see 5)]: (Msb, TA:) [when the verb is trans. by means of bi, it generally has the meaning expl. in the first sentence of this art.:] zawRajotu minohu QmoraOapF is not of the language of the Arabs: (T, Mgh, TA:) [but see a similar phrase in a verse cited in art. HSn, conj. 4:] the lawyers say, zawRajotuhu minohaA [meaning I married him to her]; but this is a phrase for which there is no reasonable way of accounting, unless that it is accord. to the opinion of those who hold that mino may be redundant in an affirmative proposition, or that of those who hold that it may be substituted for bi. (Msb.)

3. zAwjhu, [inf. n. muzaAwajapN and ziwaAjN] It, or he, was, or became, a couple, or pair, with it, or him: or made a coupling, or pairing, with it, or him. (MA.) [And zaAwajaA They two formed together a couple, or pair.]
[And zAwjA, inf. n. as above, They married each other.] You say, hucayolN yuzaAwiju Eikorimapa [The tribe of Hudheyl intermarry with that of 'Ikrimeh]. (A. [See also 6.])

zAwj bayonahumaA and Azwj↓ (tropical:) [He made them two (referring to sentences or phrases) to have a mutual resemblance in their prose-rhymes, or in measure: or to be connected, each with the other; or dependent, each on the other]. (A, TA.) See also 8, in three places.
4: see the next preceding paragraph.

5. tazawRajotu QmoraOapF, (T, S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K,) thus the Arabs say accord. to Yoo (S, Mgh) and ISK, (Mgh,) meaning I married a woman; i. e., took a woman in marriage; took her as my wife; (Msb, TA;) as also biQmoraOapK; (A, * K;) or this is rare; (K;) Akh says that it is allowable; (Msb, TA;) and it is said to be of the dial. of AzdShanooäh, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) by Fr; (S, TA;) but accord. to Yoo (S, Mgh) and ISK, (Mgh,) it is not of the language of the Arabs. (T, S, Mgh.) And tzwRj fiI baniI fulaAnK (A, Msb, TA) He married, or took a wife, among the sons of such a one. (Msb, TA.) And tzwRj Uilayohi i. q. xaAtanahu [He allied himself to him by marriage]. (K in art. xtn.)
[Hence,] tzwRjhu AlnRawomu (assumed tropical:) Sleep pervaded him; syn. xaAlaTahu. (K.)
6. tzAwj Alqawomu and AizodawajuwA↓ The people, or party, married one another; intermarried. (TA. [See also 3.])
See also the next paragraph, in three places.
8. Aizodawajati AlTRayoru [The birds coupled, or paired, one with another]. (TA.)
See also 6.

AizodawajaA and tazaAwajaA↓ [and zaAwajaA↓], said of two phrases, or sentences, (A, TA,) (tropical:) They bore a mutual resemblance in their prose-rhymes, or in measure: or were connected, each with the other; or dependent, each on the other: and in like manner, Azdwj and tzAwj↓, said of a phrase, or sentence, (tropical:) It was such that one part of it resembled another in the prose-rhyme, or in the measure: or consisted of two propositions connected, each with the other; or dependent, each on the other: (TA:) AizodiwaAjN and muzaAwajapN↓ (S, A, K) and tazaAwujN↓ (S) are syn.: (S, A, * K:) AzdwAj signifies A conformity, or mutual resemblance, [with respect to sound, or measure,] of two words occurring near together; as in the phrase mino sabaOK binabaOK [in the Kur xxvii. 22]: (Kull p. 31:) and this is also termed muzaAwajapN↓ and muHaAcaApN and muwaAzanapN and muqaAbalapN and muWaAzaApN. (Marginal note in a copy of the Muzhir, 22nd nwE.)

zaAjN [Vitriol;] a well-known kind of salt; (K, TA;) called XabRN yamaAniIRN; [but see XabRN;] which is a medicinal substance, and one of the ingredients of ink: (Lth, TA:) [pl. zaAjaAtN, meaning species, or sorts, of vitriol; namely, green, or sulphate of iron, which is an ingredient in ink, and is generally meant by the term zAj when unrestricted by an epithet; blue, or sulphate of copper; and white, or sulphate of zinc:] it is a Pers. word, (S,) arabicized, (S, K,) originally zAG. (TA.)

zawojN primarily signifies A sort of thing of any kind [that is one of a pair or couple]: and zawojaAni signifies a pair, or couple, i. e. any two things paired or coupled together, whether they be likes or contraries: zawojN signifying either one of such two things: (Az, TA:) or, accord. to 'Alee Ibn- 'Eesà, a sort of thing [absolutely]: (Mgh:) or a sort of thing having its like, (El-Ghooree, Mgh, Msb,) as in the case of species; (Msb;) or having its contrary, (El-Ghooree, Mgh, Msb,) as the moist and the dry, and the male and the female, and the night and the day, and the bitter and the sweet; (Msb;) though sometimes applied to any sort of thing; and to a single thing: (El-Ghooree, Mgh:) or it is applied to a single thing only when having with it a thing of the same kind; (Mgh, Msb;) zawojaAni signifying a pair, or couple, of such things: (Mgh:) the pl. is OazowaAji: (TA:) you say zawojaAni mino HamaAmK and zawojaA HamaAmK [A pair
of pigeons]: (A:) and AiXotarayotu zawojaI HamaAmK [I bought a pair of pigeons], meaning a male and a female: (S:) and zawojaA niEaAlK [A pair of sandals]: (S, A:) and in like manner zawojayoni is used in the Kur xi. 42 and xxiii. 28; (S;) meaning a male and a female: (Bd, Jel:) or, accord. to the M, zawojN signifies one of a pair or couple: and also a pair or couple together: (TA:) and in like manner says AO, (Mgh, Msb,) and IKt, and IF: (Msb:) and ISh says that it signifies two; (Mgh;) and so says IDrd: (Msb:) so that you say, humaA zawojN as well as humaA zawojaAni [meaning They two are a pair, or couple]; (S, K, TA;) like as you say, humaA sawaMCN and humaA siyRaAni: (S, TA:) and EinodiI zawoju niEaAlK, meaning [I have] two [sandals]; and zawojaAni, meaning four: (Msb:) or zawoju HamaAmK as meaning a male and a female [of pigeons] is a phrase which should not be used; one to which the vulgar are addicted: (TA:) IAmb says, the vulgar are wrong in thinking that zawojN signifies two; for the Arabs used not to employ such a phrase as zawoju HamaAmK, but used to say zawojaAni mina AlHamaAmi, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) meaning a male and a female; (TA;) and zawojaAni mina AlxifaAfi, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) meaning the right and the left [of boots]: (TA:) nor did they apply the term zawojN to one of birds, like as they applied the dual, zawojaAni, to two; but they applied the term farodN to the male, and farodapN to the female: (Mgh, Msb:) Es-Sijistánee, also, says that the term zawojN should not be applied to two, neither of birds nor of other things, for this is a usage of the ignorant; but to every two, zawojaAni: (Msb:) Az says that the grammarians disapprove the saying of ISh that zawojN signifies two of any things, (Mgh, * TA,) and that zawojaAni mino xifaAfK signifies [Two pairs of boots, or] four [boots]; for zawojN with them signifies one [of a pair or couple]: a man and his wife [together] are termed zawojaAni: and vamaAniyapa OazowaAjK in the Kur [vi. 144 and xxxix. 8] means Eight ones [of pairs or couples]: the primary meaning of zawojN being that first mentioned in this paragraph; (TA:) in the Kur xxii. 5 and 1. 7 [it seems to be implied that it means pair or couple; but more probably in these instances] it means sort, or species: (Bd, Jel:) it is also expl. by the word lawonN [used in this last sense]: (T, TA;) in the Kur xxxviii. 58, its pl. OazowaAjN means OalowaAnN and OanowaAEN [i. e. sorts, or species] of punishment: F explains the sing. as meaning lawonN mina AldRiybaAji wanaHowihi [a sort, or species, of silk brocade and the like]; but his restricting the signification by the words mn AldybAj wnHwh is not right, as is shown by a citation, in the T, of a verse of El-Aashà, in which he uses the phrase kulRu zawojK mina AldRiybaAji [every sort, or species, of silk brocade], as an ex. of zwj in the sense of lwn. (TA.)

[Hence,] A woman's husband: and a man's wife: in which latter sense zawojapN↓ is also used; (S, M, A, Mgh, * Msb, K; *) as in a verse of El-Farezdak cited in art bwl, conj. 10; (S, Mgh;) but it is disallowed by As; (TA;) and the former word is the one of high authority, (Mgh, Msb,) and is that which occurs in the Kur, in ii. 33 and vii. 18, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and in iv. 24, (Mgh, TA,) and in xxxiii. 37: (Mgh:) AHát says that the people of Nejd call a wife zawojapN↓, and that the people of the Haram use this word: but ISk says that the people of El-Hijáz call a wife zawojN; and the rest of the Arabs, zawojapN↓: the lawyers use this latter word only, as applied to a wife, for the sake of perspicuity, fearing to confound the male with the female: (Msb:) the pl. of zawojN is OazowaAjN (Msb, K *) and ziwajapN; (K;) and the pl. of zawojapN↓ is zawojaAtN (A, Mgh, Msb) and OazowaAjN also; (A, Msb;) and OazaAwiyju occurs [as a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of OazowaAju,] in a verse cited by ISk. (TA in art. nOj.)
[Hence also,] A consociate, an associate, or a comrade: (A:) its pl. in this sense is OazowaAjN, (S, A, K,) occurring in the Kur xxxvii. 22. (S, A.)

And A fellow, or like: pl. OazowaAjN: in this sense, each one of a pair of boots is the zwj of the other; and the husband is the zwj of the wife; and the wife, the zwj of the husband. (TA.) You say, EinodiI mino hecaA OazowaAjN I have, of this, fellows, or likes. (TA.)

As used by arithmeticians, (Mgh, Msb,) contr. of farodN; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e. it signifies An even number; a number that may be divided into two equal numbers; (Msb;) as, for instance, four, and eight, as opposed to three, and seven: (Mgh:) pl. OazowaAjN. (S, Mgh.) One says zawojN Oawo farodN [Even or odd?], like as one says xasFA Oawo zakFA [or rather zakFA Oawo xasFA] and XafoEN Oawo witorN. (S, Mgh.)
Also A [kind of cloth such as is termed] namaT [q. v.]: or silk brocade; syn. diybaAjN: (TA:) or a namaT that is thrown over the [kind of vehicle called] hawodaj. (S, K, TA.)
ziyjN: see art. zyj.
zawojapN: see zawojN, in four places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

zawojiyRapN and zawaAjN↓ [The marriage-state, or simply marriage]: the latter is a subst. from zawRaja, [i. e. a quasi-inf. n.,] like salaAmN from salRama, and kalaAmN from kalRama. (Msb.) You say, bayonahumaA HaqRu AlzRawojiyRapi and AlzRawaAji↓ [Between them two is the right of the marriage-state, or of marriage]: (A, Msb:) and AlzRiwaAji is also allowable as [an inf. n. of 3,] coordinate to AlmuzaAwajap. (Msb.)
zawaAjN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
zaAYijapN: see art zyj.
mizowaAjN A woman who marries often: (S, K:) one who has had many husbands. (K.)

1. zaAda, aor. yazuwdu, (L,) inf. n. zawodN, (L, K,) He laid in a stock of provisions for travelling or for a fixed residence; syn. OasRasa zaAdFA: (L, K:) or zaAdahu is syn. with zawRadahu; q. v.; and this is what is meant in the K by taOosiysu AlzRaAdi as the explanation of AlzRawodu. (MF.)

2. zwRdhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazowiydN; (KL;) as also AzdAhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UizowaAdN; (TA;) and zaAdahu↓, inf. n. zawodN; (MF;) He furnished him with, or gave him, provisions (S, Msb, K, * KL) for travelling [or for a fixed residence]. (S, Msb.) [It is doubly trans.:] you say, zawRadahumo miloCa AlmazaAwidi [He furnished them with what filled the provision-bags for travelling-provision]: (A:) and zwRdhu AlzRayotu [He furnished him with olive-oil for travelling-provision]. (S in art. zyt.) And Aboo-Khirásh says,
[And sometimes, or often, he will bring thee tidings whom thou wilt not furnish with the sandal nor furnish with travelling-provisions]. (TA.)
[Hence,] zawRadotuhu kitaAbFA (tropical:) [I provided him with a letter]. (A, TA.)
4: see 2, in two places.

5. tzwRd [He became furnished, or he furnished himself, with provisions for travelling or for a fixed residence;] he took, or prepared, for himself provisions (S, * KL, TA) for travelling or for a fixed residence: (TA: [Golius makes it to be trans. by means of bi as on the authority of the KL; in which the only explanation, as that of the inf. n., is twXh brGrftn:]) and he chose a thing as zaAd [or provision] for himself. (Har p. 92.) You say, tazawRada minRaA fulaAnN [Such a one was furnished, or such a one furnished himself, with provisions from us]. (A.) And tzwRd lisafarihi [He was furnished, or he furnished himself, with provisions for his journey]. (Msb.) And see another ex. voce zaAdN. You say also, tazawRada mina AldRunoyaA liloMxirapi (tropical:) [Take thou provisions from the present world, i. e. make thou provision in it, for the world to come]. (A, TA.) And tazawRada mina AlOamiyri kitaAbFA liEaAmilihi (tropical:) [He provided himself with a letter from the commander, or governor, or prince, to his prefect]. (A, TA.) And tazawRada minRiI TaEonapF bayona Oucunayohi (tropical:) [He got from me a stab, or spear-wound, or the like, between his ears]. (A, TA.)
zaAdN Provisions, or a stock of provisions, for travelling (S, L, Msb, TA) and for a fixed residence: (L, TA:) pl. OazowaAdN (L, Msb) and OazowidapN; the latter anomalous. (L.)

And hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) Any deed, or acquirement, whether good or evil, whereby one becomes changed in state, or condition; (L;) [or rather, whereby one provides for a change of state, or condition, like as a traveller provides for a journey.] It is
said in the Kur [ii. 193], faUinRa xayora AlzRaAdi watazawRaduwA↓ AltRaqowaI (L) meaning, [as is implied in the L, (tropical:) And make ye provision; but verily the best acquirement whereby to provide for a change of state, or condition, is fear of God, or piety: or the meaning is] and prepare ye provisions for your journey; and verily the best provision is that whereby one provides against begging from others, &c. (Jel.)
[It is also said to be used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Salutation and the returning of a greeting. (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., ii. 415, q. v.)]
mazaAdN: see mazaAdapN.
mizowadN A bag, or other receptacle, (S, * Msb, K, TA,) for travelling-provisions, (S, K, TA,) or for dates, made of leather: (Msb:) pl. mazaAwidu. (S, A, Msb, K.)
[Hence,] riqaAbu AlmazaAwidi [lit. The necks of provision-bags;] a nickname applied to the Eajam [or Persians, or foreigners in general,] (S, K) by the Arabs. (S.) [See art. rqb.]

mazaAdapN [A leathern water-bag, one of a pair which is borne by a camel or other beast;;] the half (XaTor) of a raAwiyap: pl. mazaAYidu; [regularly mazaAwidu; or the medial radical is I and therefore the reg. pl. is mazaAyidu;] and sometimes they said mazaAdN↓, [a coll. gen. n.,] without p: [accord. to some,] it is of the measure mafoEalapN, [originally mazowadapN,] from AlzRaAdu, because one furnishes himself with water in it for travelling-provision: (Msb:) [and therefore it is mentioned in this art.:] but this is a mistake. (TA in art. zyd, q. v.)

1. zaArahu, aor. yazuwru, inf. n. ziyaArapN (S, A, Msb, K) and zaworN (S, A, K) and mazaArN (S, Msb, K) and zuwaArapN (Ks, S) or zuwaArN; (K;) and AzdArhu↓, (S, A, TA,) of the measure AifotaEala from AlzRiyaArapu, (S, TA,) is syn. with zaArahu; (A, TA;) [He visited him: lit.] he met him with his zawor [i. e. chest, or bosom]: or he repaired to his zawor, i. e. direction: (B, TA:) [or] he inclined towards him: (TA:) [see also zawira:] or he repaired to him: (A:) or he repaired to him from a desire to see him. (Msb.)
[Hence,] zaAra XaEuwba (tropical:) [lit., He visited death; i. e., he died]. (TA.) [See 4.]
zaArahu, (K,) aor. yazuwru, inf. n. ziwaArN, (TA,) He bound upon him (namely a camel) the rope called ziwaAr, q. v. (K.)
zawira, aor. yazowaru, inf. n. zawarN, He, or it, inclined. (TA.) [App. always used in a proper, not a tropical, sense. See zawarN below.]
He had the kind of distortion termed zawarN [which see, below]. (TA.)

2. zwRrhu, (A, K,) inf. n. tazowiyrN, (S,) He honoured him; namely, a visiter; treated him with honour, or hospitality; (S, A, K;) made account of his visit; (A;) treated him well, and acknowledged his right as a visiter; (TA;) slaughtered for him, and treated him with honour or hospitality. (AZ.)
zwRr AlXRahaAdapa He annulled the testimony; (K, TA;) impugned and annulled it. (TA.)
El-Kattál says,

[And we are men whose wood of which our bows are made is hard wood of a neb'ah, and in us is hardiness not to be impugned and denied]: Aboo- 'Adnán says, [perhaps reading nuzawRaru, which may be the correct reading,] that he means, we are not to be calumniated, because of our hardness, or hardiness, nor to be held weak. (TA.)
zwRr nafosahu He stigmatized himself by the imputation of falsehood. (K.) [See also other explanations, below.]
zwRr kalaAmahu (assumed tropical:) He falsified his speech; he embellished his speech with lies; syn. zaxorafahu. (Msb.) [See also below.]
zwRr Alkaciba, (K,) inf. n. tazowiyrN, (S,) (tropical:) He embellished the lie. (S, K, TA.)

zwRr XayoYFA (tropical:) He removed, or did away with, the obliquity of a thing; (TA;) he rectified, adjusted, or corrected, it; (IAar, S, Msb, K;) whether good or evil; (IAar, Msb;) he beautified, or embellished, it. (AZ, S, K.)

zwRr kalaAmFA (tropical:) He made speech right and sound, (As,) prepared it, (As, Msb,) and measured it, (As,) fiI nafosihi in his mind, (Msb,) before he uttered it: (As:) he rectified, adjusted, or corrected, it; and beautified, or embellished, it; as also tzwRrhu↓, occurring in a verse of Nasr. Ibn-Seiyár. (TA.) And [in like manner] zwRr AlHadiyva (tropical:) He rectified, or corrected, the story, narrative, or tradition, removing, or doing away with, its obliquity: and tzwRrhu↓ he did so (ziwRrhu) to himself. (A.)

raHima QllRehu QmoraOF zawRara nafosahu EalaI nafosihi, a saying of El-Hajjáj, May God have mercy upon a man who rectifies, or corrects, himself, against himself: (S, * TA:) or, as some say, who stigmatizes himself by the charge of falsehood against himself: or who accuses himself against himself: like as you say, OanaA OuzawRiruka EalaI nafosika I accuse thee [of wrong] against thyself. (TA.)
tazowiyrN is also syn. with taXobiyhN [The likening a thing to another thing; &c.]. (TA.)
zwRr said of a bird, inf. n. as above, His crop (HawoSalatuhu) became high: (AZ, TA:) or became full. (TA.)
4. AzArhu He incited him, or made him, to visit. (S, K.) You say Oazarotuhu gayoriI I made him, or caused him, to visit another, not myself. (A.)
Oazarotuhu XaEuwba (tropical:) I made him to visit death; [i. e., I killed him.] (TA.) [See 1.]

OanaA Ouziyrukumo vanaAYiI (tropical:) [I will introduce you, or your name, in my eulogy; meaning I will praise you]. (A.) And Oazarotukumo qaSaAYidiI (tropical:) [I have introduced you, or the mention of you, in my odes]. (A.)
5. tzwRr He said what was false; spoke falsely. (A.)
See also 2, in two places.
6. tzAwrwA They visited one another. (S, A, K.) You say, bayonahumo tazaAwurN Between them is mutual visiting. (A.)
See also 9, in two places.
8. AizodaAra: see 1.
Also, accord. to Aboo-'Amr El-Mutarriz, He swallowed a morsel, or mouthful; like Aizodarada. (TA in art. zrd.)

9. AzwrR Eanohu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. AizowiraArN; (S, A;) and AzwArR↓, (S, A, K,) inf. n. AizowiyraArN; (S;) and tzAwr↓; (S, A, Msb, K;) He declined, or turned aside, from it. (S, A, * Msb, K.) tazRaAwaru↓, in the Kur xviii. 16, is a contraction tatazaAwaru: (S;) tazowarRu is another reading. (TA.)
fiI Sadorihi QzowiraArN In his breast, or chest, is crookedness, curving, or distortion. (A.)
10. AstzArhu He asked him to visit him. (S, A, * K.)
zaArN: see zaArapN.
zaworN: see zaAYirN, in three places.
Also A camel having the hump inclining. (TA.)

And, with p, A she-camel that looks from the outer angle of her eye, by reason of her vehemence and sharpness of temper: (K, * TA: [see zaworapN below: and see also Oazowaru:]) and a strong and thick she-camel. (TA.)
And falaApN zaworapN A desert not of moderate extent, or not easy to traverse. (TA.)
The direction of a person to whom one repairs. (B.)

The breast, or chest: (TA:) or its upper, or uppermost, part: (S, A, Mgh:) in a horse, narrowness in this part is approved, and width in the labaAn; as the poet 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Suleymeh says, making a distinction between these two parts: (S:) or its middle: or the elevated part of it, to the shoulder-blades: or the part where the extremities of the breast-bones meet together: (K:) or the whole of the breast of the camel: pl. OazowaArN. (TA.) Hence, banaAtu AlzRawori The ribs and other parts around the breast. (TA.) [Hence also, app. from the action of the camel when he lies down,] OaloqaI zaworahu (tropical:) [lit. He threw his breast upon the ground;] he remained, stayed, or abode. (A.)

The lord, or chief, of a people; (K, * TA;) as also zuwrN↓ (Sh, K) and zuwayorN↓ (IAar, S, K) and zawiyrN↓ (TA, as from the K, [in a copy of which SM appears to have found kaAlzRawiyri waAlzRuwayori kazubayorK waxidabRK, instead of kaAlzRuwayori waAlzRiwarRi Alx,]) and ziwarRN↓. (K, TA.)
Determination: (T, M:) or strength of determination. (K.)
See also zuwrN
A palm-branch, or straight and slender palm-branch, from which the leaves have been stripped off: (Sgh, K, TA:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Sgh, TA.)
Stone which appears to a person digging a well, and which, being unable to break it, he leaves apparent: (K:) or, as some say, a mass of rock, in an absolute sense. (TA.)

zuwrN A lie; a falsehood; an untruth: (S, Msb, K:) because it is a saying deviating from the truth. (TA.) So in the Kur xxii. 31: and so it is expl. in the trad., AlmutaXabRiEu bimaA lamo yuEoTa kalaAbisi vawobaIo zuwrK [He who boasts of abundance which he has not received is like the wearer of two garments of falsity]. (TA. [See art. XbE.]) So, too, in the Kur [xxv. 72], waQlRaciyna laA yaXohaduwna AlzRuwra And those who do not bear false witness. (Bd, Msb.) [But there are other explanations of these words of the Kur, which see below.]
What is false, or vain: (K:) or false witness: and a thing for which one is suspected, syn. tuhamapN. (TA.)
See also zaworN.
(assumed tropical:) The association of another, or others, with God: (Zj, K:) so explained by Zj, in the Kur xxv. 72, quoted above: and so the phrase XahaAdapu AlzRuwri, occurring in a trad. (TA.)

(assumed tropical:) [A place or] places in which lies are told: and the words in the Kur xxv. 72, quoted above, may mean, And those who are not present in places where lies are told: because the witnessing of what is false is participating therein: (Bd:) or the meaning here is the places where the Christians sit and converse: (Zj:) or where the Jews and Christians sit and converse: (TA, as from the K:) or the festivals of the Jews and Christians: (so in the CK and in a MS. copy of the K:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) a place, (K,) or places, (Zj,) where persons sit, and hear singing: (Zj, K:) or places where persons sit, and entertain themselves by frivolous or vain diversion: (Th:) but ISd says, I know not how this is, unless he mean the assemblies of polytheism, which includes the festivals of the Christians, and other festivals. (TA.)

Judgment: (K:) or judgment to which recourse may be had: (S:) or strength of judgment. (A.) [See also zaworN.] You say, maA lahu zuwrN walaA DayRuwrN He has no judgment to which recourse may be had: (S:) or no strength of judgment: (A:) or no judgment, nor understanding or intellect or intelligence, to which recourse may be had: (TA:) for zuwrN also signifies understanding, intellect, or intelligence; (Yaakoob, K;) and so zaworN↓: (A'Obeyd, K:) but A 'Obeyd thinks it a mistranscription, for laA zabora. (TA.)

Strength: in which sense the word is an instance of agreement between the Arabic and Persian languages: (AO, K:) or it is arabicized: (Sb:) but the Persian word is with the inclined, not the pure, dammeh. (TA.) You say layosa lahumo zuwrN They have not strength. (TA.) And HabolN lahu zuwrN A rope having strength. (TA.)
Deliciousness, and sweetness, or pleasantness, of food. (K.)
And Softness, and cleanness, of a garment, or piece of cloth. (K.)
zawarN inf. n. of zawira. (TA.)
Inclination; (S, Msb, K;) such as is termed SaEarN; (S;) crookedness; wryness; distortion. (A.)

Distortion of the zawor, (Mgh, K,) which is the upper, or uppermost, part of the breast, (Mgh,) or the middle of the breast [&c.]: (TA:) or the prominence of one of its two sides above the other: (K:) in a horse, the prominence of one of the two portions of flesh in the breast, on the right and left thereof, and the depression of the other: (S:) in others than dogs, it is said by some to signify inclination [or distortion] of a thing or part which is not of a regular square form; such as the kirokirap and the libodap. (TA.)

ziyrN, (S, K, &c.,) originally with w, written by the Sheykh-el-Islám Zekereeyà, in his commentaries on Bd, with hemz, contr. to the leading lexicologists; (TA;) or zyru nisaMCK; A visiter of women: (Az, TA in art. tbE:) a man who loves to discourse with women, and to sit with them, (S, K,) and to mix with them: (TA:) so called because of his frequent visits to them: or who mixes with them in vain things: or who mixes with them and desires to discourse with them: (TA:) without evil, or with it: (K:) and a woman is termed ziyrN also: (K:) you say AimoraOapN ziyru rijaAlK: (Ks:) but this usage is rare: (TA:) or it is applied to a man only: (K:) a woman of this description is termed maroyamN: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OazowaArN and OazoyaArN, (K,) the latter like OaEoyaAdN pl. of EiydN, (TA,) and [of mult.] ziyarapN. (S, K.)
Custom; habit; wont. (Yoo, K.)
A slender watar [or bow-string]: (S, K:) or the most slender of such cords, (OaHadRuhaA: (K, TA: in the CK OaHaduhaA:) and the most firmly twisted. (TA.)
Hence the ziyr [or smallest string] of a mizohar [or lute] is thus termed. (TA.) [In this and the next preceding senses, it is app. of Persian origin.]
Flax: (Yaakoob, S, K:) and with p a portion thereof: (K:) pl. OazowaArN. (TA.)
See also art. zyr.
ziwarRN A vehement pace. (S, K.)
Vehement; or strong: (K:) but to what applied is not particularized. (TA.)

Applied to a camel, Strong; hardy; (TA;) prepared for journeys. (K.) And ziwarRapu OasofaArK, applied to a she-camel, Prepared for journeys: or having an inclination to one side, by reason of her briskness, or sprightliness. (TA.) [See Oazowaru.]
See also zaworN.
zayirN, in the K zayRirN: see art. zyr.

zaArapu The HawoSalap [or crop] (AZ, K) of a bird; (AZ, TA;) as also zaAwarapN↓, (K, TA,) with fet-h to the w, (TA,) [in the CK zAwirap,] and zaAWuwrapu↓ (K, TA) [in the CK zAwurap]: and AlqaTaA zaAwarapu↓ The receptacle in which the [bird called] qTA carries water to its young ones. (TA.)

zaArapu AlOasadi The thicket, wood, or forest, or bed of reeds or canes, (Oajamap,) that is the haunt of the lion: so called because of his frequenting it. (IJ.) [See also zaOorapN, in art. zOr.] And zaArN↓ A thicket, wood, or forest, (Oajamap,) containing [high coarse grass of the kind called] HalofaMC, and reeds or canes, and water. (TA.)

(assumed tropical:) A collected number, (K,) or a large collected number, (TA,) of camels, (K,) and of sheep or goats, and of men: or of camels, and of men, from fifty to sixty. (TA.) [See, again, zaOorapN, in art. zOr.]
zaworapN A single visit. (S, TA.)
Distance; remoteness: (S, K:) from AlAizowiraAru. (S.) A poet (Sakhr El-Ghei, TA) says,

[To many a water have I come, notwithstanding its distance]: (S:) or, accord. to AA, EalaI zaworapK, in this ex., accord. to one relation zuwrap, but the former is the better known, means upon a she-camel that looked from the outer angle of her eye, by reason of her vehemence and sharpness of temper. (TA.)
ziyrapN A manner of visiting. (K.) One says, fulaAnN Hasanu AlzRiyrapi Such a one is good in his manner of visiting. (TA.)

ziwaArN (AA, S, K) and ziyaArN↓ (IAar, K) A rope, or cord, which is put between the camel's fore-girth and kind-girth, (AA, S, K,) to prevent the kindgirth from hurting the animal's viyl, and so causing a suppression of the urine: (AA, TA:) pl. OazowirapN. (S, K.) In a trad., Ed-Dejjál is described as bound with Oazowirap; meaning, having his arms bound together upon his breast. (IAth.)
Also, both words, (tropical:) Anything that is a [means of] rectification to another thing, (K,) and a defence, or protection; (IAar, K;) like the ziyaAr of a beast. (IAar.)
ziyaArN: see ziwaArN:
and see art. zyr.
zuwayorN and zawiyrN: see zaworN.
zaWuwrN: see what next follows, in two places.
rajulN zawRaArN and zaWuwrN↓ [A man who visits much]: a poet says,

L.foreign: UicaA gaAba EanohaA baEoluhaA lamo Oakuno lahaA

sense.s: [When her husband is absent from her, I am not to her a frequent visiter, nor do her dogs become familiar to me]. (TA.)

zaAYirN A person visiting; a visiter: (S, * Msb, K: *) fem. zaAYirapN: (Sb:) pl. zaAYiruwna, masc., (S, K,) and zaAYiraAtN, fem., (S, Msb,) and zuwRaArN, masc., (S, Msb, K,) and zawRarN, masc., (K,) and fem.: (Sb, S, Msb:) and zaworN↓ signifies the same as zaAYirN (A, Msb, K, TA) and zaAYirapN (TA) and zaAYiruwna (S, A, K, TA) and zaAYiraAtu; (S, A, Msb, TA;) being originally an inf. n.; or, as syn. with zAYrwn, it is a quasi-pl. n.; by some called a pl. of zaAYirN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Ealayoka HaqRFA UinRa lizaworika↓ [Verily there is to thy visiter, or visiters, a just claim upon thee]. (TA.) [And hence,] zaworN↓ also signifies A phantom that is seen in sleep. (K.)
zaAwarapN: see zaArapN; the former, in two places.
zaAWuwrapN: see zaArapN; the former, in two places.
Oazowaru Inclining; (K;) crooked; wry; distorted: (A:) [fem. zaworaMCu:] pl. zuwrN. (K.)
Having that kind of distortion in the zawor (or middle of the breast [&c.] TA) which is termed zawarN. (K, TA.)
A dog whose breast (jawoXanu) Sadorihi) is narrow, (K,) and the kalokal [app. meaning the part between the two collar-bones] projecting, as though his, or its, sides had been squeezed. (TA.)
A wry neck. (TA.)

[A beast] that looks from the outer angles of his eyes (K) by reason of his vehemence and sharpness of temper: (TA: [see also zaworN:]) or a camel (TA) that goes with an inclination towards one side, when his pace is vehement, though without any distortion in his chest. (K.) [See also ziwarRN. Hence, app.,] AlzRaworaMCu is a name of Certain camels (maAl) that
belonged to Uheyhah (S, K) Ibn-El-Juláh ElAnsáree. (S.)
zaworaMCu (tropical:) A bow: (S, A, K:) because of its curving. (S.)
(tropical:) A bent bow. (TA.)
(tropical:) A menáreh (manaArap) deviating from the perpendicular. (A.)
(tropical:) A well (biYor) deep: (S, K, * TA:) or not straightly dug. (TA.)

(tropical:) A land, (OaroD, S, K,) and a desert, (mafaAzap, A, or falaAp, TA,) far-extending, (S, A, K, TA,) and turning aside: (TA:) and Oazowaru is applied [in the same sense] to a country, (TA,) and to an army. (S, TA.)
(tropical:) A saying, or phrase, (kalimap,) bad, and crooked, or distorted. (A.)
Also zaworaMCu [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates] (assumed tropical:) A [drinking-cup or bowl of the kind called] qadaH. (S, K.)
And (assumed tropical:) A certain vessel (K) for drinking, (TA,) oblong, like the talotalap. (TA.)
huwa Oazowaru Eano maqaAmi AlcRulRi (A) (tropical:) He is most remote from the station, or state, of baseness, or ignominiousness. (TA.)
mazaArN A place [and a time] of visiting. (S, Msb.)
mazuwrN Visited. (A.)

muzawRarN A camel distorted in the breast, or chest, when drawn forth from his mother's belly by the mucamRir [q. v.], who therefore presses, or squeezes, it, in order to set it right, but so that an effect of his pressing, or squeezing, remains in him, whereby he is known to be muzawRar. (Lth, K.)

And kalaAmN muzawRarN (assumed tropical:) Speech falsified, or embellished with lies. (TA.) And (tropical:) Speech rectified, adjusted, or corrected, [and prepared, (see 2,)] before it is uttered: or beautified, or embellished; as also mutazawRarN↓. (TA.)
muzodaArapN Visiters of the tomb of the Prophet. (A.)
mutazawRarN: see muzawRarN.

1. zaAga, (IDrd, O, K,) aor. yazuwgu, (IDrd, O,) inf. n. zawogN, (IDrd, O, K,) He declined, deviated, swerved, or turned aside, (IDrd, O, K,) from the right course or direction, (IDrd, O,) and from the road; as also zAg, aor. yaziygu, inf. n. zayogN, which latter is the more chaste: (O, TA:) the former is a dial. var. of the latter. (Msb in art. zyg.)
And zAg fiI AlmanoTiqi, (Yz, O, K,) aor. yazuwgu, (Yz, O,) inf. n. zawagaAnN, He declined, or deviated, from the right way in speech. (Yz, O, K.)
See also 4.

It is also trans.: (O, TA:) you say, zAg qalobahu, (O, K, * TA,) aor. yazuwgu, (O, TA,) He made his heart to decline, deviate, swerve, or turn aside. (O, K, * TA.) rabRanaA laA tazugo quluwbanaA, with fet-h to the t and damm to the z, [O our Lord, make not our hearts to decline from the right way, in the Kur iii. 6, commonly read tuzigo, (see 4 in art. zyg,)] is an extr. reading of Náfi. (O, TA.)

[Hence, app., if it be correct,] zAg AlnRaAqapa, (O, K,) aor. yazuwgu, inf. n. zawogN, (O,) He pulled the she-camel by the nose-rein: (O, K:) so says Ibn- 'Abbád: but [Sgh says,] the verb in this sense is with the unpointed E only; which Ibn-'Abbád states to be the better known. (O, TA.)
3: see what next follows.

4: AzAghu fiI AlmanoTiqi, inf. n. UizaAgapN, [He made him to decline, or deviate, from the right way in speech, (see 1,)] and zawaAgotuhu↓, inf. n. muzaAwagapN and ziwaAgN, [being mentioned immediately after, without any explanation, seems to signify I made him to decline, or deviate, from the right way therein, like as baAEadotuhu is used in the same sense as OaboEadotuhu,] (TA,) and bihi zugotu↓. (O, TA.)
zaAgN is said by Sgh to belong to art. zyg [q. v.]. (Msb in the present art.)
Oazowagu [More, and most, wont to decline, deviate, swerve, or turn aside, from the right course &c.]. (IJ, TA.)

2. zwRqhu, (O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. tazowiyqN, (Msb, K,) [seems to signify primarily He washed it over with zaAwuwq, i. e. quicksilver; he silvered it therewith.] One says, zwRq AldRaraAhima [He washed over the dirhems with quicksilver]; from AlzRaAwuwqu. (MA.)
[Then, He gilded it with an amalgam of quicksilver and gold: see zaAwuwqN.

And hence,] He decorated it, and embellished it; namely, a thing [of any kind: and particularly he painted it]: but IF says that zwRqhu, meaning thus, is without foundation; that they say it is from AlzRawuwqu meaning AlziYobaqu; [as it is said to be in the K;] but that this is [mere] assertion. (O, TA.) [Whether properly or improperly, however,] one says, zawRaqa Albayota biAlzRaAwuwqi, i. e. He decorated the house, or chamber, [perhaps meaning the House of God, at Mekkeh, i. e. the Kaabeh, as appears to be probable from what here follows,] and changed its colour and its fashion or semblance, with zAwwq, i. e. zYbq. (Har p. 107.) And it is related in a trad. that he [Mohammad] said to Ibn-'Omar, UicaA raOayota qurayoXFA qado hadamuwA Albayota vumRa banawohu fazawRaquwhu faUini QsotaTaEota Almawota famuto [When thou seest Kureysh shall have demolished the House of God, then built it again, and decorated it, if thou be able to die, then die]: he disliked the tazowiyq of mosques because of its inducing desire for the things of the present world, and its finery, or because of its diverting the person praying. (TA.)

One says also, (TA,) zawRaqotu AlkalaAma, and AlkitaAba, (assumed tropical:) I embellished the speech, or language, and the writing, or book; and (tropical:) I rectified, or corrected, it. (S, TA.) And zawRara fulaAnN kitaAbahu and zawRaqahu both mean (tropical:) Such a one rectified, or corrected, his writing, or book. (TA.)

And zawRaquwA AljaAriyapa They embellished the girl, or young woman, with nuquwX [or decorations, app. such as are made by tattooing, or staining with HinRaMC]: such decoration is termed zawaAqN↓, like saHaAbN: and hence, tazayRaqiI↓, [Embellish thyself &c.,] said to a woman; [so that it is originally tazawRaqiI↓;] or this is from zyq, [i. e. ziyqN,] with I. (TA.)
5: see the last sentence above, in two places.
zuwaqN: see zaAwuwqN.
zawaqapN [pl. of zaAYiqN, act. part. n. of the unused verb zaAqa,] Decorators, or embellishers, of the ceilings of houses or chambers. (AA, TA.) [See also zawRaAqN.]
zawaAqN: see 2, last sentence.
[zawRaAqN A decorator; an embellisher: and particularly a painter. See also zawaqapN, above.]

zaAwuwqN, (S, O, K, [in the CK written zAWuqo, as though it were zaAWuwqN, the quiescent w being indicated by the sign of sukoon after the dammeh,]) of the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh, (AA, S, O,) i. q. ziYobaqN [i. e. Quicksilver]; (AA, S, O, K;) as also zuwaqN↓; (AA, O, K;) but from what is said by IB, it would seem that this last word is pl. of zaAwuwqN: (TA:) it is used in tazaAwiyq↓ [meaning decorations, or embellishments, pl. of tazowyqN used as a simple subst., or of the n. un. tazowiyqapN]; (S, O;) and hence, [accord. to some,] AltRazowiyqu signifying “ the act of decorating, and embellishing; ” (K;) for it is put, together with gold, (S, O, K,) for overlaying therewith, (K,) upon iron, (S, O,) and then it is put into the fire, whereupon the zYbq [or quicksilver] goes from it [by evaporation], and the gold remains: (S, O, K:) and hence anything decorated, or embellished, is termed muzawRaqN↓, (S, O,) though not having in it zYbq. (S.)
tazowiyqN inf. n. of 2. (Msb.) [Used as a simple subst., this, or the n. un. tazowiyqapN, has for its pl. tazaAwiyqu:] see the next preceding paragraph.

muzawRaqN Washed over with [zaAwuwq or] ziYobaq [i. e. quicksilver]; applied to a dirhem. (TA.) Decorated therewith (TA) [or with an amalgam of quicksilver and gold subjected to the action of fire so that the quicksilver is evaporated].
And hence, (TA,) Anything decorated, or embellished, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) though not having in it ziYobaq. (S, O.) See zaAwuwqN.

Also, applied to speech, or language, (assumed tropical:) Embellished: (Kr, TA:) and applied to a book, or writing, [in the same sense: (see 2:) or] as meaning (tropical:) rectified, or corrected; like muzawRarN. (AZ, TA.)

1. zaAla, aor. yazuwlu, (K,) and, accord. to the K, also yazaAlu, which is rare, on the authority of Aboo- 'Alee, but this is the aor. of zaAla like xaAfa, [which has a different meaning from the former verb,] (MF, TA,) inf. n. zawaAlN (K) and zuwuwlN (Lh, K) [which in all its senses except one mentioned below may app. be pronounced also zuWuwlN, like HuWuwlN for HuwuwlN, pl. of HawolN,] and zawiylN and zawolN, (K, TA,) the last thus, with fet-h, accord. to a rule of the K, but in some of the copies zuwlN, with damm, (TA,) and zawalaAnN, (K,) It went away; passed away; departed; removed; shifted; (K, TA;) was, or became, remote, or absent; ceased to be or exist, or came to nought; (TA;) as also AizowalRa↓, inf. n. AizowilaAlN; (K;) or, accord. to the O, AizowaOalRa↓, like AiTomaOanRa. (TA.) [See also 7.] Hence,
AldRunoyaA waXiykapu AlzRawaAli [The world, or worldly enjoyment or good, is quick in passing away, or coming to nought]. (TA.) And zAl zawaAluhu, and zawaAluhaA: see zawaAlN: and for the former see also zawiylN. And zAl zawiyluhu, and zawiyluhaA: see zawiylN. And zAl AlXRaIoCu Eano makaAnihi, (S, TA,) or mawoDiEihi, (Msb,) aor. yazuwlu, inf. n. zawaAlN (S, Msb, TA) &c., as above, (TA,) The thing removed, went away, [or ceased,] from its place; it left, or quitted, its place. (TA.) And zulotu Eano makaAniI, inf. n. zawaAlN and zuwuwlN, [I went away, &c., from my place.] (K.) [And zAl Eanohu, said of any affection of the mind or body, It went away, passed away, or ceased, from him; it left him, or quitted him.] And zaAluwA Eano makaAnihimo They turned away from their place; or returned, or went back, and fled, from it. (TA.) And zAl Eani AlrRaOoIi, aor. yazuwlu, inf. n. zuwuwlN, [He turned, or swerved, from the opinion, or judgment, or sentiment.] (Lh, TA.) And zAl alone, aor. yazuwlu, He, or it, quitted his, or its, place. (AHeyth, TA.) And He removed from one town, or country, to another. (TA.) And zAlt Alxayolu birukobaAnihaA, (K,) inf. n. ziyaAlN, (TA,) The horses removed from their place with their riders. (K, TA. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but I see not why.])

Hence, zAlt AlXRamosu, inf. n. zawaAlN and zuwuwlN, without C, (K,) as Th says, (TA,) and ziyaAlN and zawalaAnN, (tropical:) The sun declined from the meridian. (K, TA.) [And sometimes it signifies (assumed tropical:) The sun set: see 1 in art. dlk.]

And hence, but not with zuwuwlN for an inf. n. in the senses expl. in this sentence and the next following it, (TA,) zAl AlnRahaAru, (K, TA,) inf. n. zawaAlN (TA) [and app. ziyaAlN and zawalaAnN], (tropical:) (tropical:) The day became advanced, the sun being somewhat high; syn. AirotafaEa: (K, TA:) or, as some say, went away; or departed. (TA.) And zAl AlZRilRu, (TA,) or AlZRilRi zAl zaAYilu↓, (K, TA,) (tropical:) (tropical:) The sun became high, and the shade contracted, or decreased, or went away, at midday. (K, * TA.)

zAl ZEnhm, [thus in the TK (ed. of Boolák), i. e. ZaEonuhumo, thus in the K, and thus only, the verb being indicated by a preceding phrase; in the TA zAlt ZEnhm. which is an evident mistranscription;] inf. n. zayoluwlapN, (K,) like qayoluwlapN [an inf. n. of qaAla, aor. yaqiylu; but more properly compared to dayomuwmapN, an inf. n. of daAma, aor. yaduwmu]; (TA;) [a phrase which may be rendered Their journeying ceased for a while;] expl. as meaning AiYotawawoA makaAnahumo vumRa badaA lahumo [i. e. they abode in their place: then an opinion occurred to them different from their former opinion, so that it turned them therefrom, inducing them to remove]: (K:) in the K is added Eanohu; but this should be omitted: the passage is taken from the M; in which Eanohu refers to Lh as the authority. (TA.)

zAl [having for its inf. n., app., zawaAlN and zawiylN and zawolN (see the first of these below)] signifies also It moved; or was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; syn. taHarRaka: so in the saying, raOayotu XabaHFA vumRa zaAla [I saw a bodily form or figure: then it moved, &c.]. (TA.) And one says, huwa yazuwlu fiIAlnRaAsi, meaning He moves much among men, or the people, and does not remain still, or stationary. (TA.)
zaAlato lahu zaAYilapN↓ means XaxaSa lahu XaxoSN [A figure seen from a distance rose to his view]. (TA.)
And zAl bihi AlsRaraAbu The mirage raised, or elevated, (rafaEa,) and made apparent, him, or it. (TA.)
maA zaAla yafoEalu kacaA &c.: see in art. zyl.

zAl, aor. yazuwlu, also signifies He affected acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, cleverness, ingeniousness, skilfulness, knowledge, or intelligence: or did so, not having it: syn. taZarRafa. (IAar, TA.) [See also 5.]

[As a trans. verb, it belongs to art. zyl, and app. to the present art. also.] See 4. You say, zAl zawaAlahu, or zAl QllRehu zawalahu; and zAl zawaAlahaA: see zawaAlN. And ziyla zawiyluhu and zawiyluhaA and zawaAluhu: see zawiylN: and for the first, see also zawaAlN.
And zAlhu He separated himself from him; (K;) as also zAylhu. (S and K in art zyl [to which the latter exclusively belongs.])
2: see 4:
and see also 5.

3. zAwlhu, inf. n. muzaAwalapN (S, K) and ziwaAlN, (K,) i. q. EaAlajahu [as meaning He laboured, exerted himself, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, with him, or it, to prevail, overcome, or gain the mastery or possession, or to effect an object: and accord. to the KL and PS and some other lexicons, it signifies also he treated him medically; which is another meaning of EAljh; but of this meaning I have not found any ex.]: and HaAwalahu [as meaning he sought to obtain it, or effect it; or did so by artful, or skilful, management]: (S, * K:) and TaAlabahu [he made a demand on him, or prosecuted a claim upon him]. (K.) [Accord. to the TA, it seems to be used properly in relation to real things, and tropically in relation to ideal things. One says, zAwl AlSRayoda He strove to gain possession of, or to catch, i. e. he hunted, the animals of the chase. (See Tarada.)] And zaAwalotuhu Eani AlOamoru [I strove with him to avert him, or to turn him back, from the affair]. (S, in art. jHs.) Zuheyr says,

[And we passed the night standing at the head of our courser, he striving with us to repel us from himself, and we striving with him to master him]. (S.) And a man said to another, who upbraided him with cowardice, waQllRehu maA kunotu jabaAnFA walekinRiI zaAwalotu mulokFA muWajRalFA (assumed tropical:) [By God I was not a coward, but I strove, or sought, to preserve a possession appointed for a fixed time; i. e., to preserve my life though its term is fixed: see the Kur iii. 139]. (S.) One says also, yuzaAwilu HaAjapF lahu i. e. yuHaAwiluhaA (tropical:) [He seeks to accomplish a thing that is an object of want to him; or does so by artful, or skilful, management]: a tropical phrase. (TA.) And malilotu muzaAwalapa hecaA AlOamori (assumed tropical:) [I loathed, or was averse from, striving, or seeking, to accomplish this affair]. (TA.)

4. AzAlhu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. UizaAlapN; (TA;) and zwRlhu↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazowiylN; (O, TA;) and AizodaAlahu↓, [originally AizotaAlahu,] inf. n. AizodiyaAlN (O,) this being syn. with UizaAlapN; (K;) He removed it; made it to go away, pass away, depart, remove, or shift; (O, K, TA;) [and made it to cease to be or exist, or to come to nought: did away with it; annulled it: effaced, or obliterated, it:] and zilotuhu↓, aor. OazaAluhu and Oaziyluhu, [which see in art. zyl,] signifies the same as Oazalotuhu and zawRalotuhu. (K.) You say, AzAlhu Eani AlmawoDiEi He removed it from the place. (MA: and the like is said in the K.) [And AzAl Eanohu kacaA He removed from him such a thing; made it to go away, pass away, or cease, from him; or to leave him, or quit him; he freed him from it, or rid him of it. And AzAlhu En raOoyihi He, or it, made him to turn, or swerve, from his opinion, or judgment, or sentiment.] And AzAl QllRehu zawaAlahu and zawaAlahaA: see zawaAlN. [See also 4 in art. zyl.]
5. tzwRlhu and zwRlhu↓ i. q. OajaMCahu [He made him, or it, to come]: so says AAF, on the authority of AZ: in the copies of the K, erroneously, OajaAdahu. (TA.)

And tzwRl, (K,) said of a young man, (TA,) He attained the utmost degree of acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, or of cleverness, ingeniousness, skilfulness, knowledge, or intelligence. (K.) [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]

6. tzAwlwA i. q. taEaAlajuwA [They laboured, exerted themselves, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, one with another, to prevail, overcome, or gain the mastery or possession, or to effect an object]. (S, K. [See also 3.])
7. AnzAl It was, or became, removed; or made to go away, pass away, depart, remove, or shift. (S, * TA.)
And AnzAl Eanohu He became separated from him. (K.) [See also 7 in art. zyl.]
8. AzdAlhu: see 4, first sentence.
9. AzwlR: see 1, first sentence.

10: [AistzAlhu He looked at it to see if it quitted its place.] One says, AisotaHilo hecaA AlXRaxoSa waQsotazilohu, meaning Look thou at this figure seen from a distance to see if it move and if it quit its place. (AHeyth, O, TA.)
Q. Q. 4. AizowaOalRa: see 1, first sentence.
zawolN an inf. n. of 1 in the first of the senses expl. above. (K, * TA.)
See also zawaAlN.

As an epithet applied to a man, (S,) Light, agile, or active: acute or sharp or quick in intellect, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent: (S, K:) at whose acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, &c., one wonders: (ISk, S:) fem. with p; (S, K;) said to mean skilful, knowing, or intelligent, (S, TA,) as also the masc., (TA,) and cunning: (S, TA:) and a servant-girl who is sharp and effective in the conveying of messages: and applied to a woman as meaning barozapN lilrRijaAli [who goes or comes forth to men, and with whom they sit, and of whom they talk, and who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and is intelligent; &c.: see art. brz]:
(TA:) pl. masc. OazowaAlN (K, TA) and fem. zawolaAtN; the former applied to young men, and the latter to young women. (TA.)
Courageous; (K, TA;) in consequence of whose courage, men are abashed (yatazaAyaluwA [as though zawolN in this sense belonged to art. zyl]). (TA.)
And Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (K, * TA:) pl. OazowaAlN. (TA.)

(tropical:) A wonder, or wonderful thing: (S, K, TA:) pl. OazowaAlN. (S.) One says, hecaA zawolN mina AlOazowaAli (tropical:) This is a wonder of the wonders. (TA.) And one says also, [using it as an epithet,] sayorN zawolN (assumed tropical:) A journeying, or pace, wonderful in respect of its quickness and briskness or lightness: and XatowapN zawolapN (assumed tropical:) A winter, or winters, wonderful in respect of the severity and cold thereof. (TA.) [See also Oazowalu.]
(assumed tropical:) A trial, or an affliction; syn. balaMCN. (K.)

(assumed tropical:) A form, or figure, that appears in the night [and by which one is frightened: see muzaAwalN]. (TA.) (tropical:) A form, or figure, of a man or some other thing, that one sees from a distance: or a person: syn. XaxoSN: (K, TA:) as also zaAYilapN↓: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. (TA.)
The faroj [i. e. the anterior pudendum, or the pudenda,] of a man. (K.) One says, kaXafa zawolahu [He uncovered his frj]. (TK.)
And A hawk. (K.)
zawaAlN (S, Msb, K) and zawiylN↓ and zawolN↓ (K) are inf. ns. of zaAla [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.)

And all signify Motion, commotion, or agitation. (TA in explanation of the first and last, and K in explanation of the second.) [Hence,] zaAla↓ zawaAluhu, or zawaAlahu zaAla↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or QllRehu zawaAlahu zaAla↓, (S in art. zyl, and TA,) and QllRehu zawaAlahu OazaAla↓, (S in art. zyl, and K and TA,) are imprecations of destruction, or perdition, or death, (S, K,) and trial, or affliction, upon him to whom they relate: (S:) or such are the [second and] third and fourth of these phrases: but the first is a prayer for one's continuance where he is, [or his continuance in life; lit.] meaning May his motion cease; [and hence, may he continue where he is, or continue in life:] and, as expl. by ISk, the [second and] third and fourth [lit.] signify May [He i. e.] God cause his motion to cease; [and hence, may He, or God, put an end to his life;] these phrases being similar to the saying Oasokata QllRehu naAmRatahu. (TA.) [Thus all four have virtually the same lit. signification. And the first has also another meaning; as will be seen below.] El-Aashà says,

L.foreign: hecaA AlnRahaAru badaA lahaA mino hamRihaA

sense.s: (S, TA,) [app. meaning This is the day-time: an opinion has arisen in her mind such as to turn her from her former opinion and induce her to absent herself, (badaMCN, I suppose, being understood after badaA lahaA, like as it is after badaA lahumo in the Kur xii. 35,) in consequence of her anxiety: what will be her case in the night? may it (her phantom) be absent, like as she is absent: for] the meaning is said to be, zaAla AlxayaAlu zawaAlahaA: IAar says, he disliked the phantom only because it roused his desire: or [zaAla may be here syn. with OazaAla, so that] the meaning may be QllRehu zawaAlahaA OazaAla↓ [may God make her motion to cease]; and this is corroborated by the reading of AA, zawaAluhaA, in the nom. case, [i. e. zawaAluhaA zaAla↓ may her motion cease;] which makes this an instance of [the license termed] AlUiqowaMC: this, he says, is an old proverbial phrase of the Arabs, and El-Aashà has used it as he heard it: others than AA read [zawaAlahaA,] in the accus. case, without UiqowaMC, holding the meaning to be, may her phantom be absent from us in the night like as she herself is absent in the day-time. (TA.) zawiyluhu↓ ziyla↓, likewise, means His motion ceased, or may his motion cease: or, accord. to Z, he became fixed, or motionless, from fear; or may he become so. (TA in art. zyl.) [See also another rendering of this phrase in the next paragraph.] One says also, waAlEawiylu Oaxacahu AlzRawiylu↓ Commotion, or agitation, (K, TA,) and disquietude of mind, (TA,) and wailing, or raising of the voice in weeping, overcame him. (K, TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in three places.
zawiylN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

Also The side; syn. jaAnibN; and so zawaAlN↓: thus in the sayings, zawiyluhu zaAla↓ and zawaAluhu↓ zaAla↓, meaning [app. His side became in a state of commotion, or it quivered,] by reason of fright: (K:) [or] zawiylN signifies the heart: so in the saying, zawiyluhu ziyla↓ [His heart became removed from its place]: (S:) a prov., applied to one whom an event that has disquieted him has befallen: as also zawaAluhu↓ ziyla↓: (Meyd:) [see also two other renderings of the former phrase in the next preceding paragraph:] Dhu-r-Rummeh says, describing the egg of an ostrich,

meaning ziyla qalobuhaA mina AlfazaEi [i. e. And a white thing (the egg which he is describing) will not take fright, and flee from us, or will not shrink from us, while its mother, when she sees us, her heart becomes removed from its place by fright in consequence of the approach of us]: (S in art. zyl, and Meyd:) or, as some relate it, minRaA zaAla↓ zawiyluhaA [which means her heart quits its place &c.]: (TA:) and the former reading may mean the same as this. (IB, TA in art. zyl.)
zawRaAlN Having much zawol, i. e. motion. (TA.)

Accord. to J, it occurs in an Ourojuwzap, cited by AA, as meaning That moves much in his gait, but traverses a short space: but the right word in this case is zawRaAk, as is shown by the rhyme. (IB, K.)
zwylI, with damm, [app. zuwRayolaI, like qubRayoTaI &c., for, as it is not said to be a dim., I know no other form of word with which to compare it,] A thing like a ladle, belonging to sailors. (TA.)
zaAYilN [Going away; passing away; departing; transient; shifting; becoming remote, or absent; ceasing to be or exist; nonexistent: &c.: part. n. of zaAla, q. v.].
[Hence,] layolN zaAYilu AlnRujuwmi [properly A starless night, or night of which the stars are absent: but expl. as meaning] (assumed tropical:) a long night. (Z, TA.)
zaAla zaAYilu AlZRilRi: see 1.

zaAYilapN [from zaAYilN, the p being affixed to transfer the word from the category of epithets to that of substantives,] Whatever has a soul, (K, TA,) of animals; that moves (yazuwlu) from its place: (TA:) or anything that moves; (K, TA;) that does not remain fixed in its place; applied to a man and to other things. (TA.)
zawaAYilu is its pl.: (TA:) and signifies [particularly] Animals of the chase. (K, TA.)

And [hence,] (tropical:) Women. (O, K, TA.) One says rajulN raAmiI AlzRawaAYili (assumed tropical:) A man knowing in respect of the diseases, or faults, (OadowaMC,) of women: (O:) or (tropical:) skilful in the making of women to incline to him: whence the saying of Ibn-Meiyádeh,

(tropical:) [And I was a man having the art of making women to incline to me, once; but I have become such that I have relinquished the art of making women to incline to me]: this was a man who used to beguile women in his time of youthful vigour by his beauty; but when he became hoary and aged, no woman inclined to him. (TA.)
Also (tropical:) The stars: (K, TA:) because of their motion from the east and the west in their revolving. (TA.)
See also 1, near the end of the paragraph; and zawolN, last sentence but three.

zawolN Oazowalu (S, * TA) has an intensive signification [i. e. (assumed tropical:) A great wonder; or a very wonderful thing]: (TA:) [or a wonderful event that happens to one, preventing his fleeing;] accord. to Abu-sSemh, Oazowalu denotes the happening to one of an event such as prevents him from fleeing. (IB, TA.)

mizowalapN A certain instrument pertaining to astronomers, by means of which is known the declining of the sun from the meridian: [a sun-dial: used in this sense in the present day:] a vulgar term: pl. mazaAwilu. (TA.)

muzaAwalN pass. part. n. of 3: one says, maA zaAla hecaA AlOamoru muzaAwalFA biOayodiyhimo (assumed tropical:) [This affair ceased not to be striven, or sought, to be accomplished by means of their hands]. (TA.)
Also Frightened by a zawol, i. e. a form, or figure, appearing in the night. (TA.)

1: [zaAnahu, aor. yazuwnuhu, is a dial. var. of zaAnahu having for its aor. yaziynuhu.] An Arab woman of the desert is related to have said to IAar, UinRaka latazuwnunaA UicaA TalaEota, meaning taziynunaA [i. e. Verily thou gracest us when thou comest to us (EalayonaA)]. (TA.)

zaAnN Indigestion; syn. baXamN; for AlnRaXamu in the copies of the K is a mistranscription for AlbaXamu; (TA;) expl. by Ed-Dubeyreeyeh as syn. with tuxomapN; as in the phrase, layosa yaXokuw AlzRaAna [He does not complain of indigestion]: (Fr, TA:) and so
zaAnapN↓: (K and TA in art. zyn:) or this signifies a single fit of indigestion. (TA in that art.)
[In the present day, applied to The beech-tree; and its wood: as a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p: see also zaAnapN below.]
zawonN: see ziwanRN.
zuwnN An idol: and anything that is taken as a deity and worshipped, (S, K, * TA,) beside God: as also zuwrN: [an arabicized word:] in Pers. \xQ698Yuwno. (TA.)
And A place in which idols are collected and set up. (K.) It is said to be from ziynapN. (TA.) [But it may rather be from zuwnapN as a dial. var. of ziynapN.]
See also ziwanRN.
zaAnapN A thing like a mizoraAq [or javelin], which the Deylem (AldRayolam) cast: [perhaps made of the wood of the beech, (see zaAnN, latter sentence,) and therefore so called:] pl. zaAnaAtN. (Msb.)
See also zaAnN, former sentence.
zuwnapN i. q. ziynapN [An ornament, &c.], (K,) in one of the dialects. (TA.)
And An intelligent woman. (IAar, K.)
ziwanRN Short; (S, K;) applied to a man; (S;) and so, thus applied, zawonN↓ and zuwnN↓, (K,) of which two, the former is the more known: (TA:) fem. ziwanRapN, (S, K,) applied to a woman. (S.)
zuwaAnN and ziwaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and zawaAnN (K) i. q. zuWaAnN [q. v. in art. zOn]. (S, M, Msb, K.)
TaEaAmN mazuwnN Wheat in which is zuwaAn [or the grain of a certain noxious weed, app. darnel-grass: mzwn being a pass. part. n. of which no verb is mentioned]. (TA.)

1. zawaAhu, (K,) aor. yazowiyhi, (TA,) inf. n. zaIRN and zuwiIRN, (K, TA,) the latter [accord. to the CK zawoIN, but it is correctly] like EutiIRN, (TA,) He put it aside, or away, or apart; or removed it from its place. (K.) You say, zawaIa Eanohu kacaA, inf. n. zuwiIRN, He averted, diverted, or removed, from him such a thing; turned, put, or sent, it away, or back, from him. (TA.)
And zawaI sirRahu Eanohu He concealed his secret from him. (K.)

Also (K) zawaAhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. zaIRN, (Msb, TA,) He drew it, collected it, or gathered it, together; contracted it, or grasped it. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., zuwiyato liIa AlOaroDu faOoriytu maXaAriqahaA wamagaAribahaA [The earth was collected together to me, and I was shown its eastern parts and its western parts]. (S, TA.) And you say, zawaI AlmaAla, (S, Msb,) inf. n. zaIRN, (S,) He drew, or collected, together, or he grasped, the property, (Msb,) Eano waArivihi [from its inheritor]. (S.) And zawaI maA bayona Eayonayohi (S, TA) He (a man, S) drew together, or contracted, the part between his eyes. (TA.) And jaMCanaA biSarobapK tazowiI Alwajoha [He brought us some very sour milk such as contracts the face, or makes it to wrinkle]. (S in art. Srb.) And tazowiI Alwujuwha said of a cold north wind, It contracts [or wrinkles] the faces: a phrase used by Tarafeh Ibn-El-'Abd. (Ham p. 632.)
2. zwRI, inf. n. tazowiyapN: see 5.

zayRayotuhu, (S, Msb, K,) which by rule should be zawRayotuhu, (S, Msb,) but is made to accord with ziIRN in order to facilitate the pronunciation, (Msb,) inf. n. accord. to the K tazoyiyapN, but correctly, as Lth says, taziyRapN, in measure like taHiyRapN, (TA,) I invested him with, or made him to have, a ziIR [i. e. garb, guise, &c.]; (S, * Msb, K, * TA;) by means of, or with, such a thing: you say, zayRayotuhu bikacaA [which may be rendered I invested, decked, or adorned, him with such a thing; agreeably with what follows]. (Msb.) Accord. to Fr, they say, zayRayotu AljaAriyapa, meaning I invested the girl, or young woman, with a garb, or guise, &c.; and decked, or adorned, her. (TA.)
You say also, zwRI AlkalaAma, meaning He prepared the speech in his mind; like zawRarahu. (TA.)

zayRayotu zaAyFA and zawRayotu zaAyFA [mean I wrote, or uttered, a z]: some [hold the A in zAI to be originally I, and therefore] say zayRayotu: others [hold it to be originally w, and therefore] say zawRayotu. (IB, on the letter Oalif.) Zeyd Ibn-Thábit said, in relation to the expression in the Kur [ii. 261] nunoXizuhaA, [accord. to one reading, or reciting,] hiIa zaAIN fazayRihaA, meaning [It is zAI, therefore make thou it zAI in thy reading, or reciting; or] read thou it, or recite thou it, with the zAI. (S.)
4. AzwI: see art. zw.
5. tzwRI He was, or became, [or placed himself,] in a zaAwiyap, i. e. corner, of a house or chamber; as also zwRI↓, (K,) inf. n. tazowiyapN; (TA;) and AnzwI↓. (K.)

tazayRaA, from AlzRiIRu; (K, KL;) or tazayRaA biziIRK; (Lth, MA;) He invested himself with a garb, guise, or dress; [or with an external appearance;] (MA, KL;) he decked, or adorned, himself. (MA.) You say of a man, tzyRA biziIRK HasanK [He invested himself with a beautiful, or goodly, garb, &c.]. (Lth, TA.) Hence the saying of El-Mutanebbee,

(TA:) i. e.
