[And verily, or sometimes, or often, one who is not entitled to it] assumes the guise of love; and the man asks to be his companion him who is not suited to him: (W p. 374:) his disciple Ibn-Jinnee, however, objected to him his saying ytzyRA, and expressed his opinion that the correct word is yatazawRaI; and El-Mutanebbee admitted that he did not know the former word in any [classical] poetry, nor in any lexicological book, but asserted the verb in use to be only tazayRaA: (MF, TA:) in the M it is said that IJ held tazayRaA to be originally tazawoyaA, and the w to be changed into I because quiescent, and incorporated into the I preceded by it. (TA.)
7. AnzwI It was, or became, put aside, or away, or apart; or removed from its place. (K.)

Ainozawati Aljilodapu fiIAlnRaAri The piece of skin became contracted, or shrivelled, or shrunk, in the fire. (S.) And AnzwI maA bayona Eayonayohi The part between his eyes became drawn together, or contracted. (TA.) And AnzwI Alqawomu baEoDuhumo UilaI baEoDK The people, or party, drew together, one portion of them to another portion. (TA.)
See also 5, first sentence.
zaA and zFA and zaMCN and see zaAIN, below.
zaIo and zaIRN: see zaAIN, below.

ziIRN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally ziwoIN, (S, Msb,) Garb, guise, dress, habit, fashion of dress, and aspect, or outward appearance; syn. libaAsN, (S, TA,) and hayoYapN, (Fr, Msb, K, TA,) and manoZarN: (Fr, TA:) pl. OazoyaMCN. (K.) [In the Kur xix. 75,] some read OaHosanu OavaAvFA waziyRFA [Better in respect of household-goods and in respect of garb, &c.]: others read riyRFA, with r: (TA:) and riYoyFA: and riyoYFA: and riyFA. (Bd.)

zaAIN, (Kr, S, K, &c.,) in which the A, accord. to Lth, is originally I, but accord. to Sb and IJ it is w, (TA,) A certain letter (i. e. z); (S, TA;) [in spelling, pronounced zaAIo; and] also called zaMCN↓, (Kr, S, K,) and zFA↓, and [in spelling (see the first sentence of art. b)] zaA↓, (Kr, K, but omitted in some copies of the K,) this last being indecl., (Kr, TA,) and zaIRN↓ (K) and [in spelling] zaIo↓: (Kr, K:) of all which, the first is that which is held in [most] repute: (TA:) and this and zaMCN may be meant by J's saying, AlzRaAIu HarofN yumadRu wayuqoSaru walaA yukotabu UilRaA biyaMCK baEoda AlOalifi; though the author of the K asserts J to have erred in saying this: (MF, TA:) the pl. is OazowaMCN and OazoyaMCN, (Kudot;,) the former or the latter accord. to different opinions, (TA,) and OazowK and OazoIK, (K,) each [originally] of the measure OafoEulN. (TA.) One says, hecihi zaAIN HasanapN [This is a beautiful; z]: and katabotu zaAyFA SagiyrapF [I wrote a small; z]: and the like. (IJ, TA.)

zaAIo is also said by the vulgar on an occasion of wonder, and of disapproval: but [SM says,] I know not what is its origin. (TA.) [It may be from the Pers. zaIo, or zihiI; which are likewise said on an occasion of wonder. UizRaAIo and UizRaIR and UizRaIo, and with Oa in the place of Ui, are also said by the vulgar in Egypt on an occasion of wonder, and of denial, meaning How? And zaIo is used by them for the prefix ka, meaning Like.]
zuwayRapN: see what next follows.

zuyayRapN dim. of zaAIRN [accord. to those who hold the A in the latter to be originally I, or zuwayRapN↓ accord. to those who hold that letter to be originally w; like OuyayRapN and OuwayRapN as dims. of MCN accord. to different opinions: see art. A, in the middle of the first column]. (TA.)

zaAwiyapN A corner, or an angle, (rukon,) of a house or room or the like: (K:) of the measure faAEilapN from zawaI signifying jamaEa; because of its em-
bracing (liOanRahaA jamaEato) a part, or portion, (quTorFA,) thereof: (Msb, TA:) pl. zawaAyaA [which is irreg.; for by rule it should be zawaMCK, being originally of the measure fawaAEilu, not faEaAYilu]. (S, K.) They say, kamo fiI AlzRawaAyaA mina AlxabaAyaA [How many hidden things are there in the corners!]. (TA.)
[In geometry, An angle.

And hence, zaAwiyapu AlEawRaMCi The star γ of Virgo; AlEawRaMCu being composed of four stars, γ,δ,ε and η of Virgo, disposed nearly in the form of a capital L, with ε, δ, γ from top to bottom and η to the right.]
In a saying cited voce raAwiyapN, the pl. zawaAyaA is used as meaning Houses, or tents. (T in art. rwI.)

[And in the present day, the term zaAwiyapN is also applied to A small mosque, or chapel: and in some instances, a building of this kind, thus called, serves as a hospice, or an asylum for poor Muslims, students and others; like ribaATN.]
1. zuIRa, or ziIRa: see art. zw.
2. zayRayotu: see 2 in art. zwI, in two places.
5. tazayRaA: see 5 in art. zwI.
zaIo: see zaAIN, in art. zwI.
ziI ziI an onomatopoeia significant of The sound of the jinn, or genii. (TA.) [See also ziyzamN and ziyziymN, in art. zm.]
zaIRN: see zaAIN, in art. zwI.
ziIRN: see art. zwI.
zuyayRapN: see art. zwI.

Oazoyabu is of the measure OafoEalu, (S,) like OaHomaru: (K:) or, as some say, of the measure faEoyal; but this is a weak assertion, for it is said that there is no Arabic word of this measure; maroyamu being a foreign proper name, and DahoyaO being disputed. (MF, TA.) [In some of its senses it is an epithet, and used as such: in some, app. an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: and in some, a simple subst.: but in all its senses it is imperfectly decl.; and therefore seems to be originally an epithet.]
Brisk, lively, sprightly, agile, or quick. (K.)
A man who walks with short steps: (TA:) and short in stature and in step; (K, TA;) likewise applied to a man. (TA.)

Ignoble, base, or base-born. (K.) The offspring of fornication or adultery; or the offspring of fornication, begotten on a slave. (Abu-l-Mekárim, TA.) One whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; or an adopted son; or one who claims as his father a person who is not his father; or who is claimed as a son by a person who is not his father; syn. daEiIRN. (S, K.)
A devil: (K:) accord. to some, a dial. var. of OazabRu. (TA.)
The hedge-hog. (IAar, K.)
A disagreeable, a disapproved, or an abominable, thing or affair. (K.)
A calamity, or misfortune. (K.)
Much water: (AA, S:) and so Oacoyabu. (K in art. cyb.)

[A south-easterly wind; i. e.] the [wind termed] nakobaMC [q. v.] that blows between the SabaA and the januwb: (S, M, K:) or the south wind, or a southerly wind; syn. januwbN; (M, K;) of the dial. of Hudheyl; so affirm Mbr in his “ Kámil ” and IF and Et-Tarábulusee: IAth says that the people of Mekkeh use this appellation much; and it is related to be God's name for what men call the jnwb: Sh says that the people of El-Yemen, and those who voyage upon the sea between Juddah and 'Adan, cali the jnwb by the name of AlOazoyabu, and know not any other name for it; and that is because it is boisterous, and stirs up the sea, turning it upsidedown: [whence it seems to mean the boisterous, or violent:] ISh says that caAtu Oazoyaba signifies any violent wind. (L,TA.)
[Hence it appears that it signifies also Violence.]
Also Enmity. (S, K.)

And Briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, agility, or quickness: (ISk, S, K, TA:) [see also Oacoyabu:] it is fem.: one says, marRa fulaAnN walahu Oazoyabu munokarapN [Such a one passed having a disapproved briskness, &c.]: this is said when one passes quickly by reason of briskness, &c. (ISk, S.)
And Fear, or fright: (AZ, S, K:) and so Oacoyabu. (K in art. cyb.) One says, OaxacaniI mino fulaAnK AlOazoyabu [Fear, or fright, arising from such a one, seized me]. (AZ, S.)

1. zaAtahu, aor. yaziytuhu, [inf. n. zayotN,] He anointed him, or it, with zayot, i. e. oil of the zayotuwn [or olive]. (Msb.) You say, zitRN, meaning I anointed my head, and the head of another, with oil of the zytwn. (L.)

And zitRuhu, (Lh, S, K,) aor. Oaziytuhu, (S, K, TA, in the CK AazitRuh, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) inf. n. zayotN, (K,) I put zayot [i. e. olive-oil] into it; namely, the food; (S, K;) or the crumbled bread: or I prepared it therewith: (TA:) or I moistened it, or stirred it about, or moistened and mixed it, with zyt; namely, bread, and crumbled bread. (Lh, TA.)
And zaAtahumo (Lh, S, K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] zaOatahumo) He fed them with zayot: (Lh, K:) or he made zyt to be the seasoning of their food. (S.)
2. zayRatahumo He furnished them with zayot [i. e. olive-oil] for travelling-provision; (Lh, S, A;) agreeably with a general rule relating to verbs similar to this in meaning. (Lh, TA.)

4. OazaAtuwA (in the CK [erroneously] AazoiAatuwA) They had much zayot [i. e. olive-oil]; their zayot became much; (Lh, K;) agreeably with a general rule relating to verbs similar to this in meaning. (Lh, TA.)
8. AizodaAta [so in the TA and in my MS copy of the K; in the CK, erroneously, AizodaOata;] He anointed himself with zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (K.)
10. AstzAt He sought, or demanded, zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (K.) You say, jaAWuwA yasotaziytuwna They came asking for zayot as a gift; (S, L;) or seeking, or demanding, zyt. (A.)

zayotN The oil, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or expressed juice, (M, TA,) or muxR [i. e. best, or choicest, of the constituents], (A, TA,) of the zayotuwn [or olive]. (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) [In the present day it is applied to Any oil.]

zayotuwnN [The olive-tree;] a certain kind of tree, (Msb, K, *) well known, (S, Msb,) whence zayot is obtained; (S, Msb, K;) [a tree] of the kind called EiDaAh; (AHn, Mgh, TA;) As says, on the authority of 'Abd-El-Melik Ibn-Sálih Ibn-'Alee, that a single tree of this kind lasts thirty thousand years; and that every tree of this kind in Palestine was planted by the ancient Greeks who are called the Yoonánees: (TA:) and the fruit of that tree: (Mgh:) or it has the latter signification, and is tropically applied to the tree: or it properly has both of these significations: (TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: (S, TA:) accord. to some, the n is a radical letter, and the I is augmentative, because they said ArD ztnp [i. e. OaroDN zatinapN, like OaroDN EaDihapN from AlEiDaAhu], meaning “ a land in which are zayotuwn; ” so that the measure is fayoEuwlN; and if so, its proper place is art. ztn. (TA.) Respecting the phrase in the Kur xcv. l, waAltRiyni waAlzRayotuwni, see tiynN.
[zayotuwnu baniI UisoraAYiyla Lapis Judaicus: so called because resembling an olive in shape, and found in Judæa.]
[zayotuwniIRN Of, or relating to, the olive: olivecoloured.]
zayRaAtN One who sells, or expresses, zayot [i. e. olive-oil, and, vulgarly, any oil]. (TA.)
[Hence,] jaMCa fulaAnN fiI viyaAbi zayRaAtK (assumed tropical:) Such a one came in dirty clothes. (A.)
maziytN and mazoyuwtN↓ Food into which zayot [i. e. olive-oil] has been put: (S, A, K:) or prepared therewith. (TA.)
mazoyuwtN: see what next precedes.
muzodaAtN A man anointing himself, or who anoints himself, with zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (TA.)
muzayotiytN dim. of muzodaAtN. (TA.)

ziyj The builder's string, or line, (K in art. zwj, improperly there mentioned, TA,) which he extends to make even, thereby, the row of stones, or bricks, of the building; syn. miTomarN [q. v.]: (TA:) [also called ziyqN:] an arabicized word, (K,) from [the Pers.] ziho, signifying “ a bowstring: ” so in the “ Shifá el-Ghaleel. ” (TA.)

Also, as is said in the “ Mefáteeh el-'Uloom, ” [An astronomical almanac; or a set of astronomical tables;] a book, or writing, containing stellar calculations, year by year: in which sense, likewise, it is an arabicized word, from the Pers. ziho: pl. ziyajapN. (TA.)
And The science of astronomy, or of the celestial sphere. (TA.)

zaAYijapN A four-sided, or round, scheme, made to exhibit the horoscope, or places [or configurations] of the stars at the time of a birth: an astrological
term [arabicized from the Pers. zaAyoJaho]: so in the “ Shifá el-Ghaleel, ” from the “ Mefáteeh el- 'Uloom, ” by Er-Rázee. (TA.)

1. zaAHa, (S, A, K,) aor. yaziyHu, inf. n. zayoHN (S, K) and zuyuwHN (MA, K) and ziyuwHN (K) and zayaHaAnN; (MA, K; [in the CK, erroneously, zayoHAn;]) and AnzAH↓; (A, K;) It (a thing, S) became distant, or remote: (S, A, K:) it went, went away, passed away, or departed. (S, K.) You say, zaAHato EilRatuhu (S, A, MA) and AnzAHt↓ (A) His pretext, pretence, or excuse, [or his malady,] became remote [or removed], or went away. (MA.) And zaAHa EanRiI AlbaATilu What was false, or vain, ceased, passed away, or went away, from me. (TA, from a trad.)
And zaAHa, aor. as above, i. q. taOaxRara [He, or it, went back or backwards, &c.]. (TA in art. zH.)

4. AzAHhu He made it (a thing, S) to be distant, or remote: [he removed it, did away with it, or caused it to cease:] he made it to go, go away, pass away, or depart. (S, K.) Hence the saying of El-Aashà, qado OazaHonaA huzaAlahaA [We had caused her leanness to cease]. (S.) And OazaHotu EilRatahu: (S, A:) AzAH EilRatahu signifies He removed his pretext, pretence, or excuse; [or his malady;] or did away with it. (MA.)
7: see 1, in two places.
mazaAHN A place to which one [goes away, or may go away; or] removes, or may remove, far away. (Ham p. 329.)

1. zaAda, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaziydu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ziyaAdapN (S, A, * Msb, K *) and zayodN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) with which are syn. ziydN (S, K) and zayadN (K) and maziydN (S, K) and zayodaAnN, which last is anomalous, like XanoMnN (K) and layRaAnN, said to be the only instances of the kind, (TA,) all as inf. ns., (TK,) and so is mazaAdN, (TA,) and J adds that zuwaAdapN is mentioned by Yaakoob, from Ks, from El-Bekree, as syn. with ziyaAdapN, but this is a mistake, which is unfairly imputed to J by the author of the K, (MF,) [who says,] as to AlzRuwaAdapu, it is a mistranscription by J, for the words are AlzRuwaArapu and AlzRiyaArapu, [in the CK AlrRuwAdpu and AlrRiyAdpu,] with r, and without the mention of [the signification of] AlnRumuwRu, (K, TA,) It (a thing, S, Mgh, Msb, [as, for ex.,] water, and property, A) increased, or augmented, or grew; (S, A, TA;) [and in like manner said of a man, and of any animal;] as also AizodaAda↓: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or this latter has a more intensive signification than the former, like Aikotasaba in relation to kasaba. (MF. [See also 5.]) In this sense it has a single objective complement; as in zaAda kacaA It, or he, increased, or augmented, or grew, in such a thing; as also AizodaAda↓. (TA.) [The latter is more commonly used in this manner.] You say, Aizodadotu↓ maAlFA (A, Mgh, Msb) [I increased in property: also] meaning I increased to myself, or for myself, property. (Mgh, * Msb.) And AlOamoru AzdAd↓ SuEuwbapF [The affair increased in difficulty]. (A.)

[Also It exceeded; it was, or became, redundant, or superfluous; it remained over and above. And zaAda Ealayohi It exceeded it; as also tzAyd↓.] You say, zaAda EalaI AlXRaIoCi DiEofahu [It exceeded the thing by the like thereof, or more]. (A.) And zaAda EalaI maA OaraAda [It exceeded what he desired]. (A.)
Also He gave an addition: so in the saying, faqado OarobaI mano zaAda waQzodaAda↓ He who gives an addition, and who takes it, [each of these] practises usury. (Msb.)
[And He added, or exaggerated.] yaziydu fiI Hadiyvihi [He adds, or exaggerates, in his narration, or talk, or discourse,] is said of a liar. (A and TA voce sarRaAjN. [See also 5.])

It is also trans.: (Msb:) you say, zaAdahu, aor. yaziyduhu, inf. n. ziyaAdapN, He increased it, or augmented it. (L.) And in this sense it is doubly trans.: (MF:) you say, zaAdahu QllRehu xayorFA, (S, K,) or maAlFA, (A,) [God increased to him, or added to him, good fortune or prosperity or the like, or property; increased, or added to, his good fortune, &c.; or may God increase &c.;] as also zayRadahu↓: (K:) and zaAda fiymaA Einodahu, (S,) or fiI maAlihi, (A,) [He increased, or added to, what he possessed or his possessions, or his property; or may He (i. e. God) increase &c.]
zaAdahu also signifies He gave him an increase, or an addition, or more. (Msb.) See 10.

You say also, maA yaziyduka OaHadN Ealayohi [No one is more sufficient for thee than he]. (K in art. znd. [See 4 in that art.]) And laA yaziyduka Ealayohi jamalN No camel will be more sufficient for thee than he; i. q. laA yaDurRuka. (ISk, S in art. Dr [in which see other exs.].)
2. zyRd, [inf. n. tazoyiydN,] said of property, It increased, or augmented, much. (A.)
See also 1, latter part.
3. zAyd OaHadu AlmutabaAyiEayoni AlMxara, inf. n. muzaAyadapN, [One of the two persons buying together outbade the other: see also 6.] (A.)
5. tzyRd It (a price, S, A) was, or became, excessive, or dear; (S, A, K;) as also tzAyd↓. (A, TA.)

He added, or exaggerated, (MA,) or lied, (S, MA, K,) in narration, or discourse. (S, MA. [See also 1, latter half.]) And He affected to exceed the due bounds in his narration, or discourse, and his speech; (TA;) he affected excess in speech, &c.; (K, TA;) i. e. in speech and in action; (TA;) as also tzAyd↓: (K:) or AltRazayRudu fiI AlHadiyvi means the embellishing narration, or discourse, with lies, and adding in it what does not belong to it. (Har p. 195.) In the verse of 'Adee cited in art. znd, the last word is tazayRadi as some relate it, or tazanRadi as others relate it. (TA.)

He went a pace exceeding that termed AlEanaq. (S, K. [See also camala, and naSaba AlsRayora, and wasaja.]) And tzyRdt She (A camel) stretched forth her neck, and went a pace exceeding that termed AlEanaq, as though she were swimming with her rider: (A, TA:) and in like manner one says of a mare, or horse. (TA.) And tzyRdt AlUibilu fiI sayorihaA The camels tasked themselves in their pace beyond their ability. (TA.)

6. tzAyd [It increased, augmented, or grew, gradually; contr. of tanaAqaSa]. See also 1. And see 5, in two places. tzAydwA EalaI AlsRiloEapi [They bade, one against another, for the commodity, or article of merchandise, successively raising the price]: said of the people of a market when a commodity is sold to him who bids more than others. (L.) And tzAydwA fiI AlvRamani HatRaI balaga munotahaAhu [They augmented the price, one outbidding another, until it attained its utmost]. (A, TA.)
8. AizodaAda [originally AizotaAda]: see 1, in four places.
Also He took an addition. (Msb.) See, again, 1.

Also He took in addition: so in the saying, UicaA QzodaAda AlrRaAhinu daraAhima mina Almurotahini [When the pledger takes money in addition from the receiver of the pledge]. (Mgh.) One says also, Aizodado mina Alxayori [Obtain thou, or gain thou, somewhat in addition of what is good: or it may mean seek thou, or desire thou, an increase, or addition, of what is good]. (A.) See what next follows, in two places. 10. AstzAd He sought, or desired, or demanded, an increase, an addition, or more; (A, Mgh, Msb;) as also AizodaAda↓; whence the saying, to a man to whom a thing has been given, halo tazodaAdu↓ Dost thou seek, or desire, or demand, more than what I have given thee? (L.)

[Hence,] huwa yasotaziydu fiI Hadiyvihi [He seeks, or desires, to add, or exaggerate, or to exceed the due bounds, or to embellish with lies and additions, in his narration, or discourse]. (A, TA. [See also 5.])

AstzAdhu He sought, or desired, or demanded, of him an increase, an addition, or more. (Msb, K.) You say, lawi Qsotazadotuhu lazaAdaniI↓ If I had sought, or desired, or demanded, an increase, &c., he had given me an increase, &c. (Msb.)

[And hence,] (tropical:) He reckoned him, or held him, to have fallen short of doing what he ought to have done, (S, A, K, TA,) and complained of him, (A, TA,) or reproved him, for a thing that he did not approve. (TA.) And kataba Uilayohi kitaAba QsotizaAdapK (tropical:) [He wrote to him a letter of complaint, or reproof, for his having fallen short, &c.; requiring him to do more]. (A.)
zayodN an inf. n. of zaAda. (S, Mgh, Msb.)
[Hence,] humo zayodN EalaI miAYapK (S, A, L) and ziydN↓ (S, L) and ziyAadapN↓ (A) (tropical:) [They are more than a hundred].
ziydN an inf. n. of zaAda. (S, * K, * TK.)
See the next preceding paragraph.

ziyaAdapN an inf. n. of zaAda. (S, Msb.) Using it as an inf. n., (Msb,) you say, AifoEalo celika ziyaAdapF [meaning Do thou that in addition]: (S, Msb:) the vulgar say zaAYidapF↓, (S,) which one should not say. (Msb.) [Hence also,] Huruwfu AlzRiyaAdapi [The letters of augmentation; or the augmentative letters; i. e. the letters that are added to the radical letters in Arabic words]: they are ten, and are
comprised in the saying, saOalotumuwniyhaA [“ Ye asked me for them ”], (TA,) and in Oaloyawoma tanosaAhu [“ Today thou wilt forget it ”]; (K, TA;) and more than a hundred and thirty other combinations comprising them have been mentioned: (MF:) [these letters are also called zawaAYidu, of which the sing. is zaAYidapN↓.] See also zayodN.

[As a simple subst., or a subst. properly so termed, it signifies An increase, or increment; and augmentation, or augment; an addition, additament, adjunct, or accessory: an accession: excess, redundance, or superfluity: and a redundant part or portion or appertenance; a surplus; a residue: an excrescence: pl. ziyaAdaAtN and zayAYidu.
Hence,] UibilN kaviyrapu AlzRayaAYidi i.e. AlzRiyaAdaAt [Camels having much increase; lit., much, or many, increases]. (K.) A poet says,

[With a herd of forty or more camels, that fill, or glut, the eye of the envier, enjoying pasturing by themselves, having much increase]: some say, [in citing this verse,] AlzRawaAYidi, which is pl. of zaAYidapN↓; but AlzwAYd is said only in relation to the legs of a beast. (L.)

[Hence also,] ziyaAdapu Alkabidi, (so in a copy of the S, and in the A and L, and in several places in the K,) or Alkabidi zaAYidapu↓, (so termed by Zj, and so in the T, and in two copies of the S, and in the L,) both of which are correct, (TA,) [The redundant appertenance of the liver;] a certain small piece to which the liver is attached, or suspended: (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or a certain small appertenance of the liver (hunayRapN minohaA SagiyrapN), at its side, going away from it (mutanaHRiyapN EanohaA): (S, L:) or a certain piece appended, or attached, to the liver (muEalRaqapN bihaA): (A:) or a certain appendage of the liver; [so I render hanapN mutaEalRiqapN minohaA, agreeably with the next preceding explanation; though it may be rendered a thing suspended from it, i.e. from the liver; or the right reading may be hnp mtElRqp bihaA, which is virtually the same as the explanation in the A, and agreeable with what here follows: so called] because it is a redundance (taziydu) upon its upper surface: (L:) [all of these explanations seem to denote the round ligament of the liver: the Hebrew יֹחֶרֶח הַכּבֵד, in Ex. xxix. 22, literally signifies the same; like the slightly-varying appellations in Ex. xxix. 13 and Lev. iii. 4, and Lev. ix. 10: but the real meaning thereof is much disputed: the rendering of the LXX. is λοβὸσ τοῦ ἥπατοσ; which is said to mean extrema pars hepatis: that of the Vulg., reticulum hepatis: that of our authorized Engl. Vers., the caul above the liver; (with this marginal note: “ it seemeth by anatomy, and the Hebrew Doctors, to be the midriff: ”) and it is remarkable that this is one of the meanings assigned to Alxilobu, which some hold to be syn. with zayaAdapu Alkabidi: (see xilobN:) Bochart (in his Hieroz. t. i., p. 498, seq.,) and Gesenius (in his Lex.) explain the Hebrew term as meaning the greater lobe of the liver: but this is hard to reconcile with the Hebrew or the Arabic; and utterly irreconcileable with the explanations given by the Arabs; among whom, it should be observed, were many of the Jewish religion, who cannot reasonably be supposed to have not known the correct meaning of a term relating to their sacrifices:] the pl. of zyAdp is zayaAYidu, (L,) and that of zAYdp↓ is zawaAYidu. (S, L.) Hence the saying, Alwaladu kabidu ciI Alwaladi wawaladu Alwaladi ziyaAdapu Alkabidi [The child is as the liver of the parent, and the grandchild is as the redundant appertenance of the liver]. (A, TA.)
zaAYidN act. part. n. of zaAda, (Msb,) [Increasing, augmenting, or growing.

Exceeding; in excess; redundant; superfluous; remaining over and above: excrescent: additional; in addition; adscititious.] You say, Oaxacotuhu bidirohamK fazaAYidFA [I took it, i. e. bought it, for a dirhem and more]. (A.) [See also the next paragraph.]
zaAYidapN [fem. of zaAYidN: and also a subst.; being transferred from the category of epithets to that of substs. by the affix p: pl. zawaAYidu]: see ziyaAdapN, in five places.

[Hence,] AlzRawaAYidu [Certain excrescences, or pendent hairs, termed] zamaEaAt, in the hinder part of the kind leg or foot. (K. [In the explanations there given, I read AlrRijol, as in one copy, instead of AlrRaHol. It has been stated above, voce ziyaAdapN, on the authority of the L, that AlzRawaAYid is said only in relation to the legs of a beast.])
[But] cuw AlzRawaAYidi means The lion: (S, K:) by the zwAYd being mean this claws and his canine teeth and his roaring and his impetuosity. (S.)
zaAYidapu AlsRaAqi The shin-bone. (L.)

[zawaAYidiIRN a rel. n. from zawaAYidu pl. of zaAYidapN; and used, app., as meaning Having something redundant; for] Sa'eed Ibn-'Othmán was surnamed AlzRawaAYidiIRu because he had three bayoDaAt: so they assert. (S.)

buruwdN taziydiyRapN, (S, K,) and taziydiyRaAtN [alone], (S,) [Garments of the kind termed] buruwd having in them red stripes, (S, K,) to which streaks of blood are likened: (S:) so called in relation to taziyd the son of HulowaAn, the father of a tribe: (S, K:) or, as some say, taziyd the son of HayodaAn: (MF:) or from taziyd, a city, or town, of ElYemen, in which such brwd were woven: (TA:) or, accord. to some, J and F are in error; and the truth is, that there were some merchants in Mekkeh, called banuw yaziydK, thus with I and in relation to them certain [camel-vehicles for women of the kind called] hawaAdij were termed yaziydiyRapN↓. (MF.)
mazaAdN: see mazaAdapN, in two places.

maziydN an inf. n. of zaAda. (S, K.) You say, laA maziyda EalaI maA faEalota and laA musotazaAda↓, (A, Msb,) both meaning the same [i.e. There is no exceeding what thou hast done: or rather the latter means there is no desire for more than thou hast done, or there is no one of whom is desired more than thou hast done; for musotazaAd↓ may be here an inf. n., and it may be a pass. part. n.]. (Msb.)
[It is also the pass. part. n. of zaAda, signifying Increased, or augmented; as also maziydN fiyhi.]

mazaAdapN [A leathern water-bag, one of a pair which is borne by a camel or other beast;] the half (XaTor) of a raAwiyap: (Msb in art. zwd:) [a water-bag of this kind is represented in a sketch of “ Sakkàs ” in my work on the Modern Egyptians:] it has two loops, and two kidney-shaped pieces of leather (kuloyataAni), the former of which are sewed to the latter: (TA voce xurobapN:) the raAwiyap consists of two mezádehs (mazaAdataAni), which are bound upon the two sides of the camel with the [cord called] riwaMC: the pl. is mazaAyidu [often written mazaAYidu]; and sometimes the Arabs elided the p, saying mazaAdN↓: (T, TA:) [both of these forms are mentioned in the S and K as pls.:] and mazaAdN↓ without p, is [also] applied to the single one (farodap [meaning the single water-skin]) which the rider attaches behind his camel's saddle, having no EazolaMC, [or spout (which is closed by means of a thong tied round it) at one of the lower extremities for pouring out the water; thus] differing from the mazaAdap: (T, TA:) or the mzAdp is a raAwiyap, [app. accord. to some who applied this latter term to a single water-bag,] (S, A, K,) or only (K) such as is composed of two skins with a third inserted between them to widen it: (A 'Obeyd, S, M, A, K:) and so are the saTiyHap and the XaEiyb: (A 'Obeyd, S:) or the saTyHp is made of two skins put face to face; and the mzAdp is of two skins and a half, or of three skins: (ISh, TA:) or it is [a water-bag] joined (maXoEurbap) at one side; if consisting of two faces (An xrjt mn wjhyn [i. e. of two pieces of skin whereof each forms one face or side]) it is called a XaEiyb: or it is like a rAwyp having no EazolaMC [expl. above]: AM and the author of the Msb and some others assert that its medial radical letter is w, and that it is from AlzRawodu, (TA,) being so called because one furnishes himself with water in it for travellingprovision: (Msb in art. zwd:) but this is a mistake: (TA:) it is thus called because it is enlarged by the addition of a third skin: (AO, El-Khafájee, TA:) [Fei says that] accord. to analogy it should be mizaAdapN. (Msb in art. zwd.)
musotazaAdN: see maziydN, in two places.
yaziydiyRapN, applied to hawaAdij: see taziydiyRapN.

2. zyRr AldRaAbRapa He (a farrier) twisted the lip of the beast with a ziyaAr: (S in art. zwr, and TA:) and he put a ziyaAr upon the Hanak [or part beneath the chin] of the beast. (TA.) [In the present day, the instrument here mentioned is generally applied to the upper lip.]

ziyrN [A large water-jar, wide in the upper part and nearly pointed at the bottom;] a [vessel of the kind called] danR: or a [vessel such as is called] HubR, (K,) in which water is put: (TA: [but yEml is there put by mistake for yujoEalu:]) of the dial. of El-'Irák [and that of Egypt]: pl. OazoyaArN:
a foreign word. (TA in art. zwr, in which, and in art. zyr, the word is mentioned in the K.)
See also art. zwr.
Also I. q. zirRN; (IAar, TA in art. zwr;) the former r in the latter word being changed by some of the Arabs into I in this and similar instances. (Az, TA.)
[See also baSalN.]
zayirN, (Sgh, TA in art. zwr,) in the K, erroneously, zayRirN, (TA,) Angry, (IAar, Sgh, K, TA,) and severing himself from his companion: (IAar, TA:) originally zaYirN. (Az, TA.)
ziyrapN: see art. zwr.

ziyaArN [A kind of barnacle, used by a farrier;] an instrument with which a farrier twists the lip of a beast; (S in art. zwr;) a thing that is put upon the mouth of a beast when he is refractory, in order that he may become submissive. (IAth, TA. [See 2.])
See also art. zwr.
zayozafuwnN: see art. zfn.

1. zaAga, aor. yaziygu, inf. n. zayogN (S, O, Msb, K) and zayagaAnN and zayoguwgapN (O, K) and zuyuwgN, (TA,) He, or it, (a thing, Msb,) declined, deviated, swerved, or turned aside, (S, O, Msb, K,) from the right course or direction, accord. to an explanation of zayogN by Er-Rághib; and from the truth: (TA:) and zAg, aor. yazuwgu, inf. n. zawogN, is a dial. var. thereof. (Msb, TA. *) In the Kur iii. 5, (O,) zayogN means A doubting, and a declining, or deviating, from the truth. (O, K.)

You say also, zaAgati AlXRamosu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. taziygu, inf. n. zayogN (Msb, TA) and zuyuwgN, (TA,) The sun declined [from the meridian], (S, * Msb, K,) so that the shade turned from one side to the other. (S, * K.)

And zAg AlbaSaru, (S, O, K,) inf. n. zayogN, (TA,) (tropical:) The eye, or eyes, or the sight, became dim, or dull: (S, O, K, TA:) so in the phrase maA zaAga AlbaSaru in the Kur [liii. 17]: (O, TA:) or, as some say, zaAgati AlOaboSaAru signifies the eyes turned aside from their places; as in the case of a man in fear. (TA.)
2. zayRagotu fulaAnFA, inf. n. tazoyiygN, I rectified the zayog [or declining, or deviating, &c.,] of such a one. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K. *)

4. AzAghu, (S, O, Msb, K,) Eani AlTRariyqi, (S, O,) inf. n. UizaAgapN, (Msb,) He made him to decline, deviate, swerve, or turn aside, (S, O, Msb, K,) from the way. (S, O.) Hence, in the Kur [iii. 6, accord. to the usual reading], rabRanaA laA tuzigo quluwbanaA, (O, TA,) meaning O our Lord, make us not [or make not our hearts] to decline from the right way and course: make us not to err, or go astray. (TA. [See another reading in the first paragraph of art. zwg.])
And He made him to fall into AlzRayog [app. as meaning deviation from the truth, or the right way of belief or conduct]. ((TA.)

falamRaA zaAguwA OazaAga QllRehu quluwbahumo, in the Kur [lxi. 5], means, accord. to Er-Rághib, And when they quitted the right way, God dealt with them according to that: (TA:) or God turned their hearts from the acceptance of the truth, and the inclining to the right course. (Bd.)

5. tazayRagato She (a woman) ornamented, or adorned, herself, and showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, and beauties of person or form or countenance, to men, or strangers, (AZ, S, K,) and decked herself with apparel; like tazayRaqato: (AZ, TA:) IF says that its g is a substitute for n. (TA.)
6. tazaAyugN i. q. tamaAyulN, (JK, S, O, K,) An inclining towards each other, (PS,) accord. to some, peculiarly, (TA,) in the teeth. (JK, TA.)

zaAgN [The rook;] a small guraAb [or bird of the crow-kind], inclining to white, (O, Mgh, K, TA,) that does not eat carrion, (O, Mgh, TA,) and is allowed to be eaten; now called in Egypt the guraAb nuwHiIR [or Noachian crow]: (TA:) or a guraAb like the pigeon, black, with a dusty colour in its head; or, as some say, inclining to white; that does not eat carrion: (Msb in art. zwg:) or a small black guraAb, that is eaten; also called HacafN, of which the n. un. is with p: (ISh, TA in art. Hcf:) [these descriptions correctly apply to different varieties of the rook; some of which are distinguished by more or less whiteness in the head and other parts: in the present day, the word is, by some, perhaps generally, erroneously applied to the carrion-crow:] Az says, “ I know not whether it be Arabic or arabicized: ” (Msb in art. zwg, and TA:) the truth is, that it is a Pers. word, [zaAgo,] arabicized; originally applied to crows (girobaAn), whether small or large; but when arabicized, applied peculiarly to one species thereof: (TA:) pl. ziygaAnN. (O, Mgh, Msb, K.)
zaAYigN Declining, deviating, swerving, or turning aside: (TA:) pl. zaAgapN, applied to a number of men, (S, O, K, TA,) i. q. zaAYiguwna, (S, O, TA,) like baAEapN meaning baAYiguwna. (O, TA.)

1. zaAfa, aor. yaziyfu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. zayofN and zayafaAnN (O, K) and zuyuwfN, (TA,) said of a camel, (S, TA,) and of a man, &c., (TA,) He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: (S, O, K:) or he went quickly, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (TA.) And zaAfato fiI miXoyatihaA, said of a woman, She appeared as though she were turning round, or circling, in her gait. (Z, TA.) [This is app. from what next follows.] One says of a male pigeon, zAf Einoda AlHamaAmapi He dragged the tail, and impelled his fore part with his hinder part, and turned, or circled, around the female pigeon: (S, O, L, K, * TA:) and of a female pigeon one says, taziyfu bayona yadaIi AlHamaAmi AlcRakari, meaning She walks with boldness and presumptuousness before the male pigeon. (TA.) And a poet describing a battle says of it zaAfato, meaning The hinder part thereof impelled the fore part. (L, TA.)
zAf, (Kr, TA,) inf. n. zayofN, (Kr,) said of a building, (Kr, TA,) &c., (TA,) It was, or became, high. (Kr, TA.)

zAft AldRaraAhimu, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. taziyfu, (Msb,) inf. n. zayofN, (Msb,) or zuyuwfN, (Mgh, K,) for which the lawyers say ziyaAfapN, (Mgh,) The dirhems, or pieces of money, were bad: (MA, Msb:) or were rejected, or returned, (Mgh, K,) Ealayohi [to him], (S, Mgh, K,) because of adulterating alloy therein: (Mgh, K:) or, accord. to the M, simply, were rejected, or returned; (TA;) [and] so zuyRifat↓. (Mgh.)
See also 2.
zAf AlHaAYiTa, (O, K,) inf. n. zayofN, (TA,) He leaped the wall; syn. qafazahu; (O, K;) said of a man. (O.)

2. tazoyiyfN is said to signify primarily The separating, or setting apart, such [money] as is passable, or current, from such as is termed zaAYif: and hence, the rejecting [money], or returning [it]: and the making [it], or proving [it] to be, false, or spurious. (TA.) One says, zyRf AldRaraAhima, (S, MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazoyiyfN, (Msb,) He made, (MA, K,) or pronounced, (K,) or showed, (Msb,) the dirhems, or pieces of money, to be bad, (MA, Msb,) or to be such as are termed zuyuwf; (K;) as also zaAfahaA↓. (Lh, K.) See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.
[Hence, AltRazoyiyfu in relation to speech, or language: see 2 in art. rml.]

And zyRfhu, (Kr, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Kr,) (tropical:) He made his blood to be of no account, to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; or made it allowable to take, or shed, his blood: (TA:) or he made him to be contemptible, ignominious, base, or vile, in the estimation of others: (Kr, TA:) from dirohamN zaAYifN “ a bad dirhem, or piece of money. ” (TA.)
5. tzyRft, said of a woman, [like tzyRqt,] She ornamented, or adorned, herself. (O.)

[Accord. to Freytag, tzyRf signifies It was adulterated: and in Har p. 612 it is expl. as signifying SAr zyRfA fI AHwAlh, which seems to have this or a similar meaning; zyRfA being app. a mistranscription for zayofFA or muzayRafFA.]
zayofN: see zaAYifN, in four places.

Also The Uiforiyz, i. e., (Kr, TA,) the Tanaf, (Kr, O, K, TA,) [meaning the coping, or ledge, or cornice,] that protects a wall, (O, K, TA,) surrounding the upper part of the wall, (Kr,) or surrounding the walls at the top of a house: (TA:) or, as some say, (O, in the K “ and, ”) the steps, or stairs, of places of ascent: (O, K:) or, as some say, (Kr, O, in the K “ and, ”) i. q. XurafN [meaning acroterial ornaments forming a single member of a cresting of a wall, or of the crown of a cornice]: n. un. with p. (Kr, O, K.)
zayRaAfN, and with p: see the next paragraph, in three places.

zaAYifN One who walks in the manner described in the first sentence of this art.; as also zayofN↓, which is an inf. n. used as an epithet: (TA:) [and so zayRaAfN↓, but properly in an intensive sense:] and zayRaAfapN↓ a she-camel proud and self-
conceited [in her gait]. (S.) Hence, (TA,) AlzRaAYifu signifies The lion; as also AlzRayRaAfu↓; (O, K;) but the latter has an intensive meaning: (TA:) so called because of his proud and selfconceited walk. (O, TA.)

Also, and zayofN↓, (S, Kr, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the latter an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Msb,) or, accord. to IDrd, this is a vulgar term, (O,) or bad, (K,) applied to a dirhem, or piece of money, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) to gold and to silver, (Har p. 369, referring to the latter word,) Bad: (Kr, Msb, and Har ubi suprà:) or such as are rejected, or returned, because of adulterating alloy therein: (Mgh, O, K:) or, as some say, such as are less bad than what are termed bahoraj, being such as are rejected by [the officers of] the government-treasury; whereas the bhrj are such as are rejected by the merchants, or traders: (Mgh:) the pl. is ziyaAfN and OazoyaAfN, (O, K,) [the latter a pl. of pauc.,] or the pl. of zayofN↓ is zuyuwfN, and the pl. of zaAYifN is zuyRafN: (Mgh, * Msb:) accord. to some, the zuyuwf are such as are done over with a compound of quicksilver and sulphur. (Msb.) [It is implied in the Msb that zayofN↓ is the more common term, though, as has been stated above, it is said by IDrd to be vulgar: and it is also applied to human beings: for ex.,] a poet says,

L.foreign: wafiI Alqawomi zayofN mivolu zayofi AldRaraAhimi

sense.s: [Thou seest the people to be likes when they alight together; but among the people are bad like the bad of dirhems.] (TA.)

5. tzyRq He ornamented, or adorned, himself, and applied kuHol to his eyes: (K:) or tzyRqt, said of a woman, (JK, S, O,) like tzyRgt, (S, O,) she ornamented, or adorned, herself, (JK, S, O,) and applied kuHol to her eyes, (S, O, TA,) and some add, and decked herself with apparel: accord. to Z, it is from Alzwq; [app. meaning AlzRuwaqu, syn. with AlzRawuwqu; or from zawaAqN, (see 2 in art. zwq, last sentence,) so that it is originally tzwRqt;] or it may be from zyq, [i. e. ziyqN,] with I, [meaning the “ builder's string, or line, with which he makes even the rows of stones, or bricks, and with which the building is proportioned, ”] because she who embellishes herself makes her state right by adornment. (TA.)

ziyqN The part, of a shirt, that surrounds the neck: (S, K:) the collar of a shirt: (KL:) or the border of a collar; (MA;) or the hemmed border of the opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt: (JK:) [app. an arabicized word from the Pers. ziho:] J, holding the medial radical to be [originally] w, has mentioned it in art. zwq. (TA.)
[Hence, (assumed tropical:) The surrounding edge of the eyelid. (See HitaArN.)]
And The string, or line, of the builder, [also called ziyjN, q. v., with which he makes even the rows of stones, or bricks, and] with which the building is proportioned. (JK.)

ziyqu AlXRayaATiyni, expl. by Lth as meaning A certain thing that flies in the air, called by the Arabs luEaAbu AlXRamosi, [i. e. the fine filmy cobwebs termed gossamer,] is a mistake for riyqu AlXRayaATiyni, with raMC. (Az, O, K. *)
1. zaAlahu is syn. with OazaAlahu, q. v. (S, Msb, K.)

zAl zawaAlahu, or zAl QllRehu zawaAlahu; and zAl zawaAlahaA: see zawaAlN, in art. zwl. And ziyla zawiyluhu and zawiyluhaA and zawaAluhu: see zawiylN, in art. zwl; and for the first, see also zawaAlN, in that art.

zilotuhu, (S, K,) aor. Oaziyluhu, inf. n. zayolN, (S,) [first pers. of zaAlahu,] signifies also I put it, or set it, apart, away, or aside; removed it; or separated it; (S, K, TA;) namely, a thing, (S, TA,) from another thing: (TA:) and AzAlhu↓ also signifies he separated it; like zaAlahu. (TA.) See also 4. One says, zilo DaOonaka mino miEozaAka Remove, or separate, thy sheep from thy goats. (S, * TA.) And zilotuhu falamo yanozalo↓ I separated it [partly], but it did not become [wholly] separated. (S, K.)

maA zaAla yafoEalu kacaA (S in art. zwl, and Msb,) is like maA bariHa, both in its [original] measure, [which is maA zayila accord. to most authorities,] and in its meaning, which is [He ceased not to do such a thing, or he continued to do such a thing, for it denotes] the continuing to do a thing [as in the ex. above], and a constant state [as in the phrase maA zaAla zayodN qaAYimFA Zeyd ceased not to be, or continued to be, standing]: (Msb:) [using the first pers.,] one says, maA zilotu OafoEaluhu [and maA zalotu, as appears from what follows], meaning maA bariHotu [i. e. I ceased not to do it, or I continued to do it], (K,) aor. OazaAlu [supposing the measure of the pret. to be originally faEilotu] (Msb, K) and Oaziylu [supposing the measure of the pret. to be originally fEalotu]: (K:) the verb is seldom [in the Msb “ never ”] used without a negative particle: (Az, TA:) one says zilotu OafoEalu meaning maA zilotu OafoEalu; but this is rare: (K:) and maA ziyla yafoEalu kacaA, (S, Msb, K,) a phrase used by some of the Arabs, (Msb,) mentioned by Akh, (S, TA,) as is meant in [some of the copies of] the K by the addition Eanohu, though Akh is not mentioned in what precedes. (TA.) The verb in maA zaAla and laA yazaAlu is used in the manner of kaAna in governing the noun [which is its subject] in the nom. case and the predicate in the accus. case [as in maA zaAla zayodN qaAYimFA, expl. above]; but one may not say, maA zaAla zayodN UilRaA munoTaliqFA, like as one says, maA kaAna zayodN UilRaA munoTaliqFA; for zaAla denotes a negation, [meaning he did not a thing, or he was not doing &c.,] and maA and laA denote negation, and two negations together denote an affirmation; so that mA zAl is affirmative like kaAna; and as one may not say, kaAna zayodN UilRaA manoTaliqFA, so one may not say, maA zaAla zayodN UilRaA munoTaliqFA. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says also, maA zilotu bizayodK HatRaI faEala celika and maA zilotu wazayodFA [I desisted not with Zeyd until he did that], (Sb, K, * TA,) inf. n. ziyaAlN. (Sb, TA.) lamo yazalo [He, or it, has not ceased to be &c., i. e., has ever been &c., (see OazalN,)] is said of God, as meaning He has never been nonexistent; and laA yazaAlu, said of Him, He will never be nonexistent. (Kull p. 31.) This [incomplete i. e. non-attributive] verb and the complete [i. e. attributive, which signifies “ it ceased to be ” or “ exist, ” &c.,] differ in their components; the latter being composed of l w z; and this, of l I z: or the incomplete is altered from the complete; being made to be with kesr to its medial radical letter, [for it is generally held to be from zayila or zawila,] after its having been [originally zawala,] with fet-h: or it is from zaAlahu, aor. yaziyluhu, meaning “ he put it, ” or “ set it, apart, ” &c. (K.)

2. zyRlhu, (S, K,) inf. n. tazoyiylN, (S,) He separated it [i. e. acompany of men, or an assemblage of things,] much (Fr, Az, S, * K, * TA,) [or greatly, or widely; or dispersed it;] differing in degree from zaAlahu like as mayRazahu does from maAzahu. (TA.) Hence, fazayRalonaA bayonahumo [And we will separate them widely, one from another], (Fr, Az, S, K, TA,) in the Kur [x. 29]; (Fr, Az, S, TA;) where some read bayonahumo fazaAyalonaA↓; like laA tuSaERiro and lA tuSaAEiro [in the Kur xxxi. 17]. (Fr, Az, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce duwna.] zayRalotu is of the measure faERalotu because its inf. n. is as above; for were it fayoEalotu, one would say zayRalapN [of the measure fayoEalapN]. (S.)
tazoyiylN is also [said to be] an [irreg.] inf. n. of 5, q. v. (Lh, K.)

3. zAylhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. muzaAyalapN and ziyaAlN, (S, K,) He separated himself from him. (S, Msb, K. [See also 1 in art. zwl, last signification.]) One says, xaAliTuwA AlnRaAsa wazaAyiluwhumo, meaning [Mix ye with men in familiar, or social, intercourse, and] separate yourselves from them in deeds, or actions. (TA.)
zaAyalatohu biwajohihaA She veiled her face from him. (IAar on the authority of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, TA in art. bzr.) [See also 6.]
zaAyalonaA bayonahumo: see 2. And see also what next follows.

4. AzAlhu (S, Msb, K) mino makaAnihi (S) or Eano makaAnihi, (K,) inf. n. UizaAlapN (K) and UizaAlN; (Lh, K;) and zaAlahu↓, (S, Msb, K, and Har p. 393,) aor. yaziyluhu, (S, K, and Har ubi suprà,) or yazaAluhu, like yanaAluhu, (Msb,) inf. n. zayolN, (S, K, Har,) or ziyaAlN; (Msb;) both signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) He removed it [from its place; as the former is expl. in art. zwl]; (Msb in explanation of both, and Har ubi suprà in explanation of the latter;) and so zaAyalahu↓, of which the primary signification is that first assigned to it in the next preceding paragraph. (Har ubi suprà.) See also 1, fourth sentence. [And see 4 in art. zwl.]

5. tzyRlwA, (S, * Msb, K,) inf. n. tazayRulN and tazoyiylN↓, (K,) the latter [irreg., being properly inf. n. of 2,] of the dial. of El-Hijáz, mentioned by Lh; (TA;) and tzAylwA↓, inf. n. tazaAyulN; (K;) i. q.
tafarRaquwA [i. e. They became separated much, or greatly, or widely; or became dispersed: or rather, the former verb, being quasi-pass. of 2, has this meaning; and the latter verb, as quasi-pass. of 3, means simply they became separated, one from another]: (S, K:) [for] AltRazaAyulu↓ signifies AltRabaAyunu: (S, K:) tzyRlwA is syn. with tamayRazuwA: thus in the Kur [xlviii. 25], where it is said, lawo tazayRaluwA laEacRabonaA QlRaciyna kafaruwA [Had they been widely separated, one from another, we had assuredly punished those who disbelieved]: (Msb, * TA:) and some here read tazaAyaluwA↓. (Bd.) [See also 7.]
6: see 5, in three places.

[Hence,] AltRazaAyulu signifies also AlAiHotiXaAmu; (K, TA;) a tropical meaning: (TA:) one says, tzAyl Eanohu, meaning AiHotaXamahu [i. e. (tropical:) He was, or became, abashed at him]: (O, TA:) because the muHotaXim separates himself, and shrinks, from another. (TA.)
[See also mutazaAyilapN, whence it seems that one says, of a woman, tazaAyalato, meaning She veiled her face from men: see likewise 3.]

7. AnzAl It was, or became, put, or set, apart, away, or aside; removed; or separated; (S, K;) Eanohu [from him, or it]. (TA.) One says, zilotuhu falamo yanozalo: see 1. (S, K.) [See also 5. And see 7 in art. zwl.]
zayalN Width between the thighs; (S, K;) like fajajN. (S.)
OazoyalN, (K,) or Oazoyalu Alfaxicayoni, occurring in a trad., (TA,) Having the thighs wide apart. (K, TA.)

mizoyalN A man acute or sharp or quick in intellect, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent; knowing with respect to the subtilties, niceties, abstrusities, or obscurities, of things, affairs, or cases; as also mizoyaAlN↓: (K:) or vehement in altercation, or litigation, who shifts (yazuwlu) from one plea, or argument, to another: occurring in a trad., in which it is said, with reference to two claimants, kaAna OaHaduhumaA mixolaTFA mizoyalFA [One of them two was a person who mixed in, or entered into, affairs; vehement in altercation, &c.]: (IAth, TA:) accord. to which latter explanation, it should be mentioned in art. zwl, as it is by the author of the L; but Z mentions it in the present art., like F. (TA.)
mizoyaAlN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Aljyb AlmuzaAyilu [a mistranscription for AlHabiybu] means AlbaAYinu [i. e. The beloved, or the friend, who is in a state of separation, or disunion]. (TA.)
mutazaAyilapN A woman who veils her face from men. (IAar on the authority of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, TA in this art. and in art. brz.)

1. zaAnahu, (S, MA, Msb, K,) aor. yaziynuhu, (Msb,) inf. n. zayonN; (MA, Msb, KL, TA;) and zyRnhu↓, (S, MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazoyiynN; (Msb, KL, TA;) and OazaAnahu↓, (Msb, K,) and Oazoyanahu↓, (K,) which is its original form, (TA,) inf. n. UizaAnapN; (Msb;) signify the same; (S, MA, Msb, K;) He, or it, adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, beautified, or graced, him, or it. (MA, KL, PS: [and the like is indicated in the S and Msb and K.]) [zaAnahu said of a quality, and of an action, and of a saying, is best rendered It adorned him, or graced him, or was an honour to him; contr. of XaAnahu; as is indicated in the S and K: and sometimes means it was his pride: and zyRnhu↓ means as expl. above: and he embellished it, dressed it up, or trimmed it; said in this sense as relating to language: and he embellished it, or dressed it up, namely, an action &c. to another (ligayorihi); often said in this sense of the Devil; (as in the Kur vi. 43, &c.;) i. e. he commended it to him:] zaAnahu kacaA and zyRnhu↓ [Such a thing adorned him, &c.,] are expl. as said when one's excellence [faDoluhu, as I read for fElh, an evident mistranscription,] appears either by speech or by action: and QllRehi liloOaXoyaMCi tazoyiynu↓ [God's adorning, &c., of things] is sometimes by means of his creating them muzayRanap [i. e. adorned, &c.]; and AlnRaAsi tazoyiynu↓ [The adorning, &c., of men], by their abundance of property, and by their speech, i. e. by their extolling Him. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says, zaAnahu AlHusonu [Beauty adorned, or graced, him, or it]. And Mejnoon says,

L.foreign: fayaA rabRi Uico SayRarota layolaI liIa AlhawaI

sense.s: [And, O my Lord, since Thou hast made Leylà to be to me the object of love, then grace Thou me to her eyes like as Thou hast graced her to me]. (S, TA: but in the former, mina AlhawI in the place of liIa AlhawaI. [The reading in the S means of the objects of love: for hawFI, being originally an inf. n., may be used alike as sing. and pl.]) AlsRiloEapi fiI AlbayoEi tazoyiynu↓ [means The setting off, or commending, of a commodity in selling; and] is allowed, if without concealment of a fault, or defect, from the purchaser, and without lying in the attribution and description of the article. (TA.)
2: see above, in six places.
4. OazaAnahu Oazoyanahu: see 1, first sentence.
See also the paragraph here following.

5. tzyRn and AizodaAna↓, (S, K,) the latter of the measure AifotaEala, [originally Aizotayana, and then AizotaAna,] (S,) quasi-pass. verbs, [the former of zayRanahu and the latter of zaAnahu,] (K,) signify the same; (S;) [He, or it, was, or became, adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embel-lished, beautified, or graced;] as also AizRayRana, (S, * K,) [a variation of the first, being] originally tazayRana, the t being made quiescent, and incorporated into the z, and the A being prefixed in order that the inception may be perfect; (S, TA;) and AzyAnR↓; and AzynR↓. (K.) One says, Oazoyanati↓ AlOaroDu biEuXobihaA [perhaps a mistranscription for AizoyanRati↓ The earth, or land, became adorned, &c., with, or by, its herbage]; as also AizRayRanat, originally tazayRanat [as expl. above]; (S;) and some, in the Kur x. 25, read tazayRanat; and some, AzyAnRt↓. (Bd.) And they said, UicaA TalaEati Aljabohapu tazayRanati AlnRaxolapu [When Aljbhp (the Tenth Mansion of the Moon) rises aurorally, the palm-tree becomes garnished with ripening dates: that Mansion thus rose in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 12th of August, O. S; and in that region, at, or soon after, that period, the dates begin to ripen]. (TA.) [tzyRn is said of language, as meaning It was embellished, dressed up, or trimmed: and of an action &c., as meaning it was embellished, or dressed up, i. e. commended, to a person, by another man, and, more commonly, by the Devil.]

And tzyRn also signifies He adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, &c., himself. (MA, KL.) [Hence,] tzyRn biAlbaATili [He invested himself with that which did not belong to him]. (S and TA in art. XbE.)
8. AizodaAna, originally Aizotayana: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.
9: see 5, each in two places.
11: see 5, each in two places.
zaAnN: see art. zwn.

zayonN [as an inf. n., and also as a simple subst.,] is the contr. of XayonN: (S, Msb, K:) [as a simple subst.,] i. q. ziynapN, q. v.: (Har p. 139:) [and commonly signifying A grace; a beauty; a comely quality; a physical, and also an intel-lectual, adornment; an honour, or a credit; and anything that is the pride, or glory, of a person or thing: in these senses contr. of XayonN:] pl. OazoyaAnN. (K.)

Az says, I heard a boy of [the tribe called] Benoo- 'Okeyl say to another, wajohiI zayonN wawajohuka XayonN, meaning My face is comely and thy face is ugly; for wajohiI cuw zayonK wawajohuka cuw XayonK [my face is possessed of comeliness and thy face is possessed of ugliness]; using the inf. ns. as epithets; like as one says rajulN SawomN and EadolN. (TA.)
Also The comb of the cock. (S.)
zaAnapN [mentioned in this art. in the K]: see art. zwn.

ziynapN, the subst. from zaAnahu, (Msb,) signifies maA yutazayRanu bihi [i. e. A thing with which, or by which, one is adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, beautified, or graced; or with which, or by which, one adorns, &c., himself]; (T, S, K;) any such thing; (T, TA;) [any ornament, ornature, decoration, garnish, embellishment, or grace;] and so ziyAnN↓; (K;) and zayonN↓, also, [which see above,] signifies the same as ziynapN: (Har p. 139:) accord. to El- Harállee, ziynapN denotes the [means of] beautifying, or embellishing, a thing by another thing; consisting of apparel, or an ornament of gold or silver or of jewels or gems, or aspect: or, as some say, it is the beauty [seen] of the eye that does not reach to the interior of that which is adorned [thereby]: accord. to Er-Rághib, its proper mean-
ing is a thing that does not disgrace, or render unseemly, a man, in any of his states or conditions, either in the present world or in that which is to come: but that which adorns him in one state or condition, exclusively of another, is in one point of view XayonN: summarily speaking, it is of three kinds; namely, mental, such as knowledge or science, and good tenets; and bodily, such as strength, and tallness of stature, and beauty of aspect; and extrinsic, such as wealth, and rank or station or dignity; and all these are mentioned in the Kur: (TA:) the pl. is ziyanN. (Bd in x. 25.) ziynapu AlHayaApi AldRunoyaA [or simply ziynapu AldRunoyaA generally means The ornature, finery, show, pomp, or gaiety, of the present life or world; and] particularly includes wealth and children. (Kur xviii. 44.) ziynapu AlOaroDi [The ornature of the earth] means the plants, or herbage, of the earth. (TA.) yawomu AlzRiynapi [The day of ornature] is the festival (AlEiydu); (S, K;) when men used [and still use] to adorn themselves with goodly articles of apparel. (TA.) And also The day of the breaking [of the dam a little within the entrance] of the canal of Misr [here meaning the present capital of Egypt, El-Káhireh, which we call “ Cairo ”], (K, TA,) i. e. the canal which runs through the midst of Misr, and [the dam of] which is broken when the Nile has attained the height of sixteen cubits or more: this day is said to be meant in the Kur xx. 61: it is one of the days observed in Egypt with the greatest gladness and rejoicing from ancient times; and its observance in the days of the Fátimees was such as is inconceivable, as it is described in the “ Khitat ” of El-Makreezee. (TA. [The modern observances of this day, and of other days in relation to the rise of the Nile, are described in my work on the Modern Egyptians.])
qamarN zayaAnN A beautiful moon. (K.)
ziyaAnN: see ziynapN.
[ziyaAnapN The art, or occupation, of the muzayRin: so in the present day.]
zaAYinN: see the last paragraph in this art.
muzayRanN: see mutazayRinN.
[Also,] applied to a man, Having his hair trimmed, or clipped, [or shaven, by the muzayRin.] (S, TA.)
muzayRinN i. q. HajRaAmN [i. e. A cupper; who is generally a barber; and to the latter this epithet (muzayRinN) is now commonly applied; as it is also in the MA]. (S, TA.)
See also mutazayRinN.
muzayRiynN: see mutazayRinN.
muzRaAnN: see each in two places in what follows.
muzodaAnN: see each in two places in what follows.

mutazayRinN and muzodaAnN↓ and muzRaAnN↓ signify the same [i. e. Adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, or graced; as also muzayRanN↓: and the first signifies also selfadorned &c.]: (TA:) the second and third are part. ns. of AizodaAna; the third being formed from the second by incorporation [of the d into the z]: and the dim. of muzodaAnN is muzayRinN↓, like muxayRirN the dim. of muxotaArN; and if you substitute [for the d], muzayRiynN↓: and in like manner in forming the pl. you say mazaAyinu and mazaAyiynu. (S.) You say, OanaA biUiEolaAmika muzRaAnN↓ and muzodaAnN↓, meaning mutazayRinN biUiEolaAmi Oamorika [i. e. I am graced by the making known of thy command, or affair]. (TA.) And AimoraOapN zaAYinN↓ means mutazayRinapN [i. e. A woman adorned, &c.; or self-adorned &c.]: (K, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, mutazayRinN. (TA.)
